title: TSM parts with tdawgg and XXiF
cleaned_content: TSM has announced the release of both Travis " tdawgg " Regan and Damion " XXiF " Cook . This change comes only a month after their signing in November. The pair of tdawgg and XXiF came about in 2024 when both joined QoR to compete in NA Challengers. QoR placed in the top eight of Split 1 , but missed the playoffs of Split 2 , ending the team's chance for Ascension. After their elimination, tdawgg and XXiF opted not to re-sign with the organization for 2025. TSM, after a trip to Ascension, brought in the QoR duo as they rebuilt their roster for Split 3 of Challengers. This new roster played in two tournaments together. They emerged victorious at For Those Who Dare 2024 , an invitational featuring 100 Thieves , and then placed in the top eight of Challengers Split 3. tdawgg has clarified that he was not dropped by TSM, but left in order to pursue an offer from a different team. No statement has been made thus far from XXiF. TSM will need to re-complete their roster before Stage 1 of Challengers 2025, starting on Jan 29. TSM are now: Johann " seven " Hernandez Anthony " gMd " Guimond Tyler " sym " Porter Awab " Recoil " Hussain Laurynas " Nbs " Kisielius (Head coach)

title: Global Esports announces Deryeon
cleaned_content: Global Esports has signed Derrick " Deryeon " Yee for the 2025 VCT season, just under three weeks before the start of Kickoff . Global Esports owner Rushindra Sinha confirmed to vlr.gg that Deryeon will be playing in place of Mark " yokam " Musni , whose visa has been delayed. Deryeon is best known for his time on BLEED , one of the top Singaporean teams in Challengers. He joined the organization in late 2021, and led the team to consistent top-three finishes throughout 2022, including the APAC Last Chance Qualifier . The beginning of the VCT partnership league in 2023 gave BLEED free rein to dominate Challengers, capped off with an Ascension win at the end of the season. The following year was not as successful for BLEED, as the team struggled during both Kickoff and the regular season. By August, BLEED had benched four players , including Deryeon. In November, Deryeon joined Disguised , helping the team win three off-season events, and was among the ten highest-rated players in Challengers Southeast Asia Stage 3. Deryeon will return to VCT Pacific in Global Esports' opening series against Team Secret on January 19. Global Esports is now: Mark " yokam " Musni Go " UdoTan " Kyung-won (고경원) Savva " Kr1stal " Fedorov Kelly " kellyS " Sedillo Federico " Papi " Evangelista Derrick " Deryeon " Yee Preston " Juv3nile " Dornon (Head coach) Donnie " Elevated " Chell (Coach)

title: Titan Esports Club lights it up with Dynamite
cleaned_content: Titan Esports Club has signed former Trace Esports substitute Zhao " Dynamite " Zihao (赵梓浩) , securing the team's duelist for the 2025 VCT season. Dynamite joined Trace as a substitute in 2023, only making one appearance in his debut season at China Evolution Series Act 3: Heritability , where Trace finished fourth. In the 2024 offseason, he made the trip to South Korea for the team's participation in the Gwangju Esports Series , filling in for teammate Kai . Trace lost both matches in two maps, and Dynamite played Jett three times and Chamber once. Following GES, Dynamite joined Titan for their Superb Cup campaign. While Titan was eliminated in the group stage, Dynamite impressed, playing Jett and Neon and even pacing the team in kills in a loss against JDG Esports . Throughout the course of their 2024 VCT campaign, Titan's duelist duties were split between Rb and Abo . The addition of Dynamite, who looks to break into the starting five for the first time in his career, may give Titan their go-to duelist for next season. TEC finished the 2024 season dead last in China, with an eleventh-place finish at the end of Stage 2 . In an effort to climb the standings in 2025, they have signed former EDward Gaming coach AfteR , and player Haodong , who spent time in the coaching booth at Champions 2024 following a mid-season benching. Titan's 2025 VCT season will begin just under a month away at China Kickoff, when they take on TYLOO at China Kickoff . Titan Esports Club 's roster is now: Guo " Haodong " Haodong (郭浩东) Zhao " Dynamite " Zihao (赵梓浩) Li " B1ack " Songtai (李松泰) Han " Abo " Bohao (韩博皓) Piao " kawaii " Min (朴民) Goo " Rb " Sang-min (구상민) Li " Gazero " Zhe (李哲) (Manager) Liu " 3water " Miao (刘淼) (Head coach) Lo " AfteR " Wen-Hsin (罗文信) (Coach)

title: Viva signs with Xi Lai Gaming
cleaned_content: Xi Lai Gaming has signed former JDG Esports player Lifan " Viva " Ran (冉立凡) , continuing the chain of a domino effect of recent roster moves among Chinese teams. Colin " coconut " Patrick Chung (钟弘祖) , who had been on the team's roster for offseason tournaments, was also signed permanently. Viva is no stranger to Challengers teams. He spent the 2023 team on Rare Atom , and reached the grand final of Ascension China where they lost to Dragon Ranger Gaming . Following that, he was picked up by JDG Esports as part of a four-man Rare Atom signing class. Over the course of the last two seasons, Viva's in-game role has remained relatively the same. With Rare Atom, he handled the duelist duties on Jett and Iso while also logging time as Sova and Viper. This continued with JDG in 2024, though his minutes as a duelist significantly decreased. In 2024, Xi Lai Gaming defeated a new-look Rare Atom in the grand final of Ascension China , avenging two previous defeats in the competition against them to earn themselves a spot as China's 12th VCT team. Following the win, they parted ways with in-game leader Kr1stal due to the team having more than one non-resident player. XLG has been one of the busier players in the Chinese offseason window, dropping coach Fayde for new assistant ANXiOS and picking up players YOU , ZiXuan , and coconut . The ripple effect following roster movement from other Chinese VCT teams such as TYLOO and the aforementioned JDG has reached Xi Lai. They parted ways with MrCANI , who was a part of their Ascension-winning five-man core, and have now signed Viva. Ahead of their debut season in the VCT, Xi Lai have impressed at OFF//SEASON events. Top-four finishes at WALL-E Cup and FGC Invitational preceded their Superb Cup win, which saw them defeat world champions EDward Gaming . Xi Lai Gaming 's roster is now: Colin " coconut " Patrick Chung (钟弘祖) Lifan " Viva " Ran (冉立凡) Arthur " Rarga " Churyumov Deng " happywei " Minwei (邓闵维) Yip " YOU " Man Ho Zhuo " MarT1n " Zhengjie (卓政杰) Liu " ZiXuan " Junwei (刘俊伟) Aleksandr " hvoya " Eremin (Head coach) Victor " ANXiOS " Troshkin (Assistant coach) He " snowave " Yujie (何宇杰) (Analyst) Editor's note: A previous version of this article had the headline, 'Viva brings life to Xi Lai Gaming', which could have caused confusion with current FunPlus Phoenix player Life . The headline has since been changed.

title: JDG drops Viva, picks up MrCANI and Babyblue
cleaned_content: JDG Esports has let go of Lifan " Viva " Ran (冉立凡) and signed Chen " MrCANI " Tingxun (陈廷训) , and Geng " Babyblue " Haoran (耿浩然) , expanding their active roster to six ahead of the 2025 VCT season. Viva joined JDG in January 2024 as part of a four-man signing class from Rare Atom . The pickups came following Rare Atom's 2023 run to the Ascension China grand finals, where they lost to Dragon Ranger Gaming . With Rare Atom, Viva played a multitude of roles, including Jett, Iso, Sova, and Viper. This role continued with JDG in 2024, though he played considerably fewer games as a duelist. MrCANI joins after being released by Xi Lai Gaming , with whom he'd spent the entire 2024 season. After winning Ascension China with them, he was a part of Xi Lai's late offseason roster moves. He was mainly XLG's initiator player, though he occasionally filled in to play the controller role on Omen. JDG will be his fourth team in three seasons. Babyblue joins with plenty of tier-two experience. He comes from ZY Gaming , and was also previously signed to Wolves Esports , but did not see the stage for them. Throughout his career, he's mainly been used in the duelist and initiator roles. JDG's 2024 season saw them finish top six at the end of Stage 2 , missing out on reaching any international events. Since the end of their season, they've participated in three OFF//SEASON events, and have made a handful of personnel changes. They signed EGO and hypnotizing as their coaching duo, while also adding in-game leader sword9 . All three joined from All Gamers . Weeks later, they parted ways with hypnotizing and sword9, then dropped Viva and signed MrCANI. It is believed that YiHao will continue in a reserve role, meaning MrCANI rounds out their five-man roster. JDG Esports 's roster is now: Chen " YHchen " Yuhan (陳昱瀚) Park " stew " Young-chan (박영찬) Yong " jkuro " Haochong (杨浩聪) Chen " MrCANI " Tingxun (陈廷训) Geng " Babyblue " Haoran (耿浩然) Liu " Z1yan " Zihan (刘紫涵) Jiang " Jayce " Yudong (蒋昱栋) (Manager) Yang " EGO " Haozun (杨皓尊) (Head coach)

title: TYLOO welcomes sword9 and hypnotizing as coaching duo
cleaned_content: UPDATE: This article was updated on December 24 to reflect the signing of assistant coach Billyo. Following their brief stint on JDG Esports , sword9 and hypnotizing have joined TYLOO as the team's head coach and coach , respectively. The pair replaces slk and Sunshine, who were released last week . For long-time viewers of the Chinese circuit, sword9 is known for playing with KONE eSports Club , the second-best team in the region at the time. With KONE, sword9 qualified to the 2022 East Asia LCQ , where the team ended in the top four after losing to finalists Incheon OnSla2ers. After KONE disbanded in 2023, sword9 joined EDward Gaming as assistant coach. While there, the team reached Masters Tokyo and Champions 2023 . He left EDG in early 2024 to join All Gamers as in-game leader. Coach hypnotizing joined later in the season to reinforce AG's staff. The team had middling results, qualifying to both Stage playoffs with a 5-5 record but failing to advance past the single-elimination matches. In October, JDG Esports picked up sword9 as IGL and hypnotizing as assistant coach. Unfortunately, JDG was unsuccessful during the off-season, only winning two games across three events. TYLOO later announced the arrival of assistant coach Billyo . He was known for his time on FunPlus Phoenix , which he helped coached between 2022-2023, and was able to qualify to LOCK//IN ater an upset win against EDward Gaming . He next joined Bilibili Gaming , but departed for a head cosch role at JDG Esports after two months. He remained on the team through the rest of 2023, and was the only team member to stay after JDG picked up Rare Atom for the inaugural VCT China season. Kickoff China begins January 11 , leaving the new coaching staff just under three weeks to prepare for TYLOO's opening match against Titan Esports Club . TYLOO 's roster is now: Ding " 5CM " Xuanpeng (丁宣鹏) Ding " Ninebody " Yi (丁毅) Xiang " coldfish " Pengzhi (向鹏志) Kelun " slowly " Sun (孙科伦) Zhang " zjc " Juncheng (张峻程) Yang " Eren " Zhengwei (杨曾威) Li " sword9 " Wei (李卫) (Head coach) Xie " hypnotizing " Haozhi (谢昊志) (Coach) Li " Billyo " Xinyu (李新宇) (Coach)

title: AC leaves Titan Esports Club
cleaned_content: Titan Esports Club player Wei " AC " Jiacong (韦家聪) has parted ways with the team, joining Challengers side Chosen Clique Gaming . AC joined Titan in 2024 as part of an early mid-season rebuild attempt. Following a disappointing result at Kickoff that saw them fall short of the playoffs, they signed him and integrated him into the team in place of QiuYe . The changes continued throughout the course of the season, with the team also making roster moves ahead of Stage 2 . Titan ended the regular season with a 3-7 record, ranking them last in China. Since the end of the season, TEC has made significant efforts to climb the standings in 2025. They signed former EDward Gaming coach AfteR , and player Haodong , who spent time in the coaching booth following his mid-season benching. LockM , who joined ahead of 2024, also retired. AC was the team's Controller player throughout the 2024 season, most often on Omen or Viper. In the 2024 OFF//SEASON, Titan participated in WALL-E Cup , FGC Invitational , and Superb Cup . In the events, AC was used in different roles, such as the Initiator or Sentinel roles. He did not play in the Superb Cup, which was the last off-season event for the team. Chosen Clique Gaming participates in the second tier of Chinese Valorant. Last year, they reached the lower final of Ascension China , falling to eventual champions Xi Lai Gaming in five maps. Titan Esports Club 's roster is now: Guo " Haodong " Haodong (郭浩东) Li " B1ack " Songtai (李松泰) Han " Abo " Bohao (韩博皓) Piao " kawaii " Min (朴民) Goo " Rb " Sang-min (구상민) Li " Gazero " Zhe (李哲) (Manager) Liu " 3water " Miao (刘淼) (Head coach) Lo " AfteR " Wen-Hsin (罗文信) (Coach)

title: Xi Lai Gaming releases MrCANI
cleaned_content: Xi Lai Gaming has released Chen " MrCANI " Tingxun (陈廷训) , now parting ways with two of their Ascension China -winning five-man roster. He was mainly XLG's Initiator player, though he occasionally filled in to play the Controller role on Omen. Before his time with Xi Lai began, MrCANI played for Anti Eco Eco Club and TOP Esports , making his debut with the former in 2023. MrCANI joined Xi Lai Gaming ahead of the 2024 season, which was set to be their first full season after participating in Act 3: Heritability in 2023. After sweeping through the China National Competition , they earned enough circuit points to qualify for Ascension. There, they survived the group stage and made their way to the grand final. After suffering two earlier defeats to Rare Atom , they swept them in the grand final to earn China's 12th VCT slot. In XLG's 2024 OFF//SEASON events, MrCANI participated in WALL-E Cup , FGC Invitational , and Shanghai Esports Masters but was not in the team's roster for Superb Cup , which they ended up winning. Having entered its offseason competitions with a seven-man roster, Xi Lai Gaming seems to be nearing its five. Their 2025 season will begin just under a month away at China Kickoff , where they are slated to face Wolves Esports . Xi Lai Gaming 's roster is now: Arthur " Rarga " Churyumov Deng " happywei " Minwei (邓闵维) Zhuo " MarT1n " Zhengjie (卓政杰) Colin " coconut " Patrick Chung (钟弘祖) Yip " YOU " Man Ho Liu " ZiXuan " Junwei (刘俊伟) Aleksandr " hvoya " Eremin (Head coach) Victor " ANXiOS " Troshkin (Assistant coach)

title: JDG Esports parts ways with sword9 and hypnotizing
cleaned_content: JDG Esports has parted ways with assistant coach Xie " hypnotizing " Haozhi (谢昊志) and in-game leader Li " sword9 " Wei (李卫) , ending their time at the organization after just around two months. The pair joined JDG at the same time from Chinese VCT team All Gamers . They were joined by AG head coach EGO shortly after. After undergoing competition at WALL-E Cup , FGC Invitational , and Superb Cup with their offseason acquisitions, JDG has decided to move into a different direction without them. JDG accumulated a 2-6 record across all three events. In their 2024 VCT season, JDG finished Stage 2 ranked 5th-6th, and failed to qualify for any international events. JDG's 2025 VCT season begins at China Kickoff , where they will take on Dragon Ranger Gaming in the opening round. JDG Esports 's roster is now: Chen " YHchen " Yuhan (陳昱瀚) Park " stew " Young-chan (박영찬) Lifan " Viva " Ran (冉立凡) Yong " jkuro " Haochong (杨浩聪) Liu " Z1yan " Zihan (刘紫涵) Jiang " Jayce " Yudong (蒋昱栋) (Manager) Yang " EGO " Haozun (杨皓尊) (Head coach)

title: TYLOO expands roster with slowly and 5cm
cleaned_content: TYLOO has signed slowly and 5CM , expanding their active roster to six. Both players have played an active role in TYLOO's offseason events. slowly is in his second go-around with TYLOO. He spent the 2023 offseason with the organization, stepping in to play for them in one match at China Evolution Series Act 3: Heritability . In 2024, he played for Chinese Ascension side ZY Gaming . ZY was eliminated in the group stage by eventual champions Xi Lai Gaming . While slowly has mainly been used in the Initiator role, he has recently been used by TYLOO on Viper and Cypher. 5CM joins from Ascension side Xtreme Gaming , who were eliminated by ZY. He made his professional Valorant debut in 2024. The change in slowly's role may be attributed to 5CM's offseason contributions. While he handled duties as Viper and Cypher earlier, he ended the offseason as the primary Controller. In three offseason events, TYLOO has fielded three different five-man rosters with eight different players. coldfish has not participated in any, while zjc played in the team's final event, Superb Cup . Ninebody and GlXad rounded out the five-man at Superb. Former head coach Sunshine and Core , a member of the 2023 squad, played in the WALL-E CUP and FGC Invitational . While Eren participated in the WALL-E Cup, he has been out of action since then. The organization is still without any coaching staff after parting ways with Sunshine and slk . In just under a month's time, TYLOO's 2025 season will start at China Kickoff , taking on Titan Esports Club . TYLOO's roster is now: Ding " 5CM " Xuanpeng (丁宣鹏) Ding " Ninebody " Yi (丁毅) Xiang " coldfish " Pengzhi (向鹏志) Kelun " slowly " Sun (孙科伦) Zhang " zjc " Juncheng (张峻程) Yang " Eren " Zhengwei (杨曾威) Yang " fc4t " Jiawei (杨家玮) (Manager)

title: El Diablo lives evil
cleaned_content: Evil Geniuses has announced Jaccob " yay " Whiteaker to round out their 2025 VCT roster. He joins EG alongside icy and the retained core of NaturE , supamen , and Derrek . yay is no stranger to VCT, having been a dominant force in the pre-partnership era of Valorant with ENVY and OpTic Gaming . With a resume including three grand finals appearances and a masters trophy, OpTic's accomplishments were unmatched at the time. yay himself was arguably the best player of 2022, with his dominance even earning him the title of Esports Player of the Year at the Game Awards. However, following his run with OpTic, it has been nothing but turmoil for the star. After only two official matches with his new team Cloud9 in 2023, yay was suddenly released , leaving him out of the inaugural year of the partnership leagues. He would join the Challengers circuit by signing with Disguised , but the team immediately collapsed upon his arrival, failing to win a single match for the rest of the year. Looking for redemption in 2024, he crossed the ocean to join the Ascension winning BLEED in Pacific. However, both yay and Bleed were a shell of their former selves, as the team could only muster one win throughout Kickoff and Stage 1 . Soon after, yay stepped down from the active roster citing health issues. He returns from his brief hiatus back in North America with EG. yay has already made an unofficial debut with EG at the Sen City Classic , finding one win against Cloud9 to place third at the event. Evil Geniuses are now: Nicholas " NaturE " Garrison Derrek " Derrek " Ha Phat " supamen " Le Jaccob " yay " Whiteaker Jacob " icy " Lange Christine " potter " Chi (Head coach) Mike " pho " Panza (Assistant coach)

title: Evil Geniuses get a little colder with icy
cleaned_content: Evil Geniuses have signed former G2 Esports player Jacob " icy " Lange , filling their void in the Duelist role. He joins after an up-and-down season with G2. After a disappointing Americas Kickoff that saw them miss out on one of the region's two Masters Madrid slots, for the team they picked up icy. With him in the duelist role alongside three core members from the Americas Ascension -winning The Guard squad, G2 quickly grew into one of the Americas region's strongest squads in their first season in VCT. They finished second-place in Americas Stage 1 , and followed that up on the international stage with a third-place finish at Masters Shanghai . The dominance continued through Stage 2 , where they finished second yet again. At Champions Seoul , they survived the group stage with relative ease, but were swiftly eliminated two matches into the playoffs. icy's release came just over a month after the end of Champions, and his role as the Duelist was filled by Evil Geniuses star jawgemo . icy returns to EG after a long stint away from the team. He was the final piece of the organization's 10-man roster in 2023, and was released following that season. Prior to his first go-around with EG, he was a consistent face in Tier 2, playing for Cosmic Divide and Moon Raccoons . He joins a trio of 2024 Evil Geniuses returnees in NaturE , Derrek , and supamen . After lifting Champions 2023 , the villains failed to register a single playoff appearance. For G2 in 2024, icy played several Duelist roles, with Raze and Yoru being his most common picks. However, the team was forced to utilize him in different roles on occasion, with his Gekko on Icebox being a staple of their zero-Duelist composition on the map. With the signing of icy, EG moves one step closer towards finalizing its five-man roster after fielding offseason rosters with yay and sym . Evil Geniuses 's full roster is now: Nicholas " NaturE " Garrison Derrek " Derrek " Ha Phat " supamen " Le Jacob " icy " Lange Christine " potter " Chi (Head coach) Mike " pho " Panza (Assistant coach)

title: florescent: "You'll have to work extra, extra [hard], way after everyone"
cleaned_content: “It was definitely a lot of extra grinding, but I think it was worth it.” Nearly two weeks ago, 2024 EMEA Ascension champions Apeks became the first organization to sign a Game Changers competitor straight to Tier 1. Ava " florescent " Eugene of Shopify Rebellion Gold secured a reappearance at Berlin's Riot Games Arena this upcoming year, albeit in a completely different league. In an exclusive interview with VLR.gg, florescent shared her reflections on both past and present endeavors, highlighting her journey up to this point in time. The prodigy's path to pro started many years ago in the form of a small monthly tournament. “My first tournament was a Sakura Cup , an NA Monthly Game Changers tournament. I don't think it had an age restriction, because I was 14, so I just played with friends for fun.” Two monthly Game Changers tournaments made up the entirety of florescent's 2021 as recorded on VLR. However, her break into a more competitive environment took the shape of Misfits Black , the first organization she signed with. “Around that time was when I realized that I wanted to take this super seriously and focus more on playing Valorant [in general].” And play Valorant she did. Following her stay with Misfits, florescent would go on to sign with the now-Shopify Rebellion roster, vaulting her even further up the competitive ladder as she trained with the top players of Game Changers. Even heading into the 2023 Game Changers Championship, her performance did not falter, as she and the rest of Shopify claimed the organization's first GCC trophy following an undefeated run throughout the upper bracket. However, the job wasn't quite done for the coronated monarchs of Game Changers. The first international trophy florescent and Shopify hoisted. (Photo: Adela Sznajder/Riot Games) The new year meant new challenges and competition for most, but not for florescent and Shopify. The team won all three series of NA Game Changers and secured yet another appearance at this year's GCC. By this time, however, florescent's performance had finally caught the attention of organizations outside of Game Changers. “[Apeks] reached out during [Series 3]... and we organized for me to fly into Berlin earlier than my teammates so I could trial. It went pretty well… I thought I would make it off the trials. I thought I did pretty good. I didn't know how well the other people at trials did, but just for myself, I was pretty confident going into it.” Throughout her time in Berlin – which once again ended with yet another trophy for the talent alongside an MVP award – florescent's path to Tier 1 was finally solidifying through her performance in trials. Shortly after her second victory on an international stage, Apeks officially announced her signing. “I was definitely excited. I remember telling my team when it happened.” However, signing with Apeks meant leaving behind not just her teammates but competing in Game Changers. Despite this, Shopify's former star had nothing but good things to say about her stay within the scene. “It was definitely really positive, I [didn't] really have any bad experiences. I feel like I've gotten to know a lot of people and made a lot of friends. I'm pretty grateful.” florescent's signing with Apeks ended a two-year stint with meL and the rest of the rebels. (Photo: Adela Sznajder/Riot Games) Her new environment didn't seem to faze the newly-signed talent at all, either. Even making the jump from North America to EMEA for more than just a brief tournament seemed almost insignificant to florescent. “When I turned 16 I moved all the way across Canada for better ping and I didn't have any family there, so I think it'll be fine. My teammates are all nice and helpful so I feel like I won't have many problems there. I know some people in Berlin just from VCT, so I'm not too worried about that.” The shift in attitude also felt miniscule to the competitor, who confirmed the hard work that players across all scenes put into improving themselves. “I didn't really notice that much, it doesn't feel too different to me. At the end of the day everyone's just trying to win.” The rest of Apeks meshed very well with florescent, as she recalled past practices the team underwent ahead of their debut in the EMEA League. “We all get together really well. Everyone is really funny. We just had a two-week bootcamp in Serbia and it wasn't the best of circumstances for some days, but we all had a good time. I think everyone likes each other.” “We've just been grinding. We have the least amount of time compared to all the other teams since I had the GC schedule going on. I'm in NA right now, and we're working on getting our fifth fully confirmed. We just have to grind, really, that's all it is. During the bootcamp we were practicing really hard, working on everything that we could.” New to Tier 1 but not new to winning, florescent stayed confident when asked about the teams within the EMEA League, her new competition for the year. “I'm always confident. I never want to say that I think we're gonna lose or I think we'll do ok. I'm super confident. It's gonna be fun. I'm really excited, honestly.” While on the topic of teams she would want to play, the new pickup struggled to choose. “Maybe FNATIC , because I like Chronicle and Boaster a lot. I'm trying to think of the teams in the EMEA. Maybe Karmine Corp because I like saadhak .” As for teams that would be tough to play against, it was no surprise to any that last year's Champions runner-ups were first to be named. “[A tough team] this early would probably be Team Heretics because they kept the same roster and they have so much experience playing together. Right now, Team Vitality is not the strongest because even if they have a super good roster on paper they just need a little more time. Heretics… they play good together, so I think they'll be pretty exciting to play against if we get to.” Making the jump from Game Changers to Tier 1 was no small feat, and although the change in competition brought on new challenges, florescent still had goals for herself throughout the year in hopes of improving even more than she already has. “I just want to be able to play confidently and be comfortable playing with my teammates, especially because I'm just starting to get to know them more now. I just want to have fun really.” New challenges are what the two-time MVP strives for this year. (Photo: Adela Sznajder/Riot Games) Finally, when asked about advice for not just aspiring Game Changers players but all those aiming to go pro, the two-time World Champion responded with what brought her from humble beginnings to the grandest of stages. “Just grind hard, be a nice person, and sometimes you'll have to work extra, extra hard, way after everyone. Come in early, bring your stuff, just work your hardest and don't be an asshole. Can I swear? Just be a good person to others. Even if you don't reach your goals, if you leave a good impression on people, you'll be fine.” Apeks have yet to officially sign a fifth player and will debut against a rebuilt Gentle Mates in their first match of the EMEA League, which is set to kick off on Jan 16. Despite the world watching, florescent will continue to play her own game confidently, eager for each and every challenge.

title: TYLOO parts ways with coaching staff
cleaned_content: TYLOO has parted ways with its entire coaching staff, letting go of head coach Huang " Sunshine " Jinjie (黄进杰) and coach Aleksey " slk " Lynksov . Sunshine had been with Tyloo since March of this season, joining from Weibo Gaming . He played in two OFF//SEASON competitions for Tyloo, filling in as their Controller player. slk joined Tyloo in June of this season, looking to improve the team's results after a disappointing China Stage 1 . Before Tyloo, he had stints overseas with FNATIC , Team Singularity , and CrowСrowd . The 2024 season saw Tyloo finish 7th-8th in China Stage 1 and eighth in Stage 2 . They failed to reach the knockout stages of either stage, and finished the year with just four wins out of 12 matches. The organization has yet to reach an international event. In their offseason competitions against fellow Chinese teams, Tyloo competed in WALL-E Cup , FGC Invitational , and Superb Cup . In nine matches across the three tournaments, they totaled two wins and seven losses. Since the end of the season, they have seen a few changes in personnel, with Scales departing, AAK retiring and now their coaching duo on the way out. With just under a month until their season begins, Tyloo must now fill out their five-man roster and their coaching booth. Tyloo's roster is now: Ding " Ninebody " Yi (丁毅) Xiang " coldfish " Pengzhi (向鹏志) Zhang " zjc " Juncheng (张峻程) Yang " Eren " Zhengwei (杨曾威) Yang " fc4t " Jiawei (杨家玮) (Manager)

title: neT captures Cloud9's final roster spot
cleaned_content: Cloud9 has announced Michael " neT " Bernet as their final roster member for 2025. This addition comes shortly after releasing moose . neT started the partnership era of VCT in Challengers NA with The Guard , where he and his teammates would run the gauntlet to win Ascension and become the first team to be promoted into VCT Americas. After signing with G2 Esports , neT and The Guard core made their VCT debut at Kickoff . They would qualify out of their group for the play-in stage, but an upset loss to MIBR eliminated them from Masters Madrid contention. Prior to Split 1 , G2 then made a roster change, replacing neT with the newcomer icy . neT was forced to rejoin the challengers league, this time with M80 , to try and win Ascension for the second time in a row. After the addition of neT, M80 regained their place as the top team from North America, winning Stage 2 to return to Ascension . However, neT would not be able to repeat his previous victory, as he found himself on the other side of grand finals that year as M80 was defeated by Brazil's 2Game Esports . Following the loss, M80 disbanded their roster. neT steps into Cloud9 amidst a pre-season roster shuffle. After putting together the initial roster, the team decided it needed to make changes. Their IGL Rossy was swapped out for mitch , and the team began trialing replacements for moose. neT now completes Cloud9's new roster as they head into the 2025 season. Cloud9 is now: Mitch " mitch " Semago Erick " Xeppaa " Bach Victor " v1c " Truong Michael " neT " Bernet Francis " OXY " Hoang Ian " Immi " Harding (Coach) Guglielmo " GUGLi " Carraro (Assistant coach)

title: Riot reveals China Kickoff matchups for 2025
cleaned_content: Following a series of showmatches and year-end awards show, Riot revealed the results of the China Kickoff opening matchup draw. The event will have a 12 team, double-elimination bracket, with the best performing 2024 VCT teams earning a bye into the second round. The top two teams will qualify to Masters Bangkok and earn Championship Points, while the teams that round out the top four will earn 1 Championship Point. This year, two teams will qualify to Champions Paris off of Championship Points , further rewarding year-long consistency. Currently, specific times and dates are still to be announced, and the specific order of the matches is not final. Kickoff 2025 will feature 12 teams in a double-elimation bracket (Picture by VALORANT Esports CN) Xi Lai Gaming vs Wolves Esports The region's newest team, Xi Lai Gaming , will play against Wolves Esports , the most successful Chinese team in the off-season. Both teams went through roster moves after the 2024 circuit, with Wolves opting for a rebuild due to a 4-6 regular season and XLG needing to make changes due to the import rule and Wolves acquiring assistant coach Fayde . After the roster changes, the teams faced off against each other three times in the off-season, twice in a best-of-five. Wolves came out on top with three wins, including a 3-0 in the Shanghai Esports Masters grand final . The winner of this series will then play against Bilibili Gaming , who received a bye after qualifying to Champions 2024 on championship points. TYLOO vs Titan Esports Club The bracket will next pit two teams that failed to reach a playoff stage last year against each other. TYLOO ended the 2024 regular season with a 4-6 record, while Titan Esports Club remained at the bottom of the table, only winning three matches in the league and five total in an official series. The teams used most of their off-season experimenting, playing with different lineups in an effort to identify their best approach for the upcoming season. They did not show results, however, as they ended towards the bottom in the off-season tournaments they played. In terms of roster changes, on paper, TEC had a more flashy pickup , however, signing former EDward Gaming in-game leader Haodong and coach AfteR . The winner of the series will play against FunPlus Phoenix , the second best VCT CN team in 2024. JDG Esports vs Dragon Ranger Gaming Dragon Ranger Gaming will play against JDG Esports in their opening series. The teams played against each other only once last year, but the cores are familiar with each other, having been protagonists (with JDG's stew and Viva then playing under Rare Atom ) of the final leg of the 2023 Ascension tournament and T2 circuit. Both teams had middling success in 2024, with DRG reaching the top four in Kickoff and Stage 1, qualifying to Masters Shanghai , but JDG ending the year with a slightly better league record and attending the end-of-year playoffs. The teams had similar, if disappointing, results in the off-season, failing to make waves in the events they attended. Trace Esports awaits them in the next round, a team that ended 2024 as a top three team in the region and reached third place in the Valorant Radiant Asia Invitational after defeating Gen.G and DRX. All Gamers vs Nova Esports Rounding out the opening matches, All Gamers will face off against Nova Esports . The teams played each other recently in the off-season, with Nova Esports coming out on top twice. In terms of results, Nova has had a better off-season than All Gamers , reaching two finals and defeating teams such as EDG, Wolves, and Trace, while AG has only taken wins against TYLOO and JDG. That said, All Gamers has played with a different lineup in each tournament, so those results will not necessarily reflect the actual performance of the team. The team that comes out on top will need to play against EDward Gaming , the current world Champions , if they wish to remain in the upper bracket. Kickoff China will begin on January 11 (Beijing time, exact schedule to be determined), with the event's finalist qualifying to Masters Bangkok.

title: Gen.G add coach peri
cleaned_content: Gen.G has announced the addition of Jung " peri " Bum-ki (정범기) to their coaching staff. He joins former teammates solo and HSK to lead the team in 2025. peri and solo have a long history together. The two were long-time teammates in Counter-Strike, dating back all the way to 2010. They also had a brief period of playing alongside HSK in 2017. In 2020, the pair moved to VALORANT together with NUTURN and were Korea's first representative on the global stage . After 2021, both retired as players and moved to the coaching role. peri coached Incheon On Sla2ers for a season, but eventually reunited with solo as a coach for Dplus Esports . The pair led Dplus to win Challengers Korea in 2023, but fell in the group stage of Ascension . Solo would then move to Gen.G, where he helped lead a Masters winning campaign. peri remained on Dplus for 2024, taking the reins of head coach, but the team fell from their spot atop Korea, and would not return for Ascension. Shortly after the season, peri was released from the team, leaving him to once again join solo in Gen.G. Gen.G are now: Byeon " Munchkin " Sang-beom (변상범) Jung " Foxy9 " Jae-sung (정재성) Kim " t3xture " Na-ra (김나라) Chae " yoman " Young-moon (채영문) Kim " Karon " Won-tae (김원태) Kang " solo " Geun-chul (강근철) (Head coach) Jung " peri " Bum-ki (정범기) (Coach) Kim " HSK " Hae-seong (김해성) (Staff)

title: Riot reveals Pacific Kickoff bracket
cleaned_content: Riot announced matchups for the 2025 Pacific Kickoff , which features a 12-team, double-elimination bracket. Like Americas and EMEA, the draw was divided into two pools, with the first pool including teams from the region that made Champions 2024 . Those teams received a bye from the first round, qualifying for the upper bracket's quarterfinals. The second pool has the region's remaining eight teams, which were drawn against each other with the winners facing teams from the first pool. The 2025 Pacific Kickoff bracket. (Photo by Riot Games) With two new organizations and a slew of roster moves between teams, the first round brings a handful of interesting matchups. BOOM Esports vs. T1 Two months ago, BOOM lost in the grand final of Pacific Ascension finishing their 2024 season as coming close, but not close enough to reaching VCT. Following Riot's decision to remove BLEED , BOOM earned their spot as the Pacific region's 12th team. Their first test at the top level of Valorant will be against T1, who this offseason have bolstered their ranks with the signings of Meteor , BuZz , and Sylvan . The winner of this match will go on to play last year's Stage 1 champions, Paper Rex . Global Esports vs. Team Secret Team Secret enjoyed a quietly successful 2024 season, finishing with an overall record of 10-7. They were third at the end of Stage 2 , but were eliminated in the knockout stage of the playoffs. While Team Secret was in the middle of the Pacific pack, Global Esports had a 2024 to forget. They registered just four wins on the season and ended Stage 2 with just three wins without any playoff appearances. They have since revamped their team, bringing in a new five-man roster. Three of their new signees are from the Phillippines and will make their GE debuts against the Phillippines-based Team Secret. The winner will go on to face TALON . Rex Regum Qeon vs. DetonatioN FocusMe Rex Regum Qeon had a solid 2024 as one of the teams in the middle of the pack. While they missed out on the Stage 1 playoffs, a better Stage 2 got them into the playoffs, where they were eliminated in the knockouts. They have had a quieter offseason, making just one personnel change while making short-lived appearances at Red Bull Home Ground and the Radiant Asia Invitational . They will take on a DFM team that has had anything but a quiet offseason. Widespread changes saw them pick up four new players, building around Duelist player Meiy . After shaking off some rust at Red Bull Home Ground, they impressed at the Radiant Asia Invitational, reaching the grand final and falling to Paper Rex. Awaiting the winner of the two teams is the Masters Shanghai champions, Gen.G ZETA DIVISION vs. Nongshim RedForce ZETA's offseason began with the retirement of longtime player Laz . After qualifying for Champions 2023 through the Pacific LCQ , they failed to reach a single global event in 2024. They picked up a trio of players and a new head coach from tier 2 side FENNEL , and have shown some improvement. They reached the grand final of Red Bull Home Ground, falling to T1. Nongshim Redforce, previously known as Sin Prisa Gaming before they were acquired , enter their maiden season in VCT after winning Pacific Ascension. The five players and head coach from SPG remain together, while NongShim's second-tier squad disbanded following Split 3 of Challengers Korea , which they won. Korean giants DRX , who have undergone a major offseason rebuild themselves, await the winner. At least year's Pacific Kickoff, which was held with a three-group format that ended with a four-team single-elimination bracket, Gen.G put themselves on the map. After qualifying for the playoffs through the play-in, they swiftly defeated perennial powerhouses DRX and Paper Rex, marking their first competition victory in what went down as a successful 2024 for them. Pacific Kickoff action will begin on January 16, with the two finalists of the event qualifying to Masters Bangkok .

title: NRG Esports triumphs over Gen.G to claim SOOP League trophy
cleaned_content: NRG has overcome Gen.G 3-0 in the grand final of the SOOP Valorant League , earning the right to lift the trophy in one of the biggest events of the offseason. The three-map series played out on Abyss, Haven, and Ascent, Abyss and Ascent being Gen.G's picks and Haven being NRG's pick. NRG won Abyss 13-4, Haven 13-11, and Ascent 13-4. Both teams came into this match with a point to prove. For NRG, it was a chance to turn over a new leaf for an experienced core after a disappointing 2024 season with the addition of two highly anticipated rookies. For Gen.G, it was a chance to show that changing two players hadn't taken away from their ability to vie for championships. A fresh opportunity for three Americas veterans. (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games) The series kicked off on Gen.G's first map pick of Abyss . Both sides brought out distinct compositions that they had shown earlier in the event, with Gen.G locking in Astra and Omen and NRG opting for Harbor and Vyse. The first six rounds were back-and-forth, leading to a 3-3 start, but NRG tore away with a 9-3 lead as Gen.G became increasingly unable to handle the opposition's rapid site hits, ironclad postplants, and deep mid searches. In the second half, NRG demonstrated a superior defense with impressive and varied Vyse setups from FiNESSE , easily closing out Abyss 13-4. Statistically, it was Verno and s0m who controlled the server; the former found 17 kills to 6 deaths and a 1.66 rating while the latter scored 18 kills to 9 deaths and a 1.49 rating. NRG opened their map pick of Haven with a similarly dominant attack half, building an 8-4 lead despite losing the first pistol. In contrast, the second half was neck-and-neck as both teams struggled to string together multiple rounds in a row until the score was 12-8 in NRG's favor. Gen.G rallied temporarily, managing to get to 11 rounds, but NRG denied overtime and won out Haven 13-11. While Munchkin led his team with 19 kills and a 1.13 rating, it was Verno once again lighting up the scoreboard with 21 kills to only 11 deaths and a 1.67 rating. The American Initiator racked up highlights on the map, including a 1v2 in round 11 and a belting 4K with the Guardian in round 15. The final map was Ascent . This time, NRG established an even greater lead early on, converting the first pistol on their defense and then the bonus off the back of a Judge 3K from s0m. An ace from s0m in round 7 later led his team to a 6-1 lead. Every setup that NRG used seemed to work perfectly to foil Gen.G's plans as they consistently won out their duels, culminating in a 10-2 half. NRG took home Ascent 13-4 to complete the clean sweep over Gen.G and win the SOOP League. “I think we just had a really good flow in all three maps, we had a good game plan going into the game,” FiNESSE commented on the win in the post-match interview. “I think it showed that we're pretty good, so hopefully a lot of winning next season,” Ethan added when asked what fans could expect from the team going into 2025. With this win, NRG has cemented themselves as a title contender going into the 2025 season, which is now just one month away. NRG will next return for Americas Kickoff , which begins Jan. 16.

title: Gen.G sweeps Korean derby to make SOOP League grand final
cleaned_content: Gen.G has defeated DRX 2-0 in the SOOP Valorant League semifinal . They will next play against NRG Esports in the event's grand final , marking Gen.G's seventh final in 2024. DRX ends the tournament in the top four, reaching playoffs after defeating Bilibili Gaming and Rapid Lofi in groups. This series is the tenth time both teams play each other, with eight of those matches taking place this year. Overall, DRX had the upper hand with five wins prior to this encounter, but Gen.G boasts a much better record when counting only VCT matches — four wins and two losses. Gen.G opened their map, Pearl , with t3xture taking over to win the pistol. He kept the pace up, leading his team to a six round winstreak. By round five, he had 13 eliminations, which set him up to finish the attack with a 1.54 rating. Eventually, DRX took their first round win, courtesy of HYUNMIN 's Neon, but Gen.G quickly adapted, reaching double digits in the first half with ease. Karon stuck the defuse to secure the pistol, all but confirming a win on the first map. Foxy9 found a 3K on B long to overtake t3xture as top fragger, taking his team to match point. Gen.G opted to play the bonus cautiously, but it still came down to the wire, as MaKo needed to win a 1v1 for DRX's third round. Now with a full buy, Gen.G was better able to control the final round, and Karon came out on top over MaKo in the Astra mirror, taking the 1v1 and sealing Pearl 13-3. Gen.G executed a successful retake to win the first pistol round on Bind , DRX's selection. Their gun advantage let them win a second retake, but DRX's Neon-led double-sentinel composition applied enough pressure to put them in the lead. Gen.G tied the score at 3-3, but Hyunmin and Flashback helped their team stay ahead during the remainder of the half. Together, the duo found 7 first kills, while the entirety of Gen.G combined only had 5. free1ng showed up on round 10, finding a 3K with the round ended by Flashback in a 1v1. Munchkin earned a fourth point for his team after a 4K on B short, but was left in a 1v3 the next round after DRX's sentinel duo broke through Gen.G's defense. He was unable to clutch, which ended the half 8-4 in DRX's favor. A Karon 3K helped Gen.G recover, narrowing the score gap with a pistol win. He showed off his Marshall skills in the anti-eco, and t3xture helped Gen.G take the next two rounds to tie the score. DRX's stalling abilities rewarded them with a ninth point, but Gen.G played the map well, drew out DRX's resources, and took advantage of their ultimate economy to continue scoring rounds. t3xture took up an attack Operator to break through DRX, finding three with the premium weapon and another with his Showstopper. With his bullet just milliseconds ahead of the sniper shot, yoman denied t3xture the ace, ending Bind 13-9 and sending DRX home. Foxy9 mentioned conflicted feelings on defeating his former team. “I feel really happy, but it's a mix of emotions,” he said after the series. Despite this, he was confident in Gen.G. “My teammates have so much more potential than what we displayed today,” he said. “The team has helped me a lot, helped me grow.” “It's going to be a 3-0. 13-8 first map, 13-5 second map, 13-3 third map. All clean games from Gen.G,” he said regarding their grand final match.

title: NRG reaches SOOP grand final with 2-1 over MiTH
cleaned_content: NRG has defeated Made in Thailand 2-1 in the first semifinal of the SOOP Valorant League . NRG will next play against either DRX or Gen.G in the grand final , their second grand final this off-season. MiTH has been eliminated from the tournament, going out in the top four after taking wins against Sentinels and Talon Esports . The match began on Haven , with Verno cleaning up the pistol and anti-eco rounds to open the map. Three separate 4Ks followed, with MiTH getting on the board thanks to cgrs and Laz , while Verno remained on the killfeed to grant his team a tie at 3-3. He continued being key to his team's success, setting up a post-plant that returned NRG to the lead. MiTH's retakes put them up 5-4, but NRG quickly equalized following a timeout. The half remained close, ending with a tied score ahead of the break. A quick pistol round went MiTH's way, and they were able to win a 3v5 to slow the back-and-forth down and remain in the lead. The North American squad's economy forced them onto a semi-eco and a pair of half-buys, letting MiTH reach match point despite NRG closing the score gap. A tactical pause from MiTH led to a comfortable final round, ending the map 13-10 and marking MiTH's fifth map win against a VCT partnership team in this tournament. MiTH opened their map pick, Pearl , with a pistol round win. A close bonus round went NRG's way, but Kadoom extended his team's lead with a collateral Operator kill. NRG continued testing A after a timeout, closing the gap and leading to MiTH's own pause after an eco round. Undeterred, Kadoom and Killua helped put MiTH back in the lead, ending the half 7-5. NRG averted a potential disaster with a pistol win, seemingly more comfortable on the defense. They took the lead in the bonus round, and MiTH's low economy helped NRG set the score 9-7 and force a timeout from their opponents. mada opened the following round to help his team reach double digits, but cgrs countered by stopping a nearly-successful NRG retake. His efforts were not enough, however, as a Verno 3K forced MiTH into an eco-round. NRG reached match point, but was denied twice by their opponents. In the end, Ethan and FiNESSE led a retake to convert a 3v3, ending the map 13-10 and sending the series to a decider. Heading into the decider, Ascent , NRG was unstoppable. The NA team took the pistol after a retake, and was able to confirm a close bonus round by denying info to MiTH's remaining players. A flawless anti-eco prompted MiTH's first timeout of the decider, which in turn helped the Thai lineup win their first point. NRG remained confident, however, winning the next three rounds and forcing out MiTH's second pause at 7-1. MiTH was unable to find a gap in the defense until round 11, with cgrs and Kadoom shutting down NRG's retake attempt. NRG recovered quickly once again, as Ethan held an advanced position to catch MiTH's A push off-guard. MiTH kept their hopes up in the second half with a pistol win, but NRG punished an over-eager defense to take the bonus. Another patient attack put NRG at match point, and Ethan helped seal the decider 13-5 with a triple kill. Ethan was optimistic about his team's performance. “[It was a] slow start, but everyone's playing really well,” he said after the series. “The comms were good. “ “Everyone is getting used to each other,” he added. “We're getting to know what everyone likes to do. We're meshing pretty well.” He also commented on the grand final matchup. “We're excited to play a Korean team. DRX is a little more flashy, Gen.G is really good.”

title: SOOP Valorant League reaches final four
cleaned_content: The SOOP Valorant Legaue has concluded its group stage, narrowing a field of eight teams and two groups into a four-team bracket. The competition's group stage mirrors the group stage used at Champions Seoul, arranging teams in groups of four with matches to be played in a double-elimination tournament. With powerhouse teams from North America, China, the host nation South Korea, and qualified teams from Thailand and Vietnam, the group stage was filled with tight matches, upsets, and the birth of a Cinderella story. Meet Made in Thailand, the Group A Cinderellas. (Photo by SOOP ) Group A winners: Made in Thailand & Gen.G Eliminated: Sentinels & TALON Made in Thailand earned their way into SOOP by winning the Thailand Qualifier , beating out second-tier teams like XERXIA Esports and FULL SENSE while defeating Team NKT Academy in a five-map grand final. They turned heads with a 2-1 victory over fellow Thai team TALON , but topped that performance with a 2-1 upset over American giants Sentinels . On the all-decisive third map, they fought back from down 12-6 to tough out a 17-15 victory. With Killua and former Paper Rex stand-in cgrs impressing through two wins, they finished the group stage as Group A's top seed. After being placed in another double-elimination group with Sentinels, Gen.G got the better of their overseas rivals in the SOOP Colosseum. After losing to them in two maps to open the event and then making quick work of TALON, they bounced back to avenge themselves against Sentinels, winning in two maps by a difference of five total rounds. t3xture had a match to remember in the rematch, dropping a server-high 47 kills with a rating of 1.26. He is part of a three-man returning class for the Masters Shanghai winners, who seem to have finally hit their stride with two new players. With no more OFF//SEASON events on their calendars, Sentinels and TALON have just around a month to prepare for the start of their respective region's Kickoff tournaments after being eliminated. Sentinels, who reloaded their roster with bang and N4RRATE , appear to still be troubleshooting the fine details of their team. Meanwhile, an impressive showing from rising star duelist primmie , who recorded 65 kills in the team's loss to Made in Thailand, was not enough to keep TALON alive. DRX wins on home soil to set up a Korean derby in the semis. (Photo by SOOP ) Group B Winners: DRX & NRG Eliminated: Bilibili Gaming & Rapid Lofi After a back-and-forth, three-map contest against Bilibili Gaming , DRX made quick work of Vietnam qualifiers Rapid Lofi to qualify for the playoffs. Continued positive performances from Flashback on Cypher elevated the performance of DRX. He finished as the highest-fragging player in both matches with 20 more kills than deaths in both. DRX lost BuZz and Foxy9 to other Korean teams to start their offseason, and before SOOP, experienced inconsistent performances at the TEN Asia Invitational and the Radiant Asia Invitational . They move on to the playoffs as Group B's top seed, and will play Group B's second seed, Gen.G. After a shock upset to Rapid Lofi put them on the brink of elimination, NRG fought their demons of the past, defeating BiliBili Gaming in three maps. That victory set up a rematch with Rapid Lofi, one that they handled with much more ease than in the opening match. Despite struggles in pistol rounds, which at times put them at an early disadvantage, NRG ultimately prevailed. Namely, the play of new addition Verno , who ended the decider match with a server-high 38 kills, lifted the team. BiliBili Gaming failed to replicate their Champions Los Angeles success against NRG. Despite keeping both of their matches relatively competitive, they ultimately fell in three maps against NRG and DRX. Meanwhile, Rapid Lofi leaves SOOP at around the level that may have been expected of a Challengers squad, despite early hype after their win over NRG. Playoffs And then there were four. (Photo by SOOP ) The playoffs will be single-elimination, with the semifinals best-of-three and the grand final a best-of-five. With the top-seed of the groups paired with the second-seeds, the first-round matchups are: DRX vs. Gen.G The derby between Korean giants isn't quite the same as it was during the 2024 season. In Pacific play, Gen.G had the upper hand over DRX, winning four matches and dropping just one. In offseason events, DRX has gotten the better of Gen.G in both meetings. This match will be the last time that former Foxy9 will play his former team before the official season begins. Made in Thailand vs. NRG After turning heads in the group stage, Made in Thailand has a chance to cause more chaos, being matched up with NRG Esports. While the Thailand Challengers team may be new to many, one face is sure to be familiar to hardcore NRG fans: cgrs. Most known for his play on Gekko and Sova, he's iconic for his stand-in run at Masters Tokyo , which included an iconic win over a certain NRG.

title: Riot reveals 2025 EMEA agenda
cleaned_content: Riot has revealed the matchups for the upcoming VCT 2025 EMEA Kickoff as well as important changes to formats for Challengers, Ascension, Game Changers, and Premier. Kickoff Similar to the format used in the Americas 2025 Kickoff , EMEA's Kickoff will utilize a 12-team double-elimination bracket to determine which two teams will represent the region at Masters Bangkok . Each team's position on the bracket was drawn at random in the Kickoff Draw Show , and the four teams who represented the EMEA region at last year's Champions received a BYE for their efforts. Game days will typically take place weekly on Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays while Playoff games will occur on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays. Changes in the schedule can be expected for some of the “bigger moments in the season.” The EMEA Kickoff Bracket. (Image: Riot Games) A revamped Championship Point distribution system ensures each stage of competition holds high stakes and diminishes the chances of a team's season ending early into the year. The top four finishers of Kickoff will receive Championship Points for their troubles. Additionally, the playoffs of Stage 1 and Stage 2 will expand to eight teams rather than six. Challengers Riot has also released information regarding the state of EMEA Challengers this year, with many changes promoting a healthier Tier 2 ecosystem and path to Ascension. Earlier this year, Riot unveiled a revamped format for the EMEA Challengers across all leagues, which began with a 3-Stage competition that allowed for teams to garner Ascension Points. Tournament organizers now have greater flexibility designing split formats, ensuring diversity across all Challengers EMEA competition. The main focus, however, is the new format regarding the top two teams from the DACH, French, Spanish, and Turkish leagues. These eight teams will be joined by four teams from the NORTH//EAST region in a week-long competition. Featuring four matches a day in a round robin stage, the top four teams across four groups will advance to playoffs for their hearty share of Ascension Points. This process will be repeated for Stages 1 and 2, while Stage 3 will introduce another two teams from the MENA region. Regional playoffs outside of the main Challengers EMEA events will distribute less points that will increase with each stage. The dates for all three cross-Challengers League Tournaments can be found below: Challengers EMEA 1: March 3-9 Challengers EMEA 2: May 19-25 Challengers EMEA 3: Sep 1-9 Teams can earn Ascension Points by competing in their respective leagues as well as EMEA Challengers. (Image: Riot Games) Ascension While the main details of Ascension's format have yet to be released, Riot has clarified that the entire tournament will take place on LAN using a double-elimination format. Additionally, the winner of Stage 3 EMEA Challengers will receive a direct invite to Ascension, while all other teams attending will be based on Ascension Points. More details regarding Ascension will be released in 2025. Game Changers While the format for Game Changers will stay the same, Riot is introducing one change to spice up the competition and allow teams to play more games. The top ten teams will compete in one group rather than split across two, increasing the amount of games per Group Stage by over 20. Premier & Regional Circuits Finally, Premier will continue to serve as a “developmental proving ground” for players on their path to pro in 2025. However, the best amateur teams will be provided their own tournaments, with more details being shared closer to the event dates. The new EMEA format across all levels of competition has been readjusted to garner growth and development for players and teams. More games, attention, and higher stakes seem to be on the agenda for not just EMEA this year. EMEA Kickoff will begin on Jan 15 as teams fight for two tickets to the first Masters event of the year.

title: Cloud9 allows moose to explore options
cleaned_content: Cloud9 has announced that Kaleb " moose " Jayne has been allowed to explore options as a restricted free agent and is actively searching for a new team. According to the announcement, moose is currently under contract with no buyout. This news comes several days after the team parted ways with Daniel " Rossy " Abedrabbo and signed Mitch " mitch " Semago in his stead. “Both parties mutually agree that a change in environment and exploring better options would be the best path to success in the long run,” the team stated regarding the change. moose joined Cloud9 in March just ahead of Americas Stage 1 to replace Maxim " wippie " Shepelev on the Sentinel role after the team suffered a 1-2 group stage exit in Kickoff . The squad spent the season hovering around the middle of the regional standings. While they managed to qualify for playoffs in both stages and earned a respectable 6-4 regular season record, Cloud9 were ultimately eliminated in the opening knockout round in both instances and failed to qualify for any international events. During the offseason, moose and the team achieved a standout second-place performance at Red Bull Home Ground . “Obviously not happy but I do understand their decision and think it will be better for both parties, wishing them nothing but the best,” moose commented . As of this time, the team is actively running trials to find a new fifth player. Cloud9 will next return for Americas Kickoff , which begins Jan. 16. Cloud9 is currently: Mitch " mitch " Semago Erick " Xeppaa " Bach Victor " v1c " Truong Francis " OXY " Hoang Ian " Immi " Harding (Coach) Guglielmo " GUGLi " Carraro (Assistant coach)

title: crashies joins FNATIC
cleaned_content: FNATIC has signed Austin " crashies " Roberts for the 2025 season. crashies is currently set to take the place of Leo " Leo " Jannesson , who has been inactive since June due to health reasons, as long as is needed. In their announcement article, the team confirmed that Leo will not be able to play for Kickoff. “Leo is still a member of our team and we're doing everything we can in the background to support his recovery,” explained FNATIC's Team Director Colin " CoJo " Johnson . “It's very hard to predict [Leo's] return at the moment so we've decided to bring in Crashies who we're confident in to fill the role until Leo is ready.” A longstanding veteran of North American Valorant, crashies is best known for his time with the OpTic Gaming core that won Masters Reykjavik in 2022 and spent much of the pre-partnerships era contending closely for other titles. Going into the 2023 season, he joined NRG along with many other members of that core. The roster continued to be a leader in North America, placing fourth at Masters Tokyo , but suffered an unexpected group stage exit at Champions 2023 in Los Angeles. Despite this, expectations rose even higher for NRG in 2024 as they added world champions Max " Demon1 " Mazanov and Ethan " Ethan " Arnold . The superstar roster would face numerous challenges meeting those expectations, undergoing multiple roster changes, ending the Americas regular season with a 4-6 record, and ultimately failing to qualify for all three international events. crashies parted ways with the team in September. On the other side of the Atlantic, FNATIC faced similarly high expectations coming into 2024 after conquering LOCK//IN and Masters Tokyo in 2023. While still a top team in EMEA, the team struggled to match their previous heights this year as their best international result was a top-six finish at Champions 2024 . “Really happy to have Austin join for 2025 and I know his veteran leadership and mid-rounding will be a huge help to us going into the new season,” CoJo commented . FNATIC will next play at the Riot Games ONE invitational in Tokyo. As confirmed by CoJo, Ștefan " Sayonara " Mîtcu will play in their game versus ZETA DIVISION on Dec. 14 and crashies will play in their games versus LEVIATÁN and DetonatioN FocusMe on Dec. 15. FNATIC is now: Jake " Boaster " Howlett Austin " crashies " Roberts Kajetan " kaajak " Haremski Timofey " Chronicle " Khromov Emir " Alfajer " Ali Beder Ștefan " Sayonara " Mîtcu (Stand-in) Leo " Leo " Jannesson Chris " Elmapuddy " Tebbit (Head coach) Milan " Milan " de Meij (Assistant coach)

title: FURIA cook with heat, raafa, peu
cleaned_content: FURIA has finalized their 2025 VCT roster with the additions of Olavo " heat " Marcelo and Rafael " raafa " Lima while simultaneously onboarding Pedro " peu " Lopes as Head coach. The rebuilt team will debut later today in the Tixinha Invitational against Americas Ascension participant Galorys . After a fruitless 2023 with MIBR , heat impressed many after changing both his team and role in 2024. The former Duelist prodigy shifted to an Initiator role and meshed well with KRÜ Esports throughout the 2024 season, even pushing the team towards their fourth consecutive appearance at Champions , where they finished just short of a playoffs appearance. heat and the rest of KRÜ after qualifying to Champions Seoul. (Photo: Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games) One month after exiting Seoul's stage courtesy of FNATIC , heat announced that KRÜ had allowed him to explore his options for the next season, and departed the organization last month. After being denied promotion into the Americas League back in 2023 by M80 , raafa and the core of The Union took on Brazil's Challengers under Hero Base. The team managed to win Split 1 comfortably, but faltered in Split 2 and missed out on playoffs as well as an appearance at 2024's Americas Ascension . As LOUD 's coach, peu helped guide the team to the grand finals of the Americas Kickoff and qualify for Masters Madrid . Unfortunately, a top-four finish at the first major of the year would be all that there was for LOUD, as Brazil's finest struggled in both Splits of the Americas League and missed out on both Masters Shanghai and Champions Seoul. Shortly after, peu announced his departure from the team as the organization underwent changes. FURIA have not made an appearance on the VCT international stage in nearly two years. Throughout their 2024 season, the team picked up only three total wins across all three Americas events, two of which were against fellow Brazilian teams. Alongside MIBR, LOUD, and the newly-promoted 2Game Esports , FURIA look to restore Brazil's status within the VCT to that of a terrifying region blooming with talent. The now-complete roster prepares to use the OFF//SEASON to hone their skills and stay in form ahead of their opening match of the 2025 Americas Kickoff . FURIA is now: Rafael " raafa " Lima Olavo " heat " Marcelo Leonardo " mwzera " Serrati Ilan " havoc " Eloy Khalil " Khalil " Schmidt Pedro " peu " Lopes (Head coach) Lucas " lukzera " Soares (Assistant coach)

title: Oderus joins Apeks’ coaching staff
cleaned_content: Apeks have closed in on their second import of the season, signing Chad " oderus " Miller as the team's strategic coach for the 2025 season. Oderus joins Apeks for the second coaching stint of his career. His first time as coach came under Moist Moguls , a role he kept for nearly a year. Under oderus, Moist Moguls debuted as a top tier 2 team in North America — even winning one of the two Splits of the 2023 Challenger League in the region — but failed to reach VCT competitions. He returned to the server earlier in February, now under the Moist x Shopify banner, but the team struggled to keep up last year's performance. The team peaked in the first half of the year, during which they won Split 1 of the Challenger League and finished inside the top four at the Mid Season Cup . Apeks followed a similar path in 2023, claiming a place atop EMEA's tier 2 but failing to reach VCT. The team avenged themselves with a stellar run this year where, much like their 2023 run, they only lost twice. Apeks capped the regular season off with a 3-2 victory over PCIFIC Esports in the grand finals of Ascension , securing their spot in the VCT EMEA 2025. Since lifting that trophy, Apeks have made several changes to their roster. Players Kajetan " kaajak " Haremski and Dom " soulcas " Sulcas left the team , as did assistant coach Casper " Desmo " Rasmussen . To fill kaajak's duelist slot, the organization became the first to sign a Game Changers player, when they announced two-time GC champion Ava " florescent " Eugene just days ago. With florescent and oderus' signings, the team has largely rebuilt itself for the 2025 season. With a new duelist and coach signed, the team lacks just a flex player to fill the shoes of soulcas, who departed for KOI . The VCT EMEA 2025 will be the largest the region has seen since the start of partnership. The league has expanded to 12 slots to accommodate Ascension winners Gentle Mates and Apeks, where their stay in the league will be dependent on their performance throughout the upcoming season. Apeks ' current roster is: Ava " florescent " Eugene Tautvydas " hype " Paldavicius Michał " MOLSI " Łącki Auni " AvovA " Chahade Sabína " Leonieahh " Jankovič (Manager) Danail " DANNYTO " Sofroniev (Head coach) Chad " oderus " Miller (Coach)

title: Riot unveils Americas Kickoff bracket
cleaned_content: Riot held its draw for the 2025 Americas Kickoff , featuring a 12-team, double-elimination bracket for the first time. The draw was divided into two pools. The first pool had all four teams from the region that made Champions 2024 . Those teams received a bye from the first round, automatically qualifying for the upper bracket's quarterfinals. The second pool had the region's remaining eight teams. The teams were drawn against each other in the opening round, with winners facing teams from Pool 1. The 2025 Americas Kickoff bracket. (Photo by Riot Games) The draw brings forward a few interesting matchups, from cross-country rivalries to former international foes duking it out. Evil Geniuses vs. LOUD The two teams, who famously clashed in a five-map, lower final at Champions 2023 , will butt heads to open their respective 2025 seasons. Both rosters have an almost entirely new look. While tuyz and cauanzin remain from LOUD's 2023 team, Evil Geniuses has an entirely new five, with head coach potter the only constant since then. They will play for the chance to face KRÜ Esports . MIBR vs. 100 Thieves MIBR underwent possibly the biggest rebuild of the 2024 offseason, letting go of all but one player and constructing a new roster centered around Brazilian superstar aspas . Meanwhile, 100 Thieves retain much of their 2024 roster, with the one change being former M80 standout zander replacing bang , who moved to Sentinels . The winner of this match will play Sentinels, who finished fourth at Champions. NRG vs. Cloud9 NRG's busy offseason began with the team parting ways with crashies , Demon1 , and head coach Chet . They've rebuilt, picking up a pair of Tier 2 standouts in Verno and mada while picking bonkar to lead the charge as their new head coach. Cloud9 also had their fair of roster shuffling this year. They let go of vanity and runi , who had storied pasts with the organization, and picked up v1c and Rossy as their in-game leader to round out their five. However, a few weeks after losing in the grand final of RedBull Homeground , they parted ways with Rossy and signed mitch , who was last with the team in 2022. The two teams will clash to take on a star-studded G2 Esports in the upper quarterfinals. 2Game Esports vs. FURIA In a clash between Brazilian teams, FURIA will go head to head with 2Game Esports to welcome them to VCT. 2G, who defeated M80 in the grand final of Americas Ascension , boast an all-Brazilian roster. To circumvent the absence of Duelist player spike , who is ineligible due to being under 18, they picked up former Brazilian Challengers player gobera . FURIA still have some work to do in terms of roster rebuilding. They let go of kon4n , xand , and nzr after their season ended, and have just three players on their roster. Awaiting the winner is LEVIATÁN , who are also based in South America but boast a more diverse roster that's been bolstered by Demon1 and nataNk . At least year's Americas Kickoff , which was held with a three-group format that ended with a four-team single-elimination bracket, Sentinels defeated LOUD in five maps in the grand final. They qualified for Masters Madrid , where they defeated Pacific team Gen.G to lift their first international trophy since 2021. Americas Kickoff action will begin on January 16, with the two finalists of the event qualifying to Masters Bangkok.

title: nataNk completes Leviatán roster
cleaned_content: LEVIATÁN has added ex- Gentle Mates player nataNk to round out its roster for 2025. nataNk will be stepping into a crucial role alongside new addition Demon1 , replacing Mazino and 2022 world champion aspas . After a disappointing 2023, Leviatán made significant strides in 2024 following a complete roster overhaul. Although their season started poorly, culminating in an early exit at Masters Shanghai , the team rebounded in Stage 2 , finishing with an impressive 9-1 record and placing third at Champions Seoul . Despite their growing success, the roster fragmented after the season, with Mazino leaving after his contract expired and aspas' future remaining unclear. The nataNk joined Gentle Mates in early 2023, competing in the Challengers League: France . After a surprise victory over Apeks in the grand finals of EMEA Ascension 2023 , nataNk and Gentle Mates earned a spot in VCT EMEA for 2024. However, the team struggled in VCT, going winless in the Kickoff tournament and finishing the regular season with a cumulative 3-7 record, missing the playoffs in both stages. Despite these challenges, nataNk's individual performance shone through, finishing Stage 2 ranked seventh in ACS and among the top 15 in rating. Following Gentle Mates' elimination, the organization released its roster, leaving nataNk a free agent before his signing with the South American organization. Ready for 2025, Leviatán is now: Francisco " kiNgg " Aravena Max " Demon1 " Mazanov Ian " tex " Botsch Corbin " C0M " Lee Nathan " nataNk " Bocqueho Dimitar " Itopata " Staev (Head coach)

title: Masters Bangkok ticket sales information
cleaned_content: Masters Bangkok tickets will go live on Friday, Dec. 13 at 3:00 a.m. UTC. Tickets can be purchased from this link . The first Masters tournament of the year, featuring the top two teams from each league, will take place from Feb. 20 to March 2. There will be a brief pause between the group stage and playoffs from February 25-26. The whole tournament will take place in Bangkok's UOB Live Hall, which has a maximum capacity of 4,500 seated occupants. Ticket prices will increase for later games, ranging from 871 Thai baht (~$25 USD) to ฿2,468 (~$75 USD). Mastercard holders will be able to purchase tickets 24 hours early via the same link .

title: Apeks changes the game with florescent
cleaned_content: Apeks has signed two-time Game Changers champion Ava " florescent " Eugene to their 2025 VCT roster. florescent will likely take the spot of kaajak as the duelist player for Apeks. After winning Ascension , Apeks was unable to maintain their complete roster, with kaajak and soulcas leaving to sign with FNATIC and KOI respectively. florescent has been one of the most anticipated prospects in Game Changers ever since she joined the league in 2022. She drew enough attention as the star of Misfits Black to earn a spot on Version1 's 2023 roster , which was an assembly of some of the strongest North American GC talent. This roster went on to dominate the scene, and after being signed by Shopify Rebellion Gold , would win the Game Changers Championship in 2023, avenging the organization's grand finals loss the previous year. Maintaining the same roster for 2024, Shopify entered Berlin looking to win back-to-back titles. Nine maps later, they would capture their second championship trophy, doing so without dropping a single map. In Shopify's championship wins, florescent put up dominant performances, earning the MVP title for both tournaments. After her historic run with Shopify, the organization announced her release to allow her to pursue this opportunity with Apeks. Two trophies, two MVPS. Despite Shopify's supremacy, they have been unable to find success outside of GC, having always been eliminated in the open qualifiers of NA's Challenger league. Other top GC teams have similarly struggled against the wider competitive field in their own regions. With this signing, florescent will become the first ever Game Changers player to compete in VCT. “Making the jump to VCT has always been my goal since day one,” said florescent. “I'm very proud of the success my team had these last 2 years but I now feel ready to take the next step.” “Her performance during trials was outstanding,” and “her passion for the game is on another level,” commented Apeks head coach DANNYTO . “I'm looking forward to what we can achieve this year with her and I believe it's going to be special.” Apeks are now: Tautvydas " hype " Paldavicius Michał " MOLSI " Łącki Auni " AvovA " Chahade Ava " florescent " Eugene Sabína " Leonieahh " Jankovič (Manager) Danail " DANNYTO " Sofroniev (Head coach)

title: Gentle Mates announces 2025 roster
cleaned_content: Gentle Mates has signed Pontus " Zyppan " Eek , Patrik " Minny " Hušek , Robbie " RobbieBk " Boerkamp , and Haydem " Click " Ali . Alex " goked " Kie and Juan " McJuankar " Carlos Mesa Ciruelo have also joined as head coach and assistant coach respectively and Josh " jtay " Taylor has been added as an analyst. Zyppan was a member of the original FunPlus Phoenix core that lifted the Masters Copenhagen trophy in 2022 and later became the core of Natus Vincere in 2023. NAVI started strong in 2023 with a top-four finish at LOCK//IN but have been unable to reach the same heights since. In 2024, NAVI reunited the Masters-winning roster by signing ardiis but failed to return to the international stage over the course of the year. Minny is best known for competing with GoNext Esports in the Sentinel role in Challengers League East . GoNext took first prize in the league playoffs in Split 1 and Split 2 and earned qualification to EMEA Ascension , where they were eliminated in the group stage with a 2-2 record. Individually, Minny stood out in his role with a 1.10 overall rating. RobbieBk was also scouted from Challengers, having spent 2024 as the in-game leader and Initiator for Joblife in Challengers League France . Much like GoNext, the team won both Splits in their region and qualified to EMEA Ascension, narrowly exiting in the group stage with a 2-2 record.
