Click most recently played Duelist for SK Gaming in Challengers League DACH . After a middling season, the team narrowly missed out on regional playoffs. Excluding the relegation stage, in which he did not participate, Click achieved the highest ACS, KPR, and FKPR in the league during Split 2 at 251.2, 0.92, and 0.24 respectively. goked previously served as head coach for LEVIATÁN for the first half of 2024. During that time, the team came third in Americas Stage 1 and qualified to Masters Shanghai . After suffering an early elimination at the hands of FUT Esports in the Swiss stage of Shanghai, Goked mutually parted ways with the team in June. McJuankar comes into the team after spending the previous season as an assistant coach for BBL Esports and jtay was last the head coach for HEROIC Valkyries . Gentle Mates joined VCT EMEA after winning EMEA Ascension 2023 in an upset sweep in the grand final over Apeks . They kept their going full roster into 2024 and later added Thomas " Kada " Johner in place of Logan " logaN " Corti between Stage 1 and Stage 2. The French squad ultimately ended the regular season in tenth place in the regional standings with a 3-7 record; the organization chose to part ways with four players, keeping only K4DAVRA. These changes take Gentle Mates from an all-French team to an English-speaking core for the first time in the organization's history. Looking ahead to 2025, Gentle Mates must qualify for Champions Paris and outperform Apeks to retain their slot in VCT EMEA. Gentle Mates is now: Thomas " Kada " Johner Pontus " Zyppan " Eek Patrik " Minny " Hušek Robbie " RobbieBk " Boerkamp Haydem " Click " Ali Alex " goked " Kie (Head coach) Juan " McJuankar " Carlos Mesa Ciruelo (Assistant coach) Josh " jtay " Taylor (Analyst)

title: NAVI picks up hiro, koalanoob, and Ruxic, Happy as head coach
cleaned_content: Natus Vincere has signed Emirhan " hiro " Kat , Gianfranco " koalanoob " Potestio , and Uğur " Ruxic " Güç to their roster for VCT 2025. Vincent " Happy " Schopenhauer has been added to the team as head coach. hiro is best known for joining FNATIC at the beginning of EMEA Stage 2 after Leo " Leo " Jannesson stepped down from the active roster due to health issues. FNATIC won Stage 2 in undefeated fashion with hiro ranking as the eleventh highest rated player in the league in one of the most impressive rookie performances in the region. Although statistically quieter at Champions 2024 , hiro ultimately went on to finish top-six with the team at his first international event. koalanoob and Happy had both previously been with M80 since December 2022. In both 2023 and 2024, M80 won the Challengers League North America playoffs in undefeated fashion before narrowly missing out on ascending to VCT Americas, losing to The Guard in the grand final of Americas Ascension 2023 and 2Game Esports in the grand final of Americas Ascension 2024 . koalanoob ranked fourth by rating at Ascension 2024 with a rating of 1.10. Ruxic hails from Fire Flux Vatangame in Challengers League Turkey . A cornerstone of Turkish Valorant, the team won Split 1 with Ruxic earning the title of Grand Finals MVP before disappointing with a fifth-place finish in Split 2. Despite the result, Ruxic continued to perform in his role and was the highest-rated Controller player in Split 2 with a 1.17 rating. NAVI spent the 2024 season falling just short of the international stage, losing to Team Heretics in single-elimination matches both in Kickoff and the EMEA Stage 1 playoffs . In Stage 2, NAVI only managed to win one series versus Gentle Mates after previously achieving an impressive 4-1 record in Stage 1. Their season concluded in the playoffs at the hands of Team Vitality in their third single-elimination defeat of the year. This downturn spelled the end for the longstanding core famous for winning Masters Copenhagen under the FunPlus Phoenix banner and a new era for NAVI as they retained only Kyrylo " ANGE1 " Karasov and Andrey " Shao " Kiprsky for the 2025 season. Natus Vincere is now: Kyrylo " ANGE1 " Karasov Andrey " Shao " Kiprsky Emirhan " hiro " Kat Gianfranco " koalanoob " Potestio Uğur " Ruxic " Güç Vincent " Happy " Schopenhauer (Head coach) Urszula " Xirreth " Klimczak (Performance coach)

title: Cloud9 replaces Rossy with mitch
cleaned_content: Cloud9 has announced the departure of Daniel " Rossy " Abedrabbo and the addition of Mitch " mitch " Semago . This change comes less than two months after Rossy's inital signing in October. After spending the 2024 season overseas with T1 in Pacific, Rossy returned home to Americas to join Cloud9 as their new in-game leader. He, along with v1c , was one of the first signings of the off season, being announced just one day after the transfer window opened. In his short time with Cloud9, Rossy played in two off season tournaments. He debuted in blue at the SEN City Classic , where Cloud9 went winless, losing to each of Sentinels , Evil Geniuses , and NRG . A few weeks later, Cloud9 traveled to Berlin to participate in the Red Bull Home Ground tournament. In Berlin, Cloud9 found wins against the likes of FNATIC and Team Heretics before steamrolling G2 Esports , a tournament favorite, in the semifinals . It was Rossy's old team in T1 that put an end to their hot streak in the grand finals , where they were bested 3-1 in the series. Throughout the whole tournament, Rossy played lights out. He boasted the best performance of the main event with a 1.34 rating, clearing the next highest rating by a margin of 0.11. Cloud9 stated in their announcement that Rossy's removal was a result of his in-game leading "not [meshing] with how the team wanted to play," and was a unanimous decision from players and coaches. Rossy has announced that he is now looking for a new team and that he holds “no hard feelings towards anyone apart of C9.” For mitch, this will be his second stint on Cloud9. His first was as a part of Cloud9's founding roster when they joined the Valorant scene in 2020. He was the longest lasting member of that original roster, and even helped Cloud9 earn their only international qualification, that being to Champions 2021 . He was let go after the 2022 season, and moved to compete in NA Challengers as the IGL for Oxygen Esports . After two years with Oxygen, he now returns to lead Cloud9. Cloud9 is now: Mitch " mitch " Semago Erick " Xeppaa " Bach Victor " v1c " Truong Kaleb " moose " Jayne Francis " OXY " Hoang Ian " Immi " Harding (Coach) Guglielmo " GUGLi " Carraro (Assistant coach)

title: Paper Rex reclaims Pacific throne at the Radiant Asia Invitational
cleaned_content: Paper Rex has won the Radiant Asia Invitational tournament, emerging victorious over DetonatioN FocusMe in the grand finals . They took the final series 3-1 to crown themselves the champions. The two teams faced off in the previous round of the tournament in the upper finals, where DFM won in 2-0 fashion. Paper Rex quickly rebounded in the lower final , where they swept Trace Esports in dominant fashion to earn themselves a rematch against DFM. Coming from the upper bracket, DFM dictated the map pool of the series, choosing to ban Bind and Split. The map pool consisted of Ascent, Haven, Abyss, Pearl, and Sunset. The teams traded each other's map picks, with Paper Rex winning Ascent 13-10 and DFM winning Haven 13-6. Paper Rex then took the next two maps, winning Abyss 13-2, and Pearl 13-7. DFM took Paper Rex to Ascent first, a map they had won comfortably in their previous match. After their loss, Paper Rex abandoned their off meta agent compositions they were so known for and finally leaned into the established meta. They utilized the map's default comp to great success against Trace Esports, where they dominated with a 13-4 scoreline. DFM seemed unfazed by Paper Rex's changeup as they opened up the map with five rounds in a row. It took heroics from Paper Rex to find any rounds, as DFM remained firmly in control all half to end with a 9-3 lead. Paper Rex opened up their attack side with a pistol win, before narrowly converting their bonus round off of a vintage mindfreak clutch. From there, the momentum was in their hands and DFM's lead quickly crumbled. They went on to win 10 out of the 11 rounds in the second half and secured the comeback with a 13-10 win. In a crucial round, mindfreak is ice cold as always. Moving to Paper Rex's map pick of Haven, DFM decided they needed an even bigger lead than on Ascent. This time, it was nine unanswered rounds and a 10-2 lead on their attack half. The combination of Meiy 's Neon and Art 's Odin proved to be too oppressive for Paper Rex to handle. The Art of the Odin It was once again up to Paper Rex to pull off the comeback on their attack. They started off with a pistol round, but could not convert the bonus round this time. They would find two more rounds, but it was once again the Odin play from Art that would help DFM secure the final two rounds, winning the map 13-6. Shaking off the results of Haven, Paper Rex responded with their own 10-2 half on Abyss. They quickly closed it out with three quick rounds in the second half for a 13-2 stomp of a map. Throughout the map, mindfreak was electric, putting up a 19-3 kill-death ratio, bringing his team to a 2-1 lead in the series. A brawl in A main, mindfreak comes out on top. Map four, for the fourth time of the series, started off with a 5-0 lead for the attacking team. This time it was DFM taking the lead on Pearl, a map which is historically one of Paper Rex's best. After DFM's hot start, however, Paper Rex found their footing and brought their way back up to a more even 7-5 scoreline at the half. In a similar story to Ascent, Paper Rex's attack was unstoppable. Once again winning the pistol and bonus round, they proceeded to sweep the rest of the map. Paper Rex won all eight rounds of the second half to close out the series and hoist themself a trophy. A ridiculous 3K from Jinggg to secure the series. While DFM fell short in the grand finals, they have proven that they can compete with some of the best teams from Pacific and China. After two years at the bottom of the Pacific league, they can enter 2025 with some promise of success. For Paper Rex, this tournament win places them back atop the Pacific league after slipping down the rungs towards the end of the 2024 VCT season.

title: Paper Rex reaches Radiant Asia grand final with 3-0 win against Trace
cleaned_content: Paper Rex has defeated Trace Esports 3-0 in the Radiant Asia lower final . They will next play against DetonatioN FocusMe in the grand final , a rematch of the upper final in which DFM came out on top. Trace has been eliminated from the tournament, finishing in third place after taking out DRX earlier in the bracket. “ alecks just banged the table and scolded us,” d4v41 joked after the series regarding their upper bracket loss to DFM. Comparing off-season performances, the map veto erred slightly in Trace's favor , as they had shown comfort on the second map, Ascent, and had a 3-0 record on map three, Sunset. Recent performances on the first three map picks also pointed towards a possible win from Trace, as Paper Rex had lost on Split and Ascent against DFM, while Trace found comfortable wins against DRX on Sunset and Split. However, Paper Rex reaching this stage via the upper bracket gave them priority in the veto, and picking into Trace's ideal map pool indicated confidence. Paper Rex kicked off the series on Split with a dominant attack, their double-duelist composition enabling quick site hits and overwhelming lone defenders. Trace was only able to win one round in the half, with LuoK1ng winning a close 1v1 against something . Trace called a timeout soon afterwards, but the Chinese lineup was unable to recover. By the end of the half, something had found 26 eliminations, equal to Trace's combined total kills. The star Jetts take over round 6 Returning from the break, LuoK1ng once again stepped up, scoring a second point for his team after a 4K. Trace was able to take a handful of rounds, but f0rsakeN dashed any comeback hopes with a perfect Guiding Light, ending the first map 13-5 The Southeast Asian roster opened Ascent with another pistol-bonus round win, countering Trace's offense with ease. Well-timed utility forced a three-player save from their opponents, and a tactical pause was called after the round. Trace took two points afterwards, opting to end B after six straight rounds of testing the A defense. A patient post-plant added a point to Trace's score, and the support players helped Trace earn their fourth, sending Ascent to halftime with an 8-4. Paper Rex forces Trace to save with a set play The second pistol round and a close anti-eco went Paper Rex's way, further extending their lead to a 10-4. A force-buy paid off, as d4v41 sealed a 1v1 with 14 HP remaining. Ultimately, two coordinated B hits ended Trace's map pick 13-4 in Paper Rex's favor. “He knows how to be aggressive at the right time, how to play safe at the right time,” d4v41 said regarding forsakeN's initiators on Ascent. Paper Rex continued their pistol dominance with their fourth opening round win on Sunset . Their signature aggression aided them in taking an early lead, but Trace was able to take advantage of a weak A site to tie the map. Trace continued with momentum in their favor, never shying away from showing presence on A site. The half ended 8-4, the first time Trace had taken the lead in the series. Kai 's reappearance was instrumental in Trace's recovery, as he went from 0 eliminations in the first four rounds to spearheading his team's attack and ending the half with 11 kills and 7 assists. Similarly, Biank and heybay each found eight and nine kills, respectively, after their team's comeback began in round five. Jinggg wins a 1v2 to swing momentum back in his team's favor Jinggg 's Deadlock helped break Trace's round winstreak and secure another pistol round for Paper Rex. An early mid-to-B fight gave Trace the bonus round, and the Chinese lineup went up to double digits with an A retake. Paper Rex continued closing the gap after taking a semi-eco, and a Jinggg 1v2 led to a timeout from their opponents. Biank avoided a 13-10 by stopping Paper Rex with a 3K, but an early B plant overwhelmed Trace, ending Sunset 13-11 and winning the series 3-0. The victory marks Paper Rex's third off-season grand final appearance in as many events, dating back to 2022's Valorant India Invitational . They will face off against DetonatioN FocusMe, the team that dropped Paper Rex to the lower bracket after a 2-0 win in the upper final. Trace Esports finishes the event in third place, a win against DRX helping them reach the podium on home soil. After the series, d4v41 commented on the grand final rematch. “DFM [...] has very good aim. Props to them, they've been working very hard,” he said. “Hopefully things will be different when we meet them tomorrow.”

title: Team Liquid rounds out roster with paTiTek and kamyk
cleaned_content: Team Liquid has signed Patryk " paTiTek " Fabrowski and Maks " kamyk " Rychlewski to their roster for 2025. paTiTek most notably played for Team Heretics for the first half of 2024 as a stand-in for Wo0t while the latter was not yet old enough to play in VCT. During that time, Heretics defied preseason expectations with a second-place result in EMEA Kickoff and to qualify to Masters Madrid . Later, he returned to the team in place of MiniBoo for Masters Shanghai after the Duelist stepped back to focus on completing his education. Heretics went on to place second in Shanghai, where paTiTek ranked fourth in assists per round for the event at 0.41. After spending 2023 with FNATIC as their sixth man, kamyk joined Joblife in Challengers League France , where he played under Liquid's new head coach Ivo " LohaN " Albino . As the team's flex, kamyk played six different agents in Split 2 and achieved a 1.14 overall rating. Joblife claimed first prize in France to qualify for EMEA Ascension , where they were narrowly eliminated in the group stage with a 2-2 record. Team Liquid built their roster coming into 2024 around the 2023 Apeks core of Georgio " keiko " Sanassy , Enzo " Enzo " Mestari , and James " Mistic " Orfila . They eventually ended the year at eighth place in VCT EMEA with a 4-6 regular season record, failing to qualify to any international events over the course of the year. Following this result, Liquid parted ways with Elias " Jamppi " Olkkonen , Mistic, Enzo, and former head coach Emil " eMIL " Sandgren . They retained Keiko and Ayaz " nAts " Akhmetshin and announced the signings of Kamil " kamo " Frąckowiak and new coaches LohaN and Daniel " yaotziN. " Roczniak in October. With the additions of paTiTek and kamyk, Liquid has finalized their starting roster for the 2025 season. Liquid will next play on Nov. 30 against GIANTX as part of the Monsters Reloaded 2024 main event. Team Liquid is now: Ayaz " nAts " Akhmetshin Georgio " keiko " Sanassy Kamil " kamo " Frąckowiak Patryk " paTiTek " Fabrowski Maks " kamyk " Rychlewski Nico " Harmii " Harms (Sub) Ivo " LohaN " Albino (Head coach) Daniel " yaotziN. " Roczniak (Assistant coach) Jake " Bacon9 " Lloyd (Analyst)

title: Trace Esports eliminates DRX from Radiant Asia Invitational
cleaned_content: Trace Esports has defeated DRX 2-0 to stay alive in the Radiant Asia Invitational . They will go on to face Paper Rex in the lower final , while DRX is eliminated from the tournament. The two map series was played out on Sunset and Split. Trace took the first map 13-7 and the second map 13-10. Trace came out of the gates on Sunset with a vengeance. After DRX won the pistol and second round, Trace would win nine rounds unanswered before a 3K from HYUNMIN finally stopped them. DRX would start the second half with another pistol win, trying to claw back from the 9-3 deficit. Another HYUNMIN 3K put them on track to win the bonus, but heybay and Kai would orchestrate a 2v5 to curb the DRX comeback. It wasn't long before Trace closed out the map 13-7. Kai put up a dominant performance on Neon, with 26 kills on the map, and numerous round winning multi-kills for his team. DRX had no answer for Kai's Neon on Sunset. DRX started out the second map of split with their third pistol win of the series, letting them take an early 6-2 lead. Trace would find their footing towards the end of the half and win the last four rounds to end the half an even 6-6. LuoK1ng holds down the site. In the second half, DRX would once again win the pistol round, making it their fourth of the series. This time, they would also convert the bonus round, and looked to run away with the map as they took a 10-6 lead. However, once Trace got their attack side going, there was nothing DRX could do to stop it. Despite consistently finding first bloods on the rounds, DRX could do nothing but watch as their lead slipped away one round at a time. Trace won seven rounds in a row to snatch the map out of DRX's hands. In this win, Trace take their revenge on DRX after being eliminated by them in dominant fashion at Champions . Trace continue their tournament run through the lower bracket, with Paper Rex standing in the way of a rematch against DetonatioN FocusMe in the grand final .

title: Paper Rex folds to DetonatioN FocusMe in Radiant Asia upper final
cleaned_content: DetonatioN FocusMe has taken down Paper Rex in the upper final of the Radiant Asia Invitational in 2-0 fashion. This advances DFM to the grand final , while Paper Rex goes down to the lower final . The two map series was played on Split and Ascent. DFM took both maps with scores of 15-13 and 13-8 respectively. Paper Rex and DFM have a short history with each other. They have faced off only three times before, two of them being their regular season matches in the Pacific league. Given DFM's lack of success in the league, Paper Rex has dominated every match, having never dropped a map to them before. However, this iteration of DFM has proven more competitive than ever before, having taken down numerous top teams in their tournament run, including the reigning world champions, EDward Gaming . The first map was Paper Rex's pick of Split, a home ground for them, having already played it three times this tournament. DFM's pistol win was immediately answered by a round two thrifty, giving Paper Rex an early lead and momentum in the half. They would quickly jump out to a 6-2 lead, but Jinboong would claw back some rounds for DFM, bringing their half score up to five. Despite a second pistol win for DFM, the second half started with a string of Paper Rex wins, bringing them up to an 11-8 lead. However, in classic Paper Rex fashion, they would squander their anti-eco to allow DFM a chance back into the game. Four rounds in a row brought DFM to 12, before Paper Rex took the final round to bring about their seventh overtime of the tournament. For the first three rounds of overtime, the two teams took turns trading defensive rounds, until SSeeS , the stand-in for DFM, found a 1v3 on the B site to win the organization's first ever map against Paper Rex. SSeeS clutches out the map in overtime. The second map played was Ascent, a map which has infamously plagued Paper Rex for the past year. In contrast, Ascent is one of the few maps where DFM was able to find any success in their Pacific campaign. Paper Rex's discomfort on the map was almost immediately evident. After they won the pistol and second round, DFM took the next six rounds unanswered. The half would end at 8-4 in favor of DFM. Paper Rex came out in the second half to win their second pistol of the map, and would go further to win the bonus round, bringing them back into the game. However, once again, the eco round would strike, and DFM, armed with only Sheriffs, would win the round and halt any chance of a Paper Rex comeback. DFM dominated the rest of the half, and closed out the map 13-8. Meiy led the server with 21 kills. With this win, DFM continue their undefeated run in the tournament, having yet to lose a match. They will face one of DRX , Trace Esports , or Paper Rex in the grand finals, two of which they have already found wins against.

title: Dragon Ranger Gaming signs Flex1n
cleaned_content: Dragon Ranger Gaming has signed former Bilibili Gaming player Lo " Flex1n " Rui (罗瑞) . Flex1n departs BLG after a roller coaster of a 2024 season which saw him land on three different teams. He began the year with Trace Esports , with whom he'd spent the 2023 season with. Following the team's elimination in the semifinals of China Kickoff , Trace and TYLOO organized a trade that saw Flex1n move to TYLOO in exchange for LuoK1ng and coach Yiyee . With Flex1n in Stage 1 , TYLOO went 2-3 and fell short of the playoffs. They went back to the drawing board, continuing their ever-evolving rebuild and parting ways with Flex1n, which opened the door for him to join BiliBili Gaming for Stage 2 . BLG, who themselves were coming off of a disappointing Stage 1, replaced Biank with Flex1n. With him settled in as the team's full-time Controller player, BLG finished the regular season 3-1, qualifying for the playoffs. While they did not record a top-three finish, they narrowly qualified for Champions Seoul through Championship Points . At Champions, they lost to FNATIC to open up the group stage and were eliminated by KRÜ Esports . Flex1n, best known for his play on Omen and Viper, has played a wide variety of Controller roles, occasionally filling in as Brimstone and Harbor. He joins a Dragon Ranger team which, after qualifying for Masters Shanghai through a successful Stage 1 showing, failed to reach those heights again. Since the end of the season, they have also signed Lin " SpiritZ1 " Dingyu (林定宇) and Zheng " Cangshu " Yujun (手郑宇峻) . Flex1n's addition expands the team's roster to eight with Dingwei a substitute, meaning outgoings are likely on the horizon. Dragon Ranger Gaming 's full roster is now: Lo " Flex1n " Rui (罗瑞) Tang " nizhaoTZH " Zehao (唐哲昊) Ilya " vo0kashu " Ushakov Zhang " Shion7 " Haozhe (张昊泽) Zheng " Cangshu " Yujun (手郑宇峻) Shao " Nicc " Yi-qun (邵逸群) Chen " TvirusLuke " Cheng-ching (陈振庆) Lin " SpiritZ1 " Dingyu (林定宇) Wei " Dingwei " Dingwei (魏定伟) Fei " JKH " Han (Head coach) Huang " 1t " Biaohong (黄彪宏) (Coach)

title: DetonatioN makes Radiant Asia upper final with 2-1 against Trace
cleaned_content: DetonatioN FocusMe has defeated Trace Esports with a 2-1 scoreline in the Radiant Asia Invitational playoffs . They will next face off against Paper Rex in the upper final , while Trace will play against DRX in a lower bracket elimination series . DetonatioN enters the playoffs as a top seed from the Swiss stage , having defeated 2024 Champions EDward Gaming in their opening series and Rex Regum Qeon in their second match . Trace, meanwhile, went the distance, as they lost to RRQ but defeated Bilibili and Gen.G on their way to playoffs. The map veto slightly favored DetonatioN , who have played Haven, the series' decider map, three times in the off-season. Despite a low winrate, the map scores have remained close for the Japanese team. Haven was previously a first ban for Trace , but it has remained open during their Radiant Asia Invitational run. Similarly, Abyss and Ascent slightly favored DFM in terms of winrate, but Trace had more series on both maps in comparison. The match began on Ascent , where DFM took an early lead after winning the first three rounds. Trace recovered, winning an eco and Biank 's Odin helping break down the defense. Art and Meiy helped DFM recover, setting them on track to win the half 7-5. The duo ended their defense with a combined 22 eliminations, with Akame contributing 10 assists and a final-round 3K. The second half mirrored the first, as DFM's offense extended their total streak to eight rounds in a row. Art earned an ace against the eco round, and closed out the third round after a last-minute rotation. Despite DetonatioN's lead, Trace countered their slow rounds, drawing out both of the attacker's timeouts at 11-10. The Japanese squad appeared desperate, unable to find an entrance into Trace's Odin-Operator stronghold. Kai and heybay ended Ascent 13-11 with a double-kill each. Kai and heybay stop DFM's exec in its tracks Trace took over Abyss for their attack half, taking their first pistol of the series and further extending their lead with a round 4 win after two early kills. Biank opened the fifth round with an early Hunter's Fury kill, forcing DFM to save for the second round in a row. A Kai 3K prompted DFM's timeout, which in turn helped DFM adapt to Trace's B hit and win their second round of the map. Two rounds for DFM led to Trace's own timeout. The Chinese roster seemed to expect aggression from the defense, but their Operator purchase did not pay off, as DFM patiently closed out the half 6-6. DetonatioN continued winning the pistol and bonus round, their third half of the match to begin 3-0 in their favor. SSeeS helped his team go up 11-6 with a 3K, and Art returned to the Odin for a triple of his own. Trace was only able to win two more rounds, with DFM's lead proving too much to overcome. Jinboong began the final round with his 23rd kill, leaving him just shy of 300 ACS for their 13-8 map win. Kai opened Haven with a Classic 4K, helping Trace go up 3-0 to start the decider. Meiy was key the next two rounds, sealing a hectic fourth round with a 1v1 and opening the following round with a collateral. Trace's attack remained chaotic, which earned them a nearly-flawless round but was quickly shut down the next round. Two quick retakes from DFM put them in the lead, an advantage extended thanks to the Odin-Operator and DFM's coordinated retakes. Meiy closes out a chaotic round four to put his team on the board A quick A take earned DFM their fourth pistol round, eventually setting the score at 9-5. LuoK1ng held strong on C to close the gap, but an early A main fight went DFM's way, netting the Pacific squad double digits. heybay took over garage to set the score 11-7, but Akame opened up the B site the following round to reach match point. Trace's damaged economy was not enough to stay alive, as DFM won a 3v3 to end Haven 13-7 and win the series 2-1. With this win, DetonatioN FocusMe remains undefeated in the Radiant Asia Invitational, as they qualified to playoffs after victories against EDward Gaming and Rex Regum Qeon. DetonatioN is the only team at the event with a flawless record, as the other top seed, DRX, lost to Paper Rex earlier in the playoffs.

title: Xi Lai Gaming signs ZiXuan
cleaned_content: Xi Lai Gaming has signed Liu " ZiXuan " Junwei (刘俊伟) to their roster. ZiXuan last played the Controller role for Chosen Clique Gaming , the team that came in third place at China Ascension 2024 . He also recently served as a stand-in for FunPlus Phoenix at the TEN Asia Invitational in October. Xi Lai Gaming is the newest addition to VCT China after winning Ascension, where they defeated Rare Atom in a dominant 3-0 in the grand final. Since then, they have parted ways with Savva " Kr1stal " Fedorov after their former in-game leader agreed in advance to depart the team due to non-resident player restrictions and added Yip " YOU " Man Ho to the team in his stead. With this addition, XLG currently has six players. It has not been explicitly stated at this time whether ZiXuan will be replacing one of the other players on the active roster. All five of the other players are currently still listed as active in the Global Contract Database . Xi Lai Gaming is currently: Arthur " Rarga " Churyumov Deng " happywei " Minwei (邓闵维) Chen " MrCANI " Tingxun (陈廷训) Zhuo " MarT1n " Zhengjie (卓政杰) Yip " YOU " Man Ho Liu " ZiXuan " Junwei (刘俊伟) Aleksandr " hvoya " Eremin (Head coach)

title: Paper Rex defeats DRX 2-1 to open Radiant Asia playoffs
cleaned_content: Paper Rex has defeated DRX 2-1 in the upper semifinals of the Radiant Asia Invitational . Paper Rex now advances to the upper final , while DRX has been sent down to the lower bracket. The three-map series played out on Sunset, Abyss, and Pearl. Paper Rex won Sunset 15-13, DRX won Abyss 13-6, and Paper Rex won Pearl 13-6. This was the tenth matchup between the two age-old Pacific heavyweights, the most recent result being a 3-2 win for DRX in the lower finals of Pacific Stage 2 this year. DRX entered as the higher seed after a 2-0 Swiss stage, while Paper Rex fought their way through Swiss with a 2-1 record that featured five overtime maps. PRX kicked off the match by taking DRX to Sunset, a map they hadn't yet played in this event. In a continuation of their role experimentation for this event, PRX's composition featured Jinggg on Deadlock, something on Sova, and f0rsakeN on Neon. On the other side, DRX elected for a more standard composition featuring Neon, KAY/O, and Cypher. Despite suffering a thrifty loss in round 2, PRX opened up an early 5-2 lead on their defense side through coordinated retakes, forcing a DRX timeout. In the round after, free1ng won out a 1v1 versus d4v41 to stop the snowball, culminating to a closer 7-5 half in favor of PRX. The second half was equally close; DRX began building momentum with a narrow bonus win in round 15, but a 1v4 from something in round 17 gave his team a way back in. DRX managed to find a 12-11 lead, but PRX forced a sixth overtime this event for themselves with an ironclad B site postplant. Experience proved to be the difference-maker as PRX won another manic firefight on the B site to close out Sunset 15-13. something clutches a pivotal round for his team with a little help from the crowd. Both Neon players topped the scoreboard for their teams, but it was f0rsaken who took over with 26 kills to 19 deaths and 282 ACS. The next map was DRX's pick of Abyss, a map DRX hadn't lost on since July. DRX opted for their signature Ascent-esque composition with Jett, KAY/O, and Cypher, while PRX brought out their unique composition with Jett, Reyna, and Skye. Another round 2 thrifty for DRX helped them mount a 3-1 start. PRX utilized strong A hits and individual hero plays to keep the score close, but DRX adjusted their defensive setups to better reinforce their site anchors and end the half with a 7-5 lead. Crisp shots from HYUNMIN shut down the attack. The second half of Abyss, on the other hand, was anything but close. DRX exploited Paper Rex's lack of strong defensive utility to repeatedly take the B site, steamrolling to a 13-6 victory. Flashback dominated the server with 22 kills and 315 ACS; HYUNMIN trailed close behind on Jett with 20 kills and 274 ACS. The last map was Pearl, a map DRX hadn't yet played since its return to the map pool. Steadfast anchoring from MaKo on A gave DRX a 3-1 start, but PRX found greater purchase on B to find a 5-3 lead that chained into an 8-4 half. Jinggg expertly wields Phoenix's kit to deal with MaKo's Cosmic Divide. DRX took both pistols, but the rest of the map looked comfortable for PRX as the squad ran away with Pearl to win out the map 13-6. mindfreak led his team with 20 kills and 297 ACS after an impressive display of anchoring and lurking. However, it was Jinggg who demonstrated the best performance statistically over the course of the entire series with 59 kills to 44 deaths and 244 ACS. Paper Rex will return tomorrow on Nov. 29 to play the winner of DetonatioN FocusMe versus Trace Esports in the upper final , while DRX will fight for survival against the loser in the lower bracket .

title: MIBR completes roster with aspas
cleaned_content: MIBR has signed star Brazilian duelist Erick " aspas " Santos , picking him up after a short stint with LEVIATÁN . He is the last signing after MIBR completed the acquisitions of Eduardo " xenom " Soeiro , Gabriel " cortezia " Cortez and Agustin " nzr " Ibarra . The move comes after MIBR reached an agreement with Leviatán to buy out the player's contract, as his deal with the Argentine side was believed to run until 2025. Since the end of their 2024 season, Leviatán also signed former NRG and Evil Geniuses duelist Max " Demon1 " Mazanov , which expanded the team's active roster to six. aspas will be on his third team in as many years, having spent just one season with Leviatán in 2024 after leaving Brazilian giants LOUD at the end of 2023. His 2024 season with Leviatán saw the team lift its first-ever trophy at Americas Stage 2 and reach its second-ever Champions event. They finished third at Champions 2024 following a upper final loss to eventual champions EDward Gaming . While he is most known for his play on Jett and Raze, changes to the meta in 2024 also saw him pick up Neon. Since joining LOUD in 2022, aspas has been surrounded by several world-class teammates, including Matias " saadhak " Delipetro , Gustavo " Sacy " Rossi , and Felipe " Less " de Loyola Basso . He joins an MIBR roster that has little to no international experience nor has a single player with experience lifting a trophy at Valorant's highest level. After signing with LOUD, aspas immediately enjoyed a trophy-laden 2022 season with them. The team completed an unbeaten campaign at Brazil Stage 1 Challengers, qualifying for Masters Reykjavik , where they lost in the grand final to OpTic Gaming . They then continued their domestic dominance with an undefeated showing at Brazil Stage 2 Challengers , qualifying for Masters Copenhagen and Champions 2022 through circuit points. Following a disappointing showing at Masters, LOUD managed to lift the Champions trophy , exacting revenge on OpTic in back-to-back meetings to earn Brazil and the Americas region its first world championship. With the signing of aspas, MIBR are now: Arthur " artzin " Araujo Eduardo " xenom " Soeiro Gabriel " cortezia " Cortez Agustin " nzr " Ibarra Erick " aspas " Santos Daniel " fRoD " Montaner (Head coach) Iara " Iara " Rodrigo (Analyst)

title: GIANTX welcomes westside, runneR, and tomaszy
cleaned_content: GIANTX has signed Miłosz " westside " Duda , Emil " runneR " Trajkovski , and Tomás " tomaszy " Machado to their roster. They have also added Jan " wayLander " Rahkonen as assistant coach. westside most notably played for Diamant Esports in Challengers League East over the course of the 2024 season, where they finished in second place. Excluding the league's Promotion Cup, in which Diamant did not participate, westside was a top-ten player by rating in Split 2 with a rating of 1.08. The team qualified to the EMEA Ascension play-ins but were eliminated in the group stage with a 1-1 record. westside, along with runneR, also recently competed for GIANTX in a merged co-ed roster with GIANTX GC to win the EMEA Spotlight Series in October. runneR last played for Team Vitality . He began the season serving as the team's Duelist, during which the team narrowly failed to qualify for the EMEA Stage 1 playoffs in a five-way 3-3 tiebreaker in Group Alpha. After Stage 1, he swapped roles with Sayf , adopting the Sentinel position. Vitality went on to finish second in Stage 2 and qualify for Champions 2024 , exiting the group stage in Seoul with a 1-2 record. According to the announcement , he will be playing flex for GIANTX. tomaszy comes into the team after a year playing a Sentinel-focused flex role for Karmine Corp . Under the French banner, the team carved a blazing run to win EMEA Kickoff and qualify for Masters Madrid , where they placed top-six. That result would end up being Karmine Corp's peak for the year, as they ended the season with a 4-6 record and were unable to qualify for any other international events. He will be switching to the Controller role for GIANTX. Following a strong 2023 season in which they won the EMEA Last Chance Qualifier and qualified to Champions 2023 , GIANTX only made one roster change by adding Igor " Redgar " Vlasov after the retirement of Emir " rhyme " Muminovic . However, they were unable to replicate their previous performances. A 0-2 Kickoff saw the team release Žygimantas " nukkye " Chmieliauskas , add Semyon " purp0 " Borchev as their Duelist, and shift Adolfo " Fit1nho " Gallego to the flex role. GIANTX eventually ended the regular season in ninth place with a 3-7 overall record, failing to qualify for playoffs in both stages. The European organization released Fit1nho, Aaro " hoody " Peltokangas , and Ramses " Famsii " Valentino Erasmus Koivukangas at the beginning of the offseason, retaining purp0 and keeping Kirill " Cloud " Nehozhin as their in-game leader. This rebuild represents a new beginning for the squad as they seek to return to competitive form. GIANTX is next set to play against Team Liquid on Nov. 30 for Monsters Reloaded 2024 . For VCT 2025, GIANTX is: Semyon " purp0 " Borchev Kirill " Cloud " Nehozhin Emil " runneR " Trajkovski Miłosz " westside " Duda Tomás " tomaszy " Machado Daniil " pipsoN " Mesheryakov (Head coach) Jan " wayLander " Rahkonen (Assistant coach)

title: Riot unveils VCT 2025 season overview
cleaned_content: Riot unveiled its 2025 VCT season, which now features twelve-team leagues, and a January to October competitive calendar. With the new season also comes changes to distribution of Championship Points, qualification for global events, and expanded formats. The full overview is below with edits and can also be read here . The new 48-team VCT. (Photo by Riot Games) Kickoff tournaments Important Dates January 11: China Kickoff January 15: EMEA Kickoff January 16: Americas Kickoff January 18: Pacific Kickoff VCT's first-ever 48-team season will begin in January with regional Kickoff tournaments. In 2025, the Kickoff Tournament will be a 12-team double-elimination bracket, with the top four teams from the 2024 season receiving a bye into the second round. The top two teams will advance to Masters Bangkok. Global Events Schedule The full 2025 VCT schedule. (Photo by Riot Games) Masters Bangkok (February 20 - March 2) Bangkok, much like Masters Madrid in 2024, will feature an eight-team Swiss Stage, followed by a four-team double-elimination bracket. Masters Toronto (June 7 - June 22) Similar to Masters Shanghai, Masters Toronto will host the top three teams from the Stage 1 Playoffs of each league. League champions will receive a bye into the playoffs, which come after an eight-team Swiss Stage. Champions Paris (September 12 - October 5) Champions Paris will have the "top teams from Stage 2, Championship Points, and global events." The format will feature four four-team groups, which is followed by an eight-team double-elimination bracket. New in 2025 Expanded Calendar : More time between events, ensuring better pacing for teams. Increased Matches : Minimum: 12 matches per team Average: 18 matches per team Maximum: 23 matches per team (before global events) Stage Resets : Stages will have two groups of six per stage, bringing new matchups past the mid-season point. Playoff Expansion : Eight-team double-elimination playoffs in regional leagues for longer team survival. Championship Points System A revamped Championship Points System. (Photo by Riot Games) Deeper Distribution: Points are awarded to the top teams at every stage and global event. New Qualification Paths: Two teams qualify for Champions through Stage 2 Playoffs. Two teams qualify as Champions based on Championship Points. Championship Points per event Kickoff Winner: 3 points Runners-up: 2 points Third place: 1 point Fourth place: 1 point Masters Bangkok Winner: 5 points Runners-up: 3 points Third place: 2 points Fourth place: 1 point Stage 1 1 point per match win Stage 1 Playoffs Winner: 5 points Runners-up: 3 points Third place: 2 points Fourth place: 1 point Masters Toronto Winner: 7 points Runners-up: 5 points Third place: 4 points Fourth place: 3 points Fifth place: 2 points Sixth place: 2 points Stage 2 1 point per match win Stage 2 Playoffs Winner: 7 points Runners-up: 5 points Third place: 4 points Fourth place: 3 points

title: Valorant Radiant Asia Invitational enters playoff stages
cleaned_content: Following the conclusion of its Swiss Stage, Valorant Radiant Asia Invitational has shaved its field of eight teams down to four. DRX , DetonatioN FocusMe , Trace Esports , and Paper Rex have qualified for the playoffs after securing four wins in the Swiss Stage. 2-0: Dominant starts DRX earned its spot in the playoffs after wins over Bilibili Gaming and fellow South Korean team Gen.G . They were among the first teams to secure entry into the playoffs, finishing with a 2-0 record. They have experienced significant changes this offseason, parting ways with BuZz , Foxy9 , and BeYN . MaKo and Flashback are their only returnees, Additionally, head coach termi is not in Chengdu for the event, meaning glow and Argency have taken over coaching duties. DetonatioN FocusMe turned heads to open the event with a 2-1 victory over Champions 2024 winners EDward Gaming . After a first map loss that seemed almost unsalvageable, they stormed back and won maps two and three. Abyss, the third map, was won dominantly, 13-5. They then secured a playoff spot in reverse-sweep fashion again over Rex Regum Qeon , winning in three maps. DFM has also experienced a roster shakeup this offseason, only retaining Meiy while picking up players from Japan's VCL circuit and a rookie in gyen . 2-1: Bent, not broken Paper Rex suffered defeat in their opening match, losing a three-map, 88-round match to Gen.G. Following the loss, they toughed out a win against home favorites EDward Gaming, defeating and eliminating them in three maps, before eliminating fellow regional representatives Rex Regum Qeon in three maps. The fast-flying and entertaining playstyle of Paper Rex continues, with any of the five players liable to top the leaderboard on any given map. Trace Esports turned heads in the competition by qualifying for the playoffs. The Chinese team, which captured hearts with a Cinderella run to the playoffs of Champions 2024, fell flat in their opening match, losing 2-0 to RRQ. They then followed that up by defeating fellow Chinese team BLG 2-1, and then upsetting competition favorites Gen.G with a 2-0 defeat. Trace retained much of its 2024 roster, and the added level of familiarity seemed to show. Duelist Kai has topped the leaderboard in two matches, while LuoK1ng continues to show good form. 1-2: So close, yet so far Rex Regum Qeon opened the competition with a convincing 2-0 victory over Trace, but were eliminated after 2-1 losses to DFM and PRX. They have not had much roster turnover this offseason, but go into the 2025 season looking to make the jump to the next step after a 5th-6th place finish in Pacific Stage 2 . Gen.G were widely considered one of the favorites for this competition, and that seemed to ring true to begin things for the Masters Shanghai winners. After coming out on top in an instant classic three-map clash with Pacific Giants PRX, they faltered against fellow Korean team DRX, losing narrowly in three maps. Their elimination match, a 2-0 loss to Trace Esports, was only close on the second map, which they lost 14-12. Gen.G, which replaced two core pieces from the 2024 squad, will look to retain their spot at the top of the Pacific league in 2025. 0-2: Out in a hurry Champions Seoul winners EDward Gaming were swiftly eliminated. Across six maps in two matches against DFM and PRX, they lost by a difference of 11 rounds. After sending only a few starting players to the Gwangju Esports Series , EDG participated in this competition with their full 2024 roster. They made no changes, but seemed to have some postseason rust that will need to be shaken off heading into 2025. The Chinese region had three teams in this competition, and two of them were eliminated in the Swiss Stage. The second team eliminated early on was BiliBili Gaming . Their elimination came much quicker, with a 2-0 loss to DRX and a 2-1 loss to Trace. They have made a few changes to their roster after the 2024 season, but still seem to be second, or even third, fiddle in their region. Playoffs DRX vs Paper Rex DetonatioN FocusMe vs Trace Esports The rest of the competition will be played out in a four-team, double-elimination bracket. Only the grand final and the lower finals will be best-of-five, while all other matches are best-of-three.

title: MIBR adds xenom, cortezia, and nzr
cleaned_content: MIBR has announced the signings of Eduardo " xenom " Soeiro , Gabriel " cortezia " Cortez , and Agustin " nzr " Ibarra . "Very happy with this opportunity to be at MIBR and play with these incredible people, effort will never be lacking," xenom said . "Looking forward to VCT 2025." The pickup is the organization's first of the offseason and comes just days after they parted ways with four players. xenom joins after spending most of the 2024 season with Stellae Gaming , who compete in VCL Brazil . Last season with xenom, they finished fourth in Split 2, falling short of qualifying for Americas Ascension . They also failed to qualify through circuit points by a margin of 15 points, falling behind eventual Ascension winners 2Game Esports . In signing with MIBR, the Brazilian will make the jump to the top tier of Valorant for the first time. Before joining Stellae ahead of the Brazil VCL's Split 2 , xenom played for TBK Esports , TropiCaos , and Laboratorio do Leozin , making his professional Valorant debut for the latter in 2022. While he has played several roles throughout the course of his career, he was the Controller player for Stellae in 2024, mainly playing Omen but also playing Brimstone and Viper on occasion. cortezia joins after spending the 2024 season with RED Canids . Like xenom, he mainly played the Controller role for his team. He played a wide range of agents, with Harbor being the only Controller agent he did not log a map on. Before RED Canids, he played for fellow Brazilian VCL teams TropiCao and Team Brave Soldiers . He made his professional Valorant debut in late 2020, but found his first organization in 2022 Challengers side Without Org . nzr joins widely believed to be the team's Initiator player. His main agents throughout his career have been Sova and Skye, but he has also shown an ability to play other initiators, too. He spent the 2023 season with LEVIATÁN , and entered the 2024 season on their roster, but departed just before the beginning of Kickoff. After finding himself looking for a new team, he returned to FURIA , the team he made his tier-one debut with. nzr is a veteran of Valorant, having made his debut in 2020 with Team Frankkaster and playing for 9z Team and Estral Esports too. "Proud to represent an organization with a great history and trajectory," nzr said . "You can be sure that I will give my best and I am very excited for the next season!" With these signings, MIBR now has two more roster spots to fill out before the beginning of the 2025 VCT season. MIBR 's roster is now: Arthur " artzin " Araujo Eduardo " xenom " Soeiro Gabriel " cortezia " Cortez Agustin " nzr " Ibarra Erick " aspas " Santos Felipe " chivitz " Chivitz (Manager) Daniel " fRoD " Montaner (Head coach) Iara " Iara " Rodrigo (Analyst)

title: Nongshim RedForce acquires Sin Prisa Gaming
cleaned_content: Nongshim RedForce has acquired Pacific Ascension champions Sin Prisa Gaming , meaning the original core of five players and head coach will now compete in VCT under a new banner. "The SPG roster, including players and head coach, will remain fully intact but will compete under the NS banner next year," Riot's announcement said. "We are confident that Nongshim will be a valuable addition to the VCT Pacific league given their extensive experience in esports. We are also happy for the players and coach who will have access to additional training facilities and support as part of this acquisition." Sin Prisa Gaming grew quickly in the 2024 season, from one of the more unknown teams in the Korean VCL circuits to one of its most dominant. Known originally as Team OGS , current players Dambi , Ivy , and Francis were on the squad before it disbanded after its elimination from The Korean WCG Challengers League Split 2. Current DRX player Athan was also on Team OGS. For a short portion of the 2023 season, the roster was also picked up by Gwangju Shadow . For the 2024 season, the three players stayed together as Sin Prisa Gaming, and were joined by Persia and margaret . After a rocky Split 1 that saw them fail to qualify for playoffs, they dominated Split 2 , which they'd only reached by qualifying through a playoff. In Stage 2, they went on a run of eleven straight victories, only dropping six maps in the process before defeating NongShim RedForce in the grand final to reach Pacific Ascension . Their dominance, branded by an aggressive approach on both sides of the map, continued throughout Ascension as they won five straight matches, only dropping two maps in the grand final en route to securing a spot in VCT for the 2025 season. With the backing of NongShim, a South Korean food company best known for instant noodles and snacks, the former Sin Prisa Gaming team will have more resources and infrastructure than they did prior. NongShim also fields a League of Legends team that competes in LCK, one of the most prestigious LoL leagues in the world. Nongshim RedForce first entered professional Valorant in 2022, never quite reaching the heights that its League of Legends team did. They achieved their best result to date in the 2024 season, reaching the grand final of the Korean Challengers League, where they fell to Sin Prisa Gaming. In the announcement by Riot Games, it was revealed that the NongShim roster, which is currently competing in the playoffs of VCL Korea Split 3 , will no longer be affiliated with NongShim following the end of the competition. Riot said: "Their slot in Challengers Korea will remain with the players should they choose to continue to compete under a different banner." As South Korea's fourth team in the Pacific region, Nongshim's roster for its inaugural VCT season will be: Yang " Persia " Zi-on (양지온) Kim " Francis " Mu-bin (김무빈) Kim " margaret " Ji-woo (김지우) Lee " Dambi " Hyuk-kyu (이혁규) Park " Ivy " Sung-hyeon (박성현) Kim " SilKanoN " Gyeong-min (김경민) (Head coach)

title: Wolves sign Juicy
cleaned_content: Wolves Esports has added Tyler " Juicy " James Aeria to their roster. Juicy has been competing in SEA Valorant since 2020, but with this signing, he will make his first appearance in the tier one scene in the Chinese league. In 2023, he earned his right to join VCT Pacific when he won Ascension with BLEED . However, Juicy's young age prevented him from reaping the rewards of his efforts, as he was ineligible for league play at the time. He spent the following year in the Malaysia/Singapore circuit with Bleed's partner team, Disguised . He helped Disguised rise to the top of the circuit, eventually winning the league to become the region's representatives at Pacific Ascension . Juicy would not be able to repeat his Ascension victory, as Disguised were narrowly defeated by grand finalists BOOM Esports , with both of their map losses coming in overtime. In the inaugural year of VCT CN, Wolves were a troubled team, finishing at 10th place in the league. However, they look to be on the turnaround in the offseason. With the additions of Lysoar and V1yA, they have fared much better against their regional competition. They won the WALL-E Cup and came second at the 2024 FGC Invitational , both tournaments featuring most of the VCT CN teams, save for EDward Gaming and Trace Esports . Wolves Esports are now: Pong " SiuFatBB " Gaa Hei (庞加曦) Chang " V1yA " Rui-min (张睿珉) Huang " Yuicaw " Yung-chieh (黃湧傑) Liu " Spring " Jiunting (刘俊霆) Liang " Lysoar " Youhao (梁优好) Tyler " Juicy " James Aeria " Simple " (Manager) Chong " Fayde " Hoc Wah (Head coach)

title: T1 takes home Red Bull Home Ground trophy over Cloud9
cleaned_content: T1 defeated Cloud9 3-1 in the grand finals of Red Bull Home Ground #5 with strong wins on Bind and Haven after narrowly closing out Abyss. The Koreans managed to show up in the series despite an abysmal 25% pistol win rate with excellent gun rounds and by coming out on top in individual duels. T1 and Cloud9 opted to use their singular bans on Sunset and Ascent respectively before alternating picks for the best-of-five series. Flashes of brilliance from BuZz 's Yoru opened up Abyss, T1's first pick. T1 took a 4-1 lead thanks to their layered Breach stuns and Yoru flashes before a timeout was forced out from C9 coach Immi . Although aggressive plays from OXY and moose gave C9 a short string of three rounds, T1 had the lead at halftime with a 7-5 score. OXY's mechanics were on full display in the second pistol. An explosive 4K from OXY to win the second pistol was immediately responded to with a full eco win from T1. A huge 1v3 from Rossy in round 17 dragged C9 back into the game after going down 6-10. BuZz followed by bringing out the Operator and finding two picks in the following round to reset C9's economy. Some hero plays from Rossy and OXY forced out a timeout from Autumn before T1 closed out the first map 13-10. The trio of BuZz, Sylvan , and iZu provided dividends for T1 and made up for uncharacteristically absent performances from Meteor and stax . BuZz was the match MVP, topping the server with a 1.39 rating, 314 ACS, and 25 kills. iZu secured map point for T1 with a 4K. T1 once again struggled on Pearl to start as five straight B hits in a row from C9 put them up 5-0. Two separate thrifty rounds followed from T1 to give them a chance to bring the half to a respectable deficit. iZu's Operator and impact kills from Sylvan closed the gap to just two rounds as C9 led 7-5 at halftime. A v1c 3K paved the way for another C9 pistol, their third of the series, to go up 9-5. A ridiculous entry 3K from BuZz was just a bump in the road for C9 as OXY answered back with a 3K of his own in the following round. Although a closer affair than T1's game against FUT , Cloud9 comfortably tied up the series 1-1 with a 13-8 on Pearl. OXY and v1c were the standouts for C9 on the second map with 22 and 18 kills respectively, while both recorded a server high 86% KAST. Both had to overcome strong showings from their Neon and Astra counterparts, BuZz and Sylvan, and did so triumphantly. BuZz's antics helped keep Pearl from being a blowout. A fourth pistol from Cloud9 opened up T1's second pick, Bind, a map they had previously demolished FUT on earlier in the day. While Rossy pushed his team towards a 5-3 lead, stax pulled off an incredible 1v4 to tie up the map 5-5. The score was sitting on a knife-edge at 6-6 before halftime. stax showed up for T1 when it mattered most. C9 proved they were still the pistol gods with their fifth pistol win in the series to go up 8-6. This time around it was Sylvan who provided the hero play for T1 to take a slight lead at 9-8 and prevent C9 from abusing the B site. Multikill after multikill came C9's way from T1 to put the Koreans on map point 12-8. A seventh straight round came the way of T1 to close out Bind 13-8 and put T1 on series point at 2-1. Despite losing both pistols, T1 managed to be dominant in the gun rounds to push themselves over the line. The quartet of Meteor, stax, Sylvan, and BuZz took turns contributing to their team's success with Meteor being the MVP of the map with a 1.25 rating and 166 ADR. OXY had a rare weak performance on the third map despite his explosive pistol round, picking up just 9 kills in the game to bottom out the scoreboard. It was Sylvan's turn to make a hero play for T1. The fourth map, Haven, kicked off with yet another C9 pistol before a saviour BuZz 4K tied up the score at 2-2. A 1v2 from stax stopped a string of traded rounds to give T1 a lead at 5-3. C9 had no way of dealing with impenetrable A post-plant setups from T1 as the Pacific reps grabbed an 8-4 first half. BuZz has been a consistent star for T1. T1 grabbed an ever-elusive second pistol thanks to a stax 1v2 to go within touching distance of the trophy at 10-4. Map point at 12-6 came soon after as BuZz and stax put in the work to ensure a trophy lift. BuZz was far and away the finals MVP with a 1.39 series rating, 170 ADR, and an absurd 20/6 first kill to first death ratio. stax won a 1v2 to win the most important pistol of the series. T1 are the champions of Red Bull Home Ground #5. T1 win Red Bull Home Ground #5.

title: T1 makes finals over FUT in Berlin
cleaned_content: T1 has made the finals of Red Bull Home Ground #5 after a 2-1 series over FUT Esports . The Turkish team failed to find a way past T1's individuals who took turns providing high-impact kills. T1 looked dominant on Bind and narrowly closed out Ascent, which came on either side of a blowout on Pearl. BuZz had FUT's number in the first half. FUT got off to an explosive start on Bind with pistol and bonus round wins. T1 could thank back-to-back multikills from BuZz for cutting FUT's momentum and giving his team a way back into the game. The Koreans led 7-5 before halftime with an ace from yetujey breaking up seven dominant rounds from T1. yetujey's ace gave FUT an extra round in the first half. Unfortunately for FUT, T1 wouldn't slow down in the second half and took six straight to close out the map 13-5. iZu and BuZz had particularly standout performances with the latter's multikills and the former's consistency across the map ensuring a T1 victory. T1's pick, Pearl, kicked off with another strong start from FUT, going up 7-0 with an unorthodox double-sentinel comp featuring Vyse and Killjoy. T1's insistence on ignoring the B site worked perfectly for FUT as T1 struggled to get the spike planted. FUT closed out their defense with a 9-3 score before picking up the second pistol to go up 11-3. Afterwards, it was a mere formality for FUT to close out Pearl 13-3 and force a third map. New addition xeus was the MVP for FUT as the 20-year-old duelist picked up 22 kills and 225 ADR on the second map. xeus closed out the map with a 4K. The third map, Ascent, opened with FUT picking up another pistol, their fourth of the series. A 4K from xeus' Yoru in the bonus led FUT to a 5-0 start before T1 could respond with a thrifty. Impressive holds from T1's individuals shut down FUT's site executes to force a 6-6 half. xeus excelled on the off-meta Yoru. T1 took a crucial pistol and bonus in the second half to take a commanding 9-6 lead on the decider. T1's midrounding ran circles around FUT on their attack, suffocating their opponent's map control. T1 closed out Ascent 13-10 with an A hit to take the series 2-1. BuZz had an impressive 251 ACS and 20 kills on the final map. Meteor's mechanics were on point during all three maps. T1 will play Cloud9 in a best-of-five grand final, while FUT has been eliminated.

title: MIBR parts ways with quartet ahead of 2025 rebuild
cleaned_content: MIBR has parted ways with four players who joined within the past year, letting go of Felipe " liazzi " Galiazzi , Davi " Palla " Alcides , Gabriel " rich " Rosa , and Matheus " mazin " Araújo . With Stage 2 playoffs a near impossibility after just completing Stage 1 , MIBR made midseason changes looking to turn its fortunes around. In the coaching booth, they parted ways with former LOUD coach bzkA , promoting another former LOUD coach in fRoD to right the ship. On the stage, they parted ways with RgLMeister , frz , and jzz . They brought in liazzi, Palla, and mazin to replace them, while also relying on the duties of Pa1nt and ShahZaM to circumvent visa issues for their new signings. After just four matches for the organization and five months later, liazzi is once again LFT. Before joining MIBR, he played for OLIMPO and FURIA among other teams, and began his career in 2020 with exuLt.gg . He never quite had a defined role for MIBR in his brief stint with the team, but played the Sentinel and Initiator roles mostly throughout the course of his eleven maps with the team. Palla joined from Brazilian VCL team Stellae Gaming . He played as MIBR's Duelist, dividing selection between Raze and Jett. Stellae and MIBR were his first stretches as a pro Valorant player in the first or second tier. rich was MIBR's Initiator in the second half of the 2024 season, playing Gekko, Fade, Sova, and Skye. He also joined from the Challengers level, having previously played for Legacy . He made his debut in 2021 with ARDUINOS . Of the four players released, mazin is the only player who was on the MIBR roster before the 2024 season began. He joined in the offseason following 2023, which ended with the team finishing ninth out of ten teams, and bowing out in the first round of the LCQ. The Controller player joined from FURIA, after having stops at TERROR.NET and B4 Esports . The roster changes come following a disappointing 2024 season for the Brazilian side. After reaching the play-ins of Americas Kickoff where they defeated eventual Stage 2 runners-up G2 Esports , MIBR went on a run of nine straight matches without victory, only winning one map in the process. They struggled to regain the form they had at Kickoff, with a season-ending victory against Evil Geniuses being the only thing preventing them from going 0-11 in league play. They ended at the bottom of the Stage 2 standings, failing to qualify for the playoffs in any event they competed in. With just months to go before the 2025 VCT season begins, MIBR have four roster spots to fill, looking to finish above the bottom two of the Americas league for the first time since the beginning of franchising. MIBR 's full roster is now: Arthur " artzin " Araujo Felipe " chivitz " Chivitz (Manager) Daniel " fRoD " Montaner (Head coach) Iara " Iara " Rodrigo (Analyst)

title: C9 dominates G2, reaches Home Ground finals
cleaned_content: Cloud9 swept G2 Esports 2-0 at the Red Bull Home Ground #5 semifinals, quickly stomping over a regional rival to reach the finals of the off-season tournament. The maps for this series were Sunset from G2 and Pearl from C9, leaving Bind as the decider. This series was defined by the unstoppable attack side from C9, as well as some G2 pistol and bonus round woes. The series began on Sunset, with C9 winning both the pistol and the bonus round to build an early lead. G2 had to end the half strong to keep the map within reach, and they did just that to enter the half down only 7-5. When the second half began and C9 won the second pistol round, they steamrolled over G2 with good aim from OXY on Neon and a key triple kill from Xeppaa on Breach. The second half was dominant from C9 , winning the map 13-5. G2 had to win on Pearl to keep their tournament hopes alive. C9 kept their pistol rounds perfect with another round victory and bonus conversion to start Pearl, catching G2 off guard with constant two-man stacks and pop-flash plays. However, like map one, G2 ended that run, this time off of a clutch mid hold from JonahP . JonahP holds strong with three kills against Cloud9. G2 had a tough time preventing C9 from taking site and winning post-plants, especially with the hoard of utility from the Astra-led composition. Like Sunset, G2 adapted late into the half to keep the map winnable, down 8-4. However, C9 won their fourth straight pistol off of a great two-man push from mid, and they converted their fourth straight bonus to win the map 13-4 and the series 2-0. For this series, the MVP was OXY as he outplayed his counterpart jawgemo with 43 kills across two maps, as well as 13 first kills with only four first deaths. With this win, C9 is in the Red Bull Home Ground #5 finals and will face the winners of the T1 versus FUT Esports match in the tournament finals.

title: G2 Esports advances to Red Bull playoffs over FNATIC
cleaned_content: G2 Esports has defeated FNATIC 2-0 in round 3 the Swiss stage of Red Bull Home Ground #5 . G2 now advances to the playoffs, while FNATIC has been eliminated. Both teams ended yesterday with 1-1 records in the Swiss stage. FNATIC suffered an early loss to Cloud9 and later defeated FOKUS . On the other side, G2 successfully defeated Karmine Corp in their first game but later lost to T1 . On top of determining which team would go home, this series also served as a rematch of the Champions 2024 lower round 1 , where FNATIC eliminated G2 in 2-0 fashion. The match kicked off on FNATIC's map pick of Haven, where they dominated FOKUS 13-4 yesterday. They opted for their signature Yoru-Iso composition, while G2 brought out a standard Neon-Breach. Despite FNATIC's exceptional winrate on the map, G2 was in control throughout the first half on their defense, consistently countering FNATIC's pressure around the map with proactive reclears and coordinated floods to take an 8-4 lead. A second pistol win for G2 seemed to set them up for a simple win. However, reality was more complicated, as the next three rounds saw three back-and-forth round wins by the team with worse weaponry. G2 eventually stabilized in the chaos with two strong C hits to get up to 12-8. The North American squad went on to win Haven 13-9, delivering FNATIC their first loss on the map of 2024. kaajak and Alfajer nail clean Sheriff shots to take the first of multiple consecutive thrifties. valyn achieved the highest rating in the server with a 1.47 rating, 250 ACS, and 20 kills to 13 deaths. However, it was Alfajer leading in almost every category with 316 ACS, 24 kills, 8 of which first kills, and 215 ADR. The next map was G2's pick of Bind. Both teams selected relatively standard compositions, with Alfajer notably playing Raze for FNATIC and kaajak playing Gekko instead. G2's defense half on Bind proved to be even stronger than it was on Haven as they chained a pistol win into a bonus. FNATIC almost managed to win a thrifty in round 4 off the back of sharp Sheriff shots from kaajak, but jawgemo won out a 1v2 to secure the round. jawgemo picks up the pieces for his team in the clutch. From there, the rest of the game was smooth sailing for G2; they consistently burned down the clock, either cleanly retaking the sites or denying FNATIC the opportunity to plant altogether. This time, G2 easily carried forward the momentum from a second pistol win to win Bind 13-2. leaf dominated the opposition with an outsized 2.22 rating, 419 ACS, 93% KAST, and 26 kills to only 7 deaths. With this win, G2 is set to play Cloud9 today in the semifinals to determine who will secure the first spot in the grand final against the winner of FUT Esports versus T1.

title: G2 and T1 come out on top in Red Bull Home Ground Swiss R1
cleaned_content: The third and fourth games of the Swiss Stage of the Red Bull Home Ground #5 main event saw G2 and T1 find victory. In this format, four teams will qualify to the playoffs, if they can win two BO1s. G2 Esports defeated the new Karmine Corp roster on Haven, barely breaking a sweat, with a score of 13-7 while the fourth game of the day saw T1 take down FUT Esports in a 13-7 fashion on Ascent. G2 Esports vs Karmine Corp While G2 maintained their roster which had found them qualifying consistently for international events, including Champions 2024, KC were coming in with an almost complete roster rebuild, with only marteen left from the 2024 VCT season. Both teams had an almost-mirror comp, with the sole difference being Omen on G2's side while KC opted for the Astra. G2 started off strong with a pistol round win, and a failed force-buy attempt in round two ensured they got to a 3-0 start. KC were able to convert their full-buy round with saadhak winning a 1v1 against trent . Another G2 round win saw KC once again pushed into an eco which G2 won, pushing their lead to 5-1. KC won the upcoming buy with three left alive, and post a timeout, they regained their footing to tie things up at 5-5. G2 won the last two rounds were to close out the half 7-5 with a 1V3 sheriff clutch from Trent. Despite the close score, both jawgemo and Trent had 15+ kills already while none on KC had crossed six. Trent with the 1v3 sheriff clutch. The second half saw G2 on attack. They won five straight rounds in a row as Trent found two 3Ks and Jawgemo a 3K and 4K, continuing their blistering pace from the first half. It seemed over at 12-5, but KC still had some fight in them, with them winning a 2V5 and then Marteen clutching a 1v1 against Jawgemo. G2 closed out the next round to lock in their win 13-7. Jawgemo was the MVP with 27 kills on Neon – equal to the top two players on KC put together – and a kill differential of +20. Trent was close behind with 24 frags of his own. In contrast, all of KC went negative in terms of kill differential and their top frag – Marteen – had 14 kills to his name. “Our loss against FUT yesterday refreshed us as a team, it made us focus and figure out what our goals are.” said Jawgemo. The G2 duelist also casually dropped a bomb with him mentioning he always changes his settings before every event, while also calling his 347 ACS performance today “shaky.” T1 vs FUT Esports FUT came into the main stage through the international play-ins without losing a game, while T1 won the APAC play-ins to qualify. FUT had benched cNed , fielding xeus in his place, while T1 had rebuilt the roster with Masters Shanghai winners Meteor and Sylvan joining, as well as ex-DRX player BuZz joining the team, keeping only iZu and stax from 2024's VCT season. Ascent was the chosen map of play, with T1 starting on attack. FUT were able to win the pistol and anti-eco, with T1 converting their full-buy and the following round with 3Ks from Meteor and Sylvan respectively. FUT bounced back with a retake of their own but an ace from Meteor tied things up at 3-3 again. The half continued in a back and forth fashion, concluding 6-6. Meteor is clean in the clutch. With the side-swap though, T1 looked like they could do no wrong. They won six rounds in a row, the last with a 4K from Stax to reach match point. FUT finally got on the board for the first time in the half with AtaKaptan winning a 1v1 to bring the score to 12-7, but T1 won the next round to take the map 13-7. T1's Meteor had an absolutely ballistic game on the Killjoy, going +13 in terms of kill differential and a 311 ACS. For FUT's side, Atakaptan was the MVP with 19 frags and an ACS of 265. Both T1 and G2 only need one more win to qualify for the playoffs.

title: Team Heretics and Cloud9 victorious to open Red Bull Home Ground
cleaned_content: Team Heretics and Cloud9 started things off on the right foot, moving one win closer to playoff qualification to open the main stage action at Red Bull Home Ground #5 . Team Heretics secured their win on Split, defeating Germany-based second-tier side FOKUS 13-11 on Split. Meanwhile, a new-look Cloud9 went up against European giants FNATIC , defeating them on Abyss 13-11. The Swiss Stage format, which VCT fans may recognize as familiar from Masters Madrid, sees the event's teams pitted against each other by teams of identical records. The four teams to reach two victories will qualify to the event's playoffs, while the teams with two losses will be eliminated. The other half of the field will play their opening matches of the Swiss Stage later on the same day, with the next pairing of matches, the first set of qualification and elimination matches, taking place on Friday. Team Heretics vs FOKUS Team Heretics entered this matchup as the overwhelming favorite, having been one of the EMEA region's strongest teams in the 2024 season. They carry over much of the same roster into the 2025 season, centered around a young core that saw them reach four grand finals but lift none last season. However, they appeared to have some rust to shake off early on. Split, a relatively well-balanced map as far as attacking and defending goes, seemed to be defense-sided in this particular clash. After stealing the anti-eco round, the German team got out to a 5-1 lead which bubbled into an 8-4 halftime advantage. There was an element of experimentation in Team Heretics' approach, though. They have tried several different team compositions on Split over the past season, a map that's been tough for them in stretches. On Thursday, they opted for a triple-Initiator, no-Sentinel composition that saw in-game leader Boo on KAY/O and benjyfishy on Breach. While Team Heretics grabbed eight of the first nine rounds to open the second half, they started with ground to make up. A late surge by FOKUS seemed to threaten overtime, but a well-executed round with anchors from the right players and good mechanics saw them hold onto victory. The winning round for Team Heretics. Team Heretics Duelist MiniBoo topped the scoreboard, putting up 20 kills and a server-leading ACS of 239 in the win. On the other side, Mistic, formerly of Fnatic, Apeks , and Team Liquid , led the way for FOKUS with a team-leading 20 kills of his own. Cloud9 vs FNATIC FNATIC, on the double-Duelist composition which saw Alfajer pick up Iso and new signing kaajak on Yoru, had no trouble carrying that picking up space on the large two-site map, heading into the second half with a 9-3 lead. They won six of the last seven rounds, with some vintage heroics from the most decorated player in Valorant history. They don't call him the Ice Man for nothing. Fnatic's 16-year-old stand-in Sayonara took to the stage in place of Leo , who has been on the bench since the end of the team's Masters Madrid campaign. The youngster, who most recently showed out for EMEA Ascension side KPI Gaming went blow-for-blow with his tier-one opponents, finishing the map with 21 kills The side switch did see a significant momentum shift, though. After winning the pistol round but dropping the anti-eco, FNATIC dropped seven straight rounds, allowing for their American opponents to tie things up and then take the lead. Cloud9's double-Controller, and double-Initiator composition helped them put one foot forward on attack, while Duelist OXY heated up when his team needed him most. A momentum-snatching ace for OXY. A timeout after going down for the first time from head coach Elmapuddy appeared to inspire his team, as they put on a flawless round to knot things at 11, but Cloud9 would not stumble. They closed out a near-perfect attack half, outscoring Fnatic 10-2 with nine rounds being by way of eliminating all five of their opponents. Alfajer put on a stellar performance in the losing effort, with nine of his 21 kills being first-bloods. "Honestly, holy moly," OXY said after the match. "That is actually crazy, I don't even know what just happened. 3-10 comeback? Was it 3-9? Jesus." Team Heretics and Cloud9 will eagerly await the later results of Thursday's slate of games. They will be drawn against fellow 1-0 teams that leave the opening round victorious, while FOKUS and FNATIC will wait to see who loses.

title: Rossy: "It all depends on how I can lead these guys"
cleaned_content: “I think [we're] starting a little slow, but I think it's because we're taking the right way and making sure we have long term success.” Daniel " Rossy " Abedrabbo , who spent last year overseas under the T1 banner, has finally returned home to the Americas after signing with Cloud9 . Despite being picked up after his team qualified for Red Bull Home Ground through the Seattle LAN, the new in-game leader displayed confidence and trust in his team ahead of one of the biggest OFF//SEASON events of the year. “I think being under Autumn and my teammates [at T1]... taught me a lot of balance and [I] understood how to be a better person. Without that experience, I would not be able to lead this team or be able to do anything that well coming back home to America.” noted Rossy when prompted about his time with his former team. Rossy helped take T1 to their only international event of the year. (Photo: Lee Aiksoon/Riot Games) “If you look at our roster, firepower and stuff like that is not an issue at all… A lot of [our results] will be based upon our chemistry and how we want to play the game together. I know, not think, I know that these guys are all fantastic players. They're all going to have great individual seasons.” Cloud9 has gone through changes this year, with players shuffling in and out throughout many portions of the season. Most recently, the team bid farewell to vanity and runi before signing Rossy and former Moist x Shopify player v1c . The new roster took home the trophy at the Seattle Qualifier , but exited the SEN City Classic winless. “After we played in SEN City, we lost every game, but we learned what's actually good and what's not good. We want to focus on recurring issues and fixing those. We use these OFF//SEASON events to really learn about what our true strengths and weaknesses are… Obviously we want to win and we're not just there to practice, but overall it's a learning experience.” Rossy also spoke on Immi and GUGLi , the two coaches on the team who seldom received time under the spotlights. The two have helped Cloud9 prepare and practice throughout the VCT season and ahead of a new year. “They have a really good dynamic between Coach and Assistant Coach. Truthfully, they do very well and work off each other very well. They also have their own strengths and know how to divvy up the work to make sure that everyone is doing what they need to do. They keep us on the same page at all times.” Surprisingly, there seemed to be an absence of teams that Rossy had set his sights on. The in-game leader displayed calmness and indifference to his potential opponents. “There isn't anyone I'm looking forward to play… whoever God decides we need to play we need to play. Obviously there's T1 and I think it would be fun to play against some of my former teammates and friends. Whoever we play is whoever we play.” However, there were two teams that certainly seemed a cut above the rest to him.
