BOOM are guaranteed this upcoming year, but according to the revised rule set regarding ascended teams, their performance within the VCT will most likely determine how long their stay lasts.

title: 100 Thieves release bang
cleaned_content: 100 Thieves has announced the departure of Sean " bang " Bezerra ahead of the 2025 VCT season. The young talent spent almost three years with the organization before being released. bang entered the competitive scene back in 2020 under the likes of Phoenix1 , a home shared by fellow superstar Zachary " zekken " Patrone . The prodigy rose to fame after signing with TSM in 2021, a stint that netted him a Challengers 2 title and an appearance at the 2021 NA Challengers 3 Playoffs. However, bang's big break into the upper echelon of North America's scene materialized in the form of 100 Thieves, the very same team that he would qualify for an international LAN event with in 2022. Despite not finding much success at Champions Istanbul , bang would remain with the Thieves as they restructured to prepare for the partnership leagues. Over the course of the next two years, bang and his teammates struggled within the VCT, failing to qualify for Masters Tokyo or Los Angeles' Champions in 2023. However, the team's hard work paid off in 2024 after signing Kelden " Boostio " Pupello and Daniel " eeiu " Vucenovic led them to qualify for their first Masters event since 2021: Masters Shanghai . One of 100T's most-successful squads yet. (Photo: Lee Aiksoon/Riot Games) The troupe were granted a BYE straight to the playoffs of China following a Split 1 Americas League title courtesy of a 3-0 victory over G2 Esports . Despite picking up two wins over FUT Esports and Paper Rex , 100T were sent home with a respectable top four finish after being eliminated by Gen.G and Team Heretics , the eventual finalists of Shanghai's major. The rest of the year saw bang and his brothers-in-arms fail to put up ideal results within Split 2, a run that ended as the team fell to KRÜ Esports in the knockout round of playoffs. Following the conclusion of Champions Seoul , many teams began rebuilding and planning for the year to come, 100 Thieves included. Rumors have pointed to Sentinels as a potential new home for bang, while M80 's Alexander " zander " Dituri is slated to take his spot on 100T. 100 Thieves are now: Kelden " Boostio " Pupello Matthew " Cryocells " Panganiban Daniel " eeiu " Vucenovic Peter " Asuna " Mazuryk Anthony " Zikz " Gray (Head coach)

title: ShadoW becomes restricted free agent
cleaned_content: KOI has allowed their in-game leader Tobias " ShadoW " Flodström to explore his options as a restricted free agent. ShadoW has been a presence in EMEA Valorant since the beginning, most notably being a part of the old FunPlus Phoenix team that reigned towards the top of EU in 2020 and 2021. After his stint with FPX, he would join the Apeks team that went on to dominate tier two of EMEA in 2023, and were heavy favorites to ascend to the franchise league. However, they fell short at the very final hurdle, being swept in the grand finals at the hands of the heavy underdogs in Gentle Mates . After the disappointing result at Ascension, ShadoW joined KOI to be their IGL for the 2024 season. In 2023, KOI had an underwhelming season, only finishing 2-7 in the regular season , and failed to qualify to any international events. Their overhauled roster in 2024 showed promise when they upset Team Liquid in Kickoff to make it out of the group stage, but this glimmer of hope was quickly eradicated as they were shut down in the play-in stage against Team Vitality and Karmine Corp . They would fare even worse in the regular season , ending in last place in the league with a record of 3-7. With two unsuccessful seasons of franchising, KOI is looking for another shakeup of personnel, already having removed starxo , and reportedly eyeing new leadership in flyuh and Gorilla . ShadoW will now look for opportunities with other teams as an IGL. KOI is now: Kamil " kamo " Frąckowiak Grzegorz " grubinho " Ryczko Bogdan " sheydos " Naumov Kevin " Noizeeh " Jaskiewicz (Manager) André " BARBARR " Möller (Head coach) Tyler " Bambino " Jay (Analyst)

title: MEDUSA and Anthem to explore options outside of DFM
cleaned_content: DetonatioN FocusMe 's An " Medusa " Min-cheol (안민철) and Yoshitaka " Anthem " Enomoto have both announced that they are looking for a team for the 2025 VCT season. MEDUSA, a Korean Sentinel player for DFM who has played most often on Killjoy and Cypher, will leave the Japanese organization after just one season, he announced . He joined in February 2024. MEDUSA was a part of the Crazy Raccoon team that was acquired by DFM in late 2023, meaning he has been with the DFM core for two seasons. He joined in the same offseason as Meiy and neth . He is looking to play any role within a new team with the exception of Duelist, and his contract will expire in the near future. Anthem has been with DFM for two seasons. He joined ahead of the 2023 season, and has mainly played the initiator role for the team. Prior to DFM, he was on SCARZ and REJECT , two Japanese Challengers organizations. For a new team, Anthem detailed that he is open to playing all regions, and that he can play the Initiator, Sentinel and Smoke roles. He also stated that he is considering the option of coaching in a team that mainly uses Japanese. DFM's 2024 season was disappointing. One year after finishing dead last in the 2023 Pacific League , they finished second from last place in Pacific Stage 2 – just one spot above 2023 Pacific Ascension champions BLEED . They won just two matches in the 2024 season, failing to qualify for any international events in the process. DetonatioN FocusMe is now: Ibuki " Meiy " Seki Tomonori " SSeeS " Okimura Moon " Astell " Ji-won (문지원) (Head coach) Hirotaka " Melofovia " Okazaki (Coach) Tsubasa " NorthernLights " Ando (Coach)

title: Cloud9 qualifies to Red Bull Home Ground Main Event
cleaned_content: Cloud9 has emerged victorious in the Red Bull Home Ground NA Play-ins , punching their ticket to Berlin to compete in the main event. The four teams competing to represent North America were Cloud9, Sentinels , Moist x Shopify , and YFP . The teams clashed in front of a live crowd in Seattle, Washington, with the winner earning a chance to vie for the trophy in Berlin. Cloud9 debuted a new roster at this event, playing with mitch from Oxygen Esports and v1c from Moist x Shopify, the team that would be their first opponents . MXS struck first, taking map one with relative ease, but Cloud9 stomped them in the next two maps, both in 13-3 fashion. Meeting them in the grand finals was the fan favorite Sentinels, with their newcomer Reduxx making his debut. Cloud9 took the first map of Lotus, and then jumped out to a 9-3 half on the second map of Bind. Sentinels would mount a comeback to tie the score at 10-10, but a clutch from Xeppaa helped halt the comeback and allowed Cloud9 to close out the map and series 2-0. Cloud9 will represent North America in Berlin. This is Cloud9's third time competing in Red Bull Home Ground, having finished as the runner-ups in both of their previous appearances. They are now the fourth out of eight teams competing in the main event taking place in Berlin, joining the reigning champions of FNATIC , as well as Karmine Corp and FOKUS . The final four teams will be determined by the EMEA, APAC, and International Play-ins. The participants of these Play-ins are still being finalized. These final eight teams will face off from November 20 to 23.

title: Undefeated Sin Prisa Gaming wins Ascension Pacific
cleaned_content: Following a dominant showing throughout the entirety of the competition, Sin Prisa Gaming dominated BOOM Esports in the grand final of Pacific Ascension, winning 3-2 to claim their spot in VCT in 2025. In the grand final, Sin Prisa Gaming dropped the first map of their Pacific Ascension campaign. Before dropping map three, they had won ten consecutive maps, though that run was stopped on Lotus. In the buildup to the grand final, Sin Prisa defeated FULL SENSE , who themselves had not dropped a map up until that point. The second map of that 2-0 sweep was a 13-0 victory. Boom Esports finish in the top four of Pacific Ascension for the second time in two years, having fallen in the semifinals last year to eventual champions BLEED . The Pacific Ascension trophy. (Photo by Riot Games) The Asian region's Ascension competition was held in a ten-team, double-elimination bracket, with results from last year's tournament deciding the seeding for the teams. The teams qualified for Ascension Pacific were: Revenant Esports FULL SENSE Rapid Lofi Disguised Sin Prisa Gaming RIDDLE ORDER Oblivion Force NAOS BOOM Esports Justice For Tomorrow Group Stage Results Upper Bracket The upper bracket of the ten-team tournament was dominated by two teams: Sin Prisa Gaming and FULL SENSE. Both teams, due to the format and seeding of the competition, were one of four teams that were required to play an extra match, while other teams received direct qualification into the quarterfinals. Both teams did not drop a map before meeting in the upper final. Sin Prisa Gaming defeated Revenant Esports, RIDDLE ORDER, and BOOM Esports, while FULL SENSE defeated Oblivion Force, Disguised, and Justice For Tomorrow. In the upper final, Sin Prisa claimed map one in dominant fashion, 13-6. While one may have expected them to carry their momentum into map two, the 13-0 blowout that ensued may have been hard to predict. The result came about on Haven, FULL SENSE's map pick that they had won on twice before in the competition. The win made for some eye-popping stat lines, including Ivy 's 411 ACS on Haven. Lower Bracket The lower bracket had very few surprises. The team that had just been sent down from the upper bracket won in most cases, with RIDDLE ORDER being an exception. After being eliminated in the upper quarterfinals by Sin Prisa, they defeated NAOS and Justice For Tomorrow to reach the lower semifinals. There, they fell to eventual runners-up BOOM Esports. In the lower final, BOOM was matched up against FULL SENSE. Both teams had been defeated by Sin Prisa 2-0 previously, and a high-stakes rematch was on the line in the grand finals for the winner. BOOM would end up losing Lotus, but Shiro had himself a clip on it. After going up 2-0 with relatively few problems, a 14-12 overtime loss put BOOM, playing in front of a home crowd in Jakarta, in trouble of a reverse sweep. Any worries of that were negated on Sunset though, as they came out with a 3-1 victory to secure a rematch with Sin Prisa with a VCT berth on the line. Grand Final A dominant showing on their opening pick and a good-enough performance on their opponents' map pick meant that Sin Prisa had a 2-0 lead heading into map three, with the chance to sweep yet another opponent in the tournament. It looked as though Boom had a path back into the match on Lotus. With a 9-6 lead, they had the chance to steal away Sin Prisa's second map pick, but a thrifty round seemed to change the tides for the Korean team. Sin Prisa claimed six straight rounds, but three straight from Boom forced overtime, where they won 14-12 to force a fourth map in the series. Map four, played on Haven, seemed to see the home favorites pushed with a new sense of motivation. They won three rounds to open the map, but Sin Prisa were back online following the run. Nine straight rounds from Sin Prisa gave them a comfortable halftime lead. The back-and-forth nature of the match continued, as BOOM tied up the map at 9-9 after beginning their attack side. They didn't look back, dropping just one round in the second half to force map five and bring the threat of a reverse sweep close to a reality. It felt as though Boom could do no wrong. They had the momentum and the crowd behind them on Bind, which they used to come out to an 11-6 lead. Despite the cushion of rounds, a Sin Prisa comeback forced overtime, and the Ascension grand final was settled 17-15 in favor of the Koreans. Francis was named the MVP of the competition. He finished the grand final with a 92/83/43 statline. Boom's Famouz had a 103/90/25 effort in the loss. Sin Prisa Gaming join VCT Pacific League, where they will be the the fourth Korean team, joining Gen.G , DRX , and T1 . Additionally, they will have membership in VCT for at least the 2025 season.

title: Zellsis: "We both know that he ain't gonna be yelling s--t"
cleaned_content: “He needs to beat MxS first, I don't know why he's piping up, he hasn't even played the first match.” Despite not having played against Erick " Xeppaa " Bach in an official match since July, Jordan " Zellsis " Montemurro seemed confident about his team's chances against his rival in their upcoming tournament. After a thrilling 2024 season full of highs and lows, one of the VCT OFF//SEASON's most anticipated events looks to finalize its representatives. The Red Bull Home Ground #5 NA Play-Ins are soon to commence, with a total of four teams meeting in Seattle, Washington in hopes of claiming a ticket to the main event. Sentinels , Cloud9 , and Moist x Shopify all received direct invitations to the event, whereas YFP were made to brawl their way through the NA Open Qualifier , taking down Ascension and Challengers representatives alike on their trudge to the top. Now, all four teams are on the verge of showcasing their talents with the help of stand-ins. At the time of writing, MxS have yet to announce their roster for the event, while Sentinels, Cloud9, and YFP have all been forced to utilize new troops . “I'm very happy and confident with the people I'm playing with.” stated Cloud9's Xeppaa when asked about his temporary teammates Mitch " mitch " Semago and Victor " v1c " Truong . “With mitch, it's always a good time… [Him and I] click really well.” After the disbandment of Oxygen Esports , the former in-game leader found himself temporarily reunited with Xeppaa under C9 once again. The recent rostermania following the conclusion of Champions Seoul shook up team after team across all tiers and regions, North America being no exception. Despite these inconveniences, Cloud9's veteran spoke highly of the two new pickups ahead of their match against MxS. “I'm also excited to play with v1c because I know what he brings. Playing with him for a bit and hearing from other people how he is as a teammate is exciting.” Another young talent who caught the eyes of many, v1c has made his way to Seattle to fight for the trophy, albeit not under MxS, the team he competed in Challengers under this past year. Xeppaa also spoke of another teammate from the past, Jake " jakee " Anderson , who would be attending the LAN under a different jersey. “It's exciting to maybe play him and it's great to see him make it all the way here.” After taking a break from competing, jakee found himself taking on competition in NA Challengers earlier this year, but failed to make Ascension. Since then, the ex-C9 Controller had to pave his own way to Seattle alongside the rest of his team, a feat that Xeppaa acknowledged, but not without concerns. “I know they're not playing with stellar, one of the biggest reasons why they made it here considering [he] was their igl, so we'll have to see [how they do].” On the other end of the bracket, one enthusiastic Zellsis didn't let the recent retirement of Tyson " TenZ " Ngo and Gustavo " Sacy " Rossi stifle his motivation for another trophy. “I think [TenZ] just wants to take a break and live life a little bit with his wife, Kyedae , everything like that. Maybe we'll see him [again].” “Sacy has been competing for at least 10 years in eSports, way back even before Valorant, in League. He told me in Korea… he missed home, so I guess he also wanted to live life with his wife. Everyone's got a wife and are happy these days, I don't know.” “We scrimmed with curry and Reduxx last week and I think they slotted in very well. I don't know the rest of the Oxygen guys that personally, but with Reduxx he has shown a great upside in his attitude, skill, and overall potential. He's been frying in scrims, asking us what he can improve on… for his age and with his attitude I can see him having a very promising career.” Both Xeppaa and Zellsis felt confident in their new teammates who – albeit temporarily – would be playing alongside them at Seattle. The two both expressed excitement at a possible matchup, a match which would only be possible if Cloud9 and Sentinels won their openers against MxS and YFP. Who will come out on top? (Photo: Shannon Cottrell/Riot Games) “I wanna see Zellsis in the finals… and that's about it. See Zellsis in the finals and… yell at him a little bit.” Xeppaa jokingly stated. “We both know that he ain't gonna be yelling at shit… He ain't gonna be saying nothing.” Zellsis fired back. With a single ticket to Berlin on the line, fans can expect the unexpected as the four North American representatives battle it out on Washington's stage. VLR will be providing coverage of Seattle's LAN in our event hub , where streams, pick'ems, and more are available to all.

title: FURIA allows nzr to explore options
cleaned_content: nzr has announced that while he is under contract with FURIA for the 2025 season, he will be allowed to explore options as a restricted free agent. “I am interested in continuing to compete here in the Americas or in another region, motivated to continue learning as IGL or second caller,” he said in an announcement translated to English. The Argentine has had an eventual 2024 thus far. He started the year on LEVIATÁN 's roster, but was picked up by FURIA following their elimination from Americas Kickoff and the beginning of Americas Stage 1 . In the initiator player's first stint with FURIA, nzr helped the Brazilian organization reach Champions two years in a row. He then spent one season at Leviatan, where the organization achieved a 5th-6th placed finish in the Americas League in 2023. The second stint in 2024 was not as successful for FURIA or nzr. They failed to qualify for any international events, winning just three matches in VCT and finishing Americas Stage 2 with a tenth-place finish. FURIA is now: Alexandre " xand " Zizi Leonardo " mwzera " Serrati Ilan " havoc " Eloy Khalil " Khalil " Schmidt Pedro " Koy " Pulig (Coach) Lucas " lukzera " Soares (Assistant coach)

title: G2 Esports release icy
cleaned_content: G2 Esports has released their duelist player icy after one season together, ending his first stint in VCT. He is a free agent beginning Oct 7, according to G2's announcement . After years of competing in the tier two scene, icy got his first shot to prove himself in tier one when he signed with G2 after Americas Kickoff . G2 were eliminated in the play-ins stage of this tournament, where they were defeated in an upset against MIBR . icy's addition to the team was met with mixed results, as G2 ended Stage 1 with an even 3-3 record. This would be enough to qualify them for playoffs, as they barely beat out Sentinels in a tiebreaker by only two rounds. They hit their stride in playoffs as icy became more comfortable in the team. They would defeat Cloud9 and KRÜ Esports , both of whom were 5-1 in groups, to qualify for Masters Shanghai . Going into Shanghai, G2 were commonly overlooked compared to the rest of the competition. Moving past the Swiss stage with a 2-0 record, they were chosen first by Paper Rex , a team many had hyped as tournament favorites, to be their opponents. G2 would make them regret this choice in a massive upset win over them. They continued on to defeat Team Heretics for a second time in the tournament, managing a comeback after being down 2-11 in the second map. This secured a top-three finish for G2, but they were swiftly defeated by the eventual winners in Gen.G and would lose their third matchup against Team Heretics in the lower finals. Finishing third, they were the highest-placing team from the Americas region. G2 proved that their run in Shanghai was no fluke, as they returned home to Americas and dominated. They cruised through groups and playoffs until they reached the grand finals where their momentum was halted in a defeat against LEVIATÁN . They carried plenty of momentum heading into Champions Seoul . While they came out of their group seeded first, they would fail to make it any deeper, as they were eliminated in the first round of playoffs without winning a map. G2 are now: Jacob " valyn " Batio Trent " trent " Cairns Jonah " JonahP " Pulice Nathan " leaf " Orf Myungjun " Seowulf " Seo (Manager) Josh " JoshRT " Lee (Head coach) Peter " shhhack " Belej (Assistant coach)

title: M80 parts ways with entire Valorant roster
cleaned_content: In the days following the team's loss in the grand final of Americas Ascension , murmurings of players departing the organization arose. It was finally announced by M80 that its entire Valorant roster would be free agents heading into the 2025 season. M80's roster before the announcement was: Marc-Andre " NiSMO " Tayar Gianfranco " koalanoob " Potestio Michael " neT " Bernet Brendan " BcJ " Jensen Alexander " zander " Dituri Vincent " Happy " Schopenhauer (Head coach) Luke " GUNTER " Clives (Coach) M80 on stage after the 2024 Americas Ascension lower finals. (Photo by Riot Games) The loss, a back-and-forth five-map affair, came to Brazilian organization 2Game Esports , who will be in VCT Americas for the 2025 season. It was M80's second time reaching the grand final of Americas Ascension. Last year, they fell to The Guard , who in 2024 as G2 Esports qualified for two international events. The announcement by M80 included images of all five players and two coaches from the team's 2024 roster. "This roster has played a crucial role in M80's growth over the past year and we thank every single one of them for everything they have done for us," M80 said. "We are so proud of all the hard work they put into this project and we can't wait to continue supporting them in their future endeavors as we know they will kill it." NiSMO , who had been with M80 for the past two years, was the first to announce his unrestricted free agency. “Grateful for the journey with the boys, I wish all of them the best,” he said. “Very grateful to have been a part of this squad & Organization! Now it's time to find a new home and I'm more motivated than ever. Willing to play Any Initiator/Sentinel/Flex Duelist I'm very flexible and open to IGL'ing as well as I have been co-IGL'ing for a while now.” “[I] can play any duelist and excel at OPing at a top-tier level,” said koalanoob , who fans may remember for his 2024 Ascension grand finals-leading 81-kill performance. ”[I] can play all smoke agents, Chamber/Sage and I'm willing to learn and flex any role needed to make the team succeed.” neT , who was on the opposite side of the 2023 grand final as a player on The Guard, was the third player to announce his unrestricted free agency. He said that he is “Looking to play sentinel/controller, I am very vocal, and I can co-IGL defense. Willing to relocate to any region.” M80 on stage after the 2023 Americas Ascension lower finals. (Photo by Riot Games/Bruno Alvares) In a post following this year's grand final, BcJ said, "The feeling of not knowing what comes next for my career is eating me alive." "It hurts so much that AGAIN I have to sit here and write a post about how my team (legit my second FAMILY) is getting split up due to the nature of franchising and limited player slots," he said, adding context to the reason for the team splitting up. Before joining M80, BcJ was on the XSET team that finished 5th-6th at Champions Istanbul and was not included in Riot's plans for a partnership format heading into the 2023 season. Current VCT stars johnqt and eeiu were on last year's M80 roster before being signed by their current teams. M80 will now have to start from ground zero. "This season was one of the hardest seasons for me not only because of the loss but because of how much hard work went into this project and us being forced to split up," he said , suggesting that M80's roster breaking up was inevitable. He also dispelled any rumors of him retiring from competitive Valorant, emphasizing his talents as an initiator. “I wanna be the best player in the game and I'll do anything to achieve that goal,” koalanoob said in his announcement. “I loved playing with the most amazing teammates I could ask for and it sucks we are parting ways. But I know all of them will land on their feet they deserve it.” zander is still yet to make an announcement on his social platforms, but has reposted M80's announcement.

title: BBL allows pAura to explore options
cleaned_content: After one season with BBL Esports , pAura announced that he will be allowed to explore options with a new team, effectively ending his second stint with the Turkish organization. “Even though our talks with BBL for 2025 is ongoing, they have allowed me to explore my options as a restricted free agent,” he said. The sentinel player, who in 2024 expanded to play a number of initiator roles, was BBL's in-game leader this past year. This past season, BBL failed to qualify for the knockout rounds of any competitions they were in. A 3-3 start in EMEA Stage 1 saw them finish in a five-way tie on win-loss record in Group Alpha, but they finished fourth and missed out on playoffs. In EMEA Stage 2 , they went 1-3 and again narrowly missed out on playoffs, finishing with the same overall record as Karmine Corp but finishing behind them by two maps. BBL ended their 2024 season ranked 7th in Europe. pAura rejoined BBL at the end of the 2023 season after a successful season with Turkish team S2G Esports , which saw them fall short of reaching EMEA Ascension , being eliminated in the play-ins. Prior to S2G, he also played for Team Heretics , and Papara SuperMassive . In 2021 with Papara SuperMassive, he reached Masters Berlin , becoming the first team to represent Turkey on the international stage. In the group stage, they eliminated Paper Rex , but eventually fell to Acend in the group stages. Earlier in 2021 with Team Heretics, he finished second at Europe Stage 1 Masters , losing to Acend, the eventual Champions Berlins winners, in the grand final. “I am highly motivated & dedicated to win. Open to all regions as IGL or Sentinel/Flex, depending on the project,” he said in his announcement. BBL Esports is now: Efe " Elite " Teber Eren " Brave " Kasırga Kaan " reazy " Ürpek Doğukan " QutionerX " Dural Eren " Reen " Gül (Manager) Salih " marqnue " Onaran (Head coach) Juan " McJuankar " Carlos Mesa Ciruelo (Assistant coach)

title: Kr1stal departs Xi Lai Gaming
cleaned_content: Savva " Kr1stal " Fedorov has announced that he has departed Xi Lai Gaming and is now an unrestricted free agent just days after winning China Ascension 2024 . Kr1stal has been playing in various Challengers circuits in Asia since 2022. Before competing with XLG, he played as the in-game leader for the SCARZ roster that placed second in Pacific Ascension 2023 after falling to BLEED . XLG proved to be a strong team in China under Kr1stal's leadership throughout 2024. During Ascension, they only suffered defeats against Rare Atom , who they lost in both the group stage and the upper final. Faced with the same opponents for a third time in the grand final, XLG came alive and delivered a dominant 3-0 stomp. Kr1stal stood apart individually in that series with 57 kills to only 26 deaths, 274 ACS, and 174 ADR, and was a top ten player for the entire tournament by K/D ratio and ACS. XLG's decision to release Kr1stal is presumably due to the rule stating that each VCT team may only field one non-resident player, as both Kr1stal and XLG duelist Rarga hail from Russia. XLG head coach hvoya clarified that Kr1stal had already agreed before joining the team to part ways with the team in the event that they won Ascension. Xi Lai Gaming are now: Arthur " Rarga " Churyumov Deng " happywei " Minwei (邓闵维) Fei " Satoshi " Zhixian (费郅贤) Chen " MrCANI " Tingxun (陈廷训) Zhuo " MarT1n " Zhengjie (卓政杰) Aleksandr " hvoya " Eremin (Head coach) Chong " Fayde " Hoc Wah (Coach)

title: 2Game Esports lift Americas Ascension trophy
cleaned_content: 2Game Esports has won Americas Ascension and earned a spot in VCT Americas for the 2025 season. They defeated M80 in the grand finals to become the fourth Brazilian representative in VCT. A Cinderella story is complete. Six teams across the Americas region qualified to compete for Ascension. These teams consisted of the top two from each of the North American, Brazilian, and Latin American subregions. Competing for Americas Ascension were: M80 TSM RETA Esports All Knights Galorys 2Game Esports Group Stage Going into the tournament, the North American teams, and especially M80, were considered heavy favorites. In the previous year , the two representatives from NA cruised past the South American competition and met each other in the grand finals. Things would not be quite so easy for them this year. While M80 would finish the group stage with a flawless 5-0 record, they were not met without challenge, with numerous map losses and overtime conversions needed to win. The other five teams were all evenly matched, with no clear hierarchy emerging among them. The second NA team, TSM, would disappoint, as they were eliminated in last place, only managing one win. Argentina's All Knights would come second, finding three wins, only losing to M80 and their regional rivals in Reta. The other three teams would all end with a 2-3 record, although tiebreakers would place Reta at fifth, eliminating them from playoff contention. This left both Brazilian teams to qualify for playoffs, with their top seeded Galorys even bouncing back from a 0-3 start to the tournament. Playoffs Playoffs would start with a shocker, as the opening match saw Brazil's second seed 2Game Esports dominate the then undefeated M80 in 2-0 fashion. This game was followed by All Knights' win over Galorys, where in both maps, All Knights would find massive round streaks to win. This included winning ten rounds in a row to overcome a 4-12 deficit on Bind. 2Game would continue their momentum in the upper finals , where they defeated All Knights 2-1 to send them to the lower bracket to face M80, who had eliminated Galorys. The best-of-five lower finals started with All Knights domination, as they held M80 to a total of seven rounds across the first two maps. However, M80's zander would come alive in map three, putting up 31 kills to keep M80 alive. From there, the rest of M80 would wake up and roll over All Knights on the final two maps, successfully completing the reverse sweep, and earning a shot at redemption in the grand finals. The grand finals would also be a five map affair, but none of the maps were particularly close. 2Game would take Sunset and Haven, while M80 would win on Icebox and Abyss. However, 2Game's two map ban advantage meant that the final decider map would be Bind, a map M80 has only played one time in their history, that being against The Guard in the grand final of 2023's Ascension tournament. M80's inexperience showed, as 2Game would completely dismantle them, jumping out to a 10-2 score in the first half. M80 would find a couple rounds in the second half, but it wasn't long before 2Game secured their Ascension victory. This is now M80's second year in a row falling short in the grand finals of Ascension. Zap , put up a stellar performance in the grand finals, with a 1.34 rating across the series. As the IGL of the squad, he will lead his young and hungry teammates into new territory as they enter VCT.

title: Xi Lai Gaming lifts Ascension China
cleaned_content: After facing a tough road that saw them fall to the brink of elimination twice, Xi Lai Gaming won the Ascension China Tournament , earning entry into VCT China. They did so by defeating Rare Atom 3-0. The third time was the charm for XLG, as Rare Atom was the team they lost to twice before, once in the group stage and once in the upper final. Both sides have players who are coming off of landmark performances in this tournament. In the lower final, XLG's Rarga had a 110-kill performance in the five-map series against Chosen Clique Gaming . In the upper semifinals, Rare Atom's UdoTan had a 39-kill, seven-death showing in a 2-0 sweep of Ambitious Legend Gaming . XLG lifts the trophy In the Chinese region, eight active and verified teams were selected for Ascension based on circuit points earned from Valorant China National Competition . Xi Lai finished at the top of the circuit point rankings, while Rare Atom finished fourth. The eight teams that qualified for Ascension China were: Xi Lai Gaming KeepBest Gaming Chosen Clique Gaming ZY Gaming Rare Atom Ambitious Legend Gaming Qing Jiu Club Xtreme Gaming Group Stage Results In the eight-team tournament, the teams were split into two groups of four in a double-elimination format. The eventual two finalists were both seeded into group A. Rare Atom made quick work of ZY Gaming , defeating them 2-0 and never looking quite uncomfortable. Meanwhile, Xi Lai Gaming defeated Xtreme Gaming in comeback fashion after dropping the first map. In the winner's match, Rare Atom defeated XLG 2-0 to claim the top seed out of the group. In the decider, XLG defeated ZY Gaming 2-1, keeping their hopes alive. Group B saw its strongest teams make quick work of the rest of the field. Chosen Clique Gaming defeated Ambitious Legend Gaming and then KeepBest Gaming both by scores of 2-0, dopping just 24 rounds in the process. In the decider match, KeepBest Gaming fell to ALG 2-1, rounding out the four playoff teams. Rare Atom Roll in the Playoffs, fall short in grand final for second straight year In the playoffs, Rare Atom continued their dominance, sweeping ALG and only dropping just three rounds in the process. XLG defeated CCG in a less-dominant sweep, setting up a rematch of the two qualified teams from Group A. After dropping a close map one, their first map loss of the tournament, and then easily taking map two, it took until overtime for Rare Atom to defeat XLG again, for the second time in the competition. XLG went on to play CCG again in the lower final, after they defeated ALG in the elimination match. The back-and-forth lower final went to a fifth map, but the final map was a 13-2 blowout going to XLG. It saw Rarga explode for 110 kills and achieve an ACS of 290. The 3-2 win set up for a third rematch in the grand final against Rare Atom. In the grand final, XLG came out ruthless, stealing away Rare Atom's first map pick and then winning their own map pick to go up 2-0, meaning a reverse sweep would be needed for their opponents. Despite their opponents having the double map ban, it appeared that XLG learned from the previous two meetings, and went on to win 3-0. Rare Atom has now made two consecutive Ascension China grand finals without victory. Rarga impressed in the grand final with a server-leading 57 kills, and was named the MVP of the competition. XLG will be the 12th team that participates in VCT China, and will hold membership for at least a year.

title: FNATIC adds Milan as assistant coach
cleaned_content: FNATIC has announced that they have picked up Milan " Milan " de Meij from GIANTX as their assistant coach for VCT 2025. Milan has been a coach and an analyst since the early days of the game and was most notably a part of the Acend team that won Champions 2021 . He continued to coach for Acend throughout 2022 before moving on to work with the Giants Gaming team in 2023 that later would become GIANTX in 2024. Giants had a strong performance in 2023, qualifying for Champions after winning the EMEA Last Chance Qualifier and going on to place 9th-12th in Los Angeles. However, 2024 proved more difficult for GIANTX, as they ended the regular season with a 3-7 record and did not qualify for any regional playoffs throughout the year. Milan joins the team following the departure of Mini , who recently stepped down from coaching altogether after serving FNATIC since 2021. “I'm super excited to be here, and I'm very much looking forward to the next year,” Milan said in a short video clip attached to the announcement. With the addition of Milan, FNATIC is currently: Jake " Boaster " Howlett Timofey " Chronicle " Khromov Emir " Alfajer " Ali Beder Leo " Leo " Jannesson Colin " CoJo " Johnson (Manager) Chris " Elmapuddy " Tebbit (Head coach) Milan " Milan " de Meij (Assistant coach)

title: Karmine Corp parts ways with MAGNUM
cleaned_content: Martin " MAGNUM " Penkov has announced that Karmine Corp has allowed him to explore his options as a restricted free agent. This comes as yet another change in a full roster rebuild for the French organization, leaving only Marshall " N4RRATE " Massey and Martin " marteen " Pátek on the current active roster. MAGNUM first got his start at the highest level of competitive Valorant when he joined FNATIC in 2021 and was notably a member of the roster that placed second at Masters Reykjavik . He parted ways with the team in April 2022 after a disappointing group stage exit in Reykjavik a year later. In 2023, MAGNUM found himself playing with Apeks in Challengers North as part of their experienced ex-FNATIC core. The team only lost two series throughout the year, the second of which was in the finals of EMEA Ascension 2023 versus Gentle Mates . Following his impressive performance with Apeks, Karmine Corp signed MAGNUM for 2024 and presented him with a new challenge: take on the role of in-game leader for the first time and lead a squad with three rookies under the guidance of ENGH . Karmine Corp opened the season strong by winning EMEA Kickoff and going on to place 5th-6th at Masters Madrid , barely missing out on playoffs after an overtime loss in the third map to Paper Rex . However, they were ultimately unable to return to the international stage for the rest of the year and ended the regular season with a 4-6 record. Karmine Corp is now: Marshall " N4RRATE " Massey Martin " marteen " Pátek Andrey " ENGH " Sholokhov (Head coach) Ahmed " ZE1SH " El Sheikh (Coach) Sergey " fistie " Vasilev (Coach)

title: Acend pull out of Valorant
cleaned_content: Acend will not be participating in Valorant esports in 2025, ending their four-year tenure competing in the VCT. Acend was born in 2021 as a rebranding of Raise Your Edge , a team which had just qualified for the European Masters 1 . The team would make waves under their new purple banner when they upset the competition to take the crown of Europe's best. Their success would continue later in the year when they qualified for Masters Berlin and Champions 2021 . They would place a respectable top eight at Masters Berlin, but it was at Champions where they really made their name known. Acend swept through the bracket before taking down the reigning champions of Gambit Esports in the grand finals to be crowned the very first Valorant Champions, forever etching their name into history. The first of their kind (Photo by Michal Konkol/Riot Games). Acend managed to maintain their Champions winning roster for the following season, but were unable to reach the same heights. They would fall behind their regional competition and miss all three of the international events in 2022. Following this subpar season, Acend would not be selected as a partnership team for 2023, leaving their star-studded roster picked apart and forcing them to rebuild from the ground up. In the 2023 VCL East Surge , the newly rebuilt Acend were dominant, winning both splits in 3-0 fashion to qualify themselves for Ascension and earn a shot at returning to the VCT stage. They would make it to the top three at the tournament before being swept by the eventual winners of Gentle Mates . They would never quite recover from this loss, as 2024 was met with more disappointment as they failed to even make it to the Ascension tournament. In their announcement statement, Acend cite the decline of the tier two scene as a primary reason for their departure. “The increasingly hostile ecosystem has simply made it untenable to responsibly run a team,” reads their statement.

title: Apeks win VCT EMEA Ascension
cleaned_content: Apeks has joined VCT EMEA with their win in the Ascension EMEA tournament . Their 3-2 victory over PCIFIC Esports saw them crowned the champions of the regional circuit. This was Apeks' second time in an Ascension grand final, but unlike in 2023, they walked away with a trophy along with the Ascension spot. A long time coming for Apeks. The road to Ascension saw the nine EMEA Challenger leagues each crown a champion after the second split. These were: Barça eSports (Spain) MOUZ (DACH) SAW (Portugal) Joblife (France) PCIFIC Esports (Turkey) Apeks (North) DSYRE (Italy) The Ultimates (MENA) GoNext Esports (East) The second place teams of each region qualified for the play-ins tournament, where the winner would make it as the tenth team to play in Ascension. CGN Esports from DACH would only drop one map on their way to qualify, rounding out the ten Ascension teams. Ascension group results Heading into the tournament, there were a few community favorites, with Apeks and DSYRE both winning out both splits' trophies. SAW and The Ultimates were also similar in terms of regional domination but in contrast, PCIFIC had one of the most interesting paths to Ascension, being one of the first teams to make it from Premier to the VCL circuit mid-year. MOUZ and CGN were the two teams to make it last year as well. The group stage saw Apeks dominate their group, only losing to GoNext in their opening game to finish with a 3-1 record as the first seed. CGN also had a 3-1 record, being the other team to qualify from group A. In group B, PCIFIC continued their win streak, not losing a single series and being the only team to qualify for playoffs with a 4-0 record. The second slot saw more chaos, as there was a dispute over a referee ruling during Joblife vs Mouz, where Joblife were not allowed to bring in a substitute despite the rules allowing it, which was ultimately a factor in their loss. The official ruling that came out amidst calls for a retake backed up the original call, leading to The Ultimates taking the final playoffs spot. Apeks dominate in playoffs The opening playoffs game saw Apeks convincingly defeat The Ultimates, while PCFIC faced their first tournament loss to CGN, dropping them to the lower bracket. Apeks would find another clean 2-0 win over CGN in the upper bracket finals to be the first grand finalist, echoing their 2023 journey. In the lower bracket, PCIFIC recovered and defeated The Ultimates to make it to the lower bracket final against CGN. The lower final and grand final took place in Berlin, and PCIFC found their first victory on LAN, taking down CGN with a dominant 3-0 victory to be the second team to make it to the finals. The grand final saw Apeks use their upper bracket advantage to good use, banning out Bind, one of their weaker maps, and Icebox. The first map, Sunset, despite being Apeks' pick, was a dominant map for PCIFIC who took it with a 13-6 scoreline. Apeks responded with a 13-8 win on Abyss with a strong attack side performance. Both teams won their opponent's map pick, with the Ascension spot hinging on map five's winner, Ascent. Apeks dominated the map, with AvovA winning a 1v1 to confirm Apeks' date with destiny, albeit a year later. Apeks pull it off the second time around. kaajak , having played four different duelist roles, and Avova both had 77 kills apiece by the end of the series. They are the 12th team that will be a part of VCT EMEA 2025, and will hold the spot for a year at the minimum.

title: Sacy announces retirement
cleaned_content: After four years of competing in the VCT, Sentinels 's Gustavo " Sacy " Rossi has retired from competitive play. Sacy was one of the biggest names in early Brazilian Valorant. As the Sova player for Team Vikings , he made a name for himself by winning Brazil's regional Masters 1 , as well as being the first representative of the country at the international stage with his appearance at Masters Reykjavík . While Vikings and Brazil as a whole struggled against the global competition that year, it would not be long before the tides would turn in their favor. In 2022, Sacy would join the Brazilian superteam put together by LOUD . Full of young rookies new to the top tier of competition, it was up to Sacy, the veteran presence on the team, to help mentor the youngsters and develop them into the world beaters that they would become. LOUD entered the international stage with a bang, where Sacy's return to Reykjavík saw him toppling juggernauts from EMEA and NA to make it to the winner's side of the grand finals. However, LOUD's inexperience showed when they were swept in the finals by OpTic Gaming . Their problems only seemed to grow worse when they were eliminated in the bottom two of Masters Copenhagen , once again at the hands of Optic. However, they returned at Champions with a vengeance. After making it out of groups, they would go on to dominate the playoffs bracket. Even Optic, their rivals throughout the year, could not stop them, as LOUD would defeat them 3-1 in the grand finals to claim the Champions trophy for Brazil. Sacy himself would put up a dominant performance in the grand finals, with a 1.31 rating across the series to cement his legacy as a Brazilian legend. A historic moment for Brazil. (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games) Sacy joined Sentinels alongside pANcada at the beginning of franchising, with the both of them opting to leave behind their Brazilian brothers at LOUD to join the North American organization. They would struggle to deliver on the high expectations set for Sentinels, as their season was plagued with a multitude of issues. Role adjustments, coaching staff changes, and roster swaps made it difficult for Sentinels to find their footing in the Americas league , as they failed to qualify for any international events. In the off season before 2024, Sentinels added a new IGL in johnqt , as well as replacing Pancada with Zellsis , leaving Sacy as the sole Brazilian representative for the North American organization. This new roster showed promise, winning their own Sentinels Invitational as well as the AfreecaTV Valorant League tournament. They followed this up by topping the Americas league at Kickoff to qualify to Masters Madrid , where they would take home their second international trophy, as well as making Sacy the only player to ever win both Champions and a masters event. Following their big win, they would face some turbulence in Stage 1, failing to qualify for the Americas playoffs, but quickly rebounded in Stage 2 and made it to Champions off the back of championship points. At Champions , they would pull off a shocking upset against the Shanghai winners of Gen.G to make it out of the proclaimed group of death, a feat few expected going into the tournament. They would find two more wins in playoffs against DRX and FNATIC to reach the top four, but losses at the hands of the grand finalists of EDward Gaming and Team Heretics would eliminate them at fourth place. Another trophy for the bald. (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games) Sacy's long and decorated career in VCT now comes to an end as he takes a rest from professional play. Alongside TenZ , he is now the second player from Sentinels to retire, leaving the organization to find replacements for these two vital members in the off-season. Sentinels are now: Mohamed " johnqt " Amine Ouarid Jordan " Zellsis " Montemurro Zachary " zekken " Patrone Rahul " curry " Nemani Bryan " Zyto " Ybanez (Manager) Kevin " Kez " Jeon (Manager) Adam " kaplan " Kaplan (Head coach)

title: TenZ retires from competitive play
cleaned_content: After over four years of competing in Valorant, three of which spent as the face of Sentinels , Tyson " TenZ " Ngo has announced his retirement. The talent stated that he will be remaining with the organization, albeit not as a player. This change for Sentinels comes after a recent fourth place finish at Champions Seoul , a notable finish to the organization's fruitful year in the VCT. Among the initial batch of Counter Strike pros to migrate to the Valorant scene back in 2020, TenZ kicked off his new career under Cloud9 's first Valorant roster. In the early stages of the game's development, TenZ was highly-regarded as one of the best Duelist players in the scene. His explosive playstyle allowed his team to make many deep runs in tournaments. However, TenZ would suddenly retire – for the first time – in early 2021 to pursue content creation, attributing the lack of offline events and unsatisfying tournament results under Cloud9 Blue. Nearly two months later, Sentinels found themselves in a pinch after star-player Jay " sinatraa " Won was temporarily suspended from competing by Riot, forcing the organization to frantically search for a replacement to assist them for Stage 1 of the 2021 VCT. TenZ was loaned from Cloud9 and returned to the scene just in time to push Sentinels towards the first international event of VCT history, Masters Reykjavik 2021 . The global stage was where TenZ captured the hearts of fans. He fit perfectly into the five-map unit and slotted right into the team Shahzeb " ShahZaM " Khan lead. Ready to showcase their talents to the world, Sentinels dominated Reykavik 2021 without dropping a map and began gaining supporters following their 3-0 over FNATIC in the grand finals . From there, TenZ and the rest of North America's best stepped foot on every global stage in the VCT that year. The first five to ever do it. (Photo: Riot Games/Colin Young-Wolff) Following a 2021 full of regional domination, Sentinels' dynasty began to show cracks. The next two years would see the North American powerhouse shuffle players around in hopes of making Masters and Champions. Unfortunately, after a 2022 full of lackluster results, the organization would rebuild the roster from scratch, bidding farewell to almost all the former players that once hoisted Reykjavik's trophy. The time prior to the commencement of the franchised system prompted countless teams to conduct roster overhauls, with only the best of the best remaining as star players. TenZ alone survived the rostermania and Sentinels entered 2023 with a brand-new squad in hopes of finding more success. Once again, however, the team was unable to replicate the highs they once achieved in the VCT and failed to pick up a single win internationally. Once again, the organization made internal changes to prepare for the following year, and once again, TenZ began preparing with his new teammates for the next season. After two years of beatdowns and upsetting placements, Sentinels finally qualified for their first international event of the season; Masters Madrid . The team upset many fan favorites within the Americas Kickoff to re-establish regional dominance and ignite the engine that would fuel their global run. While in Spain, Sentinels defeated powerhouse after powerhouse to advance all the way to the grand finals. Throughout it all, TenZ held his own against other household names, even after finding himself in a brand-new Controller role. A 3-1 victory over Paper Rex pitted North America's sole representative in a match against Gen.G in a bid for the title, which ended in TenZ hoisting his second Masters trophy in three years. Absolute cinema. (Photo: Riot Games/Colin Young-Wolff) Despite missing out on Masters Shanghai , the Championship Points accumulated by Sentinels throughout their Kickoff and Madrid runs qualified them to Champions as the fourth seed from the Americas League . A group of death left the team unfazed as they took down FunPlus Phoenix and Gen.G to qualify for Seoul's playoffs. In their last run of the year, Sentinels defeated DRX before falling to the lower bracket courtesy of EDward Gaming , the future champions. Poetically, the last match that TenZ would go on to win in his competitive career was against FNATIC, the very team that he once defeated to claim his first-ever trophy. Unfortunately for Sentinels, their run at Champs would end after Team Heretics shattered their dreams of advancing in a three-map match, closing the chapter on TenZ's competitive journey. Years of competing amassed TenZ a large following on social media as one of – if not the – most well-known Valorant players. The former pro now takes a rest from competing professionally and will continue creating content with a relaxed schedule. Sentinels are now: Mohamed " johnqt " Amine Ouarid Jordan " Zellsis " Montemurro Zachary " zekken " Patrone Gustavo " Sacy " Rossi Rahul " curry " Nemani (Sub) Adam " kaplan " Kaplan (Head coach)

title: sh1n to explore options outside of Karmine Corp
cleaned_content: Ryad " sh1n " Ensaad has announced that Karmine Corp has allowed him to explore his options as a restricted free agent. His contract expires at the end of September, at which point he will become an unrestricted free agent. sh1n originally joined Karmine Corp in 2022 and was brought back on for 2023 as part of the French-speaking roster helmed by ScreaM . The team had a difficult year, only securing four wins throughout, although sh1n was able to demonstrate some strong individual performances on the Initiator role. Karmine Corp retained sh1n for the 2024 season and rebuilt the rest of the roster around him, where he would shift to playing Controller. Stellar performances at the start of the season led the team to win EMEA Kickoff and place 5th-6th at Masters Madrid after narrowly falling to Paper Rex in the Swiss Stage. The regular season was more turbulent for them; the European squad failed to qualify for Masters Shanghai or Champions 2024 after ending the season with a 4-6 record. The roster is now down to just three active players after tomaszy also announced his free agency yesterday. “This year has taught me a lot, and I'm ready to use those lessons to take the next step and reach my full potential,” sh1n said in his announcement. Karmine Corp is now: Martin " MAGNUM " Penkov Marshall " N4RRATE " Massey Martin " marteen " Pátek Andrey " ENGH " Sholokhov (Head coach) Ahmed " ZE1SH " El Sheikh (Coach) Sergey " fistie " Vasilev (Coach)

title: Team Liquid parts with head coach eMIL
cleaned_content: Team Liquid will be allowing their head coach Emil " eMIL " Sandgren to explore his options for the 2025 season. His run as head coach for the team comes to an end after two years together. eMIL first joined Liquid towards the tail end of 2022. Liquid were feeling the effects of the loss of their previous coach Sliggy , as they had failed to qualify for Masters Copenhagen . eMIL would step in for Liquid right before LCQ , where he would lead Liquid to win the tournament and secure a spot at Champions , where they would finish in the top eight. With a new roster in 2023, Liquid started out slow, being dominated by Team Secret at LOCK//IN . However, they would steadily improve throughout the season, and would eventually come out as the champions of EMEA, upsetting FNATIC in the grand finals to hand them their only loss of the year at that point. This result would qualify themselves for Masters Tokyo and Champions , but their regional success would not transfer to the international stage. Across both tournaments, they only found one win , placing in the top six at Tokyo and in the bottom four at Champions. With another new roster in 2024, Liquid would once again show signs of early struggles, as they failed to make it out of the group stage at Kickoff . Unlike the previous year, however, their troubles continued throughout the year, as they would only find four wins through both stages of EMEA. With these results, they failed to qualify to any international events throughout the year, a first for the Liquid organization. Team Liquid are now: Ayaz " nAts " Akhmetshin Georgio " keiko " Sanassy Nico " Harmii " Harms Eamon " cauzed " Drea (Manager) Jake " Bacon9 " Lloyd (Analyst)

title: tomaszy announces restricted free agency
cleaned_content: Tomás " tomaszy " Machado has announced that Karmine Corp has allowed him to explore his options as a restricted free agent. tomaszy joined Karmine Corp at the beginning of 2024 as part of the French organization's international rebuild following a notably disappointing 2023 season. Like many of his teammates, he was scouted from Challengers, having placed fourth in EMEA Ascension 2023 as the star duelist of SAW . Upon joining the team, he swapped to a more Sentinel-focused Flex role as marteen was selected to be the team's duelist. Karmine Corp kicked off the 2024 season with a roaring start, delivering the former kings of FNATIC their first loss of the year to qualify for Masters Madrid . They went on to win Kickoff over Team Heretics and cement themselves as the first seed from EMEA. In Madrid, the team narrowly fell in an overtime thriller to Paper Rex in the final round of the Swiss Stage and placed 5th-6th. The European squad was subsequently unable to reclaim their Kickoff heights. With a 4-6 overall regular season record, Karmine Corp managed to qualify for playoffs in both Stages but failed to qualify for Masters Shanghai or Champions 2024 after securing fewer circuit points than FUT Esports . “I would like to thank my team and teammates for the season we spent together, I have some great memories from this past year and have learnt a lot during this time,” tomaszy wrote in his announcement. Karmine Corp is currently: Martin " MAGNUM " Penkov Marshall " N4RRATE " Massey Martin " marteen " Pátek Ryad " sh1n " Ensaad Andrey " ENGH " Sholokhov (Head coach) Ahmed " ZE1SH " El Sheikh (Coach) Sergey " fistie " Vasilev (Coach)

title: KRÜ to continue without heat
cleaned_content: KRÜ Esports has allowed Olavo " heat " Marcelo to explore his offers for the next season as a restricted free agent. He has been let go from the roster after less than one year of play under the organization. heat joined KRÜ ahead of Stage 1 of the 2024 season to replace mta , who had sustained an injury and was not able to play. He had most recently played for the struggling MIBR roster in 2023, where he was benched towards the end of the season. While he was previously an almost exclusive duelist player, he showed his flexibility by stepping into the initiator role on KRÜ. His addition elevated the LATAM team to the top of Americas, winning his first five games to place first in group Alpha with a 5-1 record. This granted them a bye in playoffs, putting them only one win away from making it to Masters Shanghai . Despite this advantage, losses to the hands of G2 Esports and LEVIATÁN would eliminate them from contention. In Stage 2 , mta returned to the starting roster as KRÜ returned to playoffs, this time vying for a spot at Champions. A narrow victory over 100 Thieves would grant KRÜ the third seed slot for Americas, and continue their streak of attending every Champions event. For heat, this was his first time returning to Champions since 2021, where he played with the Brazilian Keyd Stars roster. At Champions , KRÜ would only find one win against the CN fourth-seeded Bilibili Gaming before losses to DRX and FNATIC would end their run in the groups stage for the third year in a row. “Thank you very much KRU, staff, players for giving me this opportunity, it was great to be part of KRU,” heat wrote alongside his announcement. KRÜ Esports is now: Marco " Melser " Eliot Machuca Amaro Angelo " keznit " Mori Nicolás " mta " González Fabian " Shyy " Usnayo Jorge " Atom " Siero (Head coach) Alan " ddx " Salvati (Assistant coach) Tomás " Nyogen " Castiglione (Staff)

title: Assistant coach DrewSpark departs Sentinels
cleaned_content: After two seasons with the organization, Sentinels assistant coach Drew " DrewSpark " Spark-Whitworth has announced that he is a free agent and looking for a new team. "I was informed yesterday that I will not be included in plans for 2025," DrewSpark said. "I want to thank Sentinels for trusting me to help lead SEN to new heights the team for being an absolute blast to work with over the last two years, and the fans for their relentless support!" DrewSpark first joined Sentinels as an analyst following the 2022 season, but was soon promoted to assistant coach following the dismissal of then-head coach SyykoNT . The organization had a disappointing 2023 season that saw them finish 7th in the 2023 Americas League and miss out on playoffs. That form would continue at the Americas Last Chance Qualifier , where they were eliminated in the lower bracket after posting a 1-2 record. With the same coaching staff from the year before and a mostly-retained roster, Sentinels would enjoy a better 2024 season. They retained their core roster, and signed former player Zellsis and added johnqt as their in-game leader. They finished as the Americas Kickoff champions, defeating El Clásico counterparts LOUD in five maps to qualify to Masters Madrid . At Madrid, the organization's first international tournament since the 2021 season, Sentinels dominated. A 5-1 record, which included a loss and eventual revenge victory over Gen.G in the grand final, helped write a storybook finish for the team. It was their first international trophy since Masters Reykjavik in 2021. However, a fourth-place finish in Group Alpha at Americas Stage 1 meant the Masters champions would not qualify for Masters Shanghai . Their shaky form continued through stage 2, but they would qualify for Champions Seoul through champions points, claiming the Americas region's fourth spot in the tournament. In the time between Stage 2 and Champions, Sentinels seemed to figure out what had gone wrong as of late. They survived the 'group of death' by eliminating defending Masters champions Gen.G, and would eventually finish fourth after a strong run in the playoffs. "After a successful 2024, I am more motivated than ever to return to work and achieve more," DrewSpark said. "I am open to opportunities in all regions." "A Sentinels legend," Sentinels said in a response to DrewSpark's announcement. "You helped take us further than we've ever been. Gonna miss seeing that badass kilt on stage." Sentinels is now: Mohamed " johnqt " Amine Ouarid Tyson " TenZ " Ngo Jordan " Zellsis " Montemurro Zachary " zekken " Patrone Gustavo " Sacy " Rossi Rahul " curry " Nemani Bryan " Zyto " Ybanez (Manager) Kevin " Kez " Jeon (Manager) Adam " kaplan " Kaplan (Head coach)

title: ZETA DIVISION release hiroronn and yuran
cleaned_content: Hiroki " hiroronn " Yanai and Yushin " yuran " Hato of ZETA DIVISION have each announced that the team has allowed them to explore their options as restricted free agents. Both players joined ZETA as rookies for the 2024 season, marking the organization's first roster changes since 2022 following crow 's transition to assistant coach and TENNN 's departure from the team. hiroronn was scouted from FENNEL following their third place finish in Challengers Japan , while yuran was picked up directly from ZETA Division Academy . Brazilian coach Carlao was also brought in to provide a fresh perspective to the team. Regional expectations were high for the Japanese squad at the beginning of the 2024 season after they won the Pacific Last Chance Qualifier to qualify for Champions in 2023. While ZETA were able to secure a respectable 4th-6th place finish in Pacific Kickoff , they were subsequently unable to carry their momentum forward and spent the majority of the season towards the bottom of the standings. ZETA ended the regular season with a 3-7 record and ultimately failed to qualify for playoffs. The active roster has been reduced to just two following the recent retirement of Laz . ZETA DIVISION is now: Yuma " Dep " Hashimoto Shota " SugarZ3ro " Watanabe Carlos " Carlao " Mohn (Head coach) " nokaze37 " (Analyst) " gya9 " (Analyst)

title: GIANTX Fit1nho, hoody, Famsii become free agents
cleaned_content: Adolfo " Fit1nho " Gallego , Aaro " hoody " Peltokangas , and Ramses " Famsii " Valentino Erasmus Koivukangas have each respectively announced the expiry of their contracts with GIANTX and are now all free agents. Famsii is an unrestricted free agent, while Fit1nho and hoody will become unrestricted free agents at the end of September. Fit1nho and hoody have both had long tenures with the team. Fit1nho in particular has spent most of his career as a staple on different iterations of the Giants Gaming team that is now GIANTX; he joined in 2020, departed that year and rejoined later in 2021. Similarly, hoody originally joined Giants in 2021 and returned to the team in 2023 after spending a year with G2 Esports . In 2023, Giants reigned as a strong regional contender in EMEA throughout the regular season. After narrowly missing out on qualification to Masters Tokyo, they successfully qualified for Champions 2023 as the fourth seed from EMEA by winning the EMEA Last Chance Qualifier . They went on to place 9th-12th in Los Angeles after being eliminated in the group stage by EDward Gaming . 2024 was a more turbulent year for GIANTX as they struggled to find their footing. A winless Kickoff led the European squad to release nukkye , pick up purp0 , and move Fit1nho from Duelist to the Flex role. The team from there only managed to secure their first win of the year in week 5 of Stage 1 and did not qualify for playoffs. Halfway through Stage 2 , GIANTX benched Redgar and brought in Famsii via their partnership with UCAM Esports Club . While they managed to play a close match against Team Heretics , they ultimately ended the regular season with a 3-7 record and were once again unable to qualify for playoffs. GIANTX is currently: Semyon " purp0 " Borchev Kirill " Cloud " Nehozhin Daniil " pipsoN " Mesheryakov (Head coach) Milan " Milan " de Meij (Analyst)

title: Moist x Shopify roster to explore options
cleaned_content: The players of Moist x Shopify entered restricted free agency, per player tweets. This includes Chad " oderus " Miller , Brock " brawk " Somerhalder , Xavier " flyuh " Carlson , Adam " mada " Pampuch , Victor " v1c " Truong , as well as coach Jared " mac " Schneider . Moist x Shopify was formed for the 2024 NA challengers season as a combination of the Shopify Rebellion Black and Moist Moguls rosters from the previous year. Shopify Rebellion had come off a rough season where they only just squeaked into playoffs and went out in the first round. Moist Moguls on the other hand, were only one game away from qualifying to Ascension, losing only to the two eventual grand finalists of Ascension. With a mix of players from both rosters, Moist x Shopify looked to be strong contenders for one of the NA Ascension slots. The season would start off strong for MxS with a perfect 5-0 record in the regular season of Stage 1, topping their group. However, in the Mid Season Cup , they were eliminated by Oxygen Esports to finish in the top four. After this loss, MxS struggled to maintain their form from Stage 1, ending with a troubled 3-3 record in Stage 2 . Despite this result, they still comfortably qualified for playoffs , and were still widely considered one of the favorites for an Ascension slot, with their main competition being M80 , DarkZero Esports , and Oxygen. MxS started playoffs strong with two 2-0 victories over FLUFFY AIMERS and Blinn to put them into the winner's final, only one win away from Ascension. This was the exact same position they were in the previous year, even meeting the same opponent in M80. As had happened last year, they were defeated by M80, putting them in the loser's final, where it seemed history was to repeat itself. However, with DarkZero and Oxygen being eliminated earlier in the bracket, they would play against TSM , a team they were favored against, having very comfortably beaten them a month prior. Unfortunately for MxS, in a shocking upset, TSM would overcome the odds and upset MxS, leaving them with heartbreak for the second year in a row. Although the current MxS players will be moving on from the team, Moist is likely to return in some capacity for the following year, as stated by Ludwig, a co-owner of the organization, on his stream.

title: Mini departs FNATIC
cleaned_content: FNATIC has announced the departure of former head coach and assistant coach Jacob " Mini " Harris from the coaching roster. Mini has been a part of Fnatic since the very beginning, when they entered Valorant by signing the roster of SUMN FC in 2021 which included Mini as the head coach. Since then, he has helped lead Fnatic to be the most dominant team in EMEA, as well as bring them a wealth of international success. Their regional dominance is evidenced by the fact that they have qualified for seven out of eight possible international tournaments with Mini at the helm, only missing out on Masters Berlin in 2021. Their international debut would see them place second at Masters Reykjavík , but following international performances were relatively disappointing compared to the potential they showed at the regional level of competition. It was not until 2023 where they would take home their first trophy at LOCK//IN , followed by a consecutive win at Masters Tokyo . They still remain the only team to have accomplished this feat of back to back international victories. The most decorated coach in VCT. After their dominance in 2023, Mini decided to step down as head coach, and moved into the position of assistant coach instead. His lesser presence in the team was immediately felt when the once kings of EMEA fell to Karmine Corp in 2024's Kickoff , failing to qualify for Masters Madrid and missing their first international event in three years. They would rebound to win both Stage 1 and 2 later that year, but would exit early on in the playoffs at both Masters Shanghai and Champions . With this move alongside the removal of Derke from the active roster, Boaster is now the only remaining member of the original Fnatic squad. Mini has indicated that he is looking to take a break from coaching and will likely not be joining another team for the 2025 VCT season. FNATIC are now: Jake " Boaster " Howlett Timofey " Chronicle " Khromov Emir " Alfajer " Ali Beder Leo " Leo " Jannesson Colin " CoJo " Johnson (Manager) Chris " Elmapuddy " Tebbit (Head coach)

title: LOUD and Saadhak to part ways
cleaned_content: After three seasons with the organization, LOUD has announced that they are allowing longtime in-game leader Matias " saadhak " Delipetro to explore other options as a free agent. “Today, by mutual agreement, we adjusted Saadhak's contract from 2025 to 2024, leaving him available to hear new proposals,” LOUD said. “Thank you for your partnership so far, manito! We lived through incredible moments, in which we conquered the world with LOUD.” saadhak joined LOUD before its inaugural 2022 season and has enjoyed a trophy-laden time with the Brazilian outfit. It started with a dominant, undefeated run at Brazil Stage 1: Challengers 1 that saw them qualify to Masters Reykjavik , finishing second behind OpTic Gaming . Another sweep in Stage 2 qualified them for Masters Copenhagen , but their run at the tournament would be short-lived, falling in the group stage at the hands of OpTic once more. A rivalry was brewing between the two organizations, a rivalry that's often referred to as one of Valorant's first El Clásico s. At Champions Istanbul , saadhak and LOUD took vengeance, defeating OpTic in the grand final to lift their first international trophy and the first Champions trophy for the Americas region. Their form would continue in 2023, finishing second at the LOCK//IN grand final and lifting the first Americas League trophy against NRG , which had a roster centered around the OpTic core. The performance was followed by a dismal showing at Masters Tokyo , but a run at Champions Los Angeles saw them finish third and fall to eventual champions Evil Geniuses . This past season was an off year for LOUD and Saadhak. Following key departures, their play fell below expectations. They finished fourth at Masters Madrid and then failed to qualify for another international tournament, leaving 2024 as the first trophy-less season in the organization's history. saadhak is expected to be in high demand. The Argentinian speaks Portuguese, Spanish and English and has displayed the ability to play several roles. The 2024 season even saw Saadhak pick up Neon after the duelist was buffed. Before joining LOUD, saadhak had put himself on the map with Team Vikings , with whom he had reached Masters Reykjavik and Champions Berlin with in 2021. “Thank you to LOUD and everyone who supported me in these 3 years doing LLL,” Saadhak said in a repost of the announcement. “I will soon release a video talking about my time on the team and the next steps as well. I love you!” LOUD is now: Bryan " pANcada " Luna Felipe " Less " de Loyola Basso Arthur " tuyz " Andrade Cauan " cauanzin " Pereira Pedro " peu " Lopes (Coach) Jordan " stkJ " Nunes (Assistant coach)

title: SUYGETSU to explore options outside of NAVI
cleaned_content: Dmitry " SUYGETSU " Ilyushin has announced that he will be exploring other options while still remaining on contract with Natus Vincere . He is now the third player from NAVI to do so, along with Zyppan and ardiis . SUYGETSU first joined the FunPlus Phoenix core ahead of the 2022 VCT season, during which he was able to help elevate the team to great success. FPX came first and second in stage one and two of EMEA challengers respectively, earning them a spot at the international stage for the first time. While SUYGETSU was late to arrive at Masters Copenhagen , when he did, the team went undefeated, making a full lower bracket run to win the tournament. SUYGETSU himself capped off the final round of the tournament with his iconic clutch against Paper Rex . FPX followed up this tournament win with a fourth place at Champions later that year. One of the most iconic clips in all of VCT. After being signed by NAVI for franchising, SUYGETSU and the rest of his team struggled to find the same success they had before. They started their time with their new organization with a top four finish at LOCK//IN , but have otherwise been unable to make it deep at any other events. In 2024, they failed to even qualify for an international event, being eliminated each time in the opening single-elimination round of playoffs. NAVI are now looking for a near full rebuild, having already moved on from three of their starting roster members. Natus Vincere is now: Kyrylo " ANGE1 " Karasov Andrey " Shao " Kiprsky Oliwer " LATEKS " Fahlander (Head coach) Urszula " Xirreth " Klimczak (Performance coach) Berke " Vlad " Kantürk (Analyst)

title: Leviatán allows Mazino to explore options
cleaned_content: After spending two seasons with LEVIATÁN , Roberto " Mazino " Rivas announced that he will now be allowed to explore options with a new team. He revealed that his contract with the organization is set to expire, but that he is still a restricted free agent. "My contract with Leviatán is coming to an end soon, and even if we are exploring an extension, I've also been allowed to explore all my options as a Restricted Free Agent," Mazino said. Before being signed by Leviatán following the 2022 season, Mazino played for KRÜ Esports , with whom he'd reached back-to-back Champions berths, highlighted by a semifinal finish at Champions Berlin . He, alongside keznit , was signed by Leviatán as the team's fifth and sixth player. The duo were also founding members of the Argentinian organization. keznit has since returned to KRÜ. The former CS:GO player played a key role in Leviatán's success after a less-than-ideal start to their 2024 season. After being eliminated in the Swiss Stage of Masters Shanghai , they parted ways with head coach goked and promoted assistant Itopata to head coach. Most well-known for his play on Harbor and Breach, Mazino and Leviatán enjoyed a successful 2024, lifting the organization's first trophy at VCT: Americas Stage 2 and achieving a third-placed finish at Champions Seoul . "I'm open to any region and I will try my best to win," he said. Leviatán's active roster is now: Francisco " kiNgg " Aravena Ian " tex " Botsch Erick " aspas " Santos Corbin " C0M " Lee Juan " Daykiry " Garcia (Manager) Dimitar " Itopata " Staev (Head coach)

title: crashies departs NRG as free agent
cleaned_content: NRG has announced the release of longtime player Austin " crashies " Roberts , who will be allowed to explore other options in VCT as a free agent. crashies has been with NRG since the beginning of the 2023 season. He joined the organization following a successful 2022 season with OpTic Gaming that saw the team lift the Masters Reykjavik trophy. When OpTic disbanded following the 2022 season, crashies would join NRG with a slew of familiar faces. The organization picked up head coach Chet , FiNESSE , and Victor . Chet and Victor parted ways with NRG following the 2024 season. With crashies on the roster, NRG has achieved a second-placed finish at the 2023 Americas League and a fourth-place finish at Masters Tokyo . crashies was one of the core members of ENVY when it merged with OpTic at the end of the 2021 season. With them, he achieved a second-placed finish at Masters Berlin . Prior to Envy, OpTic and NRG, crashies also spent time with T1 . "As my contract is expiring this year, NRG is allowing me to explore my options as an unrestricted F/A going into the 2025 season," crashies said . He will find himself on a different roster from the OpTic/NRG core for the first time since 2020. NRG 's roster is now: Pujan " FiNESSE " Mehta Sam " s0m " Oh Ethan " Ethan " Arnold Max " Demon1 " Mazanov Zachary " Ry " Parr (Manager) Tanishq " Tanizhq " Sabharwal (Assistant coach)

title: KOI starxo enters free agency
cleaned_content: Patryk " starxo " Kopczynski announced that he is entering free agency, leaving KOI after two seasons with the Spanish organization. The Polish player said that he is an unrestricted free agent, meaning his contract was either terminated or came to an end. He says that he is comfortable with most agents in an initiator, smokes or flex role, but that can also step up to a leadership position. "After all this time I know that I'm not scared to become a leader and one of the best IGL's," the three-year veteran said. "I can also become a very strong second voice and a tactical genius. Been sacrificing myself for a few years being full-time suport player, gave my everything only so the team could work the best. Now I know what type of team I want to be in and how to make it work the best way." starxo's time in the European VCT scene dates back to 2020, but he's most remembered for his 2021 season, when he won Champions Berlin with Acend . Prior to joining KOI, starxo played a big part in Acend's 2021, season, which saw the team also take home the Europe Stage 1 Masters and the Europe Stae 3: Challengers 1 trophies. The departure of starxo is another domino in KOI's roster rebuild. In 2024, they went 5-10 and failed to qualify for any international tournaments, and their first step in the rebuild seems to be replacing one of their final pieces when rebuilding in 2023. "If you only look at the last season you are wrong, real starxo was there only a few times," starxo said. "Never been so ready to prove people wrong after all this months." "Thank you and sorry for these 2 years," starxo said to KOI fans. "It was even harder for me than for you, trust me.
