You are very dedicated community, I could feel all of the support you gave us and also the hate. You deserve better. I hope you will have it in 2025." KOI 's roster is now: Kamil " kamo " Frąckowiak Tobias " ShadoW " Flodström Grzegorz " grubinho " Ryczko Bogdan " sheydos " Naumov Kevin " Noizeeh " Jaskiewicz (Manager) André " BARBARR " Möller (Head coach) Mark " aer0z " Ochoa (Assistant coach) Tyler " Bambino " Jay (Analyst)

title: hiro and FNATIC part ways
cleaned_content: FNATIC have announced the departure of stand-in Emirhan " hiro " Kat after nearly four months with the squad. The former Papara SuperMassive player was brought on as a replacement for starting player Leo " Leo " Jannesson , who was forced to step down temporarily due to a number of health issues leading up to Split 2 of the VCT EMEA. hiro was scouted outside of FNATIC's affiliate partnership with Mandatory . Picking up Mandatory's Damien " HyP " Souville would mean removing the team's IGL while they were fighting for an Ascension slot, while hiro and Papara SuperMassive had a much tougher path to the promotional tournament. hiro played all of Stage 2 and Champions in Leo's place, becoming a key member in FNATIC's EMEA title run and their Champions journey. At the world championship, despite strong numbers from the Dutch stand-in, FNATIC struggled to make waves and ultimately exited the competition in the top six. As the season ends, so does hiro's time with FNATIC and he is now a free agent. FNATIC's starting roster is also reduced to three. Nikita " Derke " Sirmitev is currently a restricted free agent and, at the time of publishing, the organization has not revealed whether Leo will return for the 2025 season, as it hinges on him being healthy enough to play . FNATIC 's starting roster is now just: Jake " Boaster " Howlett Timofey " Chronicle " Khromov Emir " Alfajer " Ali Beder Colin " CoJo " Johnson (Manager) Chris " Elmapuddy " Tebbit (Head coach) Jacob " Mini " Harris (Assistant coach) Edgar " psych_chek " Chekera (Performance coach)

title: Ardiis enters restricted free agency
cleaned_content: Ardis " ardiis " Svarenieks has announced that he is a restricted free agent for the 2025 VCT season. Despite returning to the FunPlus Phoenix core that led to his Masters Copenhagen victory, ardiis and Natus Vincere have decided to part ways after a season of lackluster results, although he remains under contract with the organization. ardiis has been a prominent figure in Valorant esports since its inception. He initially joined G2 Esports in 2020, where he secured multiple victories in the European Valorant Ignition Series. After failing to qualify for multiple Masters events, ardiis parted ways with G2 and briefly joined Team Heretics . Following an early exit in open qualifiers with Team Heretics, he found a new home with FunPlus Phoenix, where he dominated the VCT in 2022. Although the team could not attend Masters Reykjavik despite winning Stage 1 , they achieved significant international success, lifting the Masters Copenhagen trophy and finishing fourth at Champions Istanbul . ardiis lifts an international trophy at Masters Copenhagen (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games). ardiis decided to venture overseas in 2023, joining NRG and one of North America's most successful cores. The team experienced moderate success, highlighted by a fourth-place finish at Masters Tokyo . Still, they ultimately failed to reach their heights of the previous year, especially after an early exit at Champions Los Angeles . In 2024, ardiis rejoined NAVI with hopes of rekindling their past success. However, the team failed to qualify for either Masters event after two single-elimination losses to Team Heretics—the first time any of the players had been eliminated so early since 2021. Their form deteriorated further in Stage 2 , managing only a single group stage win before being swiftly eliminated in the playoffs by Team Vitality . Despite the team's lack of success, ardiis will be a compelling option for teams looking to rebuild for 2025, given his strong individual performance and increased agent flexibility in 2024, though teams may need to pay a buyout to NAVI to acquire him. Natus Vincere are now: Kyrylo " ANGE1 " Karasov Andrey " Shao " Kiprsky Dmitry " SUYGETSU " Ilyushin Oliwer " LATEKS " Fahlander (Head coach) Urszula " Xirreth " Klimczak (Performance coach) Berke " Vlad " Kantürk (Analyst)

title: TL Jamppi, Mistic, and Enzo enter restricted free agency
cleaned_content: In a move to rebuild their roster, Team Liquid have announced that Enzo , Mistic and Jamppi will be allowed to explore other options as restricted free agents. Enzo and Mistic, the former of whom was the team's in-game leader this past season, have been with the organization since November 2023. Both of their Valorant careers started in 2020, but their paths would not cross until 2022 when they found themselves as teammates on FNATIC . Their tenures as players on the team's active roster ended in September 2022, and they would become teammates once again when Team Liquid signed them both ahead of the 2024 season. “Willing to IGL, lead and build a team! Can also flex and second IGL,” Enzo said following the announcement. The frenchman also has his sights set on great heights in 2025. “Let's make it to Champs Paris.” Team Liquid's roster overhaul comes following less-than-desirable results in their 2024 season. Their performance was peaked by a 5th-6th place finish at EMEA Stage 1 . It was also the first season that saw the team fail to qualify for an international event. “Tough year for us so Liquid have allowed me to explore my options as a restricted F/A,” Mistic said following the announcement. Jamppi was on the Team Liquid team that won the 2023 EMEA League . Most known for his initiator play, his 1.16 rating across four maps in the grand final against FNATIC will be fresh in the minds of Liquid fans. “I'll never ever forget all the support you all have given me,” Jamppi said following the announcement. “It is still my goal to bring this organization big success.” Both Mistic and Jamppi stated that they are open to opportunities in NA, EMEA and APAC. Team Liquid is now: Ayaz " nAts " Akhmetshin Georgio " keiko " Sanassy Nico " Harmii " Harms Eamon " cauzed " Drea (Manager) Emil " eMIL " Sandgren (Head coach) Jake " Bacon9 " Lloyd (Analyst)

title: NAVI allows Zyppan to explore options
cleaned_content: Pontus " Zyppan " Eek has announced that Natus Vincere has allowed him to explore his options outside the organization. He still remains under contract as a restricted free agent with NAVI. Zyppan was one of the longest standing members of the NAVI core. Along with ANGE1 and Shao , he was one of the founding members of the original team when they debuted under the FunPlus Phoenix banner all the way back in 2020. Though they were always considered one of the strongest European squads at the time, they were never able to find any major tournament victories early on, falling short in the top four at First Strike and the EU regional Masters 1 in 2021. It was not until 2022, when the additions of ardiis and SUYGETSU launched them to the top as they earned the title of world champions at Masters Copenhagen . They would also place a respectable fourth place at Champions later that year. Zyppan becomes a world champion at Masters Copenhagen (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games). Under NAVI however, Zyppan and the rest of the team were unable to reach the same heights. For the whole 2023 season, they sat squarely in the shadow of their regional rivals in FNATIC , who were dominating the scene, both regionally and internationally. With cNed coming in to replace ardiis, the team struggled to find their footing against international competition, with their highest placement being a top four finish early on at LOCK//IN . Although they qualified for the other two tournaments of the year, they would fail to make it out of the group stage at either of them, a sure fall from the success they had achieved the previous year. In 2024, NAVI hopped to reignite an old flame, bringing back ardiis to re-form the roster that had won Masters Copenhagen. However, the team would drop even further down than they had the year prior. Two defeats at the hands of Team Heretics in Kickoff and Stage 1 knocked them out of contention for both Masters tournaments of the year. After these results, NAVI would make the decision to remove d00mbr0s (previously d00mbr0s) as head coach. The long-standing coach of the roster had been a pivotal part of their success, which became evident when in Stage 2 , they lost their first four matches, all without winning a single map. They would squeak their way into playoffs, but were eliminated at the hands of the Champions bound Team Vitality . Zyppan's removal from the active roster marks the end of one of the longest standing cores left in VCT. Zyppan has expressed willingness to move to any region and fill in any role necessary. Any teams looking to pick up the Masters winner will have to pay his buyout from NAVI. Natus Vincere are now: Kyrylo " ANGE1 " Karasov Andrey " Shao " Kiprsky Dmitry " SUYGETSU " Ilyushin Ardis " ardiis " Svarenieks Oliwer " LATEKS " Fahlander (Head coach) Urszula " Xirreth " Klimczak (Performance coach) Berke " Vlad " Kantürk (Analyst)

title: Oxygen Esports disbands Valorant roster
cleaned_content: This article was updated to reflect dapr and Reduxx's recent announcements of a full team disbanding. After a fourth-place finish in Challengers playoffs and missing out on Ascension, Oxygen Esports has disbanded their Valorant roster of Mitch " mitch " Semago , Logan " skuba " Jenkins , Michael " dapr " Gulino , Andrew " Verno " Maust , Yassin " Reduxx " Aboulalazm and in addition to head coach Malkolm " bonkar " Rench and assistant coach, Rustun " Rustun " Lusk . Oxygen entered into NA with its academy roster in 2022, featuring emerging talents like Reduxx and Verno, who would eventually join the main lineup. However, they did not participate in VCT. By the end of 2022, Oxygen replaced their academy team with a squad designed to compete in Challengers and ascend to the Americas League. Retaining Verno, they added seasoned players, ex-C9 pro mitch and controller-player skuba. The team easily qualified for Challengers and steadily improved over the season, bolstered by Reduxx's return after he reached the age threshold. Nevertheless, a loss to eventual Ascension winner, The Guard , ended their playoff run at fourth place. mitch, who attended Champions 2021 with C9, took up the reins of IGL for his new role on Oxygen (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games) Heading into 2024, Oxygen added Masters-winning sentinel dapr, forming the latest iteration of the roster. They dominated the offseason, winning multiple tournaments, including the Ludwig x Tarik Invitational 2 , and were favorites to reach Ascension . Early in the year, they lived up to expectations, achieving a 3-2 regular season record and winning the Mid-Season Cup . They continued their strong performance into the Split 2 Playoffs , but an early upset to M80 placed them in the lower bracket. Oxygen then rebounded by defeating top-seeded DarkZero Esports . However, a surprise loss to TSM in the lower round 3 ended their season in fourth place again. So far, the organization has not announced whether it plans to continue participating in NA Challengers in 2025 or is permanently exiting the scene. Despite missing out on Ascension, the former Oxygen squad, now free agents, will be compelling options for Partnership teams looking to rebuild for 2025, though Reduxx will turn 18 midway through next season. Head coach bonkar and assistant coach Rustun are other high-profile options, often praised for turning Oxygen into Ascension contender.

title: Riot announces finalized details for VCT Ascension Pacific
cleaned_content: Riot has announced finalized plans for this year's VCT Ascension Pacific , which will be held in Jakarta. The event was initially scheduled to be held in Tokyo but was relocated due to “significant event production delays and tournament quality concerns,” according to Riot. The event will now be held in Jakarta at the BritAma arena, which has a capacity of 5,000. With the announcement, Riot also announced a finalized version of the ten-team, double-elimination format. Riot says that teams were “grouped and drawn into brackets based on their region's results from last year's Ascension.” Teams from the Singapore/Malaysia region and the Japan region also received byes as BLEED and SCARZ were the finalists from both regions last year. Additionally, teams from Thailand, Taiwan, South Korea, and India finished at the bottom of last year's group stage, meaning they were seeded as the lowest four teams in this year's competition. The competition kicks off on Friday, September 20, and three matches will be played per day until the lower quarterfinals. All matches will be best-of-three, while the lower and grand finals will be best-of-five. The winner of the grand finals on Sunday, September 29 will earn a spot in the VCT Pacific League next year. The ten teams qualified for Ascension are: RIDDLE ORDER Sin Prisa Gaming Revenant Esports FULL SENSE BOOM Esports NAOS Rapid Lofi Disguised Oblivion Force Justice For Tomorrow

title: M8 TaKaS to explore options for 2025
cleaned_content: On Thursday, Jonathan " TakaS " Paupard announced that his time with Gentle Mates appears to be coming to an end, as the team is open to letting him walk. TaKaS's contract with Gentle Mates runs through the 2025 season, but he says the team has “allowed me to explore my options for 2025.” The Frenchman started his Valorant career in 2020 and has played for several teams based in France, including Karmine Corp and Team BDS . He joined Gentle Mates in January of 2023 and played a crucial role in the organization's run at a title-clinching Challengers League France run and eventually EMEA Ascension as the team's duelist. While he almost exclusively played Jett in 2023, his role would change slightly as the team entered VCT in 2024. Still on the duelist role, he would play different agents such as Yoru, Neon and Raze while the team also experimented with him on Gekko and Omen. After losing two games to start EMEA Kickoff and then missing out on the EMEA Stage 1 playoffs by one game, they finished Stage 2 ranked tenth, just one spot above last-placed KOI on head-to-head record. Gentle Mates is now: Beyazit " beyAz " Körpe Thomas " Kada " Johner Nathan " nataNk " Bocqueho Wailers " Wailers " Locart Logan " logaN " Corti Florentin " Derly " Derly (Assistant coach) Kevin " madc " Ducourtioux (Head coach)

title: Derke enters restricted free agency
cleaned_content: Nikita " Derke " Sirmitev has announced that he is now a restricted free agent. While his contract with FNATIC has not yet expired and it is possible for him to stay with the team, he is actively seeking other offers for the 2025 season. "We decided that it's best to allow Derke to explore his opportunities while we explore what the future of [FNATIC] Valorant can look like," commented Team Director CoJo . Few players have a longer or more storied history with an organization than Derke. The Finnish duelist has been with FNATIC since April 2021 and is the only other current player besides Boaster that was on the team during their first international grand finals appearance at Masters Rekyjavik . Since then, he has qualified for almost every VCT international event and has been a top player at nearly every event he has played in. One of the most decorated players the game has to offer. FNATIC kept their star-studded roster coming into 2024 following a dominant 2023 season, where they became the first and only back-to-back VCT champions of LOCK//IN and Masters Tokyo before placing fourth at Champions 2023 . While still a strong team in 2024, they were unable to replicate their previous heights, failing to qualify for Masters Madrid after being eliminated in Kickoff by Karmine Corp . They briefly appeared to find recovery after winning EMEA Stage 1 , but disappointed with an 7th-8th finish at Masters Shanghai . Stage 2 saw Leo temporarily stepping down due to health issues and hiro taking his place. Once again, FNATIC triumphed regionally as the champions of EMEA Stage 2 but were unable to do the same internationally, falling to Sentinels and placing 5th-6th at Champions 2024 . Despite the loss, Derke shone individually with the highest ACS and KPR at Champions at 257.4 and 0.92 respectively and continues to demonstrate himself one of the strongest and most consistent duelists in the world. FNATIC is currently: Jake " Boaster " Howlett Emirhan " hiro " Kat Timofey " Chronicle " Khromov Emir " Alfajer " Ali Beder Leo " Leo " Jannesson Domagoj " doma " Fancev (Sub) Chris " Elmapuddy " Tebbit (Head coach)

title: ZETA Division’s Laz announces retirement
cleaned_content: ZETA DIVISION 's Ushida " Laz " Koji has announced that he is moving to the organization's content division and retiring from competitive Valorant. “The reason behind this decision is that, although I tried to focus on VALORANT as much as possible, throughout the season I started to feel that it has become too physically demanding to maintain it,” he said. He has been in the competitive Valorant scene since 2020, previously playing for Absolute JUPITER before joining ZETA in 2021. Before Valorant, he made his professional debut in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive in 2015. In 2022, Laz and ZETA Division went on an eight-match winning streak through Japan Stage 1 Challengers and Japan Stage 1 Challengers Playoffs to qualify for Masters Reykjavik , where they finished third behind OpTic Gaming and LOUD . They would also reach Champions in 2022. Laz of ZETA DIVISION at VALORANT Champions Los Angeles (Photo by Stefan Wisnoski/Riot Games) In 2023, Laz and his team achieved a 5th-6th placed finish in the Pacific League and would go undefeated in the Pacific Last Chance Qualifier to reach their second consecutive Champions event. “I still want to contribute to the competitive scene, but in a different way,” he said. “I will be glad if you can support the Valorant esports scene with me.” ZETA Division is now: Yushin " yuran " Hato Hiroki " hiroronn " Yanai Yuma " Dep " Hashimoto Shota " SugarZ3ro " Watanabe Carlos " Carlao " Mohn (Head coach) " nokaze37 " (Analyst) " gya9 " (Analyst)

title: EDward Gaming conquer Champions 2024 in historic win for China
cleaned_content: One year ago, EDward Gaming put China on the map by taking the region's first win on the international stage at Masters Tokyo and going on to place top six at Champions 2023 . Today, EDG triumphed over Team Heretics 3-2 in the grand final of Champions 2024 and conquered the Valorant Champions Tour in one of the greatest matches of all time. The five-map series played out on Haven, Sunset, Lotus, Bind, and Abyss. EDG leveraged their double map ban as the upper bracket finalists to remove Ascent and Icebox. Heretics won Haven 13-6, EDG won Sunset 13-4 and Lotus 13-9, Heretics won Bind 13-11, and EDG took Abyss 13-9. Both teams suffered disappointment in Masters Madrid and heartbreak in Masters Shanghai , but returned home and continued to build consistency and resilience. Both blazed fiery paths through Seoul, taking down every challenger to meet in the grand final for the first time since Shanghai. The ultimate prize. (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games) For EDG, to win would mean truly shattering the ceiling for China and taking the region's first international trophy after an undefeated playoffs run. For Heretics, winning would mean avenging the pain of falling short at Shanghai and proving the growth and potential of a team with four faces fresh out of Challengers. “I have always dreamt about this moment,” nobody said in the pre-match teaser . “This time, I will realize my dreams.” Heretics controlled Haven After their unusual Sage composition failed against Sentinels, Heretics shifted all five agents to mirror EDG's more standard Neon and double initiator on EDG's first map pick. EDG took the first of many pistols, but Heretics dominated the buy rounds with the steadfast trading and varied defensive setups that brought them to the final in the first place. Wo0t 's Breach utility shuts the door in EDG's faces. Heretics secured a resounding 9-3 half by consistently burning down the clock. They then chained a pistol of their own into an eventual 13-6 win. Both Neon players demonstrated impressive fragging performances; ZmjjKK picked up 22 kills to 15 deaths while MiniBoo found 17 kills to 12 deaths. However, it was RieNs who topped the scoreboard as Sova with a 1.52 rating, a 95% KAST, and an outsized 205 ADR. Sunset was pure EDG domination The players of EDG recovered immediately after dropping Haven. A surgical 4K from CHICHOO won the bonus round for EDG, snowballing into an overwhelming 11-1 half. Heretics were unable to find an answer to ZmjjKK's constant Neon slide entries and multikills, which included an ace in round 8. The duelist ended the first half with as many kills as all of Heretics combined at 18. Smoggy 's 1v2 in the second pistol round slammed the coffin shut for Heretics as EDG won Sunset 13-4. ZmjjKK crushed the opposition with a tremendous 1.87 rating, 22 kills to 9 deaths, 248 ADR, and seven first kills. Lotus was chaos, but EDG thrived in it While the previous maps had been one-sided, Lotus was a back-and-forth brawl. The first six rounds alone saw three thrifties and perhaps the most impressive ace of the tournament by CHICHOO in round 6. Neither team could shake off the other, resulting in a 6-6 first half. Whether on Cypher or Omen, CHICHOO always goes above and beyond. The defining moment came in round 20. S1Mon found himself in a 1v2 postplant against benjyfishy and MiniBoo. benjyfishy placed his Killjoy Lockdown to flush him out, but the Breach player stood his ground and sprayed down both seconds before detainment in a tournament-defining clutch. S1Mon makes the boldest play possible under pressure. Spurred on by their rookie's heroics, EDG ran away with Lotus to a 13-9 win. Still, it was CHICHOO once again putting up impossible numbers with a 1.71 rating, 339 ACS, and 27 kills to only 13 deaths. Heretics dug deep on Bind A do-or-die lead for EDG demanded even greater heights from Heretics. Both teams refused to yield for even a moment as every single round produced higher tempos, sharper frags, unlikelier thrifties, and yet another 6-6 first half. The breakaway moment for Heretics seemingly came in round 19, where MiniBoo won two crucial duels with the spike in hand to take Heretics to an 11-8 lead that turned into 12-8. But EDG refused to lose. The next three rounds consisted of magical plays from the Chinese squad: a tense 1v1 from S1mon, a Brimstone Incendiary body block from CHICHOO, and an Operator collateral from ZmjjKK. Just when it seemed that another ZmjjKK ace had secured overtime, Boo 's postmortem Incendiary burned down the time and stole away the map 13-11. ZmjjKK 's ace matters not with Boo 's Incendiary on the spike. EDG decided it all on Abyss An entire year of victories and defeats came down to Abyss, and it was EDG who took early control with a blend of unbreakable postplants, startling mid pushes, and both pistol rounds to take a 10-4 lead. Heretics attempted to mount a comeback, bringing the score back to 11-9, but ZmjjKK broke the hearts of Los Niños with four tournament-winning Guardian kills in round 21. EDG brought Abyss home 13-9 along with the entire championship. The round that ended it all. With this victory, EDG deliver Heretics yet another second place finish and make history as the first global champions from China after the region received official access to the game two years later than everyone else. ZmjjKK made his own piece of history by breaking the VCT best-of-five kill record of 105 with a generational 111 total kills, 26 of which were first kills, and was crowned the first ever official Champions MVP. S1mon also finds himself a world champion at his very first international event. To EDG, this victory means that China will never again be underestimated. “Why can't we get the championship? And now, the whole world [is going to] focus on VCT CN FPS,” ZmjjKK declared. They are your 2024 Valorant Champions. (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games)

title: Team Heretics topple Leviátan, advance to Champions 2024 grand final
cleaned_content: Team Heretics sealed their place in the grand finals of Champions 2024 , reaching their second international grand final of the year after a dominant 3-1 victory over LEVIATÁN . The best-of-five series was played out on Icebox, Sunset, Abyss, and Lotus. Icebox and Abyss were Leviátan's map picks, while Sunset and Lotus were Team Heretics' picks. Team Heretics won Icebox 13-7, Team Heretics won Sunset 15-13, Leviátan won Abyss 13-7, and Team Heretics won Lotus 13-3. The last time these two teams met was in the upper semifinals, which resulted in a 2-0 Leviátan victory. Both maps of that match were tight, separated by five total rounds, and this series proved to be a close one until the fateful fourth map. Icebox, Leviátan's go-to map pick in the last four matches, produced four overtime wins for the Americas Stage 2 champions. They went back to the well on Saturday, but could not find the success they had previously. Despite winning five rounds in their attack half, more than their three against EDward Gaming the day before, it was Leviátan's defending half that struggled against Team Heretics. Fueled by MiniBoo , who finished with a server-high 19 kills on the map, Team Heretics handed Leviátan their first loss on Icebox since the Americas Stage 2 upper finals. Team Heretics entered halftime after securing eight attacking rounds. It felt like they carried their momentum from the first map into Sunset, but as the teams switched sides, it was evident that the map had an attacking tilt in this match. Leviátan claimed eight of the next ten rounds, reaching map point, but Team Heretics won two to force overtime. In the second set of overtime rounds, Leviátan had little to no trouble getting onto a benjyfishy -defended A site, but with the spike planted, Team Heretics executed a five-man retake that dropped just one player and secured them a second map. A clean 5v5 retake from TH. MiniBoo again shined with 22 kills, seven of them being a map-high in first kills, while initiator player RieNs had a game-leading 25 kills. Leviátan heated up, and began hitting their shots in the second half of Sunset, but now needed an emphatic reverse-sweep for any chance at lifting the Champions trophy. Map three was Abyss, a map that both teams played the day before. Leviátan lost their three-map upper final on Abyss, while Team Heretics won their three-map lower semifinal on it. Leviátan ran into a brick wall on their attacking half against EDG, and it was more of the same against Team Heretics. They finished the half down 7-5, and needed a fiery start to their defense. Well-coordinated retakes, highlighted by the layers of utility from players like Mazino , arguably VCT's best Harbor player, made for strong retakes, giving Team Heretics a hard time holding site post-plant. Mazino even managed a defuse to tie up the map, a moment that Team Heretics' in-game leader Boo was milliseconds away from stopping. It's hard to mention Leviátan's success without touching on the flanks of C0M , one of two remaining former Champions winners, alongside teammate aspas . One of those trademark flanks helped his team secure the first of a four-round streak to take Abyss. A trademark C0M flank to help Leviátan secure a 3v3 retake. On Lotus, Team Heretics left Leviátan clawing for answers. On several occasions, an incorrect gamble stack stranded their opponents. Their attack half was dominant, resulting in an 11-1 halftime score. In the first half, Team Heretics had five rounds in which at least four players survived to the end. Leviátan clinched the must-win pistol and anti-eco rounds, but the bonus round was the true test of whether or not they could come back to win. The bonus round resulted in Team Heretics surviving four players and bringing themselves to match point, where they continued to dominate. Continued dominance from Team Heretics brought them past the finish line. Team Heretics' RieNs finished with a server-high 1.22 rating and 68 kills, continuing his potential rookie of the year campaign. Leviátan was top-fragged by tex , who finished with 57 kills. “We were all our own worst enemy today,” Leviátan head coach Itopata said. “We just shut down completely. I think today, out of all the days it could happen, was probably the worst possible time.” Five first-time champions will be crowned. aspas and C0M previously won Champions with LOUD and Evil Geniuses , respectively, but with the loss will end their campaign to become two-time champions. Leviátan finished their Champions campaign third and will end their 2024 VCT season having lifted the Americas Stage 2 trophy. After avenging themselves against Leviátan, Team Heretics will move to play EDward Gaming in the grand final. The two teams met in the playoffs of Masters Shanghai , which resulted in a 2-0 victory for the European team. Seoul will be Team Heretics' third grand final this year after Shanghai and EMEA Stage 1 . Sunday's best-of-five grand final will take place at INSPIRE Arena at 4 p.m. KST.

title: Team Heretics beat Sentinels, will face Leviátan in lower finals
cleaned_content: In the first elimination match in front of the INSPIRE Arena crowd in South Korea, Team Heretics beat Sentinels 2-1 to secure their spot in the lower finals at Champions 2024. This match was a rematch of an early game at Masters Madrid , where Sentinels helped eliminate Team Heretics early on. The North American team eventually won the first international tournament of the year, but Sentinels weren't able to defeat Team Heretics at the biggest event of the year. Sentinels picked Haven to start the series, leading Team Heretics to pick Icebox, which left Abyss as the potential third map. Heretics decided to gamble with their team composition on Haven, picking Sage and Killjoy alongside a solo Gekko initiator. Picking attack side first, Heretics lost their pistol round and frequently focused on planting B. Sentinels converted their bonus, hitting key shots early on to prevent the Heretics B post-plants from working out. Yet, when Heretics won their first round on C site down 4-0, they won five rounds in a row and ended the half only down 7-5. TenZ stepped up and got a 4K to win Sentinels their second pistol round on Haven. Despite not winning their bonus round, johnqt called a clean second half to finish the map 13-8 and start the series up 1-0. It was the star Omen from Sentinels that took over Haven, as TenZ ended the map with 29 kills, a 41% headshot percentage, and a 2.01 match rating. Icebox had no big composition differences between the two teams aside from Heretics keeping MiniBoo on his signature Neon. The map started with a benjyfishy flank and a pistol round win for Heretics, but TenZ wasn't letting an agent swap onto KAY/O slow him down. TenZ gets four crispy kills as KAY/O against Team Heretics. Sentinels played retakes well, with each player having their moments sniping Heretics down. However, as soon as Sentinels hit six round wins, Heretics adjusted their tempo and won some clutches to keep the map within reach. Sentinels led 7-5 at halftime, just as they did on Haven. Heretics won their second pistol round and secured their bonus to take their first lead in the series. Sentinels kept the rounds close, but Boo led Heretics to win Icebox 13-9, leaving Abyss as the decider for one of these team's Champions hopes. It all came down to Abyss, with Sentinels making their Champions debut on the map. Heretics won their pistol round, and Boo kept his form up from Icebox to secure his team the bonus round. Sentinels took a needed timeout to get their first round win on Abyss, but RieNs caught fire as Sova to prevent any first-half comebacks. Heretics entered the half up 8-4, in control of the map. Sentinels needed to win the final pistol of the series, and they did just that off of a zekken ace. There was a scent of a comeback in the air, but Heretics were quick to snuff it out off the back of RieNs. MiniBoo got a 4K to put Heretics up 11-6, and that round ended any chance of a comeback from Sentinels. Heretics defeated Sentinels 13-7 and won the series 2-1. With this win, Team Heretics will face LEVIATÁN in the Champions 2024 lower finals for a chance to make the grand finals against EDward Gaming . Sentinels, the fourth seed from Americas, finished the tournament in fourth place.

title: EDward Gaming take down Leviátan, advance to China's first-ever international grand final
cleaned_content: EDward Gaming clinched their place in the grand finals of Champions 2024 with a triumphant 2-1 victory over LEVIATÁN , sending the Americas Region's no. 1 seed down to the lower finals. The three-map series was played out on Icebox, Lotus, and Abyss. Icebox was Leviátan's map pick and Lotus was EDG's map pick, leaving Abyss as the decider. Leviátan won Icebox 16-14, EDG won Lotus 13-4, and EDG won Abyss 13-11. EDward Gaming on stage before their upper final match vs. Leviátan (Photo by Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games). Friday's match was Champions 2024's first in the 15,000-seat INSPIRE Arena, where the competition's top four teams will be decided. Leviátan picked Icebox, a map that had been a favorite of theirs, albeit a shaky one. They had picked it in their last three matches and won all three times, each result going to overtime. EDG began on attack. The South American side seemed poised to make this Icebox different. It started with a strong defense side, which saw them clinch nine rounds thanks to a series of great retakes, highlighted by Mazino 's Harbor. EDG's team comp consisted of four agents whose utility could be lethal in the post-plant, but they could not capitalize in those situations. They planted the bomb seven times in the half, winning just one of those rounds. Even after being blown out in the first half, EDG held their heads high. A pistol, anti-eco, and bonus round snowballed into them winning the first six rounds of the half. A pair of Leviátan timeouts did not deter them, as they tied up the score after facing what looked to be an insurmountable lead. After a quiet first half, ZmjjKK seemed to have heated up. He'd finish the map with a server-high 28 kills, but in the end, it wouldn't be enough. Seven of those kills were operator kills. With the teams knotted at nine rounds apiece, a moment of heroics saved Leviátan from losing a seventh straight round. aspas flicks, ZmjjKK heroics, and chaotic gunfights. Round 19 had everything. After the EDG run, both teams traded punches before heading to overtime. In the run-up to this match, Leviátan had three consecutive overtime Icebox victories against Team Vitality , G2 Esports , and Team Heretics . On this particular day, Icebox was defense-sided. Until the third set of overtime rounds, no attack-sided OT rounds were won. In round 30, Leviátan finally found the soft spot of EDG's defense, clinching a 16-14 victory. In the end, Leviátan's nine first-half victories gave them a cushion in a less-than-ideal attacking half, and eventually their fourth straight overtime victory on Icebox. On Lotus, EDG began on attack and looked to flip the script of map one, dominating on the attack-sided, three-site map. After bolting out to a 5-1 lead, EDG seemed to lose their grip on the map. They'd regain control of it, finishing the half with an 8-4 lead. The second half was more of the same for EDG. They'd win four straight rounds, with their 12th win being an exciting clutch for their star duelist. KangKang's 1v3 clutch kills Leviátan's momentum and brings EDG to map point. While ZmjKK is most well-known for his seemingly impossible operator shots and fearless playstyle, his Neon on Lotus highlighted his movement, sliding around the Leviátan players. He had six first kills on the map, matching the combined output of his opponents. His supporting cast on Lotus shone through. Smoggy , playing on Clove, finished with a server-high 19 kills. No EDG player finished with more deaths than kills, while tex was the only Leviátan player to finish the map positive, with a team-leading 17 kills. Lotus was Leviátan's first map loss after seven consecutive victories, with their last loss coming in the group stage to Trace Esports . With both sides split at one map each, Abyss would decide who earned their way to a grand final and who faced elimination in the lower bracket. It was still anybody's match by halftime, with both sides tied at 6-6. The question entering 2024 was whether or not EDG could replicate their regional dominance on the international stage. On Abyss, going into the second half, it was whether or not EDG's zero-sentinel team comp could defend against the Leviátan attack. On attack, the Americas region's no. 1 seed laid claim on mid, with aspas's Outlaw making space for his team to the defenders' side of the map. All the while, the story for EDG was their ability to lock down the A site of Abyss. Trailing 10-7, EDG called their final timeout. Their opponents still had two to burn, meaning they had their opportunities to stop any momentum EDG might find. Both teams eventually found themselves tied at 11 rounds each, with the star duelists of either side armed with operators. EDG reach match point against Leviátan, courtesy of three kills from ZmjKK. EDG wrapped up business the following round, only dropping one player and breaking past the barrier to reach the Chinese region's first-ever international grand final. Leviátan's two losses in their Champions 2024 campaign were to Chinese teams. Leviátan head coach Itopata said that there are similarities between Trace and EDG, but that there are also takeaways from Friday's loss. “They're trading better than us. They are playing more together than us,” he said following the match. “EDG individually is a lot, a lot better. If you give them something, they're gonna run away with the game. We should know now for the grand final to not do that.” ZmjKK finished with a server-high 61 kills across all maps, including a server-leading 20 first kills. Teammates CHICHOO and Smoggy finished with 59 and 58, respectively. Leviátan's Mazino finished with a team-high 57, while star duelist aspas ended with 53. With the loss, Leviátan will play the winner of Sentinels and Team Heretics in the best-of-five lower final. EDG now advance to the first international grand final in its region's history and await the victor of that lower final. The lower final will take place on Saturday at 4 p.m. KST, and the grand final will be on Sunday at the same time.

title: VLR Rating 2.0 Update
cleaned_content: The VLR rating has received an update, and here is what you need to know. As we approach the close of two years of VCT competition since the original rating was released, a modernization is in order. The game has changed significantly over the past two years, and the rating has been exposed to far more eyes across far more games than it could have been in development. The core mechanics of the rating described in this explainer article , are still in place. However, it was determined that the rating skewed somewhat too heavily towards passivity relative to aggression. While it is important to capture the impact of supportive players that isn't reflected in their pure kill and death numbers, this update focuses around a small rebalancing of the scales against passive play. The original rating was a combination of five factors: a kill contribution, death contribution, assist contribution, damage contribution, and survival contribution. The kill and death contributions were by far the most impactful, and they incorporated information about things like economic advantages, trading, and weighting the player differential for each fight. Previously the fight weighting was based on the number of players alive on each team when a fight took place. For example, a kill in a 5v5 is worth more than a kill in a 5v2. However, turning a 4v5 into a 4v4 was worth less than the maximum weight because the player differential when the fight took place was greater than zero. It can be argued that turning a one player disadvantage into an equal situation has an equivalent impact to turning an equal situation into a one player advantage on average. Rating 2.0 makes that the case. Even though the trading logic in the original rating was modified to not count against a player if it led to team success, and top duelists still had strong average ratings compared to many other agents, aggressive players were still frequently hampered by the trading modifier. In Rating 2.0, the effect of trading on a fight has been reduced. The original rating was balanced on numbers from mid-2021 to mid-2022, but Valorant has balance changes which can significantly affect the rating. Right after the public release of the rating, patch 5.12 threw a spanner in the works with assist tails . Essentially, KAY/0, the controllers, and certain initiators suddenly saw a massive uptick in their assist totals. KAY/0 getting assists up to three seconds after his eight second suppression has expired or controllers getting assists two seconds after someone simply touched their smoke blew up a bunch of ratings in ways that didn't reflect their actual value. The overall weight of assists in Rating 2.0 has been reduced. The survival contribution was intended to be a metric that rewarded players for saving valuable guns into the next round. This entire component was removed from the rating to focus it on the value a player provides within each round. The original weighting of this contribution was small, so removing it has a fairly minimal effect, but it is another minor chip in the armor of passive play. The composite rating is roughly a bell curve, and it can be scaled to whatever mean and standard deviation is convenient. Although future balance changes will likely shift the distribution of ratings slightly, Rating 2.0 is set to have an average rating of 1.0 and a standard deviation of ⅓. There are some fringe cases, where certain ratings shift dramatically, (see this game from kaajak where he originally had a 1.03 rating but now has a 1.20), but overall, the majority of ratings will not change by more than a couple percentage points.

title: Global Esports roster become Restricted Free Agents
cleaned_content: The 2024 Global Esports player roster have entered restricted free agency, per a tweet from the Global Esports founder. This change comes soon after releasing their coaching staff and announcing open tryouts for their 2025 roster. Following an unsuccessful 2023 season, Global Esports made a complete overhaul of their roster, with not a single player from the starting five making a return for 2024. Their new roster consisted of a crop of underdog players from all around the world. The rebuild started with promoting their longstanding member and previous sixth man, Abhirup " Lightningfast " Choudhury , as well as acquiring Benedict " Benkai " Tan from the bench of Paper Rex in exchange for the Indonesian superstar Monyet . Former Guild player Russel " Russ " Mendes would then be added as the team's in-game leader, who had come off the back of a year of playing in the European VCLs. Similarly, Niko " Polvi " Polvinen would come from the depths of EMEA challengers to join the roster, along with Gary " blaZek1ng " Dastin from the Pacific Ascension semi-finalists of BOOM Esports . Going into the 2024 season, Global Esports was not very highly rated in comparison to their competition in Pacific. They looked to defy these expectations early on with a win against the Ascension winning BLEED during Kickoff , but two losses at the hands of ZETA DIVISION put Masters Madrid out of their sights. Stage 1 was a similar story, with their 2-3 record being insufficient to qualify them to playoffs. With their poor performance in Stage 1, they would've needed a miraculous Stage 2 for the team to come anywhere close to qualifying to playoffs, let alone Champions. They would only pick up one more win for the rest of the season, ending with a record of 3-7, and placing ninth in the league. Global Esports after their win against Bleed during Kickoff Global Esports is looking towards a complete overhaul of the entire team going into 2025. A new coaching staff as well as a roster found through open tryouts will bring a completely fresh look for the Indian organization. Their current player roster will also be put through the team's tryouts, with a chance to return to the active roster in 2025, but have been allowed to explore other options during the off season. Global Esports are now: Hose " taeri " Son (손호세) (Manager) Vatsal " Vatsal " Uniyal (Staff)

title: Riot announces VCT 2025 details
cleaned_content: Riot has unveiled details on the 2025 Valorant Champions Tour calendar and changes to the overall circuit. The revamped system includes new formats, an expanded calendar spanning from January to October, and will implement the new Ascension changes . Additionally, Riot has revealed the next locations for Masters and Champions, as well as announced plans for new in-game cosmetics based on the VCT. In 2025, Bangkok and Toronto will each host a Masters event, while Champions will take place in Paris. Riot also confirmed Champions will be held in China for 2026 and the Americas for 2027. VCT 2025 will run from January through October with a reworked format The 2025 season will begin in January with Kickoff. The new year brings a new format, as each region will seed their 12 teams directly into a double-elimination bracket, forgoing the group stage and play-in stage from 2024 . The top two teams from each tournament will qualify to Masters Bangkok. For the regular season, Stage playoffs will expand to eight teams, compared to the six from 2024. In Stage 1, the top three teams from each region will qualify to Masters Toronto, for a total of 12 teams. Unlike this year, Stage 1 results will not affect the Stage 2 standings. Eight teams will advance to the playoffs, with the top teams qualifying directly to Champions 2025. The final Champions slots from each region will be determined based on championship points, which have been reworked for 2025. Riot will confirm further details on their points system at a later date. Finally, Riot will update the Classic skins for team bundles, as well as release a new capsule similar to the LOCK//IN skins from 2023.

title: Secret part ways with NDG
cleaned_content: Team Secret have announced the release of Noel " NDG " De Guia from their bench. NDG was added to Team Secret to round out the roster for the 2024 season. Secret had just come off of a season where they were one match away from qualifying to two different international events. With the addition of NDG, they hoped to be able to overcome that final hurdle to the international stage. NDG debuted under the Team Secret banner during the APAC Predator League 2024 tournament, where Secret would sweep the competition with a flawless run in which they didn't drop a single map. He would shine in his new sentinel role, putting up a 1.54 rating in the grand finals of the event. NDG after winning the APAC Predator League. Unfortunately, against other franchised teams, Team Secret would not find as much success, once again failing to reach the international stage. They were eliminated in the Play-Ins of Kickoff , where they were only one round away from defeating Gen.G and denying them their run at Masters Madrid . In Stage 1 , they finished with a decent 3-3 record, one of which included handing Paper Rex their only loss in the regular season of Pacific. However, when it came time for playoffs, they faltered, and fell in the single elimination match against T1 . Before the start of Stage 2 , Team Secret decided to change up their roster, which included the benching of NDG , ending his time playing for the team. He remained on the bench for the rest of the season, where Secret again was unable to qualify to Champions. Team Secret is now: Jessie " JessieVash " Cuyco Adrian " invy " Jiggs Reyes Brheyanne " Wild0reoo " Christ Reyes James " 2GE " Goopio Jeremy " Jremy " Cabrera Yamyam " yamyam yui " Villanueva Yui (Manager) Tim " dummy " Olson (Head coach)

title: pl1xx leaves Wolves Esports after one season
cleaned_content: On Tuesday, Wolves Esports IGL Christopher " pl1xx " Li announced that he is officially a free agent. He has been in the professional Valorant scene since 2020, bouncing around teams all around the world, spanning from the US, Australia, the United Kingdom and China. pl1xx playing for Wolves Esports in Stage 1 (Photo from Wolves Esports ). Since his debut, he's been on four different lower-tier teams' rosters before landing with Wolves Esports as the team's in-game leader this January. He previously played for EXO Clan and BOBO in Australia, Soniqs in the United States, and Weibo Gaming in China. The Chinese-Australian transitioned from CS-GO, and in his first season at the top level of Valorant has a handful of highlights to look back on. Wolves began their 2024 season with a 2-0 win over eventual Champions participants BilliBilli Gaming at China Kickoff , but would lose six of their next eight matches, failing to qualify for the playoffs of Kickoff and China Stage 1 . A better Stage 2 showing for the team saw them win half of their matches and look to contend for a spot at playoffs, but they finished one game behind the top six and saw their season end in July. pl1xx is most well-known for his play on KAY/O, and said that he is looking for an IGL or initiator role to fill in a new team. He said, “I believe my strength lies in mid-rounding and leading.” He also said that he is “prioritising VCT CN/APAC/Ascension offers,” meaning he is likely to stay close to home. Ahead of the 2024 season, Wolves Esports made an ambitious move in an attempt to break into the upper ranks of the Chinese region. They signed pl1xx as part of an eight-man signing class ahead of the season. While some of that eight-man class remain, pl1xx will not be. Wolves Esports are now: Pong " SiuFatBB " Gaa Hei (庞加曦) Chang " V1yA " Rui-min (张睿珉) Huang " Yuicaw " Yung-chieh (黃湧傑) Liu " Spring " Jiunting (刘俊霆) Zhong " balua " Haojun (钟皓钧) " Simple " (Manager) Xie " jungleDSL " Zhilin (谢志凛) (Head coach) Lee " CheongGak " Il-ho (이일호) (Coach) Chen " chaPPie " Long (陈龙) (Assistant coach)

title: Team Heretics reach top four with 2-1 over DRX
cleaned_content: Team Heretics have eliminated DRX following a 2-1 win . They are now in the top four at their first-ever Champions appearance, and will next play against Sentinels following their win against FNATIC . DRX, meanwhile, are now eliminated from the event, ending in the top six in the first international tournament in South Korea. This matchup is the first time both teams have played against each other, as DRX had been unable to qualify to either Masters event earlier in the year. Both teams went through roster turmoil during 2024, as DRX saw the need to go through a rebuild and Team Heretics were forced to play with star-substitute paTiTek due to scheduling and visa conflicts . Now at their full potential, the teams were pit against each other in an elimination series at the most important VCT stage of the year. The map veto erred slightly in Team Heretics' favor , as they had more clarity on which maps they preferred and which they could leave out. Ahead of the series, the decider map, Icebox, could be considered a strong end for DRX , but most of their victories had been against weaker regional teams. The map was not uncomfortable for Heretics, however, as they tended to leave it open, only banning it first once since the beginning of Stage 2. The European team's more decisive selection process also left Abyss as the first map, on which Heretics were only slightly less successful than DRX. DRX kicked off the series by denying a retake on their Abyss B plant. A slow, two-pronged approach gave them the anti-eco, and Heretics were able to win the bonus with a quick plant denial. Flashback and BuZz were next to show up, granting the hometown team a pair of rounds to go up with a 4-1 lead. Three ultimates and a MiniBoo 3K helped Heretics close the gap, setting the score at 4-3. A back-and-forth ending at 5-5 led to both teams' respective timeouts, the second of which helped DRX close out the half 7-5. DRX recover from a 3v5 with well placed defensive utility Now on the defense, DRX extended their two-round streak, taking their second pistol and winning the anti-eco with ease. Despite a Boo lurking double-kill, DRX recovered the bonus round by using defensive utility to force mistakes from Heretics. A Heretics timeout was unfruitful, as Flashback showed up in early rounds and DRX's player advantage helped deny Boo's Astra post-plants. The map ended unceremoniously, with BeYN and MaKo finishing off a 2v2 and closing out Abyss 13-5. “We had our eye on Abyss since it first came out,” DRX coach termi said after map one. “We thought we could take on Heretics with that map pick.” His counterpart, Heretics coach neilzinho , was more optimistic on the second map. “That was shambolic,” neil said regarding their Abyss performance. “[Sunset] is always a map we're comfortable on,” he added. “We've been looking to play against certain teams; DRX is one of them.” Team Heretics changed their composition from Neon to Raze, keen for redemption on Sunset . They proved as much on defense, taking their first pistol of the half and bringing the bonus round down to the wire. Four more rounds followed for the European squad, as they consistently suffocated DRX's offensive attempts. DRX were able to recover, however, as they took an eco round and were able to use their set executes to break open the B site. With BuZz in the lead, DRX closed out the half 7-5. Heretics use their opponent's timeout to adapt and play a more straightforward round A slow pistol round helped set Heretics up for an anti-retake plant, putting control back into the Masters finalists' hands. Team Heretics continued playing with both wings of the map, using timings and well-placed utility to mask their intentions. A pause was called for by DRX after 11-5, giving the team a window to plan and reset for the rest of the half. Two fast rounds followed from Heretics, the adaptation confusing the defense and ending map two 13-5, tying the score at 1-1. Heading into Icebox, benjyfishy helped win a third pistol round for his team. Their defense started off successfully, taking an early 3-1 lead. Round five began in similar fashion, early kills leaving two DRX members stranded in mid. The round was not over, however, and Heretics began peeking into MaKo, who eliminated the defenders one by one until he ended up in a 1v1. The extra eliminations gave him a Viper's Pit, and MaKo closed out the ace. Two more rounds went DRX's way, planting on a weaker A site and giving them the lead. A Heretics timeout reinforced their problem site, but DRX poked and prodded the defense, brute-forcing their way to a sixth round win. The South Korean squad continued insisting on the site, eventually dropping a thrifty round. A Sova-Killjoy post-plant gave them the next round, and Wo0t clawed back a B retake to end the half 7-5 in DRX's favor. Wo0t saves his team from disaster The hometown team extended their lead in the second half after a stuck defuse from Flashback. Heretics stabilized after winning the bonus round, taking an additional pair of rounds without much resistance. The 9-8 scoreline led to a DRX pause, enabling Flashback and Foxy9 to take a point. Heretics continued with their A plan, which ended in success and weakened the defense's economy. The plant switched sites against the low buy, but returned to A to find success and take the lead 11-10. The European squad's continued offensive success had left them with an ultimate and economic advantage that was impossible to overcome. Despite repeat incursions into a fully-reinforced A site, they eventually left DRX with no economy or ultimates compared to Heretics' three ults. The Champions débutants took the anti-eco by using a Lockdown to plant and a Viper's Pit for their post-plant. RieNs opened their match point with his own ultimate, eliminating BuZz and leaving two more at half health. Team Heretics rushed to rotate, ending Icebox 13-10 and moving forward with a 2-1 victory. Heretics' attack eventually left DRX with an insurmountable ultimate and credit deficit. “We can play well, everybody knows that,” Boo said after their win. “I'm actually really happy to play Sentinels,” he added. His brother and Heretics spearhead, MiniBoo, was emotional following the series. “After the first game I just thought, ‘I don't want to sit another six months without doing anything and regret this day',” he said. “I did everything I could to benefit our odds to win this game,” he added. Team Heretics will now play against Sentinels in the lower semifinal , a rematch of the European team's international debut . Both teams were Masters finalists this year, but Sentinels were the only one of the pair to win an event . DRX are now eliminated on home soil, their rebuilt roster matching the team's previous Champions finish .

title: Sentinels go the distance, eliminate FNATIC
cleaned_content: In a matchup between two teams with a rivalry spanning over three years, Sentinels defeated FNATIC 2-1, eliminating them from Champions 2024 . The three-map series was played out on Sunset, Bind, and Lotus. Sunset was Sentinels's pick, Bind was Fnatic's, and Lotus was the decider. Sentinels won Sunset 13-11, Fnatic won Bind 13-9, and Sentinels won Lotus 13-6. Sunday's elimination match was the fourth-ever meeting between the two international powerhouses. Sentinels defeated Fnatic twice, 2-0 and 3-0, en route to capturing their first international trophy at Masters Reykjavik . They'd meet again two seasons later in the first round of LOCK//IN São Paulo , where Fnatic would claim a 2-0 revenge victory. On Sunset, EMEA's number-one seed got off to a flying start. They won the first three rounds of their attacking half, giving up just three kills to Sentinels in the process. They played solid team Valorant, with every peek having an accompanied teammate and every post-plant having layered utility to give them the space needed for the spike to detonate. Facing an 8-4 deficit at halftime, Sentinels regrouped and came back swinging. They won four of their first five attack rounds, seeming to have a read on Fnatic's defensive protocols. In-game leader [johnqt] had a great read on what Fnatic wanted to do, and when it seemed as though the European team could claw their way back in, Sentinels put a stamp on the map, sealing a 13-11 finish that may have been too close for comfort. SEN's star TenZ snags a crucial 4K to seal the first map. It wasn't just the in-game commanding that johnqt was great at – he was also a great shot on Sunset. He finished with the most kills in the server with a 23-12 scoreline. Fnatic had 15 first kills on the map, but couldn't make the most of their man-advantage scenarios. Sentinels began Bind on the attack and quickly identified the gaps in Fnatic's defense. Unfortunately for them, Fnatic was also adept in their attack half. They'd only give up two rounds en route to a clean 13-9 victory, with their eleventh-round clinching execution leaving Sentinels' economy limped for the rest of the map. Fnatic executes onto B site, forcing Sentinels' last two players to save. In Round 20, holding onto a 10-9 lead with Sentinels threatening to tie the game at 10 apiece, Fnatic executed a near-perfect take onto the B site. Across both Sunset and Bind, both teams made great use of ultimate abilities to seal rounds. Fnatic closed the map 13-9, bringing both teams to Lotus. Sentinels' most recent outing on the map was from their 2-1 loss to EDward Gaming the day before. Sentinels played a relatively clean attacking half to open Lotus, a map widely regarded as attack-sided. Poking and prodding at the Fnatic defense gave Sentinels easy access to either of the three bomb sites, leading to an 8-4 lead. Two of the four round wins came as a result of them running out of time, unable to get the spike planted. Fnatic's Boaster described the defensive half of Lotus as frustrating. “It could've gone either way, but that's just Valorant. It's a frustrating game to be a part of and it can happen,” he said. Similar to Sunset, Fnatic had nine first kills, but could not convert on those man-advantages. “The scoreline says one thing, but our defense should have been reversed in terms of how many rounds they got and how many rounds we got.” In the second half though, Sentinels showed their success in this series wouldn't be exclusive to the attacking half. They'd win the pistol, anti-eco and bonus rounds to reach 11 rounds, just two away from advancing and eliminating Fnatic. Facing an 11-4 deficit, Fnatic had a must-win round on their hands. They managed to plant the spike but with one man falling earlier in the round, a Sentinels retake was made too easy. With a 5-4 man advantage, Sentinels make their B site retake look easy. Fnatic mounted a comeback attempt the following round, clinching two rounds thanks to some time-savvy decision-making from Boaster. Fnatic closed out the following round, bubbling up some momentum, but it was never going to be enough against the economy-backed confidence of Sentinels, leaving them in the dust with a 13-6 scoreline. Derke finished 61-47, having the most kills in the server, while johnqt led his team in kills with a 55-37 scoreline. “It is what it is. I'm not gonna beat myself up about it. I've already had a pretty dog event,” Boaster said with a chuckle following the match. He appeared to be in good spirits, even answering a question from Sentinels' Zellsis , who has been plying his trade as a reporter as of late. With the victory, Sentinels punch their ticket to INSPIRE Arena and will move on to the lower bracket semifinals, awaiting the winner of DRX vs Team Heretics . Meanwhile, Fnatic's Champions 2024 campaign and 2024 VCT season comes to an end. They claim a 5th-6th place finish and end the season with the EMEA Stage 2 trophy on their shelf.

title: Leviátan topple Team Heretics to secure upper finals
cleaned_content: In the second upper bracket semifinal game of Valorant Champions 2024, the top seed from Americas LEVIATÁN faced off against the Shanghai finalists Team Heretics . Leviátan swept Team Heretics 2-0, managing two second-half comebacks to get their spot at the upper finals of Champions 2024. Icebox was Leviátan's map pick, while Heretics picked Lotus, which left Haven as the decider. Starting on Icebox, Leviátan won the pistol on their attack side. tex picked up an Outlaw and killed four on his bonus round to build an early lead for Leviátan. Heretics went down 7-1 struggling to defend A site, but heroics from benjyfishy and Boo pulled the map back within reach. Entering the half with a 7-5 lead, Leviátan lost the pistol and eco and the map was tied 7-7. Heretics' attack side began dominant thanks to successful post-plants. It took a timeout from Leviátan to stop a second-half blowout for Heretics. Just as they had against G2, Leviátan won close rounds to win Icebox in overtime 15-13. tex ended the map as he started it: as the best player in the lobby. tex wins Icebox in overtime for Leviátan. Map two was Heretics' map pick, and they won the first pistol and fought to earn a convincing lead. The rounds were more evenly traded in comparison to the streaky nature of Icebox, but Heretics were well-drilled and remained calm in chaotic moments to earn an 8-4 lead at the half. Moving to the defense side, Heretics lost both pistols and the bonus round to see their lead disappear. It was the star duelist of aspas that led the comeback, stepping up on Raze and improving from his passable performance on Icebox. Leviátan won seven straight rounds and closed out an 11-8 lead to win 13-10 and sweep the series. Leviátan will face EDward Gaming in the upper finals, while Team Heretics will face DRX in the lower bracket.

title: EDward Gaming push past Sentinels, progress to top three
cleaned_content: EDward Gaming bested Sentinels 2-1 in the upper semifinal of Champions 2024 . EDG has advanced to the upper final against the winner of Team Heretics versus LEVIATÁN , while Sentinels have been sent down to the lower bracket and will face FNATIC tomorrow with their tournament lives on the line. This match represented the first ever face-off between the two regional heavyweights after both had taken clean 2-0 wins in their first playoff games. The winner would claim their first top-three placement at a Champions event. EDG opened their map pick of Haven with their first of many pistol rounds, but the initial lead was short-lived as Sentinels answered back with seven rounds in a row. Everything went their way as they consistently dismantled EDG's defensive setups. TenZ in particular dominated the first half with 17 kills, including a clean three-piece in round 12 to secure his team an 8-4 lead. TenZ couldn't lose a fight on Haven. EDG collected the second pistol but were immediately thriftied after CHICHOO was caught isolated with a Bulldog. The Chinese team showed signs of life, including an impressive four kills from S1Mon in round 16, but Sentinels' lead was too much to overcome and the Americas squad closed out the map 13-9. While the headliner duelists in zekken and ZmjjKK both recorded 23 kills, zekken's impact as the spearhead far exceeded his counterpart's as he delivered 9-1 FK/FD compared to ZmjjKK's 5-6 FK/FD. On Lotus, Sentinels found another strong start as they went up 5-1. This time, EDG were able to wrestle back control, pulling the score back to 5-4 and an eventual 6-6 half off the back of a 2v3 from Smoggy and S1mon in round 7. Smoggy and S1Mon bring EDG back into the game. The second half saw EDG taking their first lead of the series as they chained a pistol and bonus win to a 10-6 lead, forcing a timeout from Sentinels. Sentinels brought it back to 10-9, but EDG maintained a stronghold on A to win the map 13-9 and take Sentinels to the first map three of playoffs thus far. That map, Sunset, wound up being the most one-sided of them all; EDG grabbed hold of a 10-2 attack half with a greater-than-usual emphasis on B postplants for the map. One of the only rounds for Sentinels was another thrifty win on round 4. CHICHOO comes online with three to extend EDG's commanding lead. The second pistol was the nail in the coffin for Sentinels; EDG found a 12-2 scoreline with a 5-1 pistol record for the series and won Sunset 13-6, closing it with a thrifty of their own. CHICHOO took over the entire server with 23 kills to 10 deaths, 333 ACS, and an outsized 1.72 rating. With this result, Sentinels will face FNATIC in the lower bracket tomorrow in a rematch of the Masters Reykjavik grand final and the teams' first meeting since LOCK//IN. On the other side, EDG have secured a historic win for China with the first ever top-three placement at a global event for their region. They will confront the winner of Team Heretics versus Leviatán in the upper bracket final as they push for VCT China's first international trophy. When asked about how he handles the pressure in the post-match interview, S1mon's answer was short and simple: “Focus on winning the games.” EDG will return on Aug. 23 for a chance at a coveted slot in the grand final.

title: FNATIC dominate G2 and survive first Champions elimination bout
cleaned_content: FNATIC delivered an absolutely clinical performance in a 2-0 victory over G2 Esports in the first round of the lower bracket at Valorant Champions 2024 . They will face Sentinels or EDward Gaming on Sunday. The EMEA champions put up a levels-to-this performance in their first match against a North American team this year, dropping just 14 rounds in both maps, undeterred by whatever G2 tried to put in their paths. On Haven, the most dominant of the two maps, Alfajer delivered a 2.02 rating — a rare sight in international Valorant — and 24 kills in just 16 rounds. His ADR approached 300 and his mere seven deaths allowed for a 94% KAST on Iso. “They nerfed Iso, but they didn't nerf me. I'm still good,” Alfajer said. Unmatched. (Photo by Li Yicun/Riot Games) After that soul-crushing performance from Alfajer allowed his team to reach a 13-3 win on their Haven pick, the match segued to Bind. G2 put a much better performance on their own pick, though, and nearly pushed FNATIC to overtime. The map seemed to go the same way Haven did for the first half, as FNATIC took a comfortable 8-4 lead. G2 would not back down as easily, and broke FNATIC's economy as they reached an 8-8 tie. The match remained incredibly tight from thereon out until the final round of regulation, when Chronicle put up the highlight of the match. With just one chance to close out the game at 12-11, Chronicle and Boaster prepared for a 2v4 A defuse while most of G2 sat in showers. Boaster got a kill and as he stuck the defuse, G2's remaining three pushed out through the Cosmic Divide with a myriad of flashes, ignoring Chronicle as he blindly sprayed down all of G2 to find victory. Alfajer was a little cooler on Bind, averaging a 1.08 rating. The larger numbers went to his teammates Derke and Chronicle, at 1.25 and 1.36 respectively. The latter also found five opening kills in a total of 24, 17 of which on attack, making the difference in FNATIC's first half. The definition of spray and pray. This victory over G2 is a lifeline for FNATIC, after a sketchy 2-0 loss against Team Heretics in the upper bracket opener . That loss threw FNATIC into the lower bracket, a place they have never recovered from ever since their Masters Reykjavik 2021 run. “We had a long discussion last night. At least an hour, probably a bit longer, just talking about how we performed because yesterday wasn't good,” Elmapuddy told the analyst desk. “It was just ‘have a win Heretics,' basically, except for the second half of Abyss.” The FNATIC that entered the server today looked rejuvenated in a way they have not been in a long time. Their Haven was a show of unparalleled dominance and, after closing out a drawn-out Bind, FNATIC's confidence is certainly unbridled going into their next lower bracket match. “It's just the energy. If we have the right energy on the right days, I think we're really hard to stop. You saw in EMEA, we just steamrolled everyone,” Elmapuddy said. “The boys stepped up, people are fragging, they're talking, they have good energy.” Historically, lower brackets have not treated FNATIC well. Most recently, at Masters Shanghai , they were eliminated without a win to their name. They have surpassed that hurdle now, but Champions will keep FNATIC up against the ropes until they are either knocked out or get their hands lifted. “I told the boys if we can get over [G2], they're a really good team, we can beat anyone else that's left. We just have to keep the energy and keep going,” Elmapuddy said.

title: DRX sweep Trace Esports in first lower bracket match of Champions
cleaned_content: DRX swept Trace Esports 2-0 in the first lower bracket match of Champions . They have advanced to the lower round 2 match against the loser of LEVIATÁN versus Team Heretics , while Trace have been eliminated, placing 7th-8th in their first international appearance. Both teams came into the match facing the prospect of an early elimination after suffering 0-2 losses in their first playoff games, DRX losing to Sentinels and Trace falling to EDward Gaming . “We'll have to do whatever it takes to win,” MaKo said in the pre-match teaser . The match kicked off on Trace's map pick of Lotus, where DRX brought out their signature Chamber pick in the hands of Foxy9 in place of the traditional Killjoy. Despite consistently finding first kills onto Foxy9 in A Rubble, Trace were unable to find rounds as DRX won six out seven 4v5 situations, bringing them up to a seemingly effortless 10-2 half. The Korean squad won the second pistol round to convert a dominant 13-3 victory. BuZz commanded the server with a 1.54 rating, 21 kills to 11 deaths, 360 ACS, and a staggering 215 ADR. Flashback followed close behind with a 1.54 rating of his own and 14 kills to 6 deaths. Flashback takes down three to convert yet another man disadvantage situation for DRX. The one-sided story remained the same on DRX's pick of Abyss. LuoK1ng nearly clutched out a 1v3 on the first pistol, but DRX were able use bodies to block the Astra's Gravity Well from pulling the defusing player off of the spike. They utilized the same trick to narrowly win out the bonus round and ride the momentum to a 4-0 lead. Trace continued to lose rounds by tragic margins; in round 5, LuoK1ng just ran out of the bullets he needed to spam the defusing player in another 1v3 attempt. Trace managed to squeak out a few rounds largely thanks to heroics from Kai , but the first half ultimately ended 9-3 in favor of DRX. MaKo denies the Gravity Well to secure DRX the defuse and steal the bonus. Any hopes of a comeback from Trace were shattered as DRX collected their fourth out of four pistol rounds in the match and closed out Abyss 13-5. This time, it was the supportive players who thrived; BeYN topped the scoreboard on Sova with a 1.44 rating, 18 kills to 11 deaths, and 170 ADR. Foxy9 followed his teammate with a 1.30 rating, 14 kills to 11 deaths, 173 ADR. Looking ahead, DRX will face the loser of Team Heretics versus Leviatán in the lower round 2. If they win, they will advance to the top four and have the chance to play at the INSPIRE Arena in front of their home crowd. “We will put our hundred percent into our prep and the next match coming up to make sure that we play at INSPIRE,” BeYN declared in the post-match interview. DRX will return on Aug. 18.

title: Team Heretics continue winstreak with 2-0 over FNATIC
cleaned_content: Team Heretics have defeated FNATIC in the Champions 2024 playoffs. The 2-0 victory sets Heretics up for a match against LEVIATÁN , while FNATIC descend to the lower bracket in an elimination series against G2 Esports . This series is the fifth time the teams have played each other, having faced off on three occasions in EMEA Stage 1 alone. This year, Team Heretics won the meeting twice, but FNATIC won the more recent, and more important, matchup in the Stage 1 grand final. In the veto, both teams continued with their previous bans: Icebox for FNATIC and Ascent for Team Heretics. Having similar map pools, the teams opted for different approaches in their map pick. FNATIC chose Lotus, on which they were 8-1 since the beginning of Stage 2 , while Heretics chose Abyss, which they tended to float but FNATIC appeared content to not play. FNATIC then banned Sunset, a strong map for both but common Heretics pick , while Heretics decided to take Bind off the table. This left Haven as the decider, FNATIC's 100% win rate map in the latter half of the season and a map which this Heretics lineup had only played three times. A 2v5 comeback gave Team Heretics the opening round on their opponent's map, Lotus . The anti-eco continued as expected, and Boo's Odin gave his team the bonus round. FNATIC turned their luck around in the anti-eco, and were able to exploit the B setup to win a pair of rounds. An oppressive round following a timeout gave the lead back to Heretics, with three more to follow as they forced mistakes out of FNATIC. The Heretics defense continued on their path to success, ending the first half 9-3. Wo0t makes impact kills look easy Team Heretics opted for a methodical approach in their attacking pistol round, with a flawless round putting them up to double-digits. In their bonus, they baited FNATIC into an early fight outside A, finishing the round out after cutting noise and continuing their push into the site. They won the final round with little resistance, winning the opener 13-3. With a now 28-9 historical record, the 13-3 scoreline is FNATIC's worst-ever defeat on Lotus. This improves on Heretics' previous wins, 17-15 and 15-13, as they now boast one-third of FNATIC's losses on the map. neilzinho was unconcerned about FNATIC's reputation on the opening map. “Lotus is one of our better maps; it was our best before Sunset” he said after their 13-3 win. “They haven't changed too much. We know what they're going to play and how they're going to react,” he added. “We also played really well; it helps when you do that.” benjyfishy agreed after the match. “I don't think we were the best prepared, but we shot very well.” Team Heretics extended their ten-round win streak on the second map, Abyss. RieNs gifted his team the pistol and bonus with separate triple kills, in turn leading to straightforward anti-eco rounds. FNATIC finally showed up on round 6, but they were unable to gain momentum, as MiniBoo won a 1v1 and then found a key opening kill to set the score 7-1. Identifying Heretics' lurking intentions, FNATIC were able to win their second point of the map. This began a back-and-forth, with the teams trading rounds and slowly adapting to the opposition's gameplan. In the end, Heretics set up a utility heavy post-plant, winning a 3v3 to end the half 9-3. hiro outshines MiniBoo with his own 3K FNATIC won a fourth round, their first pistol of the series, with a fast mid push and using a missed Heretics lineup to weaken the defense. An impossible 3K from MiniBoo was met with hiro 's own, as he clutched the bonus round to continue closing the gap. Heretics were able to win two more rounds following a timeout, but FNATIC continued taking rounds on the offense. Heretics used their second pause after FNATIC's tenth point. The defenders used their half-buy to whittle FNATIC down to a 1v2, but Derke was able to win the clutch and tie at 11-11. A late B execute turned into a hectic defense, putting FNATIC in the lead for their match point. RieNs single-handedly avoided the decider map, stopping the attacker's favored mid push and using his Hunter's Fury to find a fourth kill. RieNs avoided the decider map with a 4K Derke opened the overtime with two early kills. FNATIC left the opposite site open for a plant, and the remaining Heretics players were able to explore deep before planting, their forward positioning preventing a flood onto site and leaving the defuse without enough time. benjyfishy and RieNs continued their heroics, finding three to halt FNATIC's offense. The 5v2 was won with ease, ending the map 14-12 and closing out the series 2-0. “We all feel amazing. It's our first Champions playoffs win.” RieNs said after the series. “I want to be humble, but I don't think there's any team that can beat us,” he concluded. “We're just confident right now on every map; our map pool is super good,” benjyfishy added. The victory is Team Heretics' third win at Champions 2024, their debut in the marquee VCT tournament. It is also their second victory against a regional winner, as they defeated the Pacific title holders, Gen.G, 2-1 in the group stage . Heretics will next play against Leviatán, the Americas Stage 2 winners. The winner of the series will move on to the upper bracket final and guarantee a top-three finish.
