Trace debuted a brand new Deadlock composition on Bind and made use of several different GravNet set-plays that caught FPX off guard. Despite being at frequent man-disadvantages, FPX were able to rely on their individuals to drag them to round wins. Life and Lysoar pulled out multiple miracle multikills to save FPX and keep the first half close at 6-6. FPX turned the game around on the attack with six rounds straight after losing the pistol to reach map point at 12-8. Trace mustered up just a single round before FPX closed the map out at 13-9 and tied the series at 2-2. Trace's individuals started to cool off come the later rounds and the more experienced team won out. Lysoar made up for a weaker performance from Life with 25 kills and 297 ACS on Brimstone. FPX also benefited greatly from a 64% opening engagement win rate. Haven was left as map five and FPX carried their momentum to victory. Back and forth rounds proceeded a Trace pistol including a 1v2 from Autumn, 1v1 from BerLIN, and absurd defuse 1v2 from Life. A solid hold from Lysoar and Autumn on the C site allowed FPX to tie up the score at 4-4. Trace could rely on a superb performance from Kai with a 20-8 K/D in the first half to ensure a 6-6 scoreline. Trace fumbled a pivotal 2v1. Trace appeared fully dejected come the end of the series as FPX overwhelmed sites with their unique combination of Breach and KAY/O utility. FPX dominated the attack side of the map with six of eight rounds in the final half. Their individuals refused to give up and manifested the reverse sweep with four clutches in the final map as AAAAY closed out the series at 12-8 up with a 1v2 to steal the series 3-2. Despite losing the map, Kai's 28 kills topped the server as his Operator provided significant value in both halves. FPX could thank AAAAY for an excellent late-game performance on Breach, putting up a team-high 21 kills and the game-winning 1v2 clutch. FPX's winning moment. FPX will face off against EDG in their third VCT China final of the year tomorrow. Trace have been eliminated from the VCT China Stage 2 playoffs but will continue to ply their trade at Champions 2024 in August.

title: Leviatán dominate El Clásico with 2-0 over KRÜ Esports
cleaned_content: LEVIATÁN have defeated KRÜ Esports 2-0, advancing to the Americas Stage 2 upper bracket final . The victory means Sentinels have qualified to Champions Seoul via championship points, as Leviatán will take a higher seed in the event. Both Leviatán and KRÜ await the result of the second match of the day, G2 Esports vs. 100 Thieves , to determine their next opponent. This series is the 13th time the premier Latin American teams have played each other in non-best-of-one matches, with six victories apiece in previous encounters. Prior to this match, Leviatán had won the three most recent series, while the last time KRÜ took the win was twice in the 2023 Last Chance Qualifier. Icebox was selected to start the series, while KRÜ decided to go with Sunset as their map. KRÜ would start on attack on both maps. If KRÜ was able to end Leviatán's map streak, Haven remained as the decider map. Leviatán had a strong start, shutting down every attempt made by the offense. KRÜ's first round came after an Atom timeout, a double fake and Melser 4K catching Leviatán off guard. KRÜ were unable to shift the momentum back, however, as kiNgg and aspas each won a 1v1 and took over the remainder of the half. Shyy gets a sneaky 3K, tex gets a more impactful one In the second half, tex found his second pistol-round multikill to put his team up 11-2. The next round also went in their favor, as Leviatán played the clock to perfection and reached match point with a last-second plant. In the end, a clean aspas 4K won them their map with a dominant 13-2. “[We need to] always be one step ahead,” kiNgg said about their success. “We should be aggressive, unpredictable.” After the match, tex also emphasized the need for preparation. “We just need to prepare well, focus, and that's how we keep our confidence.” The beginning of Sunset appeared to mirror map one perfectly. Leviatán won the pistol, took the anti-eco and bonus, and a tex clutch forced a KRÜ timeout after 4-0. The tactical pause was not as effective as the first time, as Leviatán won a 2v2 and were unfazed by KRÜ's eco round. In round 7 an early C0M Hunter's Fury found heat and gave his team a player advantage. KRÜ played a slow round to find two eliminations and plant on A. Despite a double kill from tex, Melser won the clutch and put his team on the board. C0M and Mazino spraydown Leviatán quickly recovered the following round to break KRÜ's economy. keznit was able to buy a Guardian, which he used to help his team win the eco round after a mid pick and pivot to A. The next three rounds went in the defender's favor, going to half time with another 10-2 scoreline. The second pistol round went KRÜ's way, and they were able to win the anti-eco despite considerable damage from the rival squad. This meant they went into the bonus round with only two Guardians and three Sheriffs, a buy too weak to stop Leviatán's attack. KRÜ had full firepower the next round, but a surprising entry from aspas left A open, with his team cleaning up with an aggressive post-plant. Forced onto an eco, KRÜ were helpless during the final round, and Leviatán took advantage with a quick mid push to seal the series. “I expected a 2-1,” kiNgg said regarding the matchup. “I know the guys, they're insane.” He mentioned feeling comfortable today against KRÜ. “I don't know why, it always felt like we were peeking 3v1.” The victory means Leviatán have won their sixth match in a row, and extends their map winstreak to 12. The win also means aspas is two series away from a second VCT Americas title, having won the 2023 season with his previous team, LOUD. KRÜ remain in the tournament, descending to the lower bracket. They maintain their hopes of qualifying to Champions, needing to win their next series against either G2 Esports or 100 Thieves . Should they be successful, they will make the top-three in VCT Americas and join FNATIC as the only teams to attend every single Champions event.

title: FPX set up lower final rematch against Trace Esports
cleaned_content: FunPlus Phoenix took down Bilibili Gaming 2-1 in the first round of elimination at the VCT China Stage 2 playoffs . Today's match was just the second between the two rosters this year, as they had previously faced in the regular season of the first stage. FPX took a dominant 2-0 back in May, losing just eight rounds across both maps, raising the expectations for themselves coming into this lower bracket match. History quickly seemed to be repeating itself, as FPX kicked off the match by way of a 13-3 on their opponents' Ascent pick. All they would have to do now is close it out on Icebox, their pick. But BLG fought back, and they fought hard. FPX refused to let their opponents down easy, but BLG managed to score a 14-12 overtime win. Flex1n closed out the map with a 4K and topped the charts overall, scoring the highest ACS and ADR and tying for the most kills with opponent AAAAY . Lotus was also a close affair, as the pendulum of momentum swung from one side to the other. The late game belonged to FPX, though, and they eventually reached a 13-10 win that put an end to the match. Flex1n had B on lockdown. Autumn and Life were a step above the rest of the server, accruing 121 kills (30 openers) between them throughout the three maps, more than half of all of BLG put together. The former also topped the charts in ADR and ACS, where he averaged 174 and 270, respectively. Today was not the day for Bilibili, who are now on a three-match loss streak against BerliN's squad. Their last win against FPX was July 15 of last year in the lower bracket of the China Champions qualifier . They had to go the distance to beat FPX back then, but struggled to repeat that feat today. Today's result also gets FPX a better seed for Champions , as they have secured a top three placement and forced Bilibili to be China's fourth seed heading into next month's Champions. And while the tournament may be over for BLG, it's not for FPX. Life and his team will rematch Trace Esports in tomorrow's lower bracket final , where another win will set up a China Kickoff grand final between FPX and EDward Gaming .

title: EDG triumph in 2-0 sweep against Trace Esports
cleaned_content: EDward Gaming won their upper bracket final match 2-0 in the VCT China 2024 Stage 2 playoffs, securing their spot in the regional finals and improving their seeding at Champions 2024. Despite Trace Esports ' form in Stage 2 of the regular season, the team still has yet to take a single map off of EDG in 2024. The first half on Sunset was a playing ground for the updated roster of EDG. ZmjjKK on Neon fried Trace Esports en route to a 10-2 lead at the half. EDG won both pistol rounds and converted their defense-side bonus to win map one exceptionally, 13-2. Since the playoffs began, EDG have run the Team Heretics Neon composition on Sunset to much success. Abyss was next up in the series, making its debut in the Chinese region, and ZmjjKK surprised everyone by picking Yoru. EDG ran double duelist against the double smokes from Trace. Trace started their attack by utilizing their smokes to facilitate post-plants. EDG then won their defensive rounds off of their superior aim and trademark aggression. Smoggy goes down with his ship. Smoggy had multiple highlights across the EDG defense, as he was able to play more loosely when he moved from Omen to Jett. Bolstered by a strong Yoru from ZmjjKK, EDG entered the half up 7-5. After winning the second pistol round on Abyss, EDG mirrored their second half on Sunset and were perfect to close out the map 13-5. It was a quick and easy win for EDG, even with ZmjKK playing Neon and Yoru instead of his standard Jett and Raze. His 39 kills, 11 first kills, and 327 ACS led both teams as EDG walked their way into the finals. This win locks EDG into the first or second seed heading into Champions 2024. EDG will face the winner of the lower finals , while Trace will have one more chance to win and rematch against EDG for some potential revenge before heading off to Seoul.

title: KRÜ eliminate Cloud9 and keep Champions dreams alive
cleaned_content: The VCT Americas playoffs began with KRÜ Esports facing off against Cloud9 . The two teams faced off earlier last week, as KRÜ received their only win in Stage 2 against C9. The LATAM squad came out on top 2-1 and began their run for Champions, while Cloud9 were eliminated from contention. The map vetoes saw Cloud9 banning Ascent and Sunset, while KRÜ banned Bind and Icebox, the latter being one of the maps where KRÜ bested C9 just a week earlier. The series began with Cloud9's pick of Abyss, Valorant's newest map. Cloud9 opened the game with a pistol round win, but KRÜ turned the tide as they locked up five out of six rounds, giving them an early 6-2 lead. vanity 's leadership and Operator skills gave C9 the edge and locked up the four remaining rounds to tie at 6-6. The second half was a brawl as both teams traded round after round, each inching their scoreline closer to 13. Cloud9 seemed close to winning round 18 and tying the game, but a phenomenal clutch and a 0.1-second defuse from heat gave KRÜ the momentum to get to an 11-8 lead. While Cloud9 tied the map at 11-11, the LATAM squad took the first map at 13-11. The Brazilian ace topped the charts with 26 kills and 15 assists, the most out of anyone in both categories. Too close. Way too close. While the second map of Lotus was KRÜ's pick, it was Cloud9 that opened up the map with a devastating 11-1 first half, as runi 's surprise Clove pick meddled with the LATAM squad. Only heat's three-piece on round 9 was enough to stop C9's assault. KRÜ opened the second half with wins on the pistol and anti-eco, but their losses continued to pile up and soon they were facing defeat at 12-3. Round 16 began KRÜ's Herculean effort to bring it to overtime, with the team fighting tooth and nail to stay alive. keznit 's heroic 1v2 clutch gave his team one more chance to tie the series. However, OXY 's 3k at A site put an end to KRÜ's comeback. Despite losing the map, heat once again outperformed the rest of the server, being the highest-rated player and having 25 kills this time. Meanwhile, keznit's Raze matched evenly with OXY's as both players had 21 kills each. Nails were bit at this moment. The decider saw the return of one of Valorant's classic maps, Haven. KRÜ and C9 both had similar comps, with Neon being the pick for keznit instead of Jett. The change in duelists proved fatal for C9 as KRÜ's electrifying pace and aggression gave them a 9-3 lead in the first half. Even the early pistol and anti-eco round wins weren't enough for C9 to make a comeback. From there, they managed just one more round before they were defeated 13-6, ending their season. Only C9's moose remained the positive KDA player with 205 ACS and 15 kills. The rest of Cloud9 were outmatched by their counterparts. heat had Cloud9's number all game long, as he had a +29 K/D differential and a 65-36-32 KDR. KRÜ's win puts them one step closer to qualifying for Champions; however, they need a minimum top-three placement to qualify for Champions, as both 100 Thieves and G2 Esports outrank them. KRÜ could go on a run once more, but they will face their luck against LEVIATÁN in the upper semifinals on July 18 at 5:00 P.M. EST.

title: Heretics knock FUT out of playoffs, advance to lower final
cleaned_content: Team Heretics defeated FUT Esports 2-0 in the lower round of the EMEA Stage 2 playoffs and have advanced to the lower bracket final against Team Vitality . FUT have been eliminated from playoffs and will represent EMEA as the region's fourth seed at Champions via circuit points. This result comes as a disappointment for the Turkish squad considering their entrance into the playoffs as the first seed with an 8-2 record in the regular season. Coming into this match, Heretics held a dominant 8-0 map record against FUT in 2024. Both teams' losses in the upper semifinals raised the question of which team would bounce back first on FUT's map pick of Abyss, the map's first appearance in VCT EMEA. Los Niños kicked off the first half of Abyss with a 6-1 score by dominating the sites on attack, but FUT brought it back to 6-6 after a timeout from Gais . The second half was a back and forth clash that culminated in a 13-10 victory for Heretics off the back of multiple close retakes. While no one player took over the server, RieNs and Wo0t distinguished themselves with a combined 33 assists and respective ratings of 1.39 and 1.26, reflecting strong teamplay from the side of Heretics. “We just played our game, played our strats, and we won. That's all,” Wo0t said of Abyss in the post-match interview. For the second map, Heretics selected their home field of Sunset despite suffering their first loss on the map in months the day before. The map opened with yet another clutch-filled 6-6 first half, where Boo 's impressive 1v2 against yetujey and AtaKaptan in round 8 was almost immediately countered by a 4K from yetujey in round 10. Can this guy's Outlaw be stopped? Both duelists spearheaded aggressive plays for their teams throughout the map, but it was often the support players who made the difference. AtaKaptan was in strong form, with 23 kills and 280 ACS on Omen, but Boo's three clutches took Heretics over the line. RieNs continued to serve the team reliably with 17 kills, topping the scoreboard for the series with a 1.26 overall rating. Sunset remained on a razor's edge until the very end; Heretics managed to avoid overtime in the final round by sending MiniBoo 's Neon Overdrive ultimate through top mid to catch FUT's defenders off-guard. A creative overwhelm on the A site nets Heretics another win on their home map. Heretics' victory sets up an early rematch between them and Vitality, the team that beat Heretics on Sunset and sent them to the lower bracket just a day ago. “I think it's good to lose because we can learn about how other teams counter us,” Wo0t said of yesterday's loss. “We just learn what's our mistakes, what's our gaps, so we just try to fix it.” Heretics will find out if their fixes can make the difference against Team Vitality on Friday, July 19 at 6 p.m. CEST as they battle for glory and a higher seed at Champions. The victor will earn the right to challenge FNATIC in the grand final on Saturday.

title: FNATIC advance to grand final with a 2-0 win over Vitality
cleaned_content: The VCT EMEA Stage 2 playoffs upper final saw FNATIC face Team Vitality . Both teams had fought their way through the elimination stage of the tournament. The stakes were high, with FNATIC confirming a berth in the grand final post-win. The map veto saw Fnatic opt for Lotus, a staple in their pool. They continued to let Sunset through the bans, a map Vitality quickly locked in given their win on the map over Team Heretics yesterday. The decider of the series was Ascent. Vitality found a brilliant start on Lotus, their opponent's pick. On the attack, they won the first five rounds convincingly, until FNATIC won a round by running Vitality down on the timer. This let them recover, winning the next three rounds with the help of an Odin and even an Operator on Derke . Both teams netted one more round apiece to end in a 7-5 half in favor of Vitality. Odin + Op = a bad, bad time. Unfortunately, Vitality's first half momentum had been sandbagged by FNATIC's explosive attacking side, bolstered by Derke. FNATIC converted a flawless full buy round after losing the pistol and anti-eco, followed by another win off of a 3K from Derke to narrow the score to 9-7. Despite a thrifty win to bring the score to 11-9, FNATIC maintained their pace and won the next four rounds to take the map 13-11. Derke was FNATIC's hero on this map with 25 kills, six first kills, and a +10 kill differential. Vitality's pick of Sunset, following Sayf 's pop-offs on Neon in previous games, was up next. While FNATIC had a flawless record on the map so far this stage, they had played it only twice. Vitality won the pistol again, but after FNATIC stole away the anti-eco with just classics, the team collapsed. FNATIC won six more rounds to get to 8-1 before Vitality punched back with a round off a 3K from Sayf, but the damage had been done. The half culminated in a 9-3 scoreline in favor of FNATIC. FNATIC's retakes looked impeccable. Vitality won their fourth pistol of the day and the following round to narrow the scoreline to 9-5, but once again, rifles allowed FNATIC to secure the next two rounds. Boaster in particular showcased the potential of the Astra in the post-plant, as well as being able to use his own smokes to find crucial kills in both rounds. Vitality won one more round to bring the score to 11-6, but FNATIC could feel the win. They took the map 13-6, winning their final round with another explosive 4K from Derke. Welcome back to the grand finals, FNATIC. While Vitality's Sayf had the highest damage with 277 ACS and the most kills on the server, three of FNATIC's players crossed the 200 ACS threshold – Derke, Chronicle , and rookie hiro – while none of the remainder of Vitality did. FNATIC have qualified for another EMEA grand final with this win. Both teams have qualified to Champions already, along with FUT Esports and Team Heretics , so the fight right now is for a regional title. While FNATIC have multiple under their belt, this would be Vitality's first. Vitality will play the loser of FUT vs. Heretics in the lower final.

title: EDG maintain flawless record over BLG
cleaned_content: EDward Gaming have moved on to the upper finals at the VCT China Stage 2 playoffs after a 2-1 win that sent Bilibili Gaming to the lower bracket. EDG's win extends their win streak over BLG to eight, with a total map record of 19-3. The only other times the latter were able to steal a map were at last year's VCT Champions China Qualifier and at the world championship about a month later, taking one map in each meeting. Today's performance could have been a display of dominance from the Chinese kings, as they dominated their Sunset pick with a 13-5 win. Knight thought differently though, and found an ace on Bind that spurred BLG on to level the series with a 13-7 and trigger the Lotus decider. EDG quickly returned to form, though, accruing a 9-3 halftime lead on Lotus. Bilibili fought hard to come back into the game, eventually reaching double digits. It was at that moment Smoggy landed a 3K in a retake, enabling his team to close it out thereafter with a 13-10 scoreline. A great contrast between the silent RyanCentral and the excited Chinese casters EDG's Sunset performance is largely owed to ZmjjKK who, despite only downing five more than teammate nobody , put up a +10 differential and eight opening frags, nearly as many as the entire server combined. On Lotus, he combined with nobody and Smoggy for 64 kills, 12 kills shy of matching all of BLG put together. In this world nothing can be said to be certain, except death, taxes, and EDward Gaming beating Bilibili Gaming. Going on a year and a half of facing each other — having met eight times since March 2023 — the former have always come out on top. The matchup is an especially rough draw for the latter, who stand on just three map wins to EDG's 19. Conversely, it's a point of consistency for EDG, the perennial kings of China who have never taken their eyes off the ball. Today's win is a step towards yet another regional title. Overall, it would be the 12th Chinese title EDG would be able to add to their trophy case. But it will not be that simple. BLG still have a fighting chance in the lower bracket, where they face FunPlus Phoenix tomorrow . EDG themselves still have to go through at least two matches before they can lift that trophy. EDG return to the server tomorrow to face Trace Esports in the upper final at 7 p.m. China Standard Time.

title: Trace send FPX to the lower bracket with 2-0 win
cleaned_content: Trace Esports advanced to the VCT China upper bracket final after a 2-0 win over FunPlus Phoenix . This victory means Trace broke out of the top-four for the first time this year, a feat they were unable to pull off in Kickoff and Stage 1. Both teams await the result of today's second series, EDward Gaming vs. Bilibili Gaming , to determine their respective opponents for their next match on July 18. The four remaining teams have already qualified to Champions Seoul , which means they are now playing for a chance at a better group in the marquee VCT tournament. Including the pre-partnership era, this match was the seventh time both teams played against each other. In previous encounters, FPX came out on top on four occasions, but Trace had the most recent victory, a 2-1 win in the Stage 2 group stage. Despite the victory and matching FPX's 7-3 regular season record, Trace lost out on a top seed going into playoffs due to a three-way tiebreaker, meaning they were placed in the single-elimination portion of the bracket. During the veto, Sunset and Icebox received the initial bans. Trace chose to open the match on Ascent, while FPX opted for Haven as the second map. Bind and Abyss were banned next, leaving Lotus as the decider map. The veto slightly favored Trace, who had a higher winrate on all three maps across 2024, albeit with fewer maps played than FPX. An early quadruple kill for FengF gave Trace the pistol round, followed by back-to-back triples from Biank and LuoK1ng . A fourth round win forced a timeout from FPX, but they were unable to stop Trace's lead from growing. Biank had earned his fourth multikill of the match before FPX called their final timeout. His Odin found three the following round. During map one, Biank remained unfazed by FPX's offense FPX finally broke through the defense on round ten, and a well coordinated execute gave them their second round of the map. Trace used up one of their timeouts, but a fast-paced push from FPX ended the half 9-3. LuoK1ng helped win the second pistol by recovering from a 3v4 and scoring his own 4K. A quick anti-eco gave Trace their 11th point, and unfavorable engagements from FPX quickly leveled the playing field in Trace's bonus round. In the end, Trace won Ascent 13-3, one map away from the upper final. Biank was by far the standout player of the map, his defense helping his team gain an unreachable lead and setting them up for a quick second half. The classic Sova-Odin pairing earned him a 22/7 KD and 390 ACS. LuoK1ng was also instrumental, with 12 eliminations in the first half and seven in their attacking half, including the final two to win Ascent. Coming into Haven, Trace once again gained an early lead, only losing three rounds in their attack. FengF opened with another 4K, but FPX was quick to answer back after a force buy on round two and the following anti-eco. FengF's early multikills allowed him to use a Lockdown and set up a favorable post-plant, equalizing the scoreline. The attack was unrelenting, ending the half with another 9-3. FengF lead the charge this time with 18 eliminations on Killjoy, and LuoK1ng followed close behind with 15 kills and seven assists. AAAAY continued the trend of pistol-round 4Ks, preventing a fast retake from Trace and helping win a fourth round for his team. BerLIN doubled his eliminations the next round with a Spectre triple kill, but Trace reached double digits the next round, prompting an FPX tactical pause. A BerLIN Stinger round followed, and FPX began closing the gap with another three points. BerLIN swings the momentum in his team's favor Round 21 saw Trace reach match point. Kai was able to win the Operator 1v1 against Life on C, and after minimal exploration, FPX opted to finish the round on the same site. LuoK1ng and Kai were prepared, however, and they flawlessly shut down their opponent's site take. FPX won two more rounds, but were unable to reach overtime. A pair of early kills from Trace in A main gained them the upper hand, and heybay managed to stop FPX's disjointed reagress. This win extends Trace's ongoing winstreak to four victories, and is an opportunity for the team to match their historical best of second place in last year's Valorant Evolution Series . Outside of Act 2 in 2023, the team has only reached the top four at Riot-run events. Now, the only thing between Trace and a grand final appearance is one of EDward Gaming or Bilibili Gaming , who are currently playing on the other side of the bracket. FPX will need to play the remaining team if they want to continue their playoff run and improve their Champions seeding.

title: FNATIC reach EMEA upper finals over FUT
cleaned_content: FNATIC have beaten FUT Esports 2-0, sending FUT to the lower bracket and moving on to the upper final against Team Vitality . Despite FUT's loss, their run is not yet over. The team has a lifeline in the lower bracket, where they will face Team Heretics . The two teams met just a few weeks ago during the group stage of the VCT EMEA, when Heretics bested the Turks 2-0. FNATIC were already comfortable by the time they reached the second half of Haven. After dominating FUT for the past 17 rounds, Alfajer decided to strike down four opponents by himself in a clean 4K that put an end to the match. Stylin' on ‘em. That comfort was a result of Sunset, a map where FUT seemed to be the ones in control, despite dropping five rounds in the final stages of regulation. Those five, alongside rounds FNATIC would steal away — like when Derke blasted four with the Sheriff — let FNATIC trigger an overtime where they won 15-13. The lax gameplay was also a result of Derke , hiro , and Alfajer dominating on Haven, as the three chucked 3Ks and 4Ks around like a hot potato. Between the three, on Haven alone, they added up to 12 multikills; more than all of FUT combined on that map. Alfajer in particular had a stunner Haven. While both teams were largely on even ground during Sunset, FNATIC's young gun flexed his muscles in the second map, which he finished with a +17 differential across 26 kills and 230 ADR. He also clocked in a 1.79 rating and 89% KAST, topping the charts in all of those statistics. The crowd went silent until the 0.01 second defuse was confirmed. After running out of steam on Sunset, FUT seemed to have no answer for FNATIC. It was a stark contrast from the FUT that showed up to 2-1 FNATIC in Shanghai just last month. But that was just the second time FUT had ever beaten FNATIC; it was just one game. Just like this victory may be one game. FUT are down but not out, and will return tomorrow to fight for their lives against Team Heretics. Should they win, a possible rematch against FNATIC — in the lower finals or the grand finals — will still be a reality. For that to happen, though, they must go through Heretics first. FUT return tomorrow at 9 p.m. CEST to fight, now facing elimination for the first time. It's important to remember that both teams have already qualified for Champions, but they still care about regional glory. FNATIC in particular are on their way to a third regional title in EMEA, an unprecedented feat, and are just two matches away from that. Their next opponent is Team Vitality, tomorrow, at 6 p.m. CEST.

title: Vitality best Heretics and lock in Champions slot
cleaned_content: Team Vitality have beaten Team Heretics 2-1, locking in their Champions slot as the fourth team from EMEA. This victory finalizes the EMEA points leaderboard, with Vitality coming in fourth, just over Karmine Corp . Their semifinal opponents Heretics, alongside FNATIC and FUT Esports , round out the EMEA convoy heading into Seoul next month. The match almost seemed to go Heretics' way, after they kept Vitality's comeback at bay in map one. The Golden Hornets came back from a 9-3 deficit into overtime, only to lose 14-12 due to stellar plays from Boo in the final rounds of the map. It was Sayf 's Sunset performance that kept Vitality alive in the match, as he carried the team to a 13-10 victory with an ace midway through and a ridiculous slide kill to close out the map, giving Heretics their first loss on the map in 10 matches. New Neon, everybody. Bind closed everything out in favor of the Golden Hornets. The first half was a tightly-contested affair, even despite benjyfishy 's Sheriff ace, but Vitality let a comeback slip through and Heretics reached overtime. There, Kicks dealt the finishing blow in a Gekko 1v1 against RieNs that booked the bees' tickets to Seoul. Sayf felt like the catalyzing force behind Vitality's victory. The Swede put the team on his back with 27 kills, a 1.42 rating, nearly 300 ACS, and eight multikills on Sunset alone. The performance was a step above anyone else's on Icebox and unmatched on Bind, even by himself. His Sheriff isn't clean, it's the cleanest. Vitality's victory marks a new age for the Golden Hornets. Despite debuting on the scene in early 2021, the team has never qualified to a LAN event and have only attended LOCK//IN , where the bees won just a single match. This year wasn't exactly the best for Vitality either up until this point: the team missed the VCT EMEA Stage 1 playoffs, placing last in their group, and failed to reach the playoffs of Kickoff prior to that. Now they are back, in form, and ready to make their international debut. There was no better way for Vitality to end their LAN drought than to qualify for Champions, where a fourth world champion will undecidedly be crowned. But before they can do that, they have to go through the EMEA wringer. Vitality rejoin the server tomorrow, at 6 p.m. CEST, against FUT or FNATIC.

title: FNATIC continue with hiro, add doma and Anderzz
cleaned_content: FNATIC have announced that Leo " Leo " Jannesson , who stepped back from the starting roster following Masters Shanghai due to health reasons, will not return to the roster for EMEA Stage 2 playoffs or Champions . Emirhan " hiro " Kat will continue to play in his stead. The team has also brought back Domagoj " doma " Fancev as a substitute and Martin " Anderzz " Schelasin as a strategic consultant ahead of Champions. A critical member of the team since their championship run at LOCK//IN , Leo reported visible health issues in the EMEA Stage 1 playoffs and Masters Shanghai. According to team director Colin " CoJo " Johnson , Leo has been on “full rest” since stepping down and has not been involved in the team's preparation. Leo stated that he is “still not in a physical condition to be competing” and encouraged the fans to continue supporting hiro and the rest of the team. CoJo added that the team plans for Leo to return to the starting roster as soon as he recovers. FNATIC picked up hiro from Papara SuperMassive in the Turkish Challengers League as a prospective young talent to fill out the team. Since then, FNATIC have been undefeated in Stage 2 with a 4-0 record in the regular season, serving as a strong comeback from their disappointing 0-2 performance at Masters Shanghai. hiro has been a standout player for FNATIC thus far and currently holds a tenth-place 1.14 overall rating in VCT EMEA. He most recently demonstrated an impressive 30-kill Sunset map to take his team over the line against Karmine Corp in their first match of playoffs . Pending Riot approval, FNATIC have also added two familiar faces. doma has been added as a substitute for Champions and Anderzz has rejoined the team's coaching staff as a strategic consultant. doma played for FNATIC in 2021 and was part of the squad that placed second at Masters Reykjavik . He most recently competed in the Turkish Challengers League as part of Digital Athletics . He will travel to Seoul with the team and will serve as a substitute if needed. Anderzz has been a part of FNATIC three times previously and is notably credited for designing FNATIC's signature Fade team composition on Lotus prior to LOCK//IN, which is still a popular composition on the map over a year later. Anderzz' addition has sparked discussion over whether he has been brought in specifically to provide the team with insight into the new map Abyss. FNATIC have already locked their spot at Champions through circuit points. They will play FUT Esports in the upper semifinals of playoffs later today for the chance at a better seed in the group stage. For the rest of the 2024 season, FNATIC is: Jake " Boaster " Howlett Emirhan " hiro " Kat Nikita " Derke " Sirmitev Timofey " Chronicle " Khromov Emir " Alfajer " Ali Beder Leo " Leo " Jannesson (Sub) Domagoj " doma " Fancev (Sub) Chris " Elmapuddy " Tebbit (Head coach) Martin " Anderzz " Schelasin (Assistant coach) Jacob " Mini " Harris (Assistant coach) Edgar " psych_chek " Chekera (Performance coach)

title: Bilibili sweep JDG to secure Champions slot
cleaned_content: Bilibili Gaming rolled over JDG Esports 2-0 in the first round of the VCT China: Stage 2 playoffs , locking in their spot at this year's Valorant Champions. More than keeping Bilibili alive in the China playoffs, this win also locked the standings leaderboard for the region. EDward Gaming , FunPlus Phoenix , Trace Esports , and Bilibili Gaming will all represent China in South Korea next month. BLG's clean sweep is deceiving, as the team went into the final stretches of regulation on both Sunset and Icebox. The former boiled down to a more consistent effort from Bilibili who, despite not accruing huge round streaks, slowly inched their way to a 13-9 win. Despite the similar 13-7 scoreline, Icebox played out differently as the scoreline was tied at 7-7 shortly after switching sides. Two rounds later, an ace from yosemite at the back of the A site unlocked the game for his side, allowing Bilibili to chain six rounds on their way to victory. Yosemite's ace was far from the only stat making him stand out, as the flex player capped at 328 ACS on Icebox, the highest of the match and the highest of the map by over 100. Teammate whzy had a similar performance on Sunset, albeit while accruing two more kills at 23 and far fewer assists, scoring four on Sunset to Yosemite's 10 on Icebox. Who cares if it's against an eco? With this win, Bilibili maintain their flawless record of Champions attendance, and are the only team to do so alongside EDward Gaming. BLG can finally breathe a sigh of relief this year. After Champions and reaching the VCT last year, the team's road has been full of bumps, as the squad was unable to reach playoffs in both Kickoff and Stage 1 . In Stage 2, the team has gone on a near-flawless run. The only pebble in their shoe in the second half of the season is EDward Gaming, who bested them 2-0 in a tight-knit affair . And that's exactly who Bilibili are facing tomorrow in the upper semifinals . Historically, BLG have always been Robin to EDG's Batman. Only twice in seven encounters — three Bo5s — have the former managed to win a map against the latter, and never have they secured a full victory. But there's always been something on the line: elimination, Champions qualification, a VCT slot. Now that they're only fighting for regional gold, who knows what could happen.

title: Trace breeze past All Gamers to make Champions
cleaned_content: The VCT China playoffs opened with a single-elimination game between Trace Esports and All Gamers . Trace looked comfortable across both maps and took away AG's chances at Champions in a 2-0 series. Aside from a slip-up against JDG Esports , Trace had an otherwise stellar Stage 2 with a 4-1 record, including a win over FunPlus Phoenix . In contrast, All Gamers struggled to maintain form throughout the stage. AG ended with three straight losses to JDG, Trace, and FPX and narrowly squeaked into the playoffs as the eighth seed with a 5-5 record. The map veto resulted in AG picking into Lotus, a map they had played just twice in 2024, despite it being Trace's second most played map with a 67% win rate, including an overtime victory over FPX. Trace picked into their comfort pick, Sunset, which they had played 12 times this year with a 58% win rate. Haven was left over as the decider. AG's comeback into the map wouldn't last for long. AG picking into one of Trace's comforts proved a fatal mistake early on in the series as Trace looked dominant in the early stages of Lotus. A 9-3 first half on the attack was spearheaded by impactful lurks from Kai and heybay . Information from these lurks was capitalized upon by a slow control of the map that adapted well to AG's Deadlock and Cypher composition. Oversteps in the anti-eco from Trace after winning the second pistol allowed AG to close the gap to just three rounds before Trace shut them down thanks to a high impact 3K from Biank to take the first map 13-7. Kai displayed why he had been a top performer for his side in 2024 with the Sentinel dropping 23 kills and 175 ADR across the 20 rounds played. A +13 K/D combined with an 80% opening duel win rate was too much for AG as they struggled to compete with Trace's individuals in multiple pivotal moments. Biank paved the way for his team to close out the first map. Trace once again took the pistol to kick off Sunset but this time around AG looked much more composed. Trace operated on a game plan of taking aggressive map control throughout their defense with multiple set plays but strong performances from Spitfires and deLb allowed AG to take a slight lead at 7-5 before moving to the defense. Trace took their fourth pistol in a row to start the second half and carried this momentum to an early close. Trace managed to take five straight to start the second half thanks to their fourth pistol in a row and back-to-back 2v4s that propelled their momentum. AG managed to take just three rounds before Trace took Sunset 13-10 and the series 2-0. Another strong performance from former BLG player Biank with 18 kills and 149 ADR on Sova aided in his team's strong showing across the series. After relinquishing his role as an IGL and under the leadership of heybay, Biank has blossomed into a strong supportive element to complement the existing firepower of Kai and FengF. heybay's 1v2 secured the anti-eco. Trace have guaranteed qualification for Champions 2024 with their win over All Gamers and will face off against FPX in the double-elimination bracket. AG have been eliminated from Champions qualification contention.

title: NRG release Victor and Chet, Demon1 returns as starter
cleaned_content: After a sub-par 2024, NRG have broken up one of the most iconic duos of Valorant history by bidding farewell to Victor " Victor " Wong and Head Coach Chet " Chet " Singh while welcoming back Max " Demon1 " Mazanov from the bench. A veteran in the competitive scene with a notable track record, Victor was a part of the original ENVY core that attended eight majors over the course of three years. Their most successful year, 2022, net them a first, second, and third place finish at all three international events. Chet, having joined later in the 2021 season, assisted the team throughout their journey, providing additional structure and discipline to take the squad to new heights. Demon1, on the other hand, was a breakout rookie who took the scene by storm in 2023 after hoisting North America's first-ever Champions trophy in front of a home crowd. He spent time in Tier 3 prior to being picked up by Evil Geniuses and made two grand final appearances at both of the majors he attended. Following 2023's Champions, he would go on to sign with NRG ahead of the 2024 season. NRG hit a roadblock after their 2023 Champions run was cut short by two convincing losses to Chinese underdogs Bilibili Gaming , prompting Pujan " FiNESSE " Mehta and Sam " s0m " Oh to step down from the roster to pursue streaming while Ardis " ardiis " Svarenieks returned to EMEA to rejoin his teammates on Natus Vincere . Through thick and thin, the duo of Austin " crashies " Roberts and Victor was ever-reliant, allowing for a rebuild around the pair for the 2024 season. After onboarding world champions Ethan " Ethan " Arnold and Demon1, NRG brought back another familiar face – Jimmy " Marved " Nguyen – to reunite with crashies and Victor. With a roster of five ready for the Americas Kickoff , the team looked to qualify for Masters Madrid early on, but were denied a spot after falling to Sentinels – the eventual international winners – in the qualifying match of playoffs. Hoping to shake off their loss as a fluke and nothing more, NRG entered Stage 1 with Masters Shanghai in their sights. However, their results were far worse than at Kickoff, as the team failed to even qualify for playoffs, leading to more roster changes that saw the return of FNS and s0m while Demon1 was benched and Marved released. Despite these changes, Split 2 once again yielded similar results; NRG barely missed out on playoffs, this time being denied an appearance at Champions . In preparation for next season, the organization opted to not renew Victor's contract, while releasing Chet and their analyst duo of Vladimir " vladk0r " Kornev and yeboislays , the former potentially eyeing a return to the Counter Strike scene. Victor has stated that he is now a free agent for the upcoming season, while Chet announced that he is open to offers in franchising and challengers, as well as CS2. Currently rebuilding, NRG are now: Pujan " FiNESSE " Mehta Sam " s0m " Oh Austin " crashies " Roberts Ethan " Ethan " Arnold Max " Demon1 " Mazanov Tanishq " Tanizhq " Sabharwal (Assistant coach) " yeboislays " (Analyst)

title: FNATIC bounce back against KCorp in 2-1 victory
cleaned_content: FNATIC kickstarted their VCT EMEA Stage 2 playoffs run with a 2-1 victory over Karmine Corp , the third in a row against the Blue Wall. Tonight's win is a point of consistency for FNATIC, who are on a flawless run since returning from China, and inches them closer to another EMEA title. It's also their third consecutive win against Karmine Corp. FNATIC have traditionally made short work of KCorp in their bouts since the latter's inception into the VCT. KCorp's only win in that time was in this year's Kickoff semifinals , where they took a 2-0 shortly before lifting the trophy altogether. Today, however, was an exception, as the two teams endured a grueling series that only ended with FNATIC's 13-6 victory on Lotus. Prior to that, though, the momentum seemed to be all for the Blue Wall. Despite a hot start from Alfajer , when he dropped four in the second round, his team quickly cooled off. KCorp pressed on to a 13-7 win, and nearly made the same happen on Sunset, where FNATIC needed an overtime in map two to eventually clinch a match win. A heroic performance from hiro was the deciding factor, as it was his 30-bomb and 1.29 rating that let FNATIC bounce back from a sure loss to a 15-13 win on Sunset. He also kicked Lotus off the right way with the game's only ace. Never forget that wall is paper-thin. FNATIC's early control on Icebox and Sunset seemed to slip from them in later rounds, but they remained headstrong on Lotus and never gave KCorp room to breathe. This was due, in part, to several key rounds from the likes of Chronicle . Despite being the fourth-best player in the server by rating, his six multikills kept KCorp at bay throughout the decider. At the end of it all though, Alfajer and hiro were the ones to stand out from the crowd, totalling 105 kills between them and holding up a 1.09 and 1.03 rating, respectively. Even still, those numbers pale in comparison to the heroics of N4RRATE and sh1n , as they averaged a 1.30 and 1.11 match rating. The KCorp pair's stats were better in most fields compared to the FNATIC duo, but were not enough to carry their team over the line. As FNATIC's lead grew, so did Alfajer's hype. (Photo by Michal Konkol/Riot Games) Karmine Corp's elimination does not spell the end for them, though. EMEA will take four teams to Champions via points — five if FNATIC win the Stage 2 playoffs — and the Blue Wall currently sit in fourth. Should Vitality slide and crash out of the playoffs — which would require consecutive losses to Team Heretics and FUT Esports /FNATIC — KCorp will edge them out in points and qualify for Seoul. FNATIC, on the other hand, are cruising easy. The team have already claimed their spot at Champions via circuit points, and are now merely fighting for regional glory. Tonight's win is the start of a run towards an unprecedented third regional title in EMEA, back-to-back EMEA trophies, and a way for FNATIC to remind themselves they can still be the international powerhouse that dominated 2023. They just have to take it one step at a time. The next step is tomorrow, when they take on FUT Esports in the second semifinal of the upper bracket.

title: Vitality eliminate NAVI from EMEA playoffs
cleaned_content: The VCT EMEA league playoffs opened with an elimination match between Natus Vincere and Team Vitality , with Vitality winning 2-1. The winner would make it into the double-elimination bracket. Throughout their regular season, Vitality had improved upon their Stage One performance, winning three of their four games this split. On the other hand, NAVI had only found a singular win this split but made it to playoffs thanks to their Stage 1 record. The map veto saw NAVI choose the opener to be Haven. FNATIC had demolished Vitality on that map the last time they played it, so NAVI leaned into that possible advantage. Vitality countered with one of their comfort picks, Sunset, and the decider came down to Ascent. Vitality got off to a blistering start on Haven on attack with six round wins in a row convincingly. It came down to ardiis to win out a couple one versus one clutches to get NAVI on the board. From there, however, he invested in an operator and used it to great effect through the map. NAVI were able to stabilize and get themselves to a 6-6 half despite the rough beginning. NAVI were hitting some crispy shots on Haven. Vitality won the pistol after they swapped to defense, with Sayf finding a 3K. However, NAVI won the anti-eco and brought the score to 9-7. The momentum was in their favor, and Vitality's eco was broken. In the next round, Sayf found a 4K with the help of his Jett knives, but that was Vitality's last push. NAVI won the next four rounds consecutively to take the map 13-8. Ardiis had insane impact on the map, winning multiple clutches and finding 13 kills with just the operator. In comparison, he found 12 in total during all of Split 2. Despite their loss on map 1, Vitality looked extremely comfortable on map two, Sunset. Both teams rocked a mirror comp, but Sayf on Neon dominated 31-15 the last time he played the agent. Starting on attack again, they once more found themselves up 6-0 before NAVI won a round. NAVI brought the score up to 6-2 but Vitality recovered their footing, continuing their quick-paced entries off the back of Neon and Kayo. Sayf found three 3Ks in the first half, and Vitality found themselves with a 10-2 lead. NAVI seemed to recover a bit on attack after a pistol win and anti-eco conversion but the damage had been done. Vitality closed out the map, losing only one more round, 13-5. The momentum had shifted. Vitality dominated on Sunset. On Ascent, NAVI started on defense and for the first time today, found success right off the bat with a 4-1 lead and in round five, were five against one. trexx however, with some clean headshots and positioning won out the 1v5 to get Vitality on the board. The round that shifted the tides in favor of Vitality. The rest of the squad seemed to wake up after, with NAVI and Vitality trading rounds back and forth until the half ended 7-5 in NAVI's favor. On defense, Vitality looked like a whole other team. They won the pistol, anti-eco, and bonus convincingly, setting up the team's economy for an early operator buy on Sayf. They would not lose a single round on defense, with Trexx and Kicks both dropping 20-bombs. Vitality took Ascent 13-7 and the series 2-1, propelling them forward in the bracket. Unfortunately for NAVI, their competitive season for 2024 concludes with this loss. Both Sayf and trexx, the former on the duelist and the latter on Sova, ended the series with 53 kills and over 250 ACS apiece. While NAVI looked better in terms of first kills, especially on the first map, Vitality looked much more cohesive as a team. Vitality will face Team Heretics tomorrow in the upper semifinals.

title: FNATIC qualify to Seoul, Vitality return to EMEA playoffs
cleaned_content: The second season of VCT EMEA has concluded, setting the stage for Champions Seoul qualification. Due to the inclusion of Kickoff at the beginning of the year, teams played one round-robin throughout the year, split into two stages. This allowed Stage 2 to integrate both groups into one league table, of which the top-six overall would advance to playoffs. FUT Esports and Team Heretics both earned top seeds, avoiding the single elimination portion of the bracket. Alongside Heretics, three teams return to playoffs for the third time this year: FNATIC , Karmine Corp , and Natus Vincere . Team Vitality round out the top-six, after only losing once to group leaders FNATIC in the second half of the year. Three teams maintained hopes until the end Playoffs entry came down to the final day of the season, with three different teams relying on the results of the last two matches, NAVI vs. Gentle Mates and Vitality vs. Karmine Corp , to punch their tickets to the knockout stage. Gentle Mates needed a victory against NAVI to stay in contention, while Team Liquid were hoping for the same result for an opportunity at playoffs. A Gentle Mates victory could potentially end in a five-way tie between teams with a 4-6 record, which meant the final game of the season would confirm the final two playoff teams. NAVI needed to win the series, but were coming into the match with a five-game losing streak. The team had failed to win a single map since their Stage 1 playoffs match against Team Heretics, and their year was on the line. The team opted for a return to their signature roles, with Shao on initiator and ANGE1 on controller. This decision helped them take their opponent's map pick, Sunset, but they lost Ascent 13-8. In the end, a close win on the decider map secured NAVI a spot in playoffs and eliminated both Gentle Mates and Liquid from Champions contention. Rookies surprise, Derke dominates In terms of rating, a handful of newcomers and returning players joined the usual suspects towards the top of the table. Last-minute FNATIC pickup hiro appeared among the top ten, while KOI 's rookie controller grubinho showed up fifth overall. Despite a negative record in the stage, a second KOI player, sheydos , entered the ten highest-rated players, with a 1.17 rating. This marks his first top-ten placement in an EMEA regular season since 2022. By far the standout player was Derke , who topped the region in terms of rating, ACS, KD ratio, ADR, and KPR. In fact, he was the only primary duelist player to feature in the top ten players in terms of rating, with Sayf and cNed barely missing out at 11th and 12th, respectively. VCT EMEA 2024 Stage 2 Regular Season results Due to the circuit point system for Champions qualification, the cutoff for which teams made it to the Stage 2 playoffs was determined by their overall regular season results, not just their Stage 2 performance. The top-six teams from the regular season have a chance to qualify directly to Champions 2024 via the EMEA playoffs, as well as a last opportunity to earn points and qualify as the region's fourth seed. Here is how each team performed in Stage 2: Group Alpha: FNATIC (4-0, +40) Team Vitality (3-1, +7) BBL Esports (1-3, -5) Karmine Corp (1-3, -20) Team Liquid (1-3, -22) Group Omega: Team Heretics (5-0, +50) FUT Esports (4-1, +37) KOI (2-3, +4) GIANTX (2-3, -31) Natus Vincere (1-4, -44) Gentle Mates (1-4, -16) Here are the overall regular season results for VCT EMEA 2024: Team Heretics (8-2, +61, 12 pts.) FUT Esports (8-2, +76, 11 pts.) FNATIC (7-3, +46, 13 pts.) Team Vitality (6-4, -14, 6 pts.) Natus Vincere (5-5, -13, 5 pts.) Karmine Corp (4-6, -5, 8 pts.) BBL Esports (4-6, -1, eliminated from Champions contention) Team Liquid (4-6, -23, elim.) Gentle Mates (3-7, -42, elim.) GIANTX (3-7, -58, elim.) KOI (3-7, -27, elim.) Due to the circuit point system, FNATIC have already qualified to Champions. They can still qualify through the knockout stage and earn a higher seed, but, should they not win any games in playoffs, no team can place outside the top three while earning more points than them. Playoff preview The VCT EMEA 2024 Stage 2 playoffs begin on July 15, with the first matches being single elimination games. Those two matches are between the third to sixth seeds from the regular season, starting with: Team Vitality vs. Natus Vincere - 12:00 EDT / 18:00 CEST FNATIC vs. Karmine Corp - 15:00 EDT / 21:00 CEST The two winners in the knockout round will then face off against Heretics and FUT in a four-team double-elimination format. (Winner of Game 1) vs. Team Heretics - 12:00 EDT / 18:00 CEST (Winner of Game 2) vs. FUT Esports - 15:00 EDT / 21:00 CEST Team Heretics and FUT Esports received a bye due to their performance. As the top two teams in the tournament, they will need to win a single match to qualify to Champions. Should either of them fail to win a match, they will need FNATIC to place in the top three to qualify via circuit points. With eight championship points, Karmine Corp need to either reach the top three or for the three teams above them to qualify via playoffs. Lastly, Team Vitality and Natus Vincere need to win two matches in order to make Champions. They will face off against each other in the single elimination portion of the bracket, meaning the winner will need another victory to make Champions, while the loser would be directly eliminated. Coverage Coverage for the 2024 EMEA playoffs will continue on VLR.gg. Pick ‘ems are open until July 15, 17:59 CEST, while a live match ticker and statistics will be updated throughout the remainder of the event.

title: Bilibili Gaming, JDG Esports rise ahead of Stage 2 playoffs
cleaned_content: The VCT China 2024 regular season is over. The end of Stage 2 marks which teams can compete in the regional playoffs and fight for the three remaining China slots at Champions 2024. Six teams will start their playoff journey on July 16, including regional favorites EDward Gaming and FunPlus Phoenix alongside Bilibili Gaming , JDG Esports , Trace Esports , and All Gamers . Though they aren't in the playoffs, Dragon Ranger Gaming still have a chance to qualify via points if specific outcomes are met, mainly if Trace beats AG and if JDG ends in fourth place. In Stage 2, EDG and FPX underperformed while Bilibili Gaming and JDG Esports rose to the top. Both EDG and FPX still qualified for playoffs due to their regular season, but none of the Chinese teams that returned from Masters Shanghai did well in Stage 2. Bilibili Gaming finished at the top of Group Alpha over EDG, while JDG Esports and Trace Esports finished ahead of FPX in Group Omega. A Bilibili Gaming win over Nova Esports highlighted Stage 2 Across the games in Stage 2, the series between Nova Esports and Bilibili Gaming stood out as a close battle for two potential playoff teams. Nova made it to the knockouts of the Stage 1 playoffs but lost in the knockout round to Dragon Ranger Gaming , who eventually placed third and qualified for Masters Shanghai. Bilibili Gaming, despite their upset wins over NRG at Champions in 2023, started slowly in 2024 and missed out on both Masters Madrid and Shanghai. Bilibili came out the gates hot in Stage 2 by sweeping Wolves Esports but then had to face a tougher opponent in Nova to solidify their playoff chances. Bilibili were gaining new form thanks to some additions to the roster. Picking up both former BLEED player Marcus " nephh " Tan and former TYLOO player Lo " Flex1n " Rui (罗瑞) made Bilibili a more well-rounded squad. Nova were continuing to improve from Stage 1, with their players all stepping up statistically heading into this series. Map one was a wildly entertaining nailbiter that went in favor of Nova, while maps two and three showed great resilience from a Bilibili team looking to redeem their season. This win was crucial for Bilibili to qualify for the Stage 2 playoffs, while Nova lost and missed out. Outstanding players from VCT China 2024 Stage 2 Three players across Stage 2 had a significant impact on their team performance in the final stretch of the season. The first is one everyone is familiar with: Zheng " ZmjjKK " Yongkang (郑永康) . ZmjjKK posing after a victory in VCT China 2024 Stage 2. (Image via Riot Games) After returning from Masters Shanghai, EDG stumbled with a 2-2 record but ZmjjKK retained his status as the most talented player in China. He led the league in ACS with 275.1, kills per round with 0.96, and average damage per round with 171.6. ZmjjKK started to play Neon due to the meta shift, and his stats showed no drop-off. Another player who stood out was Park " stew " Young-chan (박영찬) from JDG Esports. Not only did his team go 4-1, but he ended Stage 2 with the highest K:D ratio at 1.48. He improved in every stat from Stage 1 to Stage 2 and proved himself as a duelist who could help his team beat many other squads eyeing their final chance at Champions. Wang " whzy " Haozhe (王昊哲) has always been, statistically, the star player from the Bilibili Gaming core. He ended Stage 2 tied second at first kills per round with 0.22 while sticking around the top seven across other key stats without playing Neon like the other two standout players above. His stats remained consistently high from Stage 1 to Stage 2 as he helped lead Bilibili to their first playoff game in 2024. VCT China 2024 Stage 2 and Regular Season results Due to the circuit point system for Champions qualification, the cutoff for which teams made it to the Stage 2 playoffs was determined by their overall regular season results and international tournament wins, not just their Stage 2 results. The top-six teams from the regular season have one more chance to earn points and qualify for Champions 2024 by performing well in the Stage 2 playoffs. Here is how each Chinese team performed in Stage 2: Group Alpha: Bilibili Gaming (3-1, +20) EDward Gaming (2-2, +6) Nova Esports (2-2, -12) Wolves Esports (2-2, -3) Dragon Ranger Gaming (1-3, -11) Group Omega: JDG Esports (4-1, +41) Trace Esports (4-1, +9) FunPlus Phoenix (2-3, -5) All Gamers (2-3, -12) TYLOO (2-3, -28) Titan Esports Club (1-4, -5) Here are the overall regular season results for VCT China 2024: EDward Gaming (7-3, +56) FunPlus Phoenix (7-3, +50) Trace Esports (7-3, +26) JDG Esports (5-5, +36) Bilibili Gaming (5-5, -8) All Gamers (5-5, -15) Nova Esports (4-6, -26) Dragon Ranger Gaming (4-6, -18) TYLOO (4-6, -31) Wolves Esports (4-6, -31) Titan Esports Club (3-7, -39) Due to the circuit point system, both how FunPlus Phoenix and how EDward Gaming perform in the Stage 2 playoffs will not matter for Champions qualification, but only for regional seeding. Teams across all regions will send the top three teams from the Stage 2 playoffs as well as the best remaining regional team via regional points. Playoff preview The VCT China 2024 Stage 2 playoffs begin on July 16, with the only single elimination games in the knockout round. Those two matches are between the third to sixth seeds from the regular season, starting with: Trace Esports vs. All Gamers JDG Esports vs. Bilibili Gaming The two winners in the knockout round will then face off against EDG and FPX in a four-team double-elimination format. (Winner of Game 1) vs. FunPlus Phoenix (Winner of Game 2) vs. EDward Gaming When the Stage 2 playoffs end, the top three teams will book their tickets to Champions 2024 alongside EDG. If EDG do well in the tournament and take one of those top three slots, the next-best regional team via circuit points will make it to Seoul.

title: Global Esports part with Spin and BigTime
cleaned_content: After nearly two years of service, Global Esports head coach Peter " Spin " Bradford and assistant coach Morgan " BigTime " Jay have respectively announced their departures from the organization. Following GE's approval into VCT Pacific, former MAD Lions staff Spin and BigTime initially joined in late 2022 as assistant coaches to then-head coach Hong " Eraser " Chang-pyo (홍창표) as a part of the team's full roster overhaul for the partnered leagues. Despite high expectations, GE bombed out of LOCK//IN against Team Vitality in the first round. The 2023 regular season would not play so kindly for Global Esports. A cacophony of problems plagued the team, including visa issues for Indian players Ganesh " SkRossi " Gangadhar and Abhirup " Lightningfast " Choudhury in the opening weeks alongside complications with GE's seven-player roster. The team ultimately ended the season in eighth place with a 3-6 record. GE capped off the year with another first-round knockout, this time to Rex Regum Qeon in the LCQ. Following the loss, Spin was promoted to head coach in place of Eraser, who parted with the team. Desiring greater results to make up for their lackluster debut season, Global Esports once more revamped their roster for 2024, splitting with five of their previous players while opting to keep only Lightningfast. Spin reunited with former TENSTAR members Russel " Russ " Mendes and Niko " Polvi " Polvinen , bringing alongside him tenured Pacific veterans Gary " blaZek1ng " Dastin and Benedict " Benkai " Tan . Global Esports entered Kickoff desperate to find success amidst mountains of criticism. Renewed hopes were not enough to find the results desired, as two quick sweeps in the opening and deciding match by ZETA DIVISION knocked GE out of contention for Madrid. Splits 1 and 2 yielded similar results, with GE finding only three wins combined to once again fall short of making an international event. Just days after their final match of the year against Gen.G , Spin announced that he had chosen to resign from Global Esports, with BigTime also leaving the team. Applications for the head coach position have since been publicly opened by the team for the next season. Global Esports are now down to: Russel " Russ " Mendes Gary " blaZek1ng " Dastin Abhirup " Lightningfast " Choudhury Niko " Polvi " Polvinen Benedict " Benkai " Tan Hose " taeri " Son (손호세) (Manager) Vatsal " Vatsal " Uniyal (Staff)

title: Talon Esports add primmie
cleaned_content: TALON have announced their signing of upcoming Thai prodigy Papaphat " primmie " Sriprapha heading into VCT Pacific Playoffs . Prior to this year, primmie had only previously played two professional matches on a short stint with FW Esports in 2022. Heading into 2024, he played in regional qualifiers for both splits of VCL Thailand, qualifying for Split 1 of the season with XGOD , but faced a team disqualification due to account sharing . His team's core continued to play together for Split 2 qualifiers through Promotion , yet ultimately failed to make it into Challengers. Despite a lack of officials to his name, primmie is renowned in the Asian scene due to impressive showings in both ranked and the competitive leaderboard, being the highest ranked Radiant for four acts in a row and counting. He was also previously trialed by Talon earlier in the year before his eventual signing. The signing comes just days before Talon's upcoming knockout match against third seed Team Secret. Talon ended the season 6-4 to qualify as the lowest seed in Playoffs following multiple shifts throughout the year. However, they now only need to win two matches in order to qualify for Champions. It is unconfirmed whose position primmie may take for the team's do-or-die match this Friday. TALON are now: Thanamethk " Crws " Mahatthananuyut Jittana " JitBoyS " Nokngam Papaphat " primmie " Sriprapha Thanachart " Surf " Rungapajaratkul Joseph " ban " Seungmin Oh Peter " Governor " No Jirawat " HeadHawk " Kalumpanun (Manager) Hector " FrosT " Rosario (Head coach) Aaron " b0i " Thao (Coach)

title: KRÜ bench Klaus, mta returns to starting lineup
cleaned_content: Previously inactive to recover from an injury, Nicolás " mta " González will return to the KRÜ Esports starting roster, while Nicolas " Klaus " Ferrari will move to the bench. Additionally, Marco " Melser " Eliot Machuca Amaro will return to the in-game leader role. Klaus has represented KRÜ Esports since 2021 and is one of the few Americas players to remain on the same org since the beginning of the VCT. He was also IGL for six of the eight international events the team participated in. Melser took up the role in 2023, but Klaus eventually returned as IGL due to the impact on Melser's performance. Head coach Jorge " Atom " Siero confirmed in the past that the team always intended to find a spot for mta in their lineup. His injury meant roster changes were needed prior to Stage 1. heat joined as mta's replacement and Klaus became their in-game leader, both changes helping the team finish the group stage with a 5-1 record. They were not as successful in playoffs, losing both of their matches and finishing outside the top-three. According to Atom, the team “began a slow decline in their quality of play [and] lost the strength and rhythm that kept them within their standards.” He also acknowledges the bad timing of the change, and emphasizes that the issues within the team were not due to a single player. mta will return to the Riot Games Arena on July 3 against NRG : Marco " Melser " Eliot Machuca Amaro Angelo " keznit " Mori Nicolás " mta " González Fabian " Shyy " Usnayo Olavo " heat " Marcelo Jorge " Atom " Siero (Head coach) Alan " ddx " Salvati (Assistant coach)

title: GIANTX bench Redgar, Famsii to step in
cleaned_content: GIANTX have benched in-game leader Igor " Redgar " Vlasov . UCAM Esports Club 's Ramses " Famsii " Valentino Erasmus Koivukangas will be his replacement for the foreseeable future. The former Gambit Esports in-game leader led his team to stellar achievements in 2021 by winning Masters: Berlin and taking second at Champions 2021 . After the squad disbanded in 2022, Redgar went to Team Liquid ahead of the EMEA Partnership League. The Liquid roster participated in all international events during 2023, with a top-six finish in Masters: Tokyo as their best achievement for the year. Redgar moved to GIANTX ahead of the 2024 season. GIANTX's season in 2023 culminated in a Champions appearance, where they exited the group stage with a 1-2 record. Their 2024 endeavor has been lackluster, having made an early exit in EMEA Kickoff and winning only a single match in Stage 1 . GIANTX are in dire straits for playoffs, but their two victories in Stage 2 have given them a footing. UCAM Esports picked up Famsii as their main duelist in 2023. The roster made their impact as a powerhouse in VCL Spain, finishing third in both splits. UCAM have maintained their momentum from last year as they are currently in playoffs. GIANTX need to win their remaining games for a chance at playoffs. Their first obstacle to overcome is Team Heretics on July 3. GIANTX are now: Ramses " Famsii " Valentino Erasmus Koivukangas Semyon " purp0 " Borchev Adolfo " Fit1nho " Gallego Aaro " hoody " Peltokangas Kirill " Cloud " Nehozhin Daniil " pipsoN " Mesheryakov (Head coach)

title: paTiTek's "redemption for Madrid" ended his Team Heretics run
cleaned_content: It's hard to find a more unique story in the first half of 2024 than that of Patryk " paTiTek " Fabrowski . When the best players in the world competed in LA at Champions 2023, he had just finished a season for Diamant Esports in the Eastern European tier two Valorant scene. His goal was to get back to tier one, and his shot at reaching it was slipping away. After playing for Case Esports between seasons, the FPS veteran got his second opportunity in tier one thanks to Team Heretics needing a sixth man. It wasn't a permanent role, which was clear from the start. Team Heretics had a star initiator, Mert " Wo0t " Alkan , who could not play for the first couple months of the year due to his age. Until Wo0t turned 18, paTiTek had his opportunity in the limelight once again. Both Team Heretics and paTiTek entered the year with few expectations but immediately showed the world that they were not to be trifled with. Out of all regions, EMEA had two of the biggest surprises in their Kickoff tournament. Karmine Corp and Team Heretics rose to the top off the backs of great teamwork and fresh talent. Nobody could deny the radiance around the youth movement in EMEA, especially since Heretics were playing with one of their prodigies on the bench. According to paTiTek, it didn't take long for him to realize that the team's potential was much higher than others predicted. “Before Kickoff, I just wanted to show I could play at the highest level,” paTiTek said. “The expectations then arrived when we first played together and I got along with them. I realized that we had the potential to truly make something good. I was a little stressed and constantly overthinking, especially on stage. I think I wasn't performing to my standards, but the team was doing great.” paTiTek poses on stage at Masters Madrid. (Image via Riot Games) Team Heretics had plenty of stars even with Wo0t not available. Dominykas " MiniBoo " Lukaševičius fit in perfectly alongside his veteran older brother Ričardas " Boo " Lukaševičius , while Benjamin " benjyfishy " David Fish showed that the talent he hinted at toward the end of VCT 2023 was just a taste of what was to come. Heading from the stage in Berlin to playing in front of a big crowd in Madrid, paTiTek felt the pressure build for Heretics. He may have been one of the oldest players on the roster, but his only prior time playing against the best in Valorant was during the pandemic. Madrid was his first major LAN, and he felt like his performance there was unacceptable. “Everyone on the team had their inexperience playing on a big stage like that, including me,” paTiTek said. “ Paper Rex was one of my hardest games mentally because it was a knockout game and I performed super badly. For me it was a huge blow, being a sixth man and wanting just to do my best. I was on the verge of crying post-match. It was unacceptable for my standards and it just sucked to be in that moment. It was a huge learning moment for me though, because I knew what went wrong and what I could adjust after.” Team Heretics faced two of the best teams in the tournament, Sentinels and Paper Rex, and lost to both. The team was eliminated, and with Wo0t returning weeks into the Stage 1 regular season, paTiTek knew that his best chance to prove himself so far had been a failure. He vowed to himself that if he got that second chance at an international event, it would be different. Stage 1 kept the team's expectations high. Team Heretics remained a regional competitor coming back from Madrid, but paTiTek stepped away as Wo0t turned 18 and joined the roster. Now a free agent, paTiTek still couldn't get his mind off his performance at Madrid and even considered retiring from competitive Valorant. “Going back to Berlin, my mindset was just to move on and perform, but that loss still lingered and made me think about my place in tier one,” paTiTek said. “After Wo0t rejoined the roster, I went home and focused on relaxing and improving my mental health. I thought if I got another opportunity in tier one it would be very different. If I didn't, I thought it just wasn't meant to be. I just played ranked, met with friends, and just waited to see what my future was.” paTiTek huddles alongside Team Heretics. (Image via Riot Games) In that short downtime, Team Heretics fought back to their regional finals and finished in second place. This meant that the team was headed to back-to-back international events, now traveling to Shanghai. Yet, a roster problem struck Team Heretics once again when MiniBoo decided to take a break for his studies. Heretics needed a substitute to fill in for the international event. As it turned out, they had the perfect player in mind: a flex who was familiar with their team from just weeks prior. “I accepted, of course, who wouldn't?” paTiTek said. “We went with basically zero practice with this adjusted team. We took it as another learning curve for us, taking the challenge in a more fun way, so the mood was completely different than in Madrid. I realized this was my second chance, and my improved confidence showed.” Team Heretics were heading into Shanghai just as they had when VCT 2024 began: with no expectations. They moved Wo0t from his traditional initiator role to duelist so paTiTek could fit into the roster. It looked like a desperate change until Wo0t started to get comfortable on Jett and sniped through top duelists along the team's path to the finals. Despite eliminating the Chinese home teams, a feat that could've made them the villains of the event, the crowd picked them as their favorites and cheered for them the loudest as Shanghai entered the playoff stage. paTiTek looks as Gen.G win the Masters Shanghai finals. (Image via Riot Games) Everyone on the team looked reinvigorated, but paTiTek specifically stepped up in comparison to his performance at Madrid, finishing fourth in assists per round across the entire tournament . It all clicked at Shanghai thanks to one active change he focused on. “Originally, I think I was too hectic of a player both in gameplay and comms,” paTiTek said, “so I actively tried to be more chill and see the game from a bird's eye view. I wasn't thinking my decisions through, and my focus for Shanghai was going back to the fundamentals.” One of his best moments was in the lower finals, as he clutched on one health against G2 Esports . Despite losing in the finals to Gen.G 3-2 , paTiTek's performance has demonstrated his skills as a tier-one player. He showed his ability to adapt quickly to new circumstances and opponents, while still improving as a player. Now, paTiTek is physically back in the same position he was after Wo0t joined Heretics, but not mentally, having broken through one of the toughest moments of his competitive career and completed his redemption arc. “In Shanghai, I managed to uphold my standards,” paTiTek said. “I showed my talent but also kept that level head and I knew I could be a hero if my team needed me to be. For me, it was redemption for Madrid, and I succeeded.”

title: S1Mon joins EDG
cleaned_content: After announcing Wooday1 as their sixth player, EDward Gaming have signed Hsien " S1Mon " Meng-Hsun (谢孟勋) . EDG are the only team qualified to Champions: Seoul , despite having only won one match in international events this year. After their loss to Wolves Esports , EDG are now on a three-game losing streak, their worst record in VCT since their 2022 debut. S1Mon has most recently played in both the Taiwan/Hong Kong Challengers and the Chinese T2 circuit, where he helped his teams qualify to the respective main event. He also reached third place in Split 1 of TW/HK Challengers. He has primarily played Omen, but has also flexed onto flash initiators. EDward Gaming will next play against Dragon Ranger Gaming on June 27: Guo " Haodong " Haodong (郭浩东) Hsien " S1Mon " Meng-Hsun (谢孟勋) Lin " WoodAy1 " Weihong (林伟宏) Zheng " ZmjjKK " Yongkang (郑永康) Wang " nobody " Senxu (王森旭) Wan " CHICHOO " Shunzhi (万顺治) Zhang " Smoggy " Zhao (张钊) Lo " AfteR " Wen-Hsin (罗文信) (Head coach) Tang " Muggle " Shijun (唐时俊) (Coach)

title: Riot revamps Challengers APAC for 2024
cleaned_content: In an effort to better streamline the Premier path to pro and the global Challengers circuit, Riot has announced changes to Challengers APAC for the tail end of 2024. This announcement comes alongside new information for the 2025 Challengers and Ascension formats. In order to fill out the remainder of the 2024 calendar, Riot will add a third Challengers stage to the end of the year. Additionally, Challengers APAC will be reduced from nine to five total regions, as the six Southeast Asian leagues will be condensed down to a single Challengers SEA region. The third Challengers stage of the year will integrate Premier teams into the competition, featuring Challengers Split 2 teams as well as 2-12 teams from their respective Premier region. More details on each tournament will be confirmed at a later date by local organizers. The updated calendar for Challengers Pacific The Challengers SEA consolidation is a part of Riot's plans for Premier and Challengers to have a direct connection, meaning only the top Premier Asia teams will qualify to Challengers SEA. Outside of the streamlined path to pro, Riot mentions the change being beneficial for its partners and the level of play in the long-term, and the new Challengers league will better reflect the broader Pacific ecosystem in terms of regional integration and competition. The current regions that will be combined into Challengers SEA are Indonesia, Malaysia/Singapore, Philippines, Taiwan/Hong Kong, Thailand, and Vietnam. The new Challengers SEA region will begin competition in Stage 3. The top two active teams from the previous regions will be invited directly, while remaining teams will participate in the Premier Invite division of Premier Asia. The top four teams from Premier will join Challengers SEA, rounding out the participants at sixteen teams.

title: Riot announces changes for EMEA T2
cleaned_content: Last week, Riot revealed their plans for the 2025 Challengers circuit, including a calendar update and complete overhaul of the Ascension system.
