Their five regular season wins carry over to the second split where they will have a head start on most of their competitors for stage 2 playoff qualification. 100T knock out LOUD Using Breach, an unconventional choice on Bind, LOUD pushed the pace early on their attack. Their flash-heavy blitzing style netted them easy site executes to take the first three rounds. Having used up all their energy to burst out of the gate, LOUD promptly fell apart. 100T ripped off eight rounds in a row in completely dominant fashion. The hero of the first half was undoubtedly Cryocells. He landed four triples and one quadrakill to reach 23 kills in just 12 rounds. For reference, more than half of all players in the Americas failed to reach 23 kills in a full map across the 70 maps played all regular season. Winning both pistols gave LOUD a chance, but their inability to win a single full-buy doomed them. 100T ran away with a 13-6 victory that felt nowhere near as close as the final score suggested. Asuna finished just two kills behind Cryocells' final kill total of 25 by the end; however, his 16 deaths doubled Cryo's tally. Just in case LOUD thought the Cryocells nightmare had finally ended, the superstar showed up once again on Icebox. 100T dominated the first two rounds, then got Cryocells' Operator online. Four LOUD players were bereft of kills through the first four rounds. For Less and Quick, that trend extended all the way through the seventh round. Nobody could stop the Cryocells rampage, and he finished the first half with five triple kills and a 19-4 scoreline. Somebody stop this man. A pistol win only delayed the inevitable, and 100T easily took the series with a 13-4 victory. Across both maps, LOUD only had nine rounds where they bought over 20,000 credits, and they lost all nine of them. Cryocells finished the series with an absurd 1.78 rating and a significantly higher kill differential than any kill total from LOUD's players. He was 12-0 in duels against Less to keep LOUD's young superstar from finding a foothold. Despite a world fourth place finish and Americas playoff qualification in stage 1, LOUD have a measly two circuit points to show for it, and will have an uphill battle to qualify to Champions since they will carry their 2-3 regular season record into the second split. G2 will face KRÜ Esports and 100T will face LEVIATÁN in Masters qualification matches. Both matches take place on Thursday, May 9.

title: EDG and FPX remain on top heading into Stage 1 playoffs
cleaned_content: The VCT China 2024 Stage 1 regular season is over, with six teams facing each other for three regional slots at the home ground Masters Shanghai. Regional favorites EDward Gaming and FunPlus Phoenix remain at the top, while Trace Esports , Dragon Ranger Gaming , All Gamers , and Nova Esports are all fighting for their chance to represent their country on an international stage. Notably, FunPlus Phoenix are an undefeated 5-0 after beating EDG 2-1 in the regular season. That was EDG's only loss, finishing the regular season at 4-1. The region was top-heavy in Stage 1, as the top two teams finished with a +50 round differential or better. Three different teams qualified for playoffs with a negative round differential. Three teams qualified with three wins, with Nova Esports as the only playoff team with a losing 2-4 record. The best match of VCT China 2024 Stage 1 Due to the parity of Stage 1, the best match was between EDward Gaming and FunPlus Phoenix in week four . Each team dominated a map, showing off how these teams seem to be in a different tier in comparison to the rest of the region. It began with a 13-4 on Breeze for EDG, a close 13-11 win for FPX on Bind, and a 13-4 for FPX on Ascent to close it out. Qu " Life " Donghao (瞿东豪) had one of his best VCT games so far, dropping 58 kills across the series. Not only that, but he had 48 of those kills in the final two maps. While his teammate Kale " Autumn " Dunne played Yoru on Breeze, Life played Yoru on Ascent and completely shut down EDG. He ended that map with 339 ACS, the highest across all players in the series. This series also proved a key weakness for EDG: predictability. Despite the potential of the roster, EDG ran the default Ascent composition with Jett, KAY/O, Killjoy, and Omen. FPX countered everything EDG threw at them with Viper, Yoru, and Fade to disrupt any planned executes. FPX has always been creative with their ideas, but this win over EDG proved that it was more than just a gimmick if they could execute it right. Now both of these teams will have to take their momentum and get to Shanghai though the playoffs. Stars of VCT China 2024 Stage 1 For standout players in the region, there will always be one duelist that stands out in China. Zheng " ZmjjKK " Yongkang (郑永康) , better known as KangKang, remains a top duelist in the world. His ability to play both Jett and Raze at a high level while flexing over to the KAY/O when needed is crucial to their map pool. His stats in China were absurd, with an average of 285.9 ACS, a 1.42 K:D ratio, and one kill per round. EDG rightly design their composition to play around KangKang, a strategy that has netted them regional success. At the same time, two players from FPX deserve their respect after helping the team go undefeated and topple EDG. First off, Life has proven himself one of the few duelists who can fight KangKang blow for blow, second in ACS at 259.3 and a 1.30 K:D. Another sneaky improvement that was key to FPX was Liang " Lysoar " Youhao (梁优好) . His ACS might not be as high as the two duelists higher on this list, but his K:D of 1.54 led the region. As a controller for FPX, he also finished fourth in KPR at 0.84. Statistically, he was the best regional controller main in Stage 1, able to stay alive longest and get plenty of impactful kills across their matches. VCT China 2024 Stage 1 regular season results The top three teams from both groups qualified to the Stage 1 playoffs. Group Alpha EDward Gaming (5-1, +50) Dragon Ranger Gaming (3-3, -7) Nova Esports (2-4, -14) Bilibili Gaming (2-4, -28) Wolves Esports (2-4, -28) Group Omega FunPlus Phoenix (5-0, +55) Trace Esports (3-2, +17) All Gamers (3-2, -3) TYLOO (2-3, -3) Titan Esports Club (2-3, -34) JDG Esports (1-4, -5) Prize Distribution Each team gets a circuit point per match win. 7th-8th = Bilibili Gaming - 2 points 7th-8th = TYLOO - 2 points 9th-10th = Wolves Esports - 2 points 9th-10th = Titan Esports Club - 2 points 11th = JD Gaming - 1 point VCT China 2024 Stage 1 playoff preview All regions have a playoff format where the top teams from each group receive a bye to the double elimination portion of the tournament. The first round between the other teams is single elimination, where the winners move to the double elimination bracket. This means Trace Esports will face against All Gamers, and Dragon Ranger Gaming will face Nova Esports. The respective winners will face FPX and EDG, where the loser of the first lower bracket round will be the final team not to make Shanghai. The VCT China 2024 Stage 1 playoff format. FPX and EDG have two chances each to make Shanghai, but one still can fall out if they go winless. The sole winner of the tournament will receive an extra three circuit points, but the top three all make it to Masters Shanghai.

title: KRÜ and Leviatán top VCT Americas groups
cleaned_content: VCT Americas Stage 1 has wrapped up with six teams advancing to playoffs. The teams were undecided until the final game concluded as the round differential would decide if G2 Esports or Sentinels qualified. From Group Alpha, KRÜ Esports , Cloud9 , and G2 qualified, while Group Omega was topped by Leviatán, followed by 100 Thieves and LOUD . Of the six teams, only LOUD played in Masters Madrid, and despite them beating G2, the latter squeaked over SEN into the playoffs thanks to round differential. Evil Geniuses faced a similar fate to Sentinels in the other group, being bested by LOUD. Throughout the entire split, KRÜ and Leviatán looked incredibly consistent in terms of performance. Both teams only lost a game apiece and had a round differential of greater than 20 over the next team in their respective groups. The two teams went head to head, with Leviatán finding victory after a close three-map series. They advance as top seeds directly to the upper semifinals. Key Moments The first two weeks of the league saw KRÜ, NRG, and Cloud9 win both their games. Over the next two weeks, KRÜ and Cloud9 would expand on this early lead. Before the final week, both teams had qualified for playoffs, with the former undefeated and the latter only having lost once to 100 Thieves. Leviatán had also confirmed their advance with a 4-1 record, but the final three spots were anyone's grab. For Group Alpha, the third spot could be taken by NRG, Sentinels, or G2. While NRG and G2 were at a record of 3-2, SEN had a 2-3 record. Their upcoming games as well as the round differential would play a huge role in who qualified. SEN won their game against FURIA, keeping their playoff hopes alive while NRG's 2-0 loss to 100 Thieves saw them unlikely to qualify. The final spot in Group Alpha came down to whether LOUD could defeat G2 with a round differential of less than 12, and they couldn't. G2 locked in the final playoffs slot of the group over SEN and NRG. In Group Omega, Leviatán had already qualified as the top seed. 100 Thieves, LOUD, and EG were all in contention for the final two spots, but only the former two had games this week. Both teams won their respective games and qualified for playoffs. As for seeding, both KRÜ and Leviatán topped their groups after losing one game apiece, netting them a bye in the playoffs and ensuring they will only need one playoff match win to qualify for Masters Shanghai. They also were awarded an additional championship point. While Americas had their top teams and close contenders, unfortunately neither FURIA nor MIBR were able to win a single series in the split. Meta report In terms of agent picks, Viper dominated with a >90% winrate on five out of the seven maps. Raze was also the duelist of choice on all maps except Icebox, Breeze, and Ascent. Gekko continued thriving as the initiator with the most impact, a major change from the Skye-dominant meta of last year. Finally, both Killjoy and Cypher continue to top the sentinels rankings aside from on Bind and Split, where Viper often replaces them as a pseudo-sentinel. Outstanding players Aspas was the most consistent player in terms of getting frags for his team, rocking an ACS of at least 250 in every match of the split. Cloud9's OXY performed similarly with a minimum ACS of 240, and often averaging more than 320. While both Aspas and OXY were the star duelists of their teams with crucial entries, KRÜ's Keznit dominated in terms of first kills for his team, and the rest of his team were consistently up there with him on the scoreboard. Stage 1 regular season results Group Alpha KRÜ Esports (5-1, +43 round differential.) Cloud9 (5-1, +20) G2 Esports (3-3, +23) Sentinels (3-3, +21) NRG (3-3, +8) Group Omega Leviatán (4-1, +36) 100 Thieves (3-2, +14) LOUD (2-3, -13) Evil Geniuses (2-3, -28) FURIA (0-5, -62) MIBR (0-5, -62) Prize Distribution Each team received one circuit point per match win. Playoffs structure Teams from the same group face off against each other in their opening matches. The Americas playoffs will send three teams to Masters: Shanghai and grant the winner three championship points. It will begin with two single elimination matches, with the two winners joining KRÜ and Leviatán in a four team, double elimination bracket. Cloud9 vs G2 and 100 Thieves vs LOUD will be the opening matches. As groups leaders, KRÜ and Leviatán received a bye and are seeded directly into the double elimination portion of the bracket. KRÜ will play against either Cloud9 or G2, while LEV will play against either 100T or LOUD. The top three teams of the tournament will qualify to Shanghai. In terms of Champions qualification , every match win in playoffs gives teams one point, while winning the event grants teams an additional three championship points. Outside of the top three teams in Stage 2, whichever team has accumulated the most championship points will qualify to Champions 2024 as the region's fourth seed.

title: Gen.G, Paper Rex, T1 all qualify for Masters Shanghai
cleaned_content: Gen.G , Paper Rex , and T1 have all qualified to Masters Shanghai after finishing top three in the VCT Pacific Stage 1 tournament. The two teams that made it to Masters Madrid are returning to international play, while T1 bounced back from a poor regional stage to make it to their first international tournament of 2024. DRX just miss out on Shanghai after going undefeated in Stage 1 One of the biggest surprises out of the VCT Pacific 2024 Stage 1 playoffs is DRX . They entered the playoffs undefeated since bringing in rookie flex player Kang " BeYN " Ha-bin (강하빈) , and only needed to win one game to make it to their first international tournament of the year. They even had two chances, as their strong regular season play gave them a bye to the double-elimination section. Alas, they ended up facing the two teams that went to Madrid back-to-back, and lost 2-1 both times. Both series were back and forth, but it wasn't as close as the scoreline suggested. DRX had specific maps where they looked better than their opponents, but when they lost, it was relatively one-sided. Their Ascent against Paper Rex was strong , just like their Bind against Gen.G. But they only managed to get double digits once in the other four maps. DRX lost 13-6 twice against Paper Rex, and then lost to a Gen.G team who refused to get eliminated after getting sent to the lower bracket by T1. DRX received six circuit points for their Stage 1 performance. T1 go from 2-4 to Shanghai Out of all the teams that qualified for this playoff tournament, T1 looked to be the weakest due to their regular season performance. DetonatioN FocusMe beat them, something no other Pacific team can say so far in franchising. Also, T1 were the only team with a negative win differential to make it to the playoffs in Pacific. However, as fans remember from the Pacific Kickoff tournament, the potential of the T1 roster remained high. In these playoffs, fans finally were able to see what T1 could do if Paper Rex couldn't eliminate them. After a clean 2-0 win over Team Secret , T1 faced off against Gen.G and squeaked out a 2-1 series win. While Kevin " xccurate " Susanto and Ham " iZu " Woo-ju (함우주) led the way against Team Secret, Ha " Sayaplayer " Jeong-woo (하정우) and Lee " carpe " Jae-hyeok (이재혁) stepped up against tougher opponents to get them to Shanghai. Looking at the series stats, it looked like Gen.G had the better fragging, but Carpe had a high KAST at 81% and the least deaths in the game at 39. That alone showed his patience and teamwork across that series. Plus, Sayaplayer had a great third map of the series with 25 kills and 228 ADR. T1 then lost to Paper Rex 2-0 in the upper final, but they can start getting ready for international play. Paper Rex and Gen.G return to international play The Pacific teams that made Madrid are returning to try and contend for the title in Shanghai. Paper Rex look reinvigorated with Wang " Jinggg " Jing Jie returning to the lineup, back at the same level as the team that made the Champions finals back in 2023. Beating T1 to get their spot in the regional finals, they have another chance to try and get that first seed for Pacific that they missed out on at Kickoff. As for Gen.G, while they don't look like the same team that made the Madrid finals, they still have the chance to try and win the title they missed out on. In that winner-takes-all lower bracket win against DRX, it was Kim " t3xture " Na-ra (김나라) that seized the opportunity. For the second time this year, Gen.G eliminated DRX from an international tournament, as t3xture dropped 55 kills and a remarkable 16 first kills to only six first deaths across the series. Gen.G will face off in the lower finals against T1 on May 11. Paper Rex will then face the winner of that matchup in the Stage 1 playoff grand finals to see how the seeding falls for the Pacific region heading into Masters Shanghai.

title: FUT and NAVI back in form, Liquid squeeze into EMEA Stage 1 playoffs
cleaned_content: The VCT EMEA Stage 1 regular season has concluded, with six teams advancing to playoffs . The split came down to the wire, as the final match, BBL Esports vs. FUT Esports , had both seeding and playoff implications for five different teams. Karmine Corp , Team Heretics , Natus Vincere , and FNATIC return to the playoffs, while FUT Esports and Team Liquid round out the top six. On the other hand, map differential kept both BBL Esports and Team Vitality out of Shanghai contention, joining the Group Omega teams with losing records: Gentle Mates , GIANTX , KOI . Overall, FUT and NAVI were the best performers throughout Stage 1. Both teams only lost one series, and were joint-first place, alongside Karmine Corp, in terms of map wins. FUT stood out over NAVI, as they won three matches without dropping a map, granting them the top seed for Group Omega. The Key Moments Unlike other regions, EMEA was the only league to begin their final week with no team confirmed for playoffs. Mathematically, a total of nine teams were able to advance to playoffs, and it wasn't until the end of Day 2 that NAVI, Karmine Corp, and FNATIC qualified, despite the latter two teams ending the group stage on a loss. On Day 3, Team Liquid's 2-0 victory over Gentle Mates kept their hopes alive, and their first map win guaranteed both Heretics and FUT Esports making the top six. The final match, FUT vs BBL, would determine which of BBL and Team Liquid would advance to playoffs. Prior to the match, BBL and Team Liquid were, respectively, the top and bottom team in Group Alpha in terms of record. Additionally, the outcome of the match determined the top seed from each group, granting them an additional championship point and a bye, meaning they would only need one match win to qualify to Shanghai. In the end, FUT's 2-0 victory helped Team Liquid overtake BBL based on map differential and sent BBL down to fourth place. In terms of seeding, the match meant FUT and Karmine Corp entered playoffs as the top teams from their respective groups. Interestingly, neither of the playoff teams from Group Alpha were able to take a win against the top three Group Omega teams. In contrast, Team Vitality and BBL Esports were the only teams to win against the Group Omega playoffs teams, with two victories apiece. The Outstanding Players Reflecting the sub-region's resurgence during the split, four Turkish players featured in the top five players of the group stage. Statistically, cNed is back on top, ending the group stage with a 1.20 rating and winning 59.7% of his opening duels. FUT teammate qRaxs also ended in the top five with a 1.17 rating and 0.42 assists per round. EMEA's freshest player, Wo0t , was quick to climb the ranks. After a number of visa issues, he joined Team Heretics for their final two games, where he averaged a 1.17 rating after winning both series. Stage 1 regular season results Group Alpha Karmine Corp (3-3, +2 map diff.) FNATIC (3-3, +0) Team Liquid (3-3, +0) BBL Esports (3-3, -1) Team Vitality (3-3, -2) Group Omega FUT Esports (4-1, +6) Natus Vincere (4-1, +4) Team Heretics (3-2, +2) Gentle Mates (2-3, -2) GIANTX (1-4, -3) KOI (1-4, -6) Prize Distribution Each team received one circuit point per match win. 7th-8th = BBL Esports - 3 points 7th-8th = Gentle Mates - 2 points 9th-10th = Team Vitality - 3 points 9th-10th = GIANTX - 1 point 11th = KOI - 1 point Playoffs preview Teams from the same group face off against each other in their opening matches. Image: Riot Games The EMEA playoffs will send three teams to Masters: Shanghai and grant the winner three championship points. It will begin with two single elimination matches, with the two winners joining Karmine Corp and FUT Esports in a four team, double elimination bracket. FNATIC vs Team Liquid and Team Heretics vs Natus Vincere will be the opening matches. As groups leaders, Karmine Corp and FUT Esports received a bye and are seeded directly into the double elimination portion of the bracket. Karmine Corp will play against either FNATIC or Liquid, while FUT will play against either NAVI or Heretics. The top three teams of the tournament will qualify to Shanghai. In terms of Champions qualification , every match win in playoffs gives teams one point, while winning the event grants teams an additional three championship points. Outside of the top three teams in Stage 2, whichever team has accumulated the most championship points will qualify to Champions 2024 as the region's fourth seed.

title: T1 and Paper Rex live on in VCT Pacific Stage 1 playoffs
cleaned_content: T1 and Paper Rex squeaked past the knockout rounds in the VCT Pacific 2024 Stage 1 playoffs, eliminating Team Secret and TALON from Masters Shanghai contention. Both T1 and Paper Rex move on to fight in a double elimination bracket against Gen.G and DRX respectively, with only one team out of the four missing out on Masters Shanghai. T1 sends Team Secret home T1 picked Lotus, Team Secret picked Sunset, leaving Breeze as the potential decider. Lotus had four mirror picks, with the only difference being Chamber for T1 and Killjoy for Team Secret. Starting on the defense side, T1 took an early lead despite losing the first pistol round. A second half eco win almost turned the tides for Team Secret, but Ham " iZu " Woo-ju (함우주) took T1 to a 13-7 map win. For Sunset, Team Secret decided to run Breach and Sova, while T1 ran Gekko and KAY/O. Breach has his uses on the thin hallways of Sunset, while Gekko allows for some quick B takes and easy plants. It began with Team Secret taking the lead on defense, looking confident on their map pick. The pressure they would apply just before enemy executes or just after plants seemed impossible for T1 to counter. Team Secret headed into the half up 9-3, but T1's attack side brought the map back. The map ended 13-11 for T1, winning the series 2-0. Ha " Sayaplayer " Jeong-woo (하정우) proved crucial on defense, but Kevin " xccurate " Susanto was the MVP for map two and the series as a whole. Playing both Chamber and Cypher, xccurate ended with 41 kills and a 163 ADR, second in the lobby behind Team Secret duelist Jeremy " Jremy " Cabrera . With this loss, Team Secret are eliminated from the tournament and Masters Shanghai contention. T1 will face Gen.G in the upper semifinals on May 4. Paper Rex keep themselves alive with win over Talon Esports For the second elimination map of the day, Talon picked Lotus, Paper Rex picked Bind, leaving Sunset as the potential decider. Paper Rex ran their traditional double duelist, while Talon went with a double smoke composition. Paper Rex got off to a hot start and never slowed down, winning Lotus in a perfect 13-0 . Due to this win, stats were outstanding from Paper Rex, including two players with a 100% KAST and Ilya " something " Petrov dropping both 248 ADR and seven first kills to only one first death. Credit to Talon, they somehow turned a 13-0 loss on their map pick into a strong Bind performance. It wasn't 13-0, but a 9-3 half turned into a 13-7 map win. Unlike the previous map, something wasn't the star, it was Joseph " ban " Seungmin Oh from Talon Esports, who headed into the half with a 13/6/6 stat line. After losing the pistol round in the second half, they closed out the map and took the series to Sunset. Similarly to Lotus, Paper Rex started off hot with a 10-2 first half. Their defense with both Breach and Gekko stifled everything Talon tried to throw at them, preventing Peter " Governor " No on the Neon from doing much. Thanks to Neon getting more value on their defense, Talon did bring the map back to a respectful scoreline. Yet, the lead proved too significant, and Paper Rex won 13-9 and eliminated Talon Esports from Masters Shanghai . Paper Rex will face off against DRX in the upper semifinals on May 4.

title: Rex Regum Qeon bench fl1pzjder
cleaned_content: After nearly two years, Rex Regum Qeon have moved Saibani " fl1pzjder " Rahmad to the inactive roster. He is now open to offers as a restricted free agent. The move follows the end of the Stage 1 group stage , where RRQ failed to make playoffs with a 3-2 record. James " 2GE " Goopio remains as a substitute player, but the team has not made any announcement regarding fl1pzjder's replacement on the starting lineup. 2ge last played for the team on April 21 in their match against Global Esports , subbing in for Estrella due to illness. The controller player was a pivotal part of RRQ's 2023 six-player roster, finishing the year as the third highest rated player of the Pacific LCQ . fl1pzjder first joined RRQ in October 2022, when the team underwent a last minute rebuild ahead of the 2023 partnerships. He was previously a part of BOOM Esports , best known for their map win against OpTic Gaming in Champions 2022 . During 2023, he was RRQ's in-game leader, helping the team improve throughout the season. Unfortunately, they were never able to qualify to an international event, notably missing the Pacific playoffs due to their head-to-head record against Gen.G , as well as being eliminated by Gen.G in the Pacific LCQ. The team restructured for the following season, releasing two players and picking up Estrella as their new in-game leader. RRQ were again unable to overcome Gen.G, as they lost twice to the eventual winners and Masters finalists in the Kickoff group stage. The Stage 1 group stage saw their first victory against Gen.G, but they still missed out on playoffs after losses to Global Esports and T1. Rex Regum Qeon will next play in the Stage 2 group stage against DetonatioN FocusMe : David " xffero " Monangin Hagai " Lmemore " Kristen Yesyurun Maksim " Jemkin " Batorov Park " Estrella " Gun (박건) James " 2GE " Goopio Marthinus " Ewok " Jacobus Van Der Walt (Head coach)

title: Patch 8.08 includes Cypher, Viper nerfs
cleaned_content: Patch 8.08 for Valorant has both Cypher and Viper receiving nerfs. Both Cypher's Tripwire and Spycam have been nerfed, while Viper now has only one Snake Bite and cannot move her Poison Cloud orb after the round starts. The full patch notes have been reproduced below. CHAMBER, CYPHER AND VIPER Chamber We've updated Chamber's voice lines and added interaction lines with Reyna, Astra, and Omen. Cypher Since his updates in 7.09, we've been excited to see Cypher solidify a stronger spot on the Sentinel roster, but feel it's pushed his stalling power further than we'd like for an Agent that specializes in global information. Additionally, we've seen play patterns around Spycam (E) that lack counterplay for the enemy team. Updates to Cypher's Trapwire (C) gives enemies more time to deal with it after it has been triggered while the reduction in slow duration provides those caught a slightly better chance to use movement to avoid death. Trapwire (C) Re-arm time increased 1 >>> 2s Slow on Trapwire reduced 2 >>> 1.25s We've seen it become common for Cyphers' to hide Spycams (E) in the playspace and continually watch enemies without them knowing. We've added an audio telegraph for enemies who are being watched to provide those who are quietly moving a cue that they are being watched. Spycam (E) Enemies now hear looping audio when they are actively being watched by Cypher from within the Spycam (E). Viper As you have continued to improve leveraging Viper's strengths, she's grown into a dominant meta force and constant presence in pro play. With this update, we hope to solidify clear weaknesses that Viper has compared to her peers while still maintaining her unique identity as a Controller / Sentinel hybrid. You should feel that Viper has to commit to her positions and manage shorter individual up times per smoke use with her unique ability to control her smoke over time. Reduction in total smoke uptime coupled with reduction in the cooldown of reactivating aim to reduce her total stalling uptime and push you to better manage your fuel. Increasing the minimum fuel to activate her smokes creates a larger window for enemies to attack when her fuel is fully drained. Poison Cloud (Q) only being retrievable in the Buy Phase pushes you to make sharper calls of where you'll place the ability each round and sharpen her identity of high influence in a highly committed area. Reducing Snake Bite (C) to a single charge reduces how often Viper can use the ability to fill the gaps while her smokes are down and increases the importance of fuel management. The increase in duration ensures that a single Snake Bite (C) charge is lethal to all enemies that are in the acid for its full duration. We messaged this out on socials but want to call out again that in 7.09 we unintentionally shipped some number changes to Viper's fuel. For full visibility, you'll see three numbers in some of the changes listed below: First will be before 7.09, second after 7.09, and the final is the update for 8.08. Toxic Screen (E) and Poison Cloud (Q) Max uptime on each individual smoke source reduced 15 >>> 13.5 >>> 12s Minimum fuel needed to activate smoke increased 20% >>> 30% Cooldown on re-activating smokes after putting them down reduced 8 >>> 5.5 >>> 5s Poison Cloud (Q) Can now only be picked up during the Buy Phase Snake Bite (C) Charges reduced 2 >>> 1 Price increased 200 >>> 300 Duration increased 5.5 >>> 6.5s PREMIER UPDATES A new Stage of Premier starts! With this one, we're adding promotion. See your division's promotion requirements on the standings page. Meet those requirements to be placed at least one division higher in Stage E9A1. The Premier Score playoff qualification threshold is 600 for all divisions. BUG FIXES Agent Fixed issues related to inaccurate line-of-sight checks near certain abilities (e.g., Phoenix's Blaze (C)). This could manifest in flashes not working appropriately when the detonation was on the other side of a wall that was in the process of raising or lowering. This fix applies to Phoenix's Blaze (C), Neon's Fast Lane (C), Harbor's High Tide (E), and Viper's Toxic Screen (E) and Viper's Pit (X). Fixed an issue where AI-controlled abilities (e.g., Killjoy's Turret (E)) could detect you through Harbor's High Tide (E). Fixed Clove's icons being incorrect when Ruse (E) was equipped. Fixed a bug where Cypher's Trapwire (C) showed on the map even when disabled. Maps Fixed an exploit on Split that allowed Agents to stand on a sign on A Site. Gameplay Systems Fixed an issue where footsteps were not produced when in ADS and when running while slowed by Sage's Slow Orb (Q) ability. Premier Fixed a bug where practice matches did not lock your division in.

title: DRX go undefeated, Talon Esports make Pacific Stage 1 playoffs
cleaned_content: The VCT Pacific Stage 1 regular season is over, with playoffs on the horizon. Six teams are fighting for three Masters Shanghai slots. Gen.G , Paper Rex , and DRX continue to compete for international slots, while Team Secret , T1 , and TALON look to squeak their way to Shanghai. The two teams that proved themselves as the best Pacific Stage 1 regular season teams were DRX and Paper Rex. Both of them made roster changes since the Pacific Kickoff competition, and both improved significantly. Talon Esports used a relatively easy schedule to finish 4-1, only losing to Gen.G. As for the teams not making it to Shanghai, DetonatioN FocusMe got their first win across their near two years in franchising. BLEED got their first win of the year, and both Rex Regum Qeon and ZETA DIVISION didn't qualify due to the group format. Top matches from VCT 2024 Pacific Stage 1 Two matches stand out as the best of Pacific Stage 1 heading into the playoffs. To start, we have Gen.G versus DRX in week three . Considering how Gen.G swept DRX at the Pacific Kickoff earlier this year, this was a true test for this adapted DRX roster, and they stepped up to the challenge. It was a close affair, but the game started with DRX going up in the series on Bind. This is where the new pickup of Kang " BeYN " Ha-bin (강하빈) made his mark regionally, starting on Brimstone. He already played three games with DRX, defeating Team Secret, T1, and Global Esports, but this matchup against the Madrid finalists showed his skills. He played a solid role to help DRX get the series lead and ended with a strong 17/14/5 playing Sova on Ascent. But when he moved to Omen to mirror rookie sensation Kim " Karon " Won-tae (김원태) on Split, he was the one to lead the lobby. Finishing the series with a match-leading 52 kills, 83% KAST, and 149 ADR, BeYN re-established DRX as the best Korean team in Pacific. Now, the other key matchup had little impact on playoff qualification asides from giving T1 a scare, but was a great match to watch nonetheless. DFM got their first win as the underdog against T1 , who looked like a strong regional team coming out of Kickoff. DFM took map one of Ascent thanks to a near-flawless defense side with Ibuki " Meiy " Seki stepping up on Raze. The next map, Lotus, was a return to form for T1, but Sunset was another close map similar to Ascent. Similarly to that first map, the information Yusuke " neth " Matsuda got on Cypher led to some great mid-rounding and adaptations. On top of that, he top-fragged with 23 kills, leading to DFM's first win in their season-and-a-half in franchising. Stars of VCT 2024 Pacific Stage 1 For standout players from the Stage 1 regular season, there are two to mention off the bat: both Kim " MaKo " Myeong-gwan (김명관) and BeYN from DRX. Their flexibility was key to DRX's turnaround from Kickoff, and they both statistically led the region. MaKo was first in match rating at 1.28 , first in K:D at 1.47, and second in ADR with 156.7. As for BeYN, a rookie joining a team just before the regular season began, he was second in match rating at 1.20, second in K:D at 1.30, and led the region in KAST at 85%. Then again, it's hard not to have good stats when you went undefeated in the Stage 1 regular season. A different player who stood out to help squeak their team into the playoffs was Team Secret's Jeremy " Jremy " Cabrera . Team Secret finished 3-3, second in their group only behind Gen.G, and a lot of that success was thanks to Jremy's pure fragging ability. He finished the regular season second in ACS with 247.3 and led the region in first kills per round with 0.24. Stage 1 regular season results The top three teams from both groups qualified for the Stage 1 playoffs. Group Alpha Gen.G (3-3, +20) Team Secret (3-3, +18) T1 (2-4, -1) Global Esports (2-4, -22) BLEED (1-5, -50) Group Omega DRX (5-0, +51) Paper Rex (4-1, +33) TALON (4-1, +8) Rex Regum Qeon (3-2, -12) ZETA DIVISION (2-3, +3) DetonatioN FocusMe (1-4, -48) Prize Distribution Each team gets one circuit point per match win. 7th-8th = Rex Regum Qeon - 3 points 7th-8th = Global Esports - 2 points 9th-10th = ZETA DIVISION - 2 points 9th-10th = BLEED - 1 points 11th = DetonatioN FocusMe - 1 points VCT Pacific 2024 Stage 1 playoff preview The VCT Pacific 2024 Stage 1 playoffs start with a knockout round, then adapt to a double-elimination format after the first round, with the top three teams qualifying for Masters Shanghai. The knockout round consists of Team Secret versus T1, and Paper Rex versus Talon Esports. The losers are knocked out of the tournament and Masters Shanghai contention. The teams that get the bye to the upper semifinals are the group leaders, Gen.G and DRX, who both start in the double-elimination format. Gen.G will face the winner of Team Secret and T1, while DRX will face the winners of Paper Rex and Talon Esports. Then, the winners will move to the upper finals, guaranteeing their qualification to Masters Shanghai, while the losers will move to the lower round. In the end, the two teams that reach the grand final and the team that makes the lower final will all qualify for Masters Shanghai. The winner of the grand final gets three circuit points, but those are the only points offered in this tournament outside of points for every match win.

title: Karmine Corp announce partnership with Zerance
cleaned_content: This article was updated on April 29 with further information regarding two-way players. Karmine Corp have announced an affiliate partnership with French Challengers team, Zerance . The collaboration will allow both teams to closely work together in terms of content creation, as well as unlock the option for Karmine Corp to use two-way players. Karmine Corp is the third VCT organization to announce an affiliate partnership. The affiliate system means players can now be substitutes for a VCT team without spending the rest of the season on the bench. Players designated as two-way are able to play in both VCT matches with the main organization, as well as Challengers matches with the affiliate organization, as long as the player does not participate in more than 50% of the VCT team's matches in a given stage. Currently, Karmine Corp have not officially designated any two-way players. Prior to receiving Riot approval for the partnership, Karmine Corp and Zerance had chosen Yaroslav " Jady " Nikolaev and Lucas " lux9 " Danna as two-way players, as confirmed by Jady on vkontakte . As of the time of writing, neither organization has responded to requests for comment on the status of the players or any current two-way options. Zerance recently ended Challengers France with a 3-4 record and will next play the Promotion/Relegation tournament, Up and Down . Up until week five, the team was second place in the league.

title: Riot introduces changes to Premier, adds new Invite Division
cleaned_content: The beginning of Episode 9 on June 25 will see the introduction of the new Invite Division to Premier. This tier of competition will feature top teams from the previous act's Contender Division, with the intention of providing a more streamlined path for Challengers qualification. Riot has also announced changes to promotion rules, which will be standardized throughout all divisions. Additionally, the format for the Contender Division and new Invite Division is slightly altered, in order to “foster a hyper-competitive environment”. Promotion Changes Starting from Episode 8, Act 3, teams will be promoted upon winning a playoff tournament. The new promotion rules are standardized across all divisions, adding consistency as teams climb up the ranks. When promoted, Team Owners or Captain can make roster changes as needed while keeping their promotion. Promotion guarantees advancement of at least one division, regardless of the amount of players replaced. Teams can also advance by more than one division, if they add players with significantly higher MMR than their team. The changes also mean that individual players that leave a promoted team to join another team do not carry over the promotion they earned with their initial team. Promotions are only applicable for the next stage. If a team does not participate in the next stage, they will be re-seeded the next time they play. The final change introduced in E8A3 will be a lower playoff qualification threshold. The Premier Score required to qualify to playoffs was previously 675, but will be 600 Premier Score going forward. This will allow more teams to participate in playoffs, as well as helping teams with enough points avoid scheduling conflicts or take a break from competition. A higher Premier Score will translate into a higher seed, so teams are still incentivized to participate as much as possible. Invite Division and Contender Changes The new Invite Division will allow top teams an opportunity to be promoted to Challengers. Image: Riot Games Episode 9, Act 1 will bring changes to the Contender Division format and a new division, the Invite Division. These changes are intended to increase the quality of competition and provide a better path for Challengers qualification across all regions. Any Contender team that wins the previous act's playoff tournament, as well as the top 32 teams from the Contender Division standings, will be promoted into the new Invite Division. Following playoffs, top teams from the Invite Division will be contacted by Riot with details on their opportunity at Challengers promotion. The Contender and Invite Divisions will have modified formats to increase competition. Every team must play in two scheduled events each week, and losses are now worth 0 points, down from 25 points per loss. Matchups will be decided based on team records, and rematch protection will be enabled. Playoffs qualification is based on standings at the end of weekly competition, instead of Premier Score. Finally, players will receive a new “Contender Eligible” designation, which allows them to participate in the Contender and Invite Divisions. This allows players that have participated in Elite 5 playoffs or are ranked Immortal 3 or higher to join teams in the Contender or Invite Divisions.

title: jakee announces competitive retirement
cleaned_content: Nearly a month after being released from Cloud9 , Jake " jakee " Anderson has announced his retirement from competitive play citing mental health and relationships being affected by the taxing hours of the professional scene. Initially entering the competitive scene back in 2021, jakee played for a handful of teams before briefly competing in the Collegiate scene with UST Esports . Following roster changes on Cloud9, jakee was picked up alongside Dylan " runi " Cade to assist in the team's journey through the 2023 Americas League . The team advanced to playoffs, and were a single series away from qualifying to Masters: Tokyo . Unfortunately, a three-map series against NRG denied the boys in blue a ticket to Japan, relegating them to the Americas LCQ . With one last chance at traveling to 2023 Champions , Cloud9 were only able to best Sentinels in the LCQ before falling to LEVIATÁN and KRÜ Esports , the eventual grand finalists of the event. Their 2023 run over, Cloud9 opted to participate in a multitude of OFF//SEASON events as they prepared for the 2024 season, securing two grand final appearances at the TEN Global Invitational and Red Bull HG #4 . As the Americas Kickoff rolled around, jakee and Cloud9 started off strong with a win over MIBR , but fell to NRG in the winner's match to meet their Brazilian adversaries in the deciding match. Unfortunately, the team was unable to pull through and were eliminated in two maps. Shortly after, jakee and fellow teammate Maxim " wippie " Shepelev were released ahead of Americas Stage 1 as Cloud9 welcomed back runi and new pickup Kaleb " moose " Jayne . jakee took to X and Twitch to explain that his motivation to compete had dwindled after the new roster changes and that the current state of esports led him to make the decision to step back. The young talent also communicated that he wished to focus more on relationships outside the game, which required him to step back and dedicate time to loved ones outside the server. “Playing a lot in general… it's taxing, I'll keep it real. As much as it was my dream to play video games… I would notice at the end of every week I'd be burnt out. In order to be in my best form, I would have three [caffeinated drinks] a day when I was playing pro.” Despite hinting at a potential return to the Collegiate scene, jakee expressed that he intends to put his life outside the game before everything, prioritizing relationships and income that aren't tied to the esports scene. Good luck with your future, big bean. (Photo: Colin Young-Wolff/Riot Games)

title: EMEA Challengers Promotion/Relegation details unveiled
cleaned_content: Riot have announced the date and format for the Challengers EMEA Promotion and Relegation tournaments. The series of events will be the first opportunity for EMEA Premier teams to qualify to Challengers. The promotion tournaments will take place between May 4 and May 7. Each Challengers region will have their respective promotion tournament, with a unique format depending on the region's VRC and tournament organizer. Broadly speaking, each promotion event will feature two relegated teams from Split 1, the top four teams from the region's Premier circuit, and, if applicable, teams from the region's VRC. The basic format will begin with a single elimination bracket featuring the Premier and VRC teams. The top two teams will then advance to a four team double elimination bracket, where they will play against the two relegated teams from Split 1. The top two teams from the final portion will earn a spot in the respective Challengers League for Split 2. The general structure for Promotion features two stages. Tournament organizers may modify as necessary. Image: Riot Games Northern Europe and Spain will have the top four teams from their VRC participating in the single elimination bracket. Portugal does not have a VRC, but they will hold an open qualifier instead. The top four teams from the qualifier will join the top four Premier teams in the single elimination stage. Like Portugal, neither MENA nor Turkey have a VRC. Turkey will instead have the two relegated teams from Split 1 participating against the top four Premier teams. The MENA Promotion format is unconfirmed, but they will likely have a similar system to Turkey. In Challengers East, the last place team from Split 1 will be relegated directly, with no opportunity of participating in Promotion. The eighth and ninth place teams from Split 1 will participate in the promotion tournament. The top team from East United Finals, trashcan , has qualified directly to Split 2, while the 2nd and 3rd place teams ( Szach Mat and Sila4i ) will advance to the promotion tournament alongside the Premier teams. DACH, France , and Italy will only feature the winner of their respective VRC, who are seeded into the double elimination stage. The top four Premier teams will still play in the single elimination portion of the event, with the winner being the fourth team in the double elimination bracket. DACH, France, and Italy have a modified Promotion format that features only one VRC team. Image: Riot Games Further details and broadcast information will be announced on social media by each tournament organizer: DACH East France Italy MENA Northern Europe Portugal Spain Türkiye

title: ZE1SH speaks on Karmine Corp's rise from the bottom to the top
cleaned_content: Karmine Corp assistant coach Ahmed " ZE1SH " El Sheikh has gone through a unique Valorant career trajectory, to put it mildly. Across 2023, he helped oversee one of the most entertainingly poor rosters in VCT history. Then, he had to play in that roster with near zero competitive Valorant experience as an emergency substitute. After all that, he returned in 2024 and took Karmine Corp to the top of EMEA. With an off-season of time and a new head coach to work alongside, he helped construct a new Karmine Corp for 2024. Only one player, Ryad " sh1n " Ensaad , remained from their previous roster. The rest were effectively rookies to top-tier play, with former FNATIC player Martin " MAGNUM " Penkov as the outlier. Somehow, the org went from the bottom of the league to eliminating Fnatic and winning the VCT 2024 EMEA Kickoff tournament. ZE1SH had to take the criticism and the pain from the 2023 season and use it for good. Being in the shoes of a player in 2023 helped him understand the pressure rookies have to go through to perform at the tier-one level. “I think when you play on big stages, you get knowledge, and you get a better understanding of what a player feels,” ZE1SH said. “Sometimes, coaches can think of the perspective of a player and criticize them, but can you bring it in a good and helpful way? Can you truly feel what the player feels at that moment?” ZE1SH and sh1n on stage at the KCX3 event. (Image via ZE1SH) After stepping into the roster in 2023 when Alexis " Newzera " Humbert left, ZE1SH was as eager as any rookie to prove himself. He self-admittedly knew that it was his brain that would lead his team to victory more than his aim, though he wasn't a slouch. Karmine Corp looked improved in 2023 when he joined the roster, despite not being able to make it through the gauntlet that was the VCT 2023 EMEA LCQ. “I was excited; I wanted to prove to the world that my vision and understanding of the game wasn't bad,” ZE1SH said. “Whether I trash-talked or jumped out of my seat in 2023, that was, and still is, how I naturally react to playing on stage to release the pressure out of my teammates and bring up our confidence. You can see it even though I am not playing anymore, I always have natural big-energy reactions on coach cam. I am just living the moment at 300%.” One of the highlights was soon after he joined the roster. Despite the team turmoil, KC faced off against KOI and got the team a win. He was quick to trash-talk them , but that was the way he released his stress in a more positive way for both him and his team's confidence. That same frame of mind was something he wanted the rookies joining the team in 2024 to learn or improve on. He worked in depth with each rookie on Karmine Corp, from the explosive Yoru play of Martin " marteen " Pátek to the surprising flexibility of Marshall " N4RRATE " Massey . The team's overall improvements took them to the EMEA Kickoff title, with all rookies having their key moments. ZE1SH lifting the VCT EMEA Kickoff trophy with Karmine Corp in 2024. (Image via ZE1SH) As for N4RRATE, the one non-European on the team, ZE1SH was quick to point him out as one of his crowning achievements as a coach. “I am really proud of all players on the team, but in N4RRATE's case, he's the one I worked the most with on KC,” ZE1SH said. “I work a lot with every player to help them with specifically micro-play and help correct their mistakes, but working with N4RRATE was more on macro and the overall vision of how he can impact the team with mid-round calling in his role. I worked a lot with him on that, and I think he's the player that I'm most proud of in my whole career. I always give the credit to the players though, I can try this with over a hundred players, and maybe two understand how to implement it and make it work. He's the one that implements it in his play style, while I am just a nerd who focuses on the theoretical side, so he deserves all the glory.” Considering N4RRATE entered KC as a tier-two duelist main from NA and exited Masters Madrid as one of the top 10 flex players in the world, it makes sense how proud ZE1SH is of him. Every player on KC has gone through their struggles in the past, especially since three of their starting five were on struggling rosters as recently as last year. We know the tale of shin as the sole bright spot in KC's 2023 year, but N4RRATE was also a star on the unsuccessful MAD Lions team. Include marteen, whose team couldn't even make it past the EMEA Ascension 2023 Play-ins, and you have some question marks. Thankfully for KC, their coaches Andrey " ENGH " Sholokhov and ZE1SH took the opportunity to study them and eventually scoop them up. “When you look into N4RRATE, or even marteen, who worked individually but not on their teams, you get them into the trial process and test them with the new team,” ZE1SH said. “Lots of teams just look at stats, and people don't look as much into teams that aren't working.” Karmine Corp entered Masters Madrid as the number one seed from EMEA. The region itself didn't do well at the tournament, but for a global debut, KC didn't fall on their face. They were eliminated in the Swiss stage of Masters Madrid, but were the only team who went home that early with a positive round differential at +3. A bittersweet feeling for the team, to say the least. “I would say that we weren't at our peak form, maybe at 50 or 60%,” ZE1SH said. “We played way better at Kickoff, but we also know it's the first international event for a lot of our players. Heading into Madrid, we were the youngest team in all of VCT. If we won some of those close matches, we could've built on it. They were good losses though; there is a lot we can learn from them.” KC will have to go back to their regional play and keep their pace up. They'll have to prove they're still better than some other big teams that were eliminated in surprise fashion at the EMEA Kickoff, most notably Fnatic and Natus Vincere . However, just knowing the level that they're at in comparison to the past year is outstanding. A highlight video of Sideshow reacting to Karmine Corp facing off against Team Heretics in 2023. The same organization that caster and analyst Sideshow was screaming at in both his Twitch streams and podcasts was now among the best teams in the world. He opted for the quote “from Melons to Madrid” when they eliminated Fnatic, and plenty of fans joined him from pointing and laughing at KC to screaming the word “blue” any time anyone asked what the color was. ZE1SH himself was aware of those fans, and those critics, and experienced their rise alongside them by leading the charge instead of bowing away from the pressure. “For those fans, thanks for supporting us, thanks for seeing the work we've done and forgiving me about last year,” ZE1SH said. “I've always been a really hard-working guy, and last year was tough for me because I tried everything and I gave it all to try to change our results. I didn't feel anything during the season; I was just focused on reversing our mistakes. After, when I rewatched everything and how bad we were, I felt awful that I couldn't have more impact earlier.” For ZE1SH, this year is different. “Now I can do this in my way, in my vision, and I am fully unlocked to give it all to players that are hungry.”

title: G2 Esports sign icy to complete roster before Stage 1
cleaned_content: G2 Esports have signed former Evil Geniuses reserve player Jacob " icy " Lange , completing their roster heading into VCT Americas 2024 Stage 1. He replaces Michael " neT " Bernet , the longtime sentinel who was released the day before this signing. Aside from his time with Evil Geniuses, icy mostly spent time in the North American tier two and tier three scene for teams like YFP and OREsports . He has played a little bit of every role throughout his three-year career but is known for his sentinel gameplay. Despite being rostered on EG, he was never fielded in a match, like most reserve players in 2023. Vincent " Apoth " Le was the only other former EG reserve player to receive a spot in VCT 2024 before this signing. G2 will face off against Apoth and EG to start Stage 1 . G2 Esports is now: Jacob " valyn " Batio Trent " trent " Cairns Jonah " JonahP " Pulice Nathan " leaf " Orf Jacob " icy " Lange Josh " JoshRT " Lee (Head coach)

title: G2 Esports part ways with neT
cleaned_content: Just before VCT 2024 Americas Stage 1, G2 Esports have parted ways with Michael " neT " Bernet . He spent over three and a half years with the core of G2. neT was one of the core four players of G2 that rose to the top of North American Valorant. After joining The Guard when their first Valorant team formed in November 2021, the team reached the top of the region at 2022 Stage 1 Challengers. The team could not reach that same high as 2022 went on. The Guard stayed in tier two for 2023 but were able to win their regional Ascension tournament to qualify for franchising. With that run, neT proved himself as one of the best sentinel players in the tier two scene. G2 Esports acquired the players from The Guard, then added Nathan " leaf " Orf . In the regional Kickoff tournament, G2 struggled against Evil Geniuses in their season debut. G2 reached the play-in section of the opening tournament of 2024 but were eliminated after losing to MIBR and losing a map against Sentinels . According to Alejandro Gomis , former Evil Geniuses reserve player Jacob " icy " Lange will join the roster to complete their team heading into the rest of the 2024 season. While icy played the smokes role in 2024, he has a good amount of experience on the sentinel role. G2 will face off against Evil Geniuses to start Stage 1. Their current roster is: Jacob " valyn " Batio Trent " trent " Cairns Jonah " JonahP " Pulice Nathan " leaf " Orf Josh " JoshRT " Lee (Head coach)

title: GIANTX finalize their roster with purp0
cleaned_content: Following nukkye's release , GIANTX have picked up Semyon " purp0 " Borchev as his replacement. He is best known for his time as M3 Champions 's sixth player, but has remained one of the better performing players in tier 2 since 2021. Between 2020 and 2021 he won a number of smaller, local events with CIS teams such as Team Empire and GMT Esports . In 2022, following the dissolution of VRL CIS, he went to MENA org XPLDZ . He was the highest rated player in VRL MENA, but the team did not qualify to the VRL Finals. During the year, he became a stand-in for Acend and sixth player for M3C, but only played a total of four maps in Challengers EMEA. 2023 was a less notable year, as he moved to Challengers Northern Europe with FOKUS , where he began playing the flex role. The team finished in second after a loss to Apeks, and he was moved to the bench afterwards. KPI Gaming signed him in September as part of their rebuild. The payoff was instant, as KPI finished in the top four of the Crossfire Cup , with only two series lost throughout the event. purp0 was the second highest rated player overall, with a 1.24 rating and 1.38 K:D. Recently, KPI finished the Challengers Spain regular season with a 13-1 record. Again, purp0 was the highest rated player, this time with a 1.36 rating and 1.66 K:D. purp0 will debut for GIANTX in the opening series of the 2024 EMEA League: Igor " Redgar " Vlasov Semyon " purp0 " Borchev Adolfo " Fit1nho " Gallego Aaro " hoody " Peltokangas Kirill " Cloud " Nehozhin Daniil " pipsoN " Mesheryakov (Head coach)

title: runi returns to Cloud9, moose to make franchising debut
cleaned_content: Cloud9 have announced the signings of former in-game leader Dylan " runi " Cade and Challengers prospect Kaleb " moose " Jayne ahead of their first match of the Americas League against LEVIATÁN . After just barely missing out on last year's NA Challengers , runi was signed by C9 alongside Jake " jakee " Anderson as part of a rebuild ahead of the 2023 Americas League . Despite advancing to the playoffs, Cloud9 were crushed by an upcoming Evil Geniuses in their opener. After eliminating Leviatán, the team advanced through the lower bracket to meet NRG in a last bid for tickets to Masters: Tokyo . Unfortunately, C9 were eliminated in a heartbreaking map three overtime loss, relegating them to the Americas LCQ . With one last chance at making Champions that year, the team started off strong by sending Sentinels to the lower bracket before falling in the wake of KRÜ Esports ' Cinderella run. In a twisted turn of fate, the very team that sent C9 home from the LCQ would be none other than Leviatán after a reverse sweep crushed any hope of crowning a North American LCQ champion. Shortly after, C9 released runi in the midst of the end-of-season rostermania. The orgless player had his own plans to sign with OREsports , but the project was dissolved ahead of Challengers. A different storyline awaited moose in 2023; the renowned Sentinel player was tasked with fighting his way through North America's Challengers League alongside Shopify Rebellion Black – the former Luminosity core – in hopes of qualifying for the Americas Ascension . Despite just barely making the playoffs of Challengers, two swift losses to G2 Esports and M80 – the eventual playoff kings – eliminated moose and his teammates from contention. The roster of Shopify would later be picked apart as a merger with Moist Moguls separated players from both teams in hopes of creating a contending roster for the next Challengers series. moose found himself on the short end of the stick, but relocated to Turtle Troop , another Challengers team, before opting to join YFP . The newly-formed troupe of talent breezed through the open qualifiers and secured a spot at Challengers before moose departed the team for a spot in franchising. Cloud9's new roster will make its debut against Latin American rivals Leviatán in Week 1 of the Stage 1 Americas League on Apr 6. Cloud9 is now: Anthony " vanity " Malaspina Erick " Xeppaa " Bach Dylan " runi " Cade Kaleb " moose " Jayne Francis " OXY " Hoang Ian " Immi " Harding (Coach) Guglielmo " GUGLi " Carraro (Assistant coach)

title: GIANTX part ways with nukkye
cleaned_content: After more than two years, GIANTX have parted ways with Žygimantas " nukkye " Chmieliauskas . Now a free agent, he is currently looking for offers . nukkye has been a mainstay at the top of European Valorant since 2020. His resumé includes winning First Strike and reaching the 2021 regional Masters grand final with Team Heretics . He next played for G2 Esports . There, he represented EMEA in two different Masters events, becoming the first Lithuanian player to attend an international tournament. In 2023, with G2's exclusion from the VCT partnerships, nukkye was picked up by Giants Gaming , now GIANTX. The team was unsuccessful at LOCK//IN, but showed a better performance in the EMEA League. Their improvement was not enough to qualify to Masters Tokyo, as they only reached the top six before being eliminated from contention. Giants next won the EMEA LCQ, earning a spot in Champions. In both EMEA tournaments, nukkye was one of the better players in the region, finishing with the sixth and third highest ratings, respectively. Unfortunately, the team went out in the group stage at Champions, only taking a series from KRÜ Esports. Their in-game leader, rhyme, retired soon afterwards. GIANTX were able to win the only off-season event they participated in, with nukkye once again featuring towards the top in terms of statistics. The first event of 2024, Kickoff, was a disappointment. GIANTX went out in the group stage after 2-1 losses to FUT Esports and the eventual winners, Karmine Corp. This was the third time in nukkye's career that his team failed to make it out of groups, and the first time he had back-to-back exits from a tournament without progressing past the opening stage. He remained the second best performer of the team, but his 1.00 rating only put him towards the middle of the pack, overall. As reported by Alejandro Gomis , nukkye's replacement is expected to be Semyon " purp0 " Borchev . The Russian flex was recently released from KPI Gaming , currently the best team in Challengers Spain with a 13-1 record in the regular season. GIANTX will next play a rematch against Karmine Corp : Igor " Redgar " Vlasov Adolfo " Fit1nho " Gallego Aaro " hoody " Peltokangas Kirill " Cloud " Nehozhin Daniil " pipsoN " Mesheryakov (Head coach)

title: Jinggg returns to active PRX roster
cleaned_content: Wang " Jinggg " Jing Jie will return to the active roster of Paper Rex and compete in Split 1 of VCT Pacific , according to an announcement from the organization. The Singaporean duelist was slated to fulfill his National Service Obligation in 2024, but has since been granted a medical exemption owing to a "life-long medical condition that is managed with ongoing treatment." As part of this move, Cahya " Monyet " Nugraha has been moved to the reserve roster. With Jinggg in 2023, PRX secured a first-place finish in VCT Pacific and third at Masters Tokyo . Their official season culminated in grand final appearance at Champions, where they were runners-up to Evil Geniuses . His last appearance with the team was in December at the AfreecaTV Valorant League OFF//SEASON event. Paper Rex recently concluded their playoffs run at Masters Madrid . After exiting the Swiss Stage 2-1, PRX was seeded against Gen.G in the playoffs. A loss to their VCT Pacific rivals sent them to the lower bracket, where they defeated LOUD . They faced Sentinels next, but were unable to overcome the eventual tournament champions. With Jinggg's return, Paper Rex are now: Aaron " mindfreak " Leonhart Wang " Jinggg " Jing Jie Jason " f0rsakeN " Susanto Khalish " d4v41 " Rusyaidee Ilya " something " Petrov Cahya " Monyet " Nugraha (Substitute) Alexandre " alecks " Sallé (Coach)

title: Bilibili sign bail as head coach
cleaned_content: Bilibili Gaming have signed Lee " bail " Sung-jae (이성재) as their head coach. He will replace Zhiqiang " Xpz " Li (李志强) , who had been the team's head coach since the beginning of 2024. bail's career goes back to 2020, when he helmed Vision Strikers' sister team, Quantum Strikers . There, he led players such as TS and eKo to multiple playoff runs, but the team never came close to Vision Strikers' success. The roster then went to TNL Esports, where they maintained similar results. In 2022, he joined NORTHEPTION as part of their rebuild. As head coach, he helped the new roster win Challengers 2, defeating favorites ZETA Division. The victory meant they qualified to Masters Copenhagen, becoming the third Japanese squad to make an international event. Unfortunately, their run was short, but they avoided a last-place finish by defeating XERXIA 2-1. Due to their performance, NORTHEPTION attended the 2022 East Asia LCQ. They made a modest effort, but ended in third place after losses to EDward Gaming and OnSla2ers. Upon their announcement as one of ten VCT Pacific partner teams, Gen.G picked up bail as their assistant coach. The team also signed familiar players, such as eKo and TS, as well as Meteor, Northeption's star duelist. Gen.G was not particularly successful in 2023, failing to qualify to any international event, but they were still able to make fourth and third in the Pacific league and the LCQ. By the end of the season, Gen.G opted to restructure their coaching staff. bail next went to China, where he joined Octagonal Disposition Gaming alongside two former Gen.G players. They did not advance past the qualifying stages of the China Evolution Series. bail's arrival follows Bilibili's disappointing performance at Kickoff . After defeating NRG Esports twice to make playoffs in Champions 2023 , the team was expected to continue improving. They failed to do so, unable to break into the top four at any of the three China Evolution Series main events. For 2024, Bilibili brought in Xpz to replace head coach Jexen, who moved to assistant coach. The change did not pay off, and a top-four finish once again evaded the squad at Kickoff. Xpz was released on March 25. With a revamped staff, Bilibili Gaming will next play against TYLOO : Yang " B3ar " Zhanxiong (杨瞻雄) Wang " whzy " Haozhe (王昊哲) Liu " Knight " Yuxiang (刘宇翔) Wang " yosemite " Lei (王磊) Zhong " Biank " Jianfei (钟剑飞) Lee " bail " Sung-jae (이성재) (Head coach) Wang " Jexen " Lin Xiao (王林骁) (Coach)

title: JDG sign former ASE in-game leader YHchen
cleaned_content: After a disappointing Kickoff performance, JDG Esports have signed Chen " YHchen " Yuhan (陳昱瀚) . The initiator player arrives in an effort to fix JDG's in-game leader woes, as they were forced to drop yoman from the core roster due to having too many import players. He is expected to start over Yong " jkuro " Haochong (杨浩聪) , but the team has not made a public announcement on the starting lineup. YHchen is the final player to join VCT China from the Attacking Soul Esports roster that qualified to Masters Tokyo. During that period, he was the IGL, and led the team to a win against EDward Gaming in the FGC Invitational Act 2, as well as a third-place finish the following Act. They went 0-2 at Masters Tokyo, and ASE brought in Zero1 to replace him in future events. The move was unsuccessful, as they didn't advance past the top-six in the Champions 2023 China Qualifier and Act 1 of the China Evolution Series. Alongside Zero1, YHchen returned to the starting lineup for the following Act. They reached fourth place, eliminated in a close match against Rare Atom , the current JDG core. The team then finished in the top six of Act 3 after close losses to EDward Gaming and FunPlus Phoenix. Losses to Rare Atom and eventual winners Dragon Ranger Gaming ended their Ascension run. Upon being selected as partners for the upcoming VCT China league, JDG planned to build a roster with jkuro as their first acquisition. Rare Atom were one of the better teams in the region, their “worst” performance in the Evolution Series being a third-place finish in Act 2. The org was not selected as a partner team, and they were expected to win Ascension. This did not happen, as they lost 3-1 to Dragon Ranger Gaming in the grand final. JDG scrambled to pick up the roster, largely considered to be the second best team in the region. Unfortunately, the partnership system placed a limit on import players, and they decided to release in-game leader yoman instead of star duelist stew . As their first signing and with a similar agent pool to yoman, jkuro remained on the team. Without an in-game leader, the team faltered. They were eliminated in the Kickoff group stage, with two losses against Titan Esports Club. TEC advanced to the play-ins, but they went out in sixth place with a 0-2 record. The first seed from their group, Dragon Ranger Gaming, lost 2-0 to FunPlus Phoenix in playoffs. JDG seek to correct course with this new signing, and return to the heights they achieved with yoman at the helm. YHchen is expected to debut for JDG against EDward Gaming: Chen " YHchen " Yuhan (陳昱瀚) Park " stew " Young-chan (박영찬) Lifan " Viva " Ran (冉立凡) Yong " jkuro " Haochong (杨浩聪) Chen " YiHao " Yihao (陈一豪) Zhuo " MarT1n " Zhengjie (卓政杰) Ma " ValAnalysis " Hyun-sung (마현성) (Head coach)

title: Nova welcome SWERL as their duelist player
cleaned_content: Nova Esports have announced former Royal Never Give Up duelist Ali " SWERL " Kobraee as their new player. As confirmed by SWERL, he is expected to replace PangH on the starting lineup. Their previous import player, Vsevolod " neveR " Suslov , has been removed from the Global Contract Database , but neither he nor the org have made an announcement regarding his status. The move follows Nova's exit in the Kickoff group stage , which they ended with a 1-2 record after a surprise debut against FunPlus Phoenix. SWERL spent most of his career in the Oceania scene, playing for notable regional orgs such as Dire Wolves, Mindfreak, and Wildcard. He was able to reach multiple semifinals throughout the years, and win a handful of local events, but Oceania's lack of integration into the greater VCT circuit hindered the development of the region. By 2023, many of the top Oceania players began moving onto international teams. WRONSKI's move to Global Esports kicked off an exodus, and China's increasing investment offered a prime opportunity for aspiring prospects. Among the new organizations was Royal Never Give Up, returning to Valorant after previously fielding a team in 2020-2021. The org acquired SWERL and Dale as part of their new roster. They were able to qualify to events such as the FGC Invitational and the Champions 2023 China Qualifier, but did not advance past the early stage of those events. Ahead of the China Evolution Series, RNG picked up GuanG , who is currently on Nova. The team maintained a similar level, advancing to the Act 2 and Act 3 main events, but failing to make it past the group stage. After not being invited to VCT China, and despite having enough points to participate in Ascension, RNG exited the scene in November. Nova Esports look to reinforce their roster after an early exit from Kickoff. They defied low community expectations with a competitive opening map against FunPlus Phoenix and a 2-0 victory against TYLOO, but were unable to make it past the group stage. The team seeks to continue improving with their focus on SWERL as their new duelist and his past synergy with GuanG. He has struggled with wrist pain in the past, but Nova have made an effort to assist him as they further integrate him into the roster. SWERL will debut for Nova Esports against Trace Esports: Song " PangH " Wenhao (宋文浩) Ye " o0o0o " Xiaodong (叶晓东) Chen " OBONE " Yijie (陈怡洁) Ali " SWERL " Kobraee Wang " cb " Qingchuan (王庆川) Guang " GuanG " Honglin (光洪霖) Shao " 24K " Yubo (邵玉波) (Head coach)

title: TEC expand their roster with AC
cleaned_content: Titan Esports Club have signed Wei " AC " Jiacong (韦家聪) , previously on Shenzhen NTER . Recently their controller player, AC had been a part of NTER since before Valorant's official release in China. Until further announcements, TEC remain with eight players on their roster. AC was unsuccessful throughout the early days of the local scene. They had some modest results in 2021, reaching the top-eight in various tournaments, but did not make it further until the following year. He survived a roster rebuild in early 2022, as the org picked up players such as Spring , now duelist for Wolves Esports, and York , currently assistant coach for TEC. After the move, NTER reached the top-three in multiple FGC Invitationals, then the premier competition in China. They also won a number of weekly tournaments, defeating teams such as EDward Gaming and FunPlus Phoenix ZHUQUE . The team continued to find success early into 2023, taking series off of most top teams in the region, but began a steep decline by May of that year. Upon York's transition to a coaching role, NTER lost their series in the single-elimination portion of the Champions 2023 China Qualifer playoffs. After the tournament, Ninjas In Pyjamas bought out Eren and Spring, further weakening the squad. NTER were unable to advance past the opening round of all three China Evolution Series, failing to earn enough points to make Ascension. Throughout the years, AC has had to fill multiple roles for his team. He was originally signed as a controller player, and switched to the initiator role after their first rebuild. During the Chamber meta, he took up the agent, but played Killjoy or Viper on most maps. He continued on sentinel agents until York's move to coach, after which he began playing duelist agents. By the end of the year, he was back to controller, as his team struggled to find a starting five. Despite his team's lack of success and constant role swaps, AC was able to maintain a decent form. Whether as a starter, sixth player, or substitute, his arrival will allow TEC to fill a number of positions as required. Titan Esports Club will next play against Wolves Esports : Wei " AC " Jiacong (韦家聪) Xing " LockM " Fuling (邢福凌) Li " QiuYe " Runtao (李润涛) Wu " shameless " Hongjie (吴洪杰) Han " Abo " Bohao (韩博皓) Piao " kawaii " Min (朴民) Goo " Rb " Sang-min (구상민) Li " B1ack " Songtai (李松泰) Liu " 3water " Miao (刘淼) (Head coach)

title: DRX sign BeYN, release coach before Stage 1
cleaned_content: DRX have signed former Maru Gaming and All Gamers duelist Kang " BeYN " Ha-bin (강하빈) as the sixth player on the roster. BeYN's recent form in both the Chinese and Pacific Valorant scenes showed his capability on the duelist role. He grew in popularity playing for Maru Gaming, finishing in third for the second Korean Challengers split in 2023 . That split determined which sole Korean team would compete for the one VCT Pacific slot in 2024, and BeYN ended his run with a 1.06 match rating. He was among the tournament leaders in first kills per round, tied at seventh with 0.19. Towards the end of 2023, BeYN joined Chinese team All Gamers as a loan. He ended his time in China with an average of 244.3 ACS in the China Evolution Series Act 3: Heritability tournament . DRX also released one of their coaches, Ye " Anaks " Sang-jun (예상준) , who oversaw the DRX Prospects team and their development. He joined DRX as an organization back in September 2022, moving from coach on the main roster to his development role a month later. DRX starts their regional Stage 1 with a match against Team Secret on April 6. DRX is now: Yu " BuZz " Byeong-cheol (유병철) Kim " MaKo " Myeong-gwan (김명관) Kim " stax " Gu-taek (김구택) Jung " Foxy9 " Jae-sung (정재성) Cho " Flashback " Min-hyuk (조민혁) Kang " BeYN " Ha-bin (강하빈) Pyeon " termi " Seon-ho (편선호) (Head coach)

title: Trace pick up LuoK1ng, coach Yiyee
cleaned_content: Following TYLOO 's announcement of their departure, Trace Esports have acquired Zhang " LuoK1ng " Zhanpeng (张展鹏) and Zhang " Yiyee " Tianyuan (张天元) as their assistant coach. In exchange, Trace transferred controller player Lo " Flex1n " Rui (罗瑞) to TYLOO. Flex1n was a part of the Trace core for two years, first joining the roster in September 2022 under the Totoro Gaming banner. The following year, upon advancing to the China Qualifier playoffs, Trace signed the full roster. The team was unable to reach the top-three and qualify to Champions, ending the tournament with losses to Bilibili Gaming and FunPlus Phoenix. Statistically, Flex1n was the highest rated controller player at the event with a 1.23 rating. As Trace continued to improve in the standings, he consistently contributed to the team in a more supportive role, maintaining a high APR throughout 2023. Since the China Qualifier, Trace has not placed outside of the top-four in any local event. Their best performance was the China Evolution Series Act 2, where they were able to take a series off of local powerhouse EDward Gaming to make the grand final. More recently, Trace finished in the top-four at Kickoff. They won their opening matchup against TYLOO, with both Flex1n and LuoK1ng finishing towards the top of the scoreboard for their teams. Trace advanced to the play-ins, defeating Bilibili and Titan Esports Club, but they were unable to move past EDward Gaming in the semifinal to qualify to Masters Madrid. The new Trace Esports lineup will debut on April 6: Zhang " LuoK1ng " Zhan Peng (张展鹏) Lu " Kai " Zhinan (卢智楠) Cui " cxyy " Xinyu (崔新宇) Song " FengF " Xuefeng (宋学锋) Yip " YOU " Man Ho Ho " heybay " Shun Hei Jin " XYG " Xin (金鑫) Gu " destroyeR " Jiaming (顾佳鸣) (Coach) Zhang " Yiyee " Tianyuan (张天元) (Assistant coach)

title: TYLOO sign Flex1n, Eren, pick up coaching staff
cleaned_content: TYLOO have expanded their roster by signing two new players and a coaching staff. Among the acquisitions are Lo " Flex1n " Rui (罗瑞) , who was traded from Trace Esports in exchange for LuoK1ng and coach Yiyee , and Yang " Eren " Zhengwei (杨曾威) , previously on Ninjas In Pyjamas. Additionally, former Chao Hui EDward Gaming coach Deng " shuaishuai " Chuanyi (邓传义) joins as head coach, and Huang " Sunshine " Jinjie (黄进杰) , previously on Weibo Gaming , joins as assistant coach. Flex1n's arrival will reunite him with ICEKING, as the duo was previously a part of Totoro Gaming in 2023. They were signed by Trace Esports soon after, but ICEKING left in August to join TYLOO as part of their rebuild. Also joining is Eren, who last played for Ninjas In Pyjamas. He initially joined the project as a flex duelist player, but transitioned to an initiator role for Ascension. The team was unsuccessful initially, unable to qualify to any of the China Evolution Series main events across the year. Their performance was still enough to earn circuit points, which allowed them to make Ascension, the final event of the year. There, Ninjas In Pyjamas were able to survive the group stage, but they were eliminated after losses to Attacking Soul Esports, where now teammate hfmi0dzjc9z7 was playing at the time. In the lower bracket they lost 2-0 to eventual winners Dragon Ranger Gaming. During the tournament, Eren flexed to Deadlock for their Ascent composition, averaging 272 ACS on the agent.
